Enriqueta Marquez Martinez, 73, was born there. She has lived much of her life in absolute poverty, never knowing whether there would be food for the next family meal. All of her 10 children went at one time or another to work in the United States, and three settled there permanently. Eventually, when she was in her 60's, Mrs. Marquez also began to travel to the United States.

The company, which is based in Phoenix, said an entity controlled by its chairman and principal shareholder, Ernest Garcia, had bought the unit, which provides financing for small, independent dealers. The transaction consisted of $17.5 million in cash, a $12 million 10-year promissory note backed by Verde Investments Inc. and the assumption of $8 million in debt owed to Verde. Ugly Duckling said it wanted to focus on its used-car dealerships.

One prosecutor has called it ''the oddest kaffeeklatsch in the history of Western civilization.'' Its members are Timothy J. McVeigh, who bombed the federal office building in Oklahoma City; Theodore J. Kaczynski, the Unabomer; and Ramzi Ahmed Yousef, the mastermind of the World Trade Center bombing. title: 'They Just Moved a Brick, Because the Brick Was Right in Their Face'
description: Those who risked their lives for the civil rights movement, like Unita Blackwell, did so to prevent the next generations from having to do the same, a dream largely realized. Ms. Blackwell, 66, the daughter of Mississippi sharecroppers, was regularly attacked and arrested while trying to register black voters, and helped found the Mississippi Freedom Democratic Party, an alternative to the all-white regular Democrats. She also created several education and housing programs in the state, and in 1976 became mayor of the Delta hamlet of Mayersville (population: 500), which she helped incorporate; it is a position she still holds. Her generation's work seems distant to Marcus Moore, the 20-year-old son of a black Army officer and a white German mother. He grew up in Columbus, Ga., one of many children of interracial marriages at Fort Benning, and is now a senior majoring in African-American studies at Emory University in Atlanta. He is editor in chief of ''The Fire This Time,'' Emory's black student magazine, and has been active in campus demonstrations to persuade fraternities to stop displaying the Confederate flag. He helps teach science at a local elementary school and plans to get a Ph.D. in urban anthropology. DAVID FIRESTONE

title: 'We Accepted That We Were Working for the Good of the Country'
description: Revolution and change convulsed Russia twice in the last century, the first time in 1917, when the Bolsheviks seized power, and then in 1991, when the communist system they introduced, at such a fearful cost, collapsed under its own weight. Each time ordinary lives were swept up, sometimes swept away. In midcentury, millions died, killed by war, famine and a totalitarian regime.

title: A Year Of Fluff, Smut and Letting Go
description: Ask any critic to comment upon this final year of the Century of American Music, and you're likely to hear a heavy sigh. The year 1999 gave us fluff and smut, the inflatable sweethearts of the teenage market and the foul-mouthed bullies of hip-hop and rock. Releases from aspiring legends like Nine Inch Nails, R. Kelly and Mary J. Blige failed to make the anticipated cultural impact, while previously dismissed artists like Limp Bizkit and Kid Rock rose to rule the Zeitgeist. People actually looked to Cher, rising again with her smash ''Believe,'' as a beacon of artistic integrity.

title: U S WEST SELLS PART OF GLOBAL CROSSING STAKE
description: U S West Inc., the local telephone company merging with Qwest Communications International Inc., said yesterday that it had sold 65 percent of its stake in Global Crossing Ltd. to take advantage of a rise in Global Crossing's shares. U S West sold about 24 million shares, valued at $1.15 billion. It bought the shares in June before canceling a planned merger with Global Crossing, a two-year-old company that is building a worldwide phone and data network. Global Crossing stock has risen about 84 percent since October. Global Crossing and U S West agreed to merge in May, but the deal fell apart in July after Qwest made a bid for both U S West and the Frontier Corporation. U S West eventually agreed to Qwest's $45.2 billion bid.

title: Toward Dow 3,000,000 and Other Millennial Ruminations
description: AS the 20th century began, high-yielding railroad shares were virtually the only blue-chip American stocks that a conservative investor would consider. As it ended, the most popular stocks were being issued by young companies that had never earned a dollar, let alone paid a dividend.

title: The Artist Formerly Known as Spectator
description: IMAGINE yourself as a member of an empty orchestra. The music, ever changing within a basic set of themes, wafts forth from instruments held by invisible hands, but the chairs are open for you to occupy and add your part.

title: All's Well Now Between Sprewell and Van Gundy
description: The fourth-quarter clock was slipping toward the final two minutes Thursday night as Latrell Sprewell sat on the bench with the patience and contentment of a bird watcher.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A11, 13-19

title: 'The United States of Africa -- It May Yet Come.'
description: Fritz Israel and Bernd Matzner were witnesses to two of this century's most transforming events. Mr. Israel, 74, fought as a German soldier during World War II and grew up with the horror of Hitler and the Holocaust. Mr. Matzner, 27, grew up under communism in East Germany and watched in amazement when the Berlin Wall fell without bloodshed.

title: Celebrating a Milestone for Freedom; Black Americans Honor Anniversary of Proclamation to End Slavery
description: As people wake up this morning with the future on their minds, having left the 1900's for the 2000's, William Stallings will prepare to look back, 137 years to be exact.

title: Going Higher Tech Degree by Degree
description: Despite warnings that too many people are overeducated, new high school graduates and adults long out of school are expected to flock to college in ever-growing numbers in the years ahead, even as the notion of higher education expands and changes. There will always be a Harvard (and a Yale and a Princeton). But other traditional colleges are likely to be bypassed as students seek convenience and specially tailored services -- and colleges respond. The watchwords will be high technology and cost efficiency, and courses will be delivered in many ways. For better or worse, the future is full of niches to be filled. Here are some institutions that higher education experts expect to be on the cutting edge.

title: The New York Times - Reporter Biography: Pamela Mendels
description: Pamela Mendels, a Manhattan-based writer, covers education, government, censorship and civil rights issues for CyberTimes.

title: STRONG GROWTH IN SINGAPORE
description: Singapore's economy grew 8.2 percent in the fourth quarter and 5.6 percent for the full year 1999, Prime Minister Goh Chok Tong said in a New Year message. Mr. Goh noted that the recovery in the economy had been ''much faster than we had expected,'' buttressed by external factors like ''the strong upswing in electronics, the beginnings of a turnaround in Japan and continued robust growth in the United States.'' He said the outlook for 2000 was positive.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  DEIN, GITTIE
description: DEIN-Gittie. My sis, you are with us always and today especially. We love you.

title: Absence of 'Midnight' Doesn't Darken Spirits
description: With the midsummer sun standing high over the South Pole, painting its vast featureless snow fields with light so intense it hurt the eyes, scientists and support staff began celebrating the new year along with a planeload of tourists and seven intrepid

title: Retail Darwinism Puts Old Malls in Jeopardy
description: The fully enclosed shopping mall, that island of boxy chain stores and lost apostrophes in a sea of asphalt, was not born in California. But this seems to be the place where people are digging its grave, at least in its present form.

title: Religion Journal; Fort Worth Saw a Way to Set This Holiday Apart
description: Several months ago a Fort Worth committee charged with planning the city's millennial events decided that this New Year's Eve ought to be more than just a party, and instead offer people a chance to reflect on something of greater meaning.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  BARISON, DAVID ANDREW
description: BARISON-David Andrew. September 26, 1964-January 1, 1995. ''Do not let your grief be measured by his worth, for then your sorrow has no end.'' Mom, Dad, Steven, Amy, Gregg, Jessica and Billy

title: SCHLUMBERGER COMPLETES SPINOFF OF OFFSHORE OIL UNIT
description: Schlumberger Ltd., a leading oil services company, said yesterday that the spinoff of its Sedco Forex Offshore unit and its merger with Transocean Offshore Inc. had been completed in a $3.61 billion transaction that creates the world's largest offshore drilling company. Schlumberger investors received one share in Sedco Forex for each share held. The shares were exchanged for 0.1936 share in the new company, Transocean Sedco Forex Inc. Schlumberger shareholders retained a 52 percent stake in the new company. Schlumberger is getting out of offshore rig rentals to concentrate on developing technology that gets more oil out of wells. The merger lets Transocean, the third-largest offshore driller, add to its fleet of deep-water rigs.

title: Two Idealized Worlds With Contrasting Moods
description: The glorious athletes of Eliot Feld's ''Aurora I'' might seem to inhabit a different universe from the sacred and profane gods of Mr. Feld's ''Gods Amused.'' But the two dissimilar sets of characters share an airy, idealized world, or so it seemed when the pieces were performed on the same program, presented by Ballet Tech on Wednesday night at the Joyce Theater.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  GRIST, KEITH PAUL
description: GRIST-Keith Paul. 7/24/67-1/1/98. Always in our thoughts, always in our hearts. Love, Mom and George

title: New Frontiers for Jeeves
description: IN the swelling ranks of the superwealthy, where the number of American families worth more than $10 million has jumped fourfold, to 275,000, over the last decade, demand for servants has risen to levels not seen since the Roaring Twenties, before household appliances brought factory-floor efficiency to the home.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: AMERICAN ARCHITECTURAL PRODUCTS CORP., Boardman, Ohio, a maker of windows and doors, said it would close an unprofitable plant in Youngstown, Ohio, and dismiss most of the 100 workers there.

title: Their Hopes and Fears Know No Season
description: ''If I could erase this year and do it over, I would,'' said Anthony Boyce, a heroin addict who wanted to check into a detoxification program and celebrate the dawn of the new year by sleeping through it. ''I need to clear my head and not think about what to do next,'' said Mr. Boyce, 47. ''When you're carrying a load on your shoulders 24 hours a day, it gets to where you can't think of a way out.''

title: Foreign Affairs; Boston E-Party
description: Last summer I was changing planes at Singapore's swank new airport, which has lounges spread all over, at which transit passengers can watch satellite TV. As I walked through the airport, I bought a snack and sat down in one of these lounges. There I found two elderly Indian women, in traditional sari robes, watching American professional wrestling. These two petite Indian ladies were sitting transfixed, gazing at huge wrestlers in Tarzan suits body-slamming one another. All I could think was: ''What in the world are they making of this?''

title: On Top, Still a Mystery: Vladimir Vladimirovich Putin
description: After the Kremlin's newborn political party registered a thumping victory in parliamentary elections last week, reporters asked Prime Minister Vladimir V. Putin whether his strengthened hand might lead to changes in the government. Mr. Putin was characteristically forthcoming. ''We'll see,'' he said.

title: Will Entrepreneurs Still Be Heroes?
description: WHEN Fortune magazine was introduced in February 1930, its premise, according to one historian, was ''that the great businessmen were the new supermen of civilization.'' Almost 70 years later, the rest of America is coming around to Fortune's way of thinking.

title: Will Dust Survive? And Other Nagging Questions
description: In the next century, will those bodies that have been frozen in liquid nitrogen be brought back to life?

title: Yeltsin Leaves Russians Glad or Uninterested
description: If Boris N. Yeltsin really meant it about being forgiven for his mistakes when he made the stunning announcement of his resignation today, as far as many people on the streets of Moscow were concerned, he needn't have bothered.

title: Past, Present and Future in One Stroke
description: ''But where are the snows of yesteryear?'' the poet Francois Villon asked in the 15th century, not even halfway through the millennium we are making a fuss about leaving. Nothing new under the sun, though in his case it was not an early global-warming alert but a lament for departed loveliness. Nothing new there either.

title: Left the Light on, But Nobody Came
description: IN 1939, the physicist Enrico Fermi posed his famous paradox: If life is common in our galaxy, why have we never seen extraterrestrial visitors on Earth?

title: The New York Times: Cybercrime
description: The New York Times: Cybercrime

title: Works In Progress From All Over; Discovering a Deficit Of Attention Deficit
description: The centruy's turn has been a time of retrospectives: what was the most important event, who was the most influential thinker? Arts & Ideas decided to take a look ahead at what some of today's researchers are working on. From the most raked-over field, like the history of the ancient world, to the latest medical technology, scholars are coming up with fresh insights. Some ideas may turn into breakthroughs, and others may turn out to be dead-ends, but the journey is rarely boring. Here is a handful of works in progress.

title: Suit by Waste Management Says It Overpaid in Deal
description: Waste Management Inc., the nation's biggest hauler of trash, contends in a lawsuit that it overpaid in last year's $1.15 billion acquisition of Eastern Environmental Services Inc. because Eastern's chairman overstated profits.

title: 'We Accepted That We Were Working for the Good of the Country'
description: Not so long ago, when people referred to immigrants in Southern California, they usually meant someone like John Fleetwood. Mr. Fleetwood, 80, came from Kansas City in 1939 to work in aircraft manufacturing. He climbed his way up to running the operation that produced the Apollo command modules. His daughter has become the mayor of the town in which he lived for many years, Downey. He left when it started to become heavily populated by the next wave of immigrants, Hispanics.

title: On This First Day, a Fanfare for the New Era; Older, and Better
description: To the Editor:

title: Ancient Temple in Tokyo Rings In Just a New Year
description: As the monks in their long black robes and golden sashes put the finishing touches on preparations for the New Year celebrations here, there was little room for doubt that this was a big day for Zojoji Temple, one of Tokyo's great Buddhist houses of worship.

title: Slowly, Slowly, Slowly, The Year's First Dawn
description: The first to greet the new day on Taveuni Island were the birds, singing from the treetops at the ocean's edge, skimming along the surf, filling the pale pre-dawn with celebration.

title: Party Like It's 1999? That's So, Like, 'Stalg

title: Heartened Investors Give Stock Market a Lift
description: President Boris N. Yeltsin's resignation today drove Russian stocks to their highest levels since the 1998 economic collapse, reflecting hope among investors that the acting president, Vladimir V. Putin, would revive stalled economic reforms.

title: Russian Troops Are Edgy as They Prepare to Go 'Clean' Grozny
description: After Dmitri Baidanov's legs had been shattered by mortar fire, he crawled for three days through the streets of Grozny until he reached the Russian lines.

title: Power Shift Is Not Viewed As a Threat To U.S. Ties
description: Clinton administration officials said today that President Boris N. Yeltsin's surprise resignation would not dramatically alter relations with Russia and could improve the chances that Moscow and Washington will break a stalemate over a major arms control treaty.

title: A Running Start to the Year 2000
description: ''Welcome to the first marathon anywhere in the world this millennium,'' the public-address announcer said as approximately 2,000 runners applauded the news here on the first morning of 2000.

title: In Ads, Candidates' Gloves Stay On
description: In a new commercial running in early primary states this week, Gov. George W. Bush comes out squarely in favor of phonics. ''See,'' he explains, ''I believe every child can learn.''

title: N.Y.S.E. Sets Levels for Trading Halts
description: In its quarterly adjustment of ''circuit breakers,'' the New York Stock Exchange set the level for a trading halt in United States equity markets at a drop of 1,100 points in the Dow Jones industrial average.

title: The Only Naval Engagement Ever Won at the Card Table
description: The most remarkable bridge game of the past century, or indeed the millennium, occurred in 1917 in the Turkish harbor of Constantinople, now Istanbul. An American gunboat, the Scorpion, was attached to the American Embassy there, and it was boarded by the Turks, who were German allies, when the United States entered World War I.

title: Brooklyn Throws a Party Just for the Locals
description: ''Gee, I guess we're the first,'' said Karen Minott, a Brooklyn resident who showed up at Grand Army Plaza about 5 p.m. with her cousin and a friend.

title: Produce Market Owners Allow Workers to Unionize
description: The owners of a handful of fruit and vegetable markets in the East Village agreed yesterday to allow their workers to join unions, ending a bitter six-month boycott that crippled their business and turned their stores into neighborhood pariahs.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  REESE, WILLIAM WILLIS
description: REESE-William Willis. The Board of Assistants of The Society of Mayflower Descendants in the State of NY mourn the death of our Deputy Governor, William Willis Reese. His generosity, loyalty and warmth of spirit will be sorely missed. We extend our sympathies to his widow, Sonia Van Voorhis Reese. Walter R. Brewster, Jr., Governor Irene C. Coleman, Secretary

description: Flamma Mvunelwa, 77, and Mvuselelo Jompolo, 13, both live in Mlungisi, a township in the eastern Cape province of South Africa.

title: On Empty Battlefields, the Shadows of Cyberwarriors
description: AS commandant of the Army War College, Maj. Gen. Robert H. Scales Jr. regularly leads students, politicians, foreign officers and other visitors on tours through the landmarks of the battlefield here: Devil's Den, Little Round Top, Cemetery Ridge. Though the Battle of Gettysburg was fought 136 years ago, General Scales thinks it still offers lessons on the art of war. At the same time, it is getting harder and harder to see them.

title: Chief Justice's Annual Report Notes Progress in the Judiciary
description: Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist surveyed the state of the federal judiciary today and, in contrast to many of his 13 previous year-end reports, pronounced himself quite pleased.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROWLEY, LOUIS N.
description: ROWLEY-Louis N.. Jr. Age 90 of Shelton, CT., formerly of Port Washington, L.I., on December 30, 1999. Beloved husband of Maybelle ''Billie'' (nee Chemidlin) for over 66 years, he is also survived by his sons; Rev. Louis E. Rowley of Mount Vernon, New York, Robert S. Rowley of Danbury, CT, and David C. Rowley of Swarthmore, PA., eight grandchildren and five great grandchildren. A memorial service will be held at 2:00 PM on Saturday, January 8 at Crosby Commons, 580 Long Hill Ave., Shelton, CT. Memorial Contributions may be made to the United Methodist Church 1515 Middle Neck Road, PO Box 929, Port Washington, NY 11050, or to the charity of your choice.

title: A Small Leap To Designer Babies
description: UNLIKE the sheep named Dolly, the mouse named Lucy has barely made a ripple in the news. Lucy, born on Oct. 26, 1998, is the creation of scientists at Chromos Molecular Systems, a biotechnology company in Vancouver, British Columbia. She has black-brown fur and is not unlike mice bred in laboratories around the world, the company says, with one exception: Lucy has an artificial chromosome that she has passed to her offspring.

title: MACK-CALI REALTY SELLS NEW JERSEY AND ARIZONA STAKES
description: The Mack-Cali Realty Corporation, a real estate investment trust in Cranford, N.J., said late on Thursday that it had sold stakes in properties in New Jersey and Arizona for more than $100 million. The company sold a 71,000-square-foot office building in Princeton, N.J., and a 119,000-square-foot office property in Phoenix, each for about $9 million. The company said it sold a 55 percent stake in five buildings in Parsippany, N.J., for $84 million. Mack-Cali, which owns or has stakes in 257 properties, used part of the proceeds to buy three office buildings in Moorestown, N.J., for $8 million.

title: Gore's Latest Attack on Bradley Tells Only Part of Story
description: Vice President Gore has denounced former Senator Bill Bradley for taking large amounts of campaign cash from drug companies and, Mr. Gore says, doing their bidding during his 18 years in the Senate.

title: A Vigilant Army of Officers Encounters Few Problems
description: Saddling up all its horses, putting all its helicopters in the air and sending nearly all its officers out on the street in uniform, the New York Police Department yesterday mounted one of its largest security operations ever -- three years in the planning and costing $6 million -- and by early this morning it appeared to have paid off with a genial and almost uneventful New Year's Eve.

title: Looking Back, With an Eye to the Future
description: For India, the last century was bisected into a before and after on Aug. 15, 1947, the day the British Indian empire gained its independence and was divided into Islamic Pakistan and overwhelmingly Hindu but secular India.

title: 'As an Archaeologist, I Have Seen Too Many Destructions'
description: Lily Yen, born to a merchant family in Shanghai, was one of very few women in China able to attend a university in the early part of the 20th century. She volunteered to teach schoolgirls in a poor, inland rural province. War and recurrent political campaigns intruded, and Mrs. Yen's family was divided when half her relatives moved to Taiwan in 1949. Now 96 and a retired homemaker, she thinks today's young people are too self-centered and have lost the spirit of sacrifice.

title: Solemnity and Flash In the Land of Jesus
description: In a beautiful, almost ethereal scene, about 2,000 Christians quietly ascended the Mount of Olives as midnight approached. Following a lighted crucifix, they carried votive candles that flickered in the still darkness of a city devoid of any official celebration of the millennium.

title: Party? What Party? We're Going Shopping
description: President Jiang Zemin spoke here of China's glorious future and a few adventurous souls ventured to the Great Wall, but most Beijingers spent the ticking over of the calendar doing what average folks here do when given half a chance: they went shopping.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MCCRORY, SYLVIA (NEE HOGBEN)
description: McCRORY-Sylvia (nee Hogben). of Pound Ridge, NY; born London, England. She was the daughter of Lancelot Hogben and Enid Charles. She will be remembered as a loving Grandmother, Mother and Wife. Breeder of Liafail Irish Setters. She volunteered at Pound Ridge, Hiram Halle Memorial Library. She is survived by her husband Wallace W. McCrory, M.D., Chief of Pediatrics, NY Hospital, Cornell Medical Center (Emeritus); her children Pamela Sylvia McCrory of Lawrenceville, NJ, Michael Wallace Lancelot McCrory of Tucson, AZ and Christen Claire Gilley of Streetsboro, OH; her two brothers, Adrian Hogben and Dr. David Hogben; and cherished grandchildren James, David, Wendy, Holly and Andrew. Calling hours 2-4PM Monday, Jan. 3rd at the Cassidy-Flynn Funeral Home, Mt. Kisco, NY. Friends may send memorial donations to the American Friends Service Committee. Please omit flowers.

title: Sugar Adds the Spice To the Bowl Season
description: They are the first college football matchups of the 21st century, these eight remaining bowl games. All of them promise to be entertaining, but only one will decide the national title: the Sugar Bowl on Tuesday night.

title: 'The United States of Africa -- It May Yet Come.'
description: In 1957, the Gold Coast became the first country to gain independence in sub-Saharan Africa, led by Kwame Nkrumah. Nkrumah's vision of African solidarity inspired independence movements across the continent, but his rule ended in a morass of corruption and an army coup in 1966. Nkrumah's hometown lies in western Ghana, a small town called Nkroful, where Ambrose Ackah was born some 64 years ago. Mr. Ackah, the son of farmers and one of seven children, was the first one in his family to attend school. He became an elementary school teacher and retired three years ago.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GIBSON, LESLIE FULLER LARNED
description: GIBSON-Leslie Fuller Larned. Died December 14 at home in Washington, CT. A devoted wife, mother and grandmother, Mrs. Gibson divided her time between her home in CT, a residence in NYC, her son's in Birdsboro, PA, and at Bear Island in Penobscot Bay, ME, a property jointly held with other members of the Fuller family. She was the elder daughter of Edward P. (Ned) Larned and of Lesley Fuller Larned (Mrs. J. Nelson Borland II in later life). She was a devoted niece of Rosamond L. Fuller (Mrs. Alphonse Kenison) of Newcastle, ME; the same of, and to, R. Buckminster Fuller of world-wide address. Among her activities, she was a contributor to Scenic Hudson, and served on its Board of Directors. Her father was a brother of William P. Larned, at one time topranked singles tennis player. Together they were champions in doubles. On December 18, at the First Congregational Church on Washington Green, Rev. Cheryl Anderson led a memorial service for Mrs. Gibson. Immediate survivors are her husband, R. Dana Gibson, a painter (they married in Wiscasset, ME in 1942); also a sister, Mrs. Albert F. Winslow (Katherine P. Larned) of Tuxedo Park, NY; also a son, George Brayton Larned Gibson of Birdsboro, PA; his wife, Lynn Updegrave Gibson, and three grandchildren, Miles, Graham and Lila. Contributions may be sent to ''Save the Shepaug,'' care of the Steep Rock Association, PO Box 279 Washington Depot, CT. 06794 or to Scenic Hudson. Interment will take place in the cemetery by Washington Green when available in April.

title: Hostages Are Safe As Hijacking Ends
description: The hijackers of an Indian Airlines plane won the release of three prominent militants jailed in India. All of them sped away from the airport in Afghanistan, trying to get out of the country. The names and nationalities of the hijackers are still unknown. With the release, more than 150 haggard passengers, kept on board for eight days, were freed unharmed. They flew to New Delhi, for family reunions, both wrenching and joyous.

title: Smells Like Teen Spirit, or Whatever
description: ''Inappropriate'' is not ''Rent.'' A theatergoer might be forgiven for thinking it is, since the show, a rock musical, stars an ensemble of young actors wearing headset microphones, attitude and the combination of layers, mismatches, glitter and sportswear that make up homeless-person chic. Averie Boyer, who is excellent in his understated way as one of the central performers (there are no character names), even looks something like Anthony Rapp, who played Mark in ''Rent's'' original Broadway and Off Broadway cast.

title: Essay; Why Die?
description: Of all the instincts in animals, the strongest is the will to survive. In the human animal, that inborn defense is sometimes overcome by the maternal instinct, by love of country or comrades in battle, or by an illness like depression. But in most of us, nothing makes the weak strong or the fearful brave as much as our bodies' innate drive to stay alive.

title: Sam Shapiro, 68, Pioneer in Use of Mammograms
description: Sam Shapiro, a health care analyst and biostatistician whose studies in the 1960's proved that mammograms saved women's lives by catching breast cancers at an early, treatable stage, died on Thursday at his home in Baltimore. He was 85.

title: REFLECTIONS: ISRAEL AND WEST BANK; 'As an Archaeologist, I Have Seen Too Many Destructions'
description: Avraham Biran, 90, and Ayman Abu-Shirbi, 13, define themselves through scholarship. A second-generation descendant of the earliest Zionist pioneers, Dr. Biran grew up under Ottoman rule in Rosh Pina, a village in the Galilee highlands founded by his Romanian great-grandparents. One of Israel's pre-eminent archaeologists, he has spent most of his life connecting the Israel of today to the Israel of the Bible.

So the beginning of the 2000's in Rio de Janeiro turned into what authorities proudly called the largest celebration in Brazilian history: an estimated 3.5 million people lining Copacabana, Ipanema and more than 25 miles of other beaches in a tropical spectacle that blended the spiritual and the profane.

description: With hundreds of millions of dollars of private and federal research work behind it, the General Motors Precept, an experimental model to be introduced here on Jan. 9, is probably the most expensive single car ever built. Yet it is still a lot of car for the money.

title: Rx for Brain Makeovers
description: THE Scarecrow in ''The Wizard of Oz'' wanted only a brain -- he did not much care what kind.

title: Suspect Is Shot As Bronx Police And Carjackers Exchange Fire
description: A carjacking suspect was shot three times early yesterday in an exchange of gunfire with a team of plainclothes police officers who stopped the car theft on a Bronx street, the police said.

title: The New York Times - CyberTimes Reporter Biography: Carl S. Kaplan
description: Carl S. Kaplan is a New York-based lawyer and journalist. His news background includes stints at The Nation as an editorial intern, The New Leader as associate editor, CES Publishing as editor and writer, and New York Newsday as a business reporter. His freelance articles have appeared in many publications.

title: Sports of The Times; For Some, End of Season Is End of Line
description: THE 2000 National Football League playoff field becomes crystalline late tomorrow afternoon. Then we learn which 12 teams will compete for a chance at Super Bowl XXXIV on Jan. 30 at the Georgia Dome in Atlanta.

title: 2000 and Beyond -- The Shape of an Age to Come
description: So now at last begins the year 2000, a juncture in time so long anticipated it is hard to believe it has arrived, disguised as a mere Saturday. The year is so utterly new, all four digits overturned at once, that simply seeing the date in print jars the eye.

title: 'We Just Waited for Our Moment to Be Killed'
description: Few countries suffered as deeply as Cambodia over the last half-century. The tiny, beautiful Southeast Asian land was a battleground among the great powers and the scene of hugely destructive American bombing during the Vietnam War. Then its own internal demons rose from within its people's brutalized psyche. Cambodia became the scene of horrific mass killings by the radical communist Khmer Rouge, who from 1975 to 1979 took the lives of as many as one-fourth of the population of eight million.

description: In percent

title: Pub Has Eye On Dublin: 2 Midnights In Queens
description: Sean Cunningham nodded to the television hanging above him in the smoky air of the Starting Gate Pub. It was 5 p.m. in Woodside, Queens, and, by Mr. Cunningham's calculation, two hours to midnight.

title: Ray Hubbard, 75, Executive And Pioneer in Broadcasting
description: Ray Hubbard, a television producer and broadcasting executive and a pioneer in the medium, died on Monday in Kenwood, Calif. He was 75 and had been suffering from Parkinson's disease.

title: How Many in a Throng? Crunching the Numbers
description: Half a million? A million? A zillion? The world will never know how many humans squeezed their way into the Designated Watching Zones around Times Square to see the ball drop, but it is not impossible to estimate how many people could have been there.

title: BANK INDONESIA NEEDS CAPITAL
description: The Indonesian government will have to recapitalize its own central bank after state auditors refused to give Bank Indonesia a clean bill of health, the Finance Minister, Bambang Sudibyo, said. Two new investigations into the bank were also announced, including one to be led by Indonesia's attorney general. An audit released to Parliament by the state audit agency indicated that the central bank had negative net worth, Mr. Sudibyo said. There has been widespread talk that state auditors took issue with 51 trillion rupiah ($7.1 billion) lent by Bank Indonesia to banks as emergency liquidity support.

title: A Day in the Spotlight: No Naps on the Agenda
description: Earlier in the day, the mayor, who gave himself the job of ubiquitous master of ceremonies of the city's new year celebration, said he began his last morning of the 1900's at 5:30 a.m. having trouble getting his lights on. ''I was convinced that it was Y2K,'' the mayor said, but ''actually I was sleepy.''

title: ITALY DEFICIT SHRINKS
description: Italy's budget deficit declined by almost half this year as tax evaders were forced to pay up, the government said. The deficit dropped to 31.6 trillion lire ($16.4 billion) from 58.34 trillion lire in 1998, the Treasury announced. The decline was partly because of a December surplus of some 25 trillion lire. ''The result was better than expected, and Italians have good reason to be satisfied,'' Treasury Minister Giuliano Amato said.

title: A Blanket of Snow Brings Some Warmth
description: The snow everyone had been waiting for all winter finally came. The narrow streets leading down to Red Square, usually clotted with traffic, were empty. For all its imperfections, Moscow on New Year's Eve seemed suddenly, subtly perfect.

title: Year-End Stock Tables
description: Tables showing how stocks in the United States performed in 1999 will appear in a special Part 2 of Business Day on Monday.

title: Great Hits Headed for The Attic
description: The challenge put to The Times's critics was direct: Name a 20th-century work considered ''timeless'' today that you think will be all but forgotten in 100 years. Their selections:

title: Pristine Cuisine Kills Germs, and Tastebuds
description: IN the anteroom of Island, the latest Pristine Cuisine restaurant in fashionable Forest Hills, the crowd was avoiding any contact with one another as they switched their shoes for nylon booties and dipped their hands in that pricey California biocide coyly evocative of eau de Lysol (just ask your grandmother).

title: The Human Touch Will Only Inflate College Bills
description: WHEN Mozart was alive, it took two to three months for a craftsman to make a watch and about 18 minutes for an ensemble to perform ''Eine Kleine Nachtmusik.'' Today, it takes two minutes for a machine to make a watch. But a performance of Mozart's familiar composition still takes musicians more than a quarter-hour.

title: From an Ancient Calendar, Scenes of Life at the Last Millennium
description: Its appearance, with 12 months represented in 12 pages, is not so different from that of a calendar you might find hanging on a kitchen wall (except for the words in Latin). But the Julius Work Calendar is nearly 1,000 years old. It was probably created by a cleric working in the manuscript studio at Canterbury Cathedral in England. Down the left side of the page are the days of the month in Roman numerals, and on the right the names of saints and religious festivals. Across the bottom runs a delicate drawing illustrating the task of the month. Over all the calendar offers a window on life in England at the start of the second millennium.

title: Brooklyn Man Charged in Terror Plot Is Held Without Bond
description: The Algerian man arrested in Brooklyn on charges of being part of a terrorist bomb plot was ordered held without bond yesterday in a court proceeding that otherwise offered few new details about the suspect or his activities.

title: The New York Times: Digital Copyright Issues
description: The New York Times: Digital Copyright Issues

title: In a Speedy World, Software's a Snail
description: SOFTWARE is the DNA of the high-technology age, the mediator between man and machine, conveying our questions or orders to the computers that surround us. No small irony, then, that the task of making software remains a remarkably painstaking endeavor of step-by-step iteration, more handcraftsmanship than machine magic.

title: Manifestoes To Give City A New Edge
description: For anyone who thinks New York City institutions never die, there is one word: vaudeville. Vaudeville bombed with the advent of radio and television, proving that even dancing girls and the old soft shoe can't save an institution whose time has passed.

title: Up Periscope! Submarine Service Is 100, and Unsilent
description: After spending most of its first 100 years as the ''silent service,'' the Navy's submarine force is preparing to make a lot of noise during its centennial year, which begins today.

title: Audis and Cell Phones, Poverty and Fear
description: LUCIANA MARIA DOS SANTOS lives on the south side of the world's third-largest city in Favela 19, or Slum 19, a collection of shacks traversed by a stream that doubles as the sewage system. Her waterfront property consists of a shanty with a corrugated-iron roof; rats are not infrequent visitors. Despite the limited space, she has managed to squeeze in 2,638 discarded cans.

title: Brooklyn Groups Back Use Of Park by Mets Farm Team
description: A group of Brooklyn community groups that sued to stop a minor league Mets team from moving into a planned ballpark in Flatbush has dropped its opposition to the plan, now that the city has promised to renovate a park where the team would play.

title: A Good Run for Actor Who Specializes in Bad
description: Harris Yulin doesn't have a killer's face, but if you saw him walking down the street you could be excused for taking cover.

title: A Glittering Party For Times Square
description: Two thousand years after Christ's obscure birth in a dusty town in Judea, the world's six billion people - most of them non-Christian and many of them preoccupied with terrorism, computers, diets, bank accounts, politics and the perils of the future - rode their turning blue planet across time's invisible line today and, by common consent, looked into the dawn of a new millennium.

title: Opposition Ex-Communist Favored in Croatia Vote
description: Ivica Racan, a 55-year-old ex-Communist with a beard and a taste for rock music, is likely to be Croatia's next prime minister if the polls hold and an opposition coalition wins parliamentary elections on Jan. 3.

title: Suspect in Beatle Attack Held in Psychiatric Unit
description: The man accused of stabbing George Harrison on Thursday was charged with attempted murder today and then sent to a prison mental clinic for evaluation.

title: A Stud in Every Tongue, and Logo Tattoos
description: IT took America almost the entire 20th century to catch up with the rest of the world in its collective interest in body adornment, but in the end the country's beauty industry has embraced its extremes.

title: Keeping His Promise, Pope Opens New Year
description: John Paul II gave his first blessing of the Year 2000 as fireworks exploded and church bells tolled, ushering in the new year across Rome.

title: Mets Cast a Longing Eye Toward Guzman or Others
description: Next summer will provide either the best of times for the Mets, or the worst. Manager Bobby Valentine has one year left on his contract, as does General Manager Steve Phillips, and the team has mortgaged much of its farm system in an attempt to win in 2000. Either the Mets will contend for a championship, or many of them will be looking for jobs.

title: Works In Progress From All Over; Eliot's Sly Revenge Against a Darwinist
description: The centruy's turn has been a time of retrospectives: what was the most important event, who was the most influential thinker? Arts & Ideas decided to take a look ahead at what some of today's researchers are working on. From the most raked-over field, like the history of the ancient world, to the latest medical technology, scholars are coming up with fresh insights. Some ideas may turn into breakthroughs, and others may turn out to be dead-ends, but the journey is rarely boring. Here is a handful of works in progress.

title: Brisk Race in the Park At the Midnight Hour
description: Some came in tuxedos, others dressed as dragons, Santa Claus or Father Time. There were butterflies, famous buildings, and -- for reasons not entirely obvious -- make-believe waiters. They came to the annual Midnight Run at Central Park to race, jog and, in some cases, stumble into a new year.

title: A Generation's Anthem: 'Smells Like Teen Pressure'
description: YOUNG, hip and smart, Casey Collier seems to glide from one peak to the next, knocking out A's, winning student council elections and starring in the school play.

title: In Leading Nations, A Population Bust?
description: LADIES and gentlemen, welcome to Shanghai,'' said China's president, greeting leaders of the world's powers as they gathered on Jan. 1, 2100. ''A century ago, our predecessors worried that the world was headed for a Malthusian meltdown -- that we could not feed, clothe or find enough energy for an overpopulated earth. This city was a symbol of their fears.

title: The Big City; Millennium? It's Really 1703!
description: ARE you already disappointed by the alleged new millennium?

title: A Once Glorious City, Overlooked by Time
description: ''Timbuktu 2000! Timbuktu 2000!'' cried 3-year-old Aboubacari Sidiki, as he dangled from the bumper of a truck parked on a sand-filled street here.

title: Before Stocks Go Public, Some Will Go to Charity
description: When the newly rich get richer, shouldn't others get richer, too? That is the idea behind a new form of fund-raising that has helped one local nonprofit group raise hundreds of thousands of dollars.

title: As the 'American Century' Extends Its Run,
description: IT was Henry Luce, as every red-blooded Yankee knows, who christened the 20th the American Century. He proved to be right, but that was not necessarily obvious throughout the 100 years.

title: Sports of The Times; Postcards: This Time From a New Century
description: NORMALLY, this is a good time to look back at postcards from the past year, but it seems only appropriate to present postcards from the future.

title: Woman Kills Her Family and Then Herself
description: A 47-year-old woman shot and killed her two adult children and her husband in the family's Mahopac, N.Y., home last week before killing herself, the police said yesterday.

title: It's the Fans vs. the Athletes In an Interactive World
description: With the same prophetic wisdom that predicted Jim Thorpe's Olympic triumphs in 1912, Cassius Clay's victory over Sonny Liston in 1964, and the Stanley Cup landing in Texas -- Texas! -- in 1999, Times sportswriters look into the future from their press boxes.

title: A Derelict School Gets New Life With the Arts
description: OVER the years, the old Neptune High School building here saw thousands of students come and go. Then, 20 years ago, the 1898 building was closed. The board of education did not want it, municipal officials did not want it, the Chamber of Commerce and local historical societies did not want it.

description: IN summing up this year's electronic Christmas, most everyone uses the same adjective: big.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LORD, COMFORT (NEE PARKER)
description: LORD-Comfort (nee Parker). Died on December 25, 1999 in her 88th year at her home in Palm Beach, FL after a long illness. She is survived by a daughter Julia (Jill) Rodgers of New York City, and a son Cornelius O'Connor of West Palm Beach, FL. A memorial service will be held at the Church of the Holy Trinity, 316 E. 88 St. on Friday, January 7 at 10:30 AM. There will be an additional service in West Palm Beach. In lieu of flowers please give to the charity of your choice.

title: Weedy Slice of Riverfront Pits Enclave Against the City
description: As the city sees it, a new five-acre park on the weedy grounds of a demolished asphalt and gravel plant along the Hunts Point shoreline would significantly benefit a neighborhood long neglected when it comes to greenswards.

description: FOR more than a decade, the vacant International Business Machines building here served as a harsh reminder of not only this city's persistent economic tribulations but also of the weak economy of the entire county.

description: AMELIA EARHART

description: BRYER-Richard. Your 53rd birthday, my cherish Richie. I love you and miss you every one of my days. Mom

description: National Lighthouse Center and Museum

title: POSTINGS: 40,000 Sq. Ft., $8.425 Million Building; Sound Stage, Its Seventh, For Astoria
description: The 80-year-old Kaufman Astoria Studios in the Astoria section of Queens is about to add a new building at its sprawling, 12-acre site, giving the studios a seventh sound stage. The studios are a national historic landmark, and celebrated performers from Rudolph Valentino to Placido Domingo have worked on its stages and in its studios.

title: Streetscapes/The Brockholst, at Columbus and 85th; A Building's Fortunes Rise With the Neighborhood's
description: THE Brockholst, built in 1890 at 85th Street and Columbus Avenue, is something of a poor man's Dakota -- lesser in all respects than the famous apartment house farther south, but still majestically craggy, with wide, rambling marble-paneled halls and some of the most interesting apartments on the West Side. When Marcus Retter bought the Romanesque revival building nearly half a century ago, the West Side was headed downhill. But now the neighborhood -- and the Brockholst -- are on the way up.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KAUFMAN, CAROLE
description: KAUFMAN-Carole. On December 31, 1999. Beloved wife of Morton, loving mother of Richard and Joanne, devoted mother-in-law of Robin and Alan, dear sister of Mildred, Gerald, Ted and Susan, adoring ''Grammy'' of Melissa, Jenny, Jesse and Zak. Her warmth, love and extraordinary capacity for giving meant so much to her friends and family. As a teacher, her dedication and creativity touched many lives. She will always be with us. Services will be held Tuesday, 12 noon, at ''The Riverside,'' 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: Nurses Unionize
description: In a vote of 404 to 93, nurses, technicians, clerical workers and skilled maintenance and service workers at the 190-bed Yonkers General Hospital have voted to unionize, Pamela LaFrance, the hospital's vice president for human resources, said. The workers will become part of Local 1199 of the Service Employees International, which is based in Manhattan.

title: A Friend of the Bride
description: Remembering the anxiety she endured when she put her wedding together five years ago, Claudia Hanlin, a 34-year-old former strategic managing consultant, vowed to simplify the famously nerve-racking experience of coordinating a wedding. Ms. Hanlin recently opened the Wedding Library, a research refuge at 50 East 81st Street (212-327-0100), where brides-to-be can browse through bound portfolios of photographers, caterers, florists, stationers, makeup artists, bakers and calligraphers and also hear tapes from bands and watch videos of weddings for inspiration. ''I wanted to offer people a chance to see some great suppliers without overwhelming them,'' said Ms. Hanlin, whose library is open free to the public. Suppliers, who pay to be included in the archive, provide everything from a society band for a lavish Pierre Hotel soiree to a Porta Potti for a barefoot-on-the-beach reception, but Ms. Hanlin thinks it's important to keep the number of options manageable. ''We try to find the supplier to fit the need of every kind of bride,'' she said. ''I got hundreds of photography portfolios and narrowed it down to 10.'' KAREN ROBINOVITZ

title: The Lives They Lived: Gina Berriault, b. 1926 - Andre Dubus, b. 1937; What Writer's Writers Write
description: The saddest words of tongue or pen? ''Writer's writer,'' a synonym for obscurity. Every writer understands exactly what that fearful possessive hints at: a modicum of professional admiration accompanied -- or subverted -- by dim public recognition and even dimmer sales. Yet the writer's writer is said to write not in hope of fame but out of quiet passion, and is thereby accorded a purity not granted to the household name. Both Andre Dubus and Gina Berriault labored long under this doubtful encomium. Both escaped it; both came to be celebrated as writers, released at last from the piously diminishing apostrophe.

title: 13,000 Hellos So Far, Only 987,000 to Go
description: On any given day in New York City, it's possible to say ''hello'' to hundreds of people, or none at all. Carrie Dashow is one New Yorker who knows exactly how many people she greets each day.

title: The Lives They Lived: John Michael Lamb, b. 1957; No. 587
description: John Lamb was the 87th death-row inmate executed this year, and the 587th since the Supreme Court upheld the death penalty in 1976. On Nov. 10 he was interviewed at the Ellis Unit, a state prison near Huntsville, Tex., one week before his execution.

title: A Playground With a Difference: It's Designed for One and for All
description: FOR a while, when he was younger, his wheelchair did not stop Matthew Cavedon of Berlin from having fun at a playground. His mom, Susan Cavedon, would simply lift him out of it.

title: The Lives They Lived: Fred C. Trump, b. 1905; The Fred
description: Donald Trump remembers exactly when he realized his father was beginning to fade. About six years ago, they were driving down Fifth Avenue when he gave his father big news: he had just bought the land beneath the Empire State Building. ''That's a tall building, isn't it?'' Fred C. Trump replied. ''How many apartments are in that building?'' At first, Donald thought he was kidding. But his father, 87, was developing Alzheimer's.

title: Charter Schools Enroll Few of Learning Disabled
description: When state education officials released a report last week showing that charter schools lagged behind public schools in the number of students with learning disabilities, advocacy groups representing parents were ready to say ''I told you so.''

title: The Year Is Young
description: The year is just a couple of days old, so there's plenty of time to get your money's worth if you invest in a year 2000 calendar. That's particularly true if you choose a calendar that features artwork of teenagers from New Jersey. The New Jersey State Teen Arts calendar is the 31st put out by New Jersey State Teen Arts, which is dedicated to promoting arts education for students in public and private schools, mainly through mentorships (the organization just got a grant from Channel 11 to set up mentorships with video professionals). The calendars have gone to legislators and schools, but there are some left at no charge beyond $2.50 for shipping, from New Jersey Teen Arts, 1422 Route 179, Lambertville, N.J. 08530; (609) 397-0505. The group also publishes an anthology of writing by teenagers, puts on a touring art show (at the State Aquarium in Camden through this month) and holds an annual arts festival. This year's, at the College of New Jersey in Trenton, will be May 24 and 25. You can mark the dates.

title: Dec. 26 - Jan. 1; Big Recall of Luxury Foods
description: In what may be the first Internet recall of contaminated food, D'Artagnan, the Newark, N.J., company known nationwide for its high quality foods, went beyond notifying the usual retailers and distributors of its voluntary recall of all of the pates, mousses and terrines made at a Huntington, N.Y., plant.

title: 7 Airlines Give an Inch For Middle Passenger
description: Seven foreign airlines have made a small change on their single-aisle Airbus jets to ease that feeling of being squeezed into a middle seat. Those middle seats -- designated B and E on the six-across economy-class seating layouts -- are now 20 inches wide, one inch wider than the aisle and window seats.

title: To Be Michael Jordan's, Or, Perhaps, Not to Be . . .
description: Had he envisioned the modern-day legal system, Shakespeare might have thought twice before so cavalierly asking, ''What's in a name?''

title: At-Home Fathers Step Out To Find They Are Not Alone
description: In a gray lecture hall in the Oakton Community College, a group of middle-aged men were shouting affirmations.

title: The Lives They Lived: Gene Sarazen, b. 1902 - Payne Stewart, b. 1957; Drive, He Said
description: The knickers were a mistake. They called attention to Payne Stewart, just as he had intended, but in their clownishness they also camouflaged his seriousness of purpose and the purity and simplicity of his golf game. Stewart's swing wasn't the most powerful or the most accurate on the tour, but it was by far the prettiest -- the one weekend dubbers would most readily sign over their souls for.

title: As Friends Divorce, A Look Within
description: ''ARE you sitting down?'' my friend asked over the telephone. She had some bad news, the kind that didn't qualify as tragedy but was more serious than gossip. I sat. She spoke. Not one, not two, but three couples we know were divorcing, she said.

description: To the Editor:

title: The Lives They Lived: Rudy Burckhardt, b. 1914; The Enabler
description: Rudy Burckhardt, a Swiss-born photographer, filmmaker, painter, occasional writer (''Love in Three Acts: A Swiss Play'') and guru (he would have hated the term) to several generations of New York artists and poets, committed suicide on Aug. 1 by walking into a pond near his summer home at Searsmont, Maine. He seems to have arranged his death according to the same offhand, slightly eccentric principles that guided his life. His wife, the painter Yvonne Jacquette, reports that Rudy's middle name was August, and that a couple of days before taking his life he pointed out to her that Aug. 1 is ''Swiss independence day.'' (He had never shown any pronounced fondness for the land of his birth.) At about the same time, he painted a portrait of himself, which he labeled ''The Last Portrait.'' When Yvonne asked him about the title he merely shrugged and made an evasive answer. On the evening of July 31 the Burckhardts had a pleasant dinner with the poet Bill Berkson and his wife. The next day Rudy was simply gone.

title: Over His Head?
description: To the Editor:

title: Disaster, And Then The Sequel
description: I WAS finally at the end of an exhausting trip, a three-week zigzag from Romania to Lithuania, from Hungary to Poland and back, but in a few short minutes I would be on my way home.

title: State Plan for Camp Hero Cabins Assailed
description: THE state parks commissioner, Bernadette Castro, said last week that 415 acres of state land at Camp Hero near the Montauk Lighthouse should be opened to the public as soon as possible for uses that could include hiking, fishing and accommodations in cabins available for rent.

description: To the Editor:

title: Dec. 26 - Jan. 1; Violence Visits a Beatle
description: Anyone who was once a Beatle, even the ''quiet'' one, can never fade away and live a simple life -- no matter how big the mansion, how high the walls. George Harrison learned that in a spasm of violence, one with echoes of John Lennon's murder nearly two decades ago.

title: Cleveland Orchestra Is Getting Its Home Back
description: Severance Hall, home of the Cleveland Orchestra, reopens Saturday after a two-year restoration. The building, containing a 2,000-seat concert auditorium and a 400-seat chamber hall, was opened in February 1931 and named for Elisabeth Severance, the wife of John Severance, the president of the orchestra's board.

title: That Elusive Surplus
description: For two decades, American politics were defined by what David Stockman, the Reagan-era budget director, memorably proclaimed to be deficits as far as the eye could see. With the arrival of this new year, the United States economy will shortly break the record set in the 1960's and achieve the longest boom in history. As a result, political candidates are now debating how to spend surpluses rather than how to reduce deficits. But the new game can be as tricky as the old one. The true size of any surplus is debatable. Even its existence is provisional, depending on yet unrealized spending cuts. So far the presidential candidates are more interested in talking about what a surplus might buy than in the painful choices that lie ahead.

title: Lives Lived Well And the Lesson That They Teach
description: THEY never made the cover of People magazine. Sometimes they didn't even make headlines in their community's weekly newspaper.

title: The Lives They Lived: David W. Belin, b. 1928 - Leonard C. Lewin, b. 1916; The Paranoia Gap
description: The year 1999 was not, it turned out, a vintage year for paranoia. Heaven knows why. We were prepared for all manner of hysteria: survivalist panics, religious retreats, cultic chaos. None of it materialized. Perhaps it was the genuine fear of a Y2K computer crash that distracted us from premillennial fantasies. Perhaps it was the transparency of the Internet and the power of hackers that made government secrecy seem less intimidating. Or maybe the paranoids of the mid-1990's simply blew themselves out with their ''X-Files'' excesses.

title: Woman Is Raped in Stairwell After Returning From a Party
description: A 21-year-old Manhattan woman returning home from a New Year's Eve party was raped early yesterday in the stairwell of her apartment building near City Hall, the authorities said.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MEIER, JUNE
description: MEIER-June. On December 26, 1999. Wife of the late Frank Meier. Mother of Diane, Gordon and Richard. Grandmother of Bennett, Bradford, Rebecca and John. As master-craftsman, teacher and advocate, she helped to rediscover and resurrect lost decorative arts from decoupage to all manner of painted finishes and taught a new generation to appreciate the beauty of the past and weave it into the context of the present. In lieu of flowers, please make donations to The Isabel O'Neil Foundation for the Art of the Painted Finish. A private memorial service is being planned.

title: How to Shop for the Baby Without Leaving the Nursery
description: BabyBox.com opened its Web site, specializing in gifts for newborn to 12-month-old babies, on Dec. 7. Featuring 36 ''shopping aisles'' with baby items ranging from teether rattles ($8.95) to grand Alsatian bassinets ($615-720), BabyBox.com, based in Brooklyn, consolidates on one site (www.babybox.com) a selection of upscale goods that would normally require a trip to many boutiques.

title: Annie Oneta Plummer, 63; Gave Dictionaries to Children
description: Annie O. Plummer, a housekeeper in Savannah, Ga., whose single-minded campaign to distribute thousands of free dictionaries to needy schoolchildren made her nationally known as ''The Dictionary Lady,'' died Dec. 23 at her home. She was 63.

title: To Find a New Killer Attack, Try Renovating an Old One
description: The National Chess Congress, held in Philadelphia from Nov. 22 to 28, finished with a four-grandmaster tie for first place. Joel Benjamin of Manhattan, Aleksandr Goldin of Russia, Alexander Ivanov of Brookline, Mass., and Alexander Shabalov of Pittsburgh each scored 5-1 in the 84-entrant, Swiss-system event and each was awarded a prize of $1,425. No tiebreak coefficients were used. The tournament, run by the Continental Chess Association, was held at the Adam's Mark Hotel.

title: The Talk of the Archdiocese: Who's Likely to Succeed the Cardinal
description: As the shepherd to 2.4 million parishioners and a man whose utterances are closely monitored, the archbishop of New York has historically had the tallest pulpit in the Roman Catholic Church in the United States.

title: Fed Up With Lean Pay, Cabbies Head to Court
description: RIZWAN RAJA always considered himself good at keeping track of money. As an accountant in his native Pakistan, he was hired to help audit large companies, calculating their earnings with pen and paper.

description: To the Editor:

title: Dean of 'Dadgum' Sets His Sights On a Championship
description: The coach is looking for soup in his kitchen, something warm to take to the couch while he puts up his feet and watches a nature show and lets his head clear from the cold he always manages to catch around the holidays. For an hour at least, until the wives of his assistant coaches arrive for a gift exchange, Bobby Bowden does not have to be Bobby Bowden, the kindly, homespun icon of Florida State football.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  OLAN, SUSAN MARIE TORIAN

Susan died confident that she had lived a life of integrity having done her best to make this world a better place. She is survived by her daughter, Anita Marie Olan, of Los Angeles, California; her aunt Minerva Quinlan of Hingham, Massachusetts; and her brother, Philip Torian, of Dallas, Texas.

title: The Lives They Lived: Hermann Merkin, b. 1907; The Public Father
description: My father died last March, at the age of 91, in his own bed, surrounded by his family; it was a sober, patriarchal, even old-world death, befitting his life. He had been ailing for close to two years, from heart failure and then lymphoma, but it still came as a surprise to see him yielding at last instead of rallying, as he had so many times before. My mother took the most extraordinary care of him, which included packing him off to the office for a few hours every day, right up until the week of his death. I rarely visited my father at his office, where he worked as an investment banker, but I knew that its ongoing affairs were more crucial to him, in many ways, than the life he led at home -- just as I knew that his public face as a philanthropist was easier to read than his private face as a father or husband. My father was an Orthodox Jew who had grown up in Leipzig, Germany; he remained committed to Jewish causes until his death, and his knowledge of the dizzying intricacies of Israeli politics was impressive. Throughout his life my father supported Jewish scholarship; he also helped endow the kosher kitchen at Mount Sinai, as well as the Merkin Concert Hall on West 67th Street (which is silent from Friday at sundown to Saturday at sundown, in observance of the Sabbath).

Today, we are struck by the enormous gulf that Madame Chu sought to span and by the tone with which she spanned it: she opens her groundbreaking 1962 cookbook, ''The Pleasures of Chinese Cooking,'' with the tremendous poise of an ambassador. ''We Chinese,'' she begins, ''like to think of cooking as a distinctive art form.''

title: Stock-Option Warriors

In its annual executive compensation report on companies with up to $200 million in revenue, Segal found that the stock-option warriors -- those whose compensation came primarily from stock options -- were in the high-technology area.

title: Single-Sex Swimming Beyond the Political

The request may be sound or unsound, and granting the request may be wise or unwise, but surely the decision cannot be based on the political correctness of the beliefs held by those who made the request! I cannot think of any grounds for resolving this matter that would be more ''inappropriate'' than that.

So when the magazine gave a book party to toast ''Abfab to Zen: Paper's Guide to Pop Culture'' not long ago, it was notable that the editors chose not a grungy club on Rivington Street but the newly renovated Russian Tea Room. Guests mingled in the eye-befuddling interior, decorated with mirrors, mosaics, a 15-foot revolving see-through bear filled with live fish and a gold tree laden with Faberge-inspired eggs. ''It was a bar mitzvah in Las Vegas,'' said Kim Hastreiter, a co-editor of Paper, who is planning an article for the March issue on the new vulgarity.

Survived by wife Phyllis Gold Gluck; sons Josiah, Theodore and Sebastian; sister-in-law Zina Gold Stern (Dr. Ernest Stern); and cousins. BA Ohio State; Colorado School of Mines; Ph.D. in Philosophy, Columbia. Professorships included Hofstra; College of Mount Saint Vincent. An industrial consultant in heavy industry. His publications and lectures, here and abroad, were fiery and humorous. He also inspired non-traditional students to fulfill their ambitions and dreams. Even more so on a recent night, midway through the American segment of the World Festival of Sacred Music -- the first of five pan-ecumenic, multiethnic and ecosensitive celebrations planned under the aegis of the Dalai Lama to take place on consecutive continents in the coming millennial months. Behind us, vistas of city lights unfolded like star maps. High above, the museum's floodlit walls glowed celestially white against the blackness. I was reminded -- Hollywood, after all, lay just beyond the freeway -- of all those comedies, wishfully divine, in which heaven is accessed by up-to-the minute forms of transportation.

title: The Lives They Lived: Jim Jensen, b. 1926; Authority Figure
description: The two most famous fictional TV news anchormen of the 1970's -- Ted Baxter of ''The Mary Tyler Moore Show'' and Howard Beale of ''Network'' -- may not have been directly inspired by Jim Jensen, but they could have been. Jensen, who worked at WCBS from 1964 to 1995, was the very model of a modern local newsman. With his deep Midwestern baritone, rangy good looks and a humorless, macho manner that suggested he could reach out of the tube and slug someone, he laid down the news with the authority of -- well, if not God, then at least Charlton Heston at full Old Testament throttle.

Martha Graham, for example, whose technique and stylization were based on her own physique and temperament, gave up choreographing for a number of years when her body could no longer uphold her self-imposed physical demands.

description: Whom do we remember, and why? Those are personal questions, and they are answered in dozens of ways in the pages ahead. This is the sixth edition of ''The Lives They Lived,'' an annual look back at noteworthy lives that ended in the year just past. Once more we have chosen to remember, and often (though not always) to celebrate, lives we find compelling.

This can easily be overlooked or disfavored, especially at a time when the most offensive or provoking works are getting most of the attention. One institution in particular, the Gallery at the Macy Pavilion at Westchester Medical Center here, believes in ''nurturing the spirit'' through beauty and selects works for exhibition accordingly.

title: The Lives They Lived: Questions for Tim Robbins; Body Double
description: Q: Your new film includes an aging ventriloquist. What accounted for the heyday of that now-overlooked genre? Did ventriloquism ever have a heyday? Seriously, I think what worked for the really popular ventriloquists, like Senor Wences and Edgar Bergen, is that the puppet had high disregard for the manipulator -- the nastiness that goes back and forth that's mostly directed toward the ventriloquist. Probably mischievousness is a better word. The funny thing about Edgar Bergen, of course, is that he was a radio star. Think about that -- a ventriloquist who was a radio star.

title: The Ominous Message of a Box on Union Square
description: ONE UNION SQUARE SOUTH fails on three counts. The architecture is big and boring, the artwork glued to its main facade is pretentious, and the thinking that joined the two is out of date. This is the worst example yet seen of a formula that has helped to drain the life out of New York architecture in recent years: the use of public art to cover up for uninspired buildings. What we also have here is a crisis for the Municipal Art Society, the venerable civic organization that brokered this unhappy consortium of art, architecture and real estate development. If anything of value can be salvaged from this failure, it is the opportunity to examine the circumstances from which it arose.

Like the stores in Miami, Boston and Chicago, the New York For Eyes features frames by designers like Calvin Klein, Cynthia Rowley and Kenneth Cole, at discount prices. Their frames are sold with the proper lens as a complete set, starting at $59.95.

title: The Third Millennium: So Far, So Good
description: FOR me, and I assume for most of you -- since whatever I'm thinking so too is the nation -- it was difficult to know exactly what to celebrate on Dec. 31, 1999. Do I celebrate the end of the year, the end of the 20th century or the end of the millennium? I chose the one remaining option, and therefore I assume so did most of you: the end of the day. This made for significantly reduced partying intensity. However, waking up on Saturday, knowing that Friday was now over, I felt compelled to write about the past 2,000 years and the changes that would be wrought in this new age. This was indeed a challenge to me as I desired to write the history of humankind, past, present and future, without bothering to do any research.

Is that what you are doing with your life?'' But Mrs. O'Neill just laughs about it. The reaction comes with the territory, of course; few topics rank as high on the ridicule meter as sea serpents.

It was the quintessential modern city, unrivaled in America, if not the world.

title: Beloved, in a Way, And Immortalized By Composers

So here is a chance to hear how three prominent composers have created their own images of this extraordinarily dynamic, technically superb and expressive artist.

''They call their mothers or best friends, then they call their real estate broker,'' said Sheila Siderow, a principal of Siderow Kennedy Real Estate in Chappaqua, adding that she often receives frantic calls from former customers, women on the verge of separation or divorce.

title: Ideas & Trends; Boot Camps: An Idea Whose Time Came and Went
description: FIVE years ago, responding to an increase in serious juvenile crime, the state of Maryland initiated one of the nation's largest boot camp programs for teenage criminals. The program, called the Leadership Challenge, quickly became the model for other states. But last week, after reviewing a task force report that documented instances of physical abuse at their camps, Maryland officials appeared on the verge of conceding that the current initiative was a failure.

title: Never Seen a Ruder Pesht
description: How do you say the name Sandor Turai like a Hungarian? Remember to click the r. ''And the ai is like oy,'' said Anne Vaughan, director of developement at New Jersey Rep in Long Branch. So much for Turai. As for Sandor, just say Shandor. Mrs. Vaughan, whose husband, Stuart Vaughan, is staging ''The Play's the Thing,'' which opens Friday at the company's Lumia Theater, was overhearing such pointers on pronunciation, freshly imparted by the executive producer, Gabor Barabas, who was born in Budapest. Budapesht, that is.

title: PULSE; Tea Bags to Sniff At
description: For those who can't commit to wearing a single scent for an entire day, L'Artisan Parfumeur personal sachets may do the trick. These portable packs of fragrance resemble shimmering silk tea bags and are filled with tiny perfumed beads. They're designed to be tucked into a shirt pocket, tied in the hair or thrown into a pocketbook. (They can also be used more conventionally in a dresser drawer or closet.) Marie Dumont, the company's creative director, said the goal was maximum aromatic versatility: wearers can switch scents at will. And the personal sachets also work for people with sensitive skin, who don't react well to direct application of perfumes or colognes. In addition to the spicy fragrance found in the tea bags, L'Artisan also offers small rectangular sachets in amber and blackberry scents, with colorful silk tassels intended to dangle outside a breast pocket. Prices are $10 each for the tea bags and $25 to $35 for the sachets. The first sachets arrived at Barneys New York last week, sold out and are on reorder. Have scratch, will sniff. ELLEN TIEN

Their essay, along with Ray Charles's sunglasses, photos of Earth from space, a Twinkie, Corningware, a computer chip, the Bill of Rights, a World War II helmet, a cell phone and a piece of the Berlin Wall will be among the items sealed this summer in the National Millennium Time Capsule until 2100.

E-commerce looks poised to transform entire sectors of the economy.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HSIEH, JUI SHENG, PH.D.
description: HSIEH-Jui Sheng, Ph.D.. Age 78, of Southport, CT, beloved husband of Mary Wang Hsieh, died on Thursday, December 30, 1999 in Bridgeport, CT. Born in China, he came to the U.S. in 1948 and had lived in Belle Mead, NJ for 22 years before moving to CT in 1998. Dr. Hsieh graduated from Wuhan University in China in 1943, and earned his Masters Degree in Mechanical Engineering from the University of Kentucky in 1950 and his Ph.D. from Ohio State in 1955. He taught at the University of Bridgeport, then at New Jersey Institute of Technology for 31 years until his retirement in 1991. He authored 3 text books, ''Principles of Thermodynamics'' (McGraw-Hill), ''Solar Energy Engineering'' (PrenticeHall), and ''Engineering Thermodynamics'' (Prentice-Hall), and was listed in the World and America editions of ''Who's Who.'' In addition to his devoted wife of 38 years, he is survived by a son Lawrence and his wife Janice; two daughters, Esther and her husband William, Vivian and her husband Tad; four grandchildren;, one brother, Chi Sheng Hsieh; a stepbrother, Dong Sheng Hsieh; a stepsister, Zhou Ru Hsieh; many nieces and nephews. Private services will be held in CT. Memorials can be made to: The Bridgeport Hospital's Medical I.C.U., 267 Grant St, Bridgeport, CT 06610.

title: The Lives They Lived: Gorilla Monsoon, b. 1937; When Wrestling Was Noir
description: The first time I saw the face of Evil, I was 8 or 9. It was a little after midnight, and I had sneaked out of the bedroom and felt my way into the basement, where my father kept an old black-and-white TV with a cracked wooden cabinet in his workshop. I clicked it on in the dark and froze in terror at a sight I had never seen upstairs before bedtime: a human monster, repulsive in a one-piece bodysuit, twirling a man over his head, cackling demonically. He was Gorilla Monsoon, the announcer said with a suitable tremor, and for some time I thought he existed only on a broken TV in the basement at night.

title: 'Lady in the Van' Offers a Moral Behind the Laughter
description: ALAN BENNETT has been much on the minds of British theatergoers of late. Two different actors, each complete with specs, floppy hair and mournful Yorkshire accent, perform the playwright himself in ''The Lady in the Van,'' the dramatic memoir he recently opened at the Queen's. The National Theater is staging ''Battle Royal,'' which is by the lesser-known Nick Stafford but has been widely seen as a sequel to Mr. Bennett's ''Madness of George III.'' We would not have been too astonished if the dramatist, who has occasionally appeared on the London stage in the past, had rematerialized as a melancholy sprite in the magnificently original ''Midsummer Night's Dream'' that the Royal Shakespeare Company is presenting at the Barbican.

title: The Lives They Lived: Kurt Eissler, b. 1908; Keeper of Freud's Secrets
description: In preparation for writing about the psychoanalyst, writer and scholar Kurt Robert Eissler, who died in February, I went to the library of the New York Psychoanalytic Institute to read the memorial tributes that colleagues traditionally put on record there. Eissler, who was born in Vienna and came to America in 1938 to escape Hitler, had been one of the institute's ornaments. He was the author of 12 books, among them ''Goethe: A Psychoanalytic Study'' and ''Talent and Genius: The Fictitious Case of Tausk Contra Freud.'' In addition to his writing and a full-time psychoanalytic practice, he created, and for many years single-handedly ran, the Sigmund Freud Archives, an enterprise designed to save from oblivion the scattered letters, photographs and papers of Freud, and to preserve the recollections of Freud's living colleagues, relatives and patients through tape-recorded interviews.

title: So Many Great Women, So Little Time
description: Every year they're confronted with the same vexing situation at Ladies' Home Journal: so many fabulous women, so little time. It was the same case a few months back, when the magazine's editors sat down to figure out their choices for the fourth annual broadcast of ''Ladies' Home Journal's Most Fascinating Women'' -- and how to include them all in the one-hour special, which is to be shown tomorrow night at 10.

The package is not valid from Wednesday to Jan. 11; March 16 to 20, and April 17 to 28. The 307-room hotel, which opened last month on the southern Sinai Peninsula, overlooks a reef where diving can be arranged. There are several pools and three lighted tennis courts. The newly released 94-minute DVD (Columbia Music Video, $29.99) includes an accompanying documentary, ''Retrospective,'' in which the principals look back nearly two decades, bemused at the most unpleasant shoot.

Still giddy from the gala send-off the night before in Harlem, they milled around the Brooklyn pier waiting for Langston Hughes, who at the last minute ran up the gangplank with a typewriter, Victrola and a boxful of Louis Armstrong records. Most of them had never been abroad, but now they were on their way to Moscow to make ''Black and White,'' a film about ''Negro life'' in America.

title: Russia's Flawed Reformer
description: In suddenly resigning as Russian president on Friday, Boris Yeltsin showed once again why he will be remembered as a practitioner of the unexpected political stratagem. Like so many of Mr. Yeltsin's gambits over the years, the move upended expectations and scrambled Russian politics. It also came with a promise of immunity from prosecution for Mr. Yeltsin for any misdeeds of his government. That will likely roil the coming presidential campaign, a fitting legacy for a courageous but disappointingly erratic man who guided Russia through the first years of a turbulent, still unfinished journey from tyranny to democracy.
