title: Books in Brief: Fiction & Poetry; Italy's Women Warriors
description: PARTISAN WEDDING (University of Missouri, paper, $19.95), Renata ViganRated R's spare and heart-wrenching story collection, is centered on women involved in the Italian resistance during World War II. The author, who died in 1976, was herself a courier, or staffetta, for the partisans who fought the Germans near Bologna; she fictionalized her experiences and those of other women she knew in these captivating and vivid stories. The title story describes the humble wedding of a servant, Marina, to a partisan in a hilltop hideout. Set against the backdrop of wartime Italy, the ominous mood surrounding the ceremony, together with the bride and groom's innocence, establishes the tone for the collection and introduces one of the book's dominant themes: how the clandestine war was fought on a personal level. In ''Campalbo'' a 13-year-old girl whose father was shot by the Germans proudly risks her life to bring newspapers to the partisans hiding in the hills. Many of ViganRated R's stories depict women deliberately using their sexuality in order to achieve a desired goal. In ''Red Flag,'' a woman hides ammunition under her used sanitary napkins. In ''Argelide,'' a former prostitute poses as the madam of a brothel so that Germans won't suspect her house as a partisan meeting place. ''The Last Action'' tells the story of a German sympathizer who seduces a partisan in order to get him to reveal his colleagues' names. Suzanne Branciforte's translation beautifully renders ViganRated R's simple but passionate prose into English, and her informative introduction rightfully claims for ViganRated R the invaluable contribution her writing has made to the literature of World War II. Jenny McPhee

title: The Lives They Lived: Lili St. Cyr, b. 1918; When Burlesque Was Beautiful
description: Lili St. Cyr, who died last January at the age of 80, was one of the last survivors of an era that now seems as remote as the Hapsburg dynasty. That era might be called the age of burlesque, which makes it sound rather grand, and let's say it lasted from 1893 until 1960, or thereabouts. Burlesque was a stratum of entertainment, not exactly underground but not quite legit -- in the theatrical sense of the word -- which might or might not involve singers, comedians, chorus lines or canned-ham raffles. Its essential feature, however, was women slowly removing most or all of their clothing. Lili St. Cyr excelled at this art and introduced several refinements, like her trademark emergence from an onstage bubble bath with the bubbles selectively clinging to her salient parts.

title: Books in Brief: Nonfiction; Have a Look! Have Two!
description: In a sense, the aerial photographs of Yann Arthus-Bertrand are happy accidents: he took them from aircraft in 60 countries, and composition on the fly is chancy. But the prints are proof that, if the earth itself is not alive, its whole surface is always moving. Wind, water, tectonic plates and people are slow agents, but the marks of change are vast; the images capture eons in a moment. Whether you look down on the Lakagigar volcanoes in Iceland or the man-made windbreaks of the Aran Islands, you know Galileo said more than he meant when he insisted, ''It moves.'' Almost 200 of Arthus-Bertrand's images are lavishly reproduced in EARTH FROM ABOVE (Abrams, $65). The project was sponsored by Unesco, and the book has commentaries by French scientists who worry about humanity covering the planet too fast. But the photographs undermine their eloquence; to paraphrase John Lyly, the pictures are honey though the words are gall. From above, acres of carpets laid out on the sands of Morocco or even the dumps of Mexico City are as gorgeous as the autumn forests of Quebec or the mineral ''forest'' of Madagascar. Shots of the sprawl of monstrous cities are not reassuring, but over all one marvels at how naturally humanity's endless sand-castling fits into nature. And what a work nature is! Everywhere -- in cosmic brush strokes of bacteria in the Grand Prismatic Spring of Yellowstone or minerals washed over by the Rio Carrao in Venezuela -- the earth creates color and patterns that reduce human art to its proper place. ''Earth From Above'' is translated from French (by David Baker), and here and there one is reminded of the pitfalls of translation, as when it tells us the Yankees are ''the most winningest team'' in baseball, and of how iffy proofreading is in any language, as when it says the Maldives are ''120 isles or islets, of which almost 420 are inhabited.'' But it is a terrific book to look at and think about. D. J. R. Bruckner

At the interview, the men told the board that all that was needed for the business was a desk, a phone and a fax, and that only rarely would clients come to the office. The board approved the lease and the men paid me one month's rent and two months' security. Twenty-one days after the lease began the men had still not moved into the unit. Then, after one of them told the chairman of the co-op board that he intended to open a Holistic Medical Center, which would require major renovations and would serve hundreds of clients, the board rescinded its approval. I have refused to return the rent and security deposit on the ground that the tenants had broken the lease. Now I am being sued. What is the law in such a matter? . . . Wayne Martens, Manhattan.

title: The Lives They Lived: Harry Callahan, b. 1912 - Raghubir Singh, b. 1942; Two Landscapes
description: Harry Callahan, the abstract photographer from the Midwest, and Raghubir Singh, the realist from Rajasthan, are not on the same page, metaphorically speaking. One was Western, the other Eastern. One looked inward, the other outward. Callahan, an influential teacher of photography at the Institute of Design in Chicago and the Rhode Island School of Design, had important predecessors (Laszlo Moholy-Nagy), colleagues (Aaron Siskind) and students (Linda Connor, Ray K. Metzker, Emmet Gowin). He photographed weeds in water and scarred walls, but mostly, over and over again, in exposure and double exposure, he shot the body of his wife, Eleanor, as an intimate landscape. Singh, meanwhile, often complained of the ''wholly Western,'' angst-ridden nature of photography, saying, ''The Indian photographer had to cut his own route.'' He photographed Benares, Bombay, Calcutta, Kashmir -- landscapes teeming with bodies and buildings and public ritual.

title: The Lives They Lived: Dusty Springfield, b. 1939; The Sound of ... Pop
description: When I met Dusty Springfield in 1995, she was in the pocket -- a musician's term akin to ''in the zone'' for athletes. She was enjoying renewed acclaim for her 60's recordings, which covered a virtually unplottable graph of moods and styles, from the girl-groupy joy ride of ''I Only Want to Be With You'' to the breathy eroticism of ''The Look of Love.'' She had just won a round in her battle with cancer and seemed in no hurry to get back to the recording studio. ''Although, if someone let me record an album of every cover I've ever dreamed of singing, I might think about it,'' she coolly intoned.

title: Dining Out; Critic's Choice: Where Service Counts
description: THE bull market may rage on, but dining opportunities in Westchester are turning decidedly bearish. That is not to say there are no fabulous restaurants that would repeatedly draw us back for occasions ranging from a casual repast with a peckish friend to a formal bash celebrating one of life's great events. There are, and they are listed below. But observant readers will notice that this year's choice picks number fewer than those in the past. And the primary cause for these cuts is ungracious or inattentive service.

title: An N.B.A. Power Broker Who Lost His Power
description: Just over two years ago, he secured for Kevin Garnett the richest contract in professional sports history -- a $126 million deal that helped stoke the flames of a labor war between players and owners. Eric Fleisher was becoming such a feared power broker, he even held a franchise hostage while inviting a bevy of comparisons to David Falk, the shrewdest and best known of the sports agents. Fleisher's clientele included Stephon Marbury, Joe Smith and Al Harrington.

title: Food for Thought, Zero Calories
description: I have a scale that subtracts five pounds from my actual weight, a husband who constantly tells me that I am adorable, and all my jeans contain Lycra.

title: The Lives They Lived: William Woodward III, b. 1944; Manhattan Gothic, Final Chapter
description: Anyone who knew Woody Woodward felt a dreadful pity at how the drama of his life was resolved that Sunday morning in May when he stepped into the abyss outside the kitchen window of his Manhattan apartment and fell 14 stories to his death. He was 54 years old. He left a 6-year-old daughter, an estranged wife and an estate worth upwards of $60 million. His old Harvard pals; his Newport sailing mates; the women who left soup at his door when he was under the weather and who were smitten by his almost unsporting mix of charm, looks, wounded romanticism and old money -- they all cast about for reasons. Was it a reprise of the manic-depression that he seemed to have under control? The ordeal of a bitterly contested divorce? Or had their funny, fragile, self-absorbed friend been propelled by something more perverse, which is to say the larger tragedy of the Woodward family itself? He had contested his family's legacy of self-destruction all his life, until the last moment, when, abruptly, he embraced it.

title: A Town Aspires to Landmark Status
description: In a matter of months, this Midwestern small town of big-city architecture that is a who's who of post-war design may boast yet another distinction: a group of its buildings is likely to become the first in modern architecture to win National Historic Landmark status, an honor more often bestowed on the nation's earliest buildings.

title: The Lives They Lived: James Farmer, b. 1920 - Daisy Bates, b. 1914 - Frank M. Johnson Jr., b. 1918; Veterans of a Domestic War
description: America has spent the past several years acknowledging the indisputable heroes of World War II: the G.I.'s who stormed Omaha Beach, liberated concentration camps, fulfilled Gen. Douglas MacArthur's pledge to return to the Philippines and so much more. But members of that same generation who led the modern civil rights movement have yet to receive the same treatment, and portrayals of them still often give off a whiff of un-Americanism, a lasting effect of the 1950's Red scare, which labeled as a Communist rabble-rouser anyone -- and certainly any black -- who threatened the social order. It's a troubling paradox when considering the lives of three extraordinary, yet dimly remembered, heroes of the civil rights movement: James Farmer, Daisy Bates and Frank M. Johnson Jr.

title: Taking the Time to Repair or Replace a Balustrade
description: A WELL-CONSTRUCTED staircase is made of many components: treads, risers and stringers that fit together like a fine cabinet. Some staircases are enclosed between two walls, but most are usually built against one wall with the opposite side being open. For safety reasons, the open side should be enclosed with a balustrade. The balustrade is a series of vertical posts, called balusters. These support the handrail. One end of the handrail is usually anchored to a wall or a railing at the top of the stairs. At the other end of the balustrade, at the foot of the stairs, is the newel post. It supports the handrail and anchors the balustrade.

description: Oh Bayonne, you will shine once again as with diamonds. from ''O, Bayonne on Approaching the Millennium'' by Herschel Silverman

title: The Eloquent Words Of Legendary Writers
description: Until the beginning of the 20th century, the coverage of sports in newspapers, except for the occasional heavyweight title fight or a local football or baseball game, was little more than an afterthought. Then, with increasing leisure time for readers to both play and watch, sports grew more important to life and lifestyle. Editors caught on, and sportswriting began to flourish.

That may seem a small satisfaction compared with the absence of computer mayhem, but television's millennium display was often more revealing in its smaller moments than in its scope.

title: The Wisdom of Y2K Planning
description: In a welcome anticlimax to two years of dire warnings, the new millennium arrived over the weekend without a computer-driven meltdown of the globe's electronic infrastructure. So far even the countries that did not spend vast sums to prepare for a Y2K-bug disaster have been spared major problems, raising questions about whether all the planning and expense were necessary. The speculation about what might have happened had there been no preparation is intriguing and inevitable. But common sense suggests that inaction was not an option for government and business leaders once the experts determined the existence of a threat to power grids, defense systems, air transport, financial communications and other vital linkages.

title: The Rural Life; The Feel of a Rope in Hand
description: Every evening, just at dusk, I carry two hay bales into the middle pasture. One goes into the high feed-bunk, the other into the feeder just below it. Each bale is bound by two strings of sisal baling twine. I cut the strings near their knots, which were tied by a mechanical baler sometime late last summer in a Massachusetts hayfield. The bale springs apart, and the hay falls into flakes. I coil the strings into a neat loop and put them in my pocket. There is at least one coil of twine in every jacket I own and another in the hip pocket of every pair of jeans. On this place, baling twine is the thread of life.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WALTZMAN, STUART ALAN, M.D.
description: WALTZMAN-Stuart Alan, M.D., 63. Devoted and adoring husband to Dava, father to Michael, Howard and Lynn, grandfather to Robert, brother to Susan and beloved friend. A graduate of Cornell University, Class of 1957, and Chicago Medical School, Class of 1961, he trained in Psychiatry at Hillside Hospital of Long Island Jewish Medical Center and was commissioned as a Captain in the U.S. Army from 1965 through 1967. He was an accomplished and respected psychiatrist: A former Director of Liaison Psychiatry at Jacobi Hospital, a member of the faculty of the Department of Psychiatry at Albert Einstein College of Medicine, Attending Physician at Norwalk Hospital and a Private Practitioner for over 30 years in Westport, CT. He had an uncanny perception of people and a remarkable appreciation for life. He was a lover of sports, classical music, golden retrievers and the Florida Keys. His compassion, loyalty, intelligence, sense of humor and ability to use these traits to interact were a source of pleasure to all who were fortunate enough to have associated with him. To know him was to be enriched beyond comprehension. To have lost him will leave a vacuum never ending. A memorial service will be held on Wednesday, January 5th, at 10 AM, in the Perkin Auditorium at Norwalk Hospital, Norwalk, CT. Donations in his memory may be made to Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center, Box E, 1275 York Ave., NY NY 10021.

The trade surplus for all of 1999 fell to $24.5 billion from $39 billion in 1998.

She touched all who knew her by her graciousness, keen intelligence and extraordinary degree of competence. Born in, and a lifelong resident of Englewood and Fort Lee, NJ she was an employee of Drexel Burnham Lambert and its successor Burnham Securities, Inc. for the last 34 years. She was the consummate professional. Her outward gentleness, tact and reserve masked a steely determination and ability to deal with all kinds of people who crossed her path. This same determination enabled her to graduate from St. Peter's College at age 59. In addition to her son, Jim, daughter, Adrienne, and daughter-in-law, Lisa, she is survived by cousins, nieces, nephews, and extended family, all of whom respected and loved her. Her death leaves us with a hole in our hearts. Her tastefulness, and appreciation of the fine and performing arts was well known to all who knew her, particularly her love of the opera. Private cremation. Memorial service will be held Tuesday, January 4, at 6 pm at the Frank E. Campbell Funeral Home, 81st & Madison in Manhattan. Rest in peace, mom. title: OCCIDENTAL AND EOG RESOURCES SWAP PROPERTIES
description: The Occidental Petroleum Corporation and EOG Resources Inc. said yesterday that they had exchanged oil and natural-gas fields in the United States to cut costs and increase production. Occidental, the ninth-biggest United States oil company, received fields in California that produce about 12 million cubic feet of gas a day. It also got properties in the western Gulf of Mexico that produce 26 million cubic feet of gas equivalent a day. They are adjacent to fields Occidental already owns. EOG received properties in eastern Texas that are next to fields it owns. Occidental's shares fell 81.25 cents, to $20.8125, on the New York Stock Exchange, while EOG, formerly the Enron Oil and Gas Company, fell $2.0625, to $15.50.

Robert Craft, who was Stravinsky's constant companion, helpmeet and guide throughout most of his years in the United States, probably feels close to every note of the output, and yet the latest installment in his complete recorded edition of the composer (Koch 3-7470-2-H1) lacks fire.

title: Tradition of Equality Is Fading in New Japan

title: Fleeing an Abusive Spouse and Finding a New Home

title: ISRAEL AND SYRIA RETURN TO SEARCH FOR MAJOR ACCORD
description: Talks between Israeli and Syrian leaders on a comprehensive peace accord opened today behind closed doors. The meetings began with a sense of urgency, American officials said, but they pointed to signs that the path would not be easy and that a single round of negotiations would probably not conclude the talks.

title: BERINGER TO SELL NAPA RIDGE BRAND TO BRONCO WINES
description: Beringer Wine Estates Holdings Inc. said yesterday that it had agreed to sell its Napa Ridge brand and inventory to the Bronco Wine Company of Ceres, Calif., for about $40 million. Beringer said no winery facility, vineyard holdings or other real estate would be included in the sale, which is expected to close this week. Beringer reported revenue of $391.6 million for the last 12 months.

description: Wal-Mart Stores Inc. has circled quietly over German retailers for nearly two years. Today, it attacked.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BENJAMIN, DR. BERNARD
description: BENJAMIN-Dr. Bernard. Formerly of Brooklyn NY. On January 1, 2000 at age 96. Noted pediatric physician who first identified pernicious anemia in children. A Research Fellow at the Rockefeller Institute. He was also a Professor at the State Univerity of New York, Downstate Medical Center at Brooklyn for 25 years. He practiced pediatrics and lived in Bedford-Stuyvesant for over 60 years. During WW II, Col. Benjamin received the Bronze Star Medal for his medical service in Europe. His first wife, Professor Helen Benjamin died in 1982. He is survived by his wife, Margery Benjamin (nee Hofstater), his son, Dr. Robert Benjamin of Houston TX, his daughter, Ann Goldblatt of Norwalk CT, four grandchildren and one great grandchild. Funeral services Wednesday, January 5 at 12:45PM at Riverside Chapel, Amsterdam Ave at 76th Street, NYC

title: The Festival in Times Square
description: Ever since a vast throng gathered in Lower Manhattan to hail the ratification of the United States Constitution in 1787, New York City has served as the premier location for great national celebrations. The New Year's Eve spectacle last weekend was no exception. Thanks to exhaustive planning by the police and city officials under Mayor Rudolph Giuliani, the Times Square bash was a glittering triumph. The crowd could be joyous because it knew that all possible precautions had been taken even in the absence of specific hints of terrorist threats or other mayhem. Yet the security measures were installed in a spirit that did not jeopardize the chance of having an uproariously good time.

title: Few Year 2000 Glitches Are Reported on First Working Day
description: Year 2000 computer glitches began appearing as much of the world headed back to work yesterday after the New Year's holiday, but they remained scattered and, for the most part, trivial.

title: 5 Judges to Hear Big Cases Against City
description: To streamline the city's overburdened courts, administrators are starting a pilot program in Manhattan that will assign all major lawsuits filed against the city and state to a select group of five judges.

title: Islanders' Odjick Suspended 8 Games
description: Sucker punches in the National Hockey League are becoming very expensive. Gino Odjick of the Islanders found out just how expensive yesterday when he was suspended for eight games without pay for hitting Darius Kasparaitis of the Pittsburgh Penguins from behind on Dec. 30.

title: The Odds Against the Weary Driver
description: Drivers who work night shifts or long hours (or who have more than one job) are much more likely to be in car accidents caused by being tired, a new study suggests.

description: AL GORE

title: MEXICO BREWER RAISES PRICES
description: Mexico's largest brewer, Grupo Modelo S.A., raised by 16 percent the average domestic price of its 10 beer labels. That increase could help the company strengthen profits because it is 6 percent higher than the Mexican government's 10 percent inflation target for 2000. The price change does not apply to exports. Modelo exports five of its labels, including Corona Extra, the largest-selling imported beer in the United States.

description: Physicists, if they are successful enough to penetrate the public consciousness, learn that with fame come fans with -- to put it mildly -- eccentric ideas.

title: G.O.P. Is Fined, Settling Dispute Over Disclosure Of Expenses
description: The New York Republican State Committee has paid a fine of $128,000 to the Federal Election Commission for making cash expenditures and failing to disclose their purpose while it monitored balloting in New York City in 1994 and 1996, the commission said yesterday.

title: From the Pipeline To the Courtroom; Gap on BP Amoco-ARCO Deal Is Wide
description: Senators and governors from the West Coast and Alaska, as well as oil executives and lawyers, have been flocking to the Federal Trade Commission in recent weeks in what has quickly turned into one of the most contentious political and regulatory campaigns of the season.

title: Democrats Vary Subtly On Education Goals
description: When it comes to education, the difference between the Democratic presidential candidates is not so much what they have to say as how often they say it.

title: Despite Inmate Strike Threat, No Disruptions
description: Despite threats that prison inmates across New York State would begin a strike on New Year's Day, state officials said no major disruptions had occurred as of yesterday, the first day inmates were expected to return to jobs after the holidays.

title: One Big Catch Needed to Complete Warrick's Turnaround
description: He knows why he lost the Heisman Trophy. He knows how he dropped the Biletnikoff award for the nation's best wide receiver. He knows how he undid all the admiration that he had earned last winter when he decided to skip the National Football League draft to return to Florida State for his senior year. Still, Peter Warrick also knows that he is just 60 minutes away from having a pretty good year.

title: Ex-Detective Is Sentenced To 30 Months for Bribes
description: A former detective convicted of taking bribes to protect prostitution and gambling operations in a West New York police corruption scandal was sentenced yesterday to 30 months in federal prison.

title: Cable Company Blocking Fox Programs
description: Cox Communications Inc., the fifth largest cable operator in the United States, has blocked 500,000 customers from seeing local programming from News Corporation's Fox Entertainment Group Inc. after the two companies failed to reach a new distribution agreement.

title: Mets Make The Call On Bonilla: You're Out
description: Bobby Bonilla guaranteed that he would become a major distraction if the Mets did not play him regularly in the 2000 season. Bonilla played cards with Rickey Henderson in the clubhouse during the final innings of the tense 1999 National League Championship Series. He once threatened to fight Manager Bobby Valentine. The Mets always wondered what he would do or say next.

title: In Siberia, the World Moves In With Lenin's Legacy
description: Not that long ago it was one of Russia's largest Lenin museums, five stories devoted solely to the first Soviet leader and his Communist state. It is now one of Russia's most unconventional, multifaceted museums, serving not Moscow or St. Petersburg but a swath of Siberia better known for concentration camps than culture.

title: I.M.F. CALLS FOR INDONESIAN ACTION
description: The International Monetary Fund, which is leading a multibillion dollar bailout for Indonesia, called for Bank Indonesia to take corrective action on problems highlighted in a critical report prepared by an independent audit. The I.M.F.'s Indonesia representative, John Dodsworth, said the agency was waiting to see what corrective measures Bank Indonesia would take in response to an audit conducted by the government's Supreme Audit Board. The audit revealed that the central bank was near insolvency and that it had mishandled government funds to ailing banks in late 1997 and the first half of 1998.

title: EDO AGREES TO BUY AIL TECHNOLOGIES FOR $88.4 MILLION
description: The Edo Corporation, a maker of electronic systems for the military industry, agreed to buy the closely held Ail Technologies Inc. for about $88.4 million in cash, stock and debt to add military and aerospace technologies. Edo will issue about 6.55 million shares, pay about $13.1 million and assume about $35.2 million in debt from Ail Technologies, based in Deer Park, N.Y. Edo said the companies' combined revenue could reach $240 million. Edo, based in New York, makes electronic optical products, including undersea sonar systems. Ail's products include defensive electronics on the B-1B bomber and aircraft, marine and satellite antennas

title: Under Legal Attack, H.M.O.'s Face a Supreme Court Test

title: Israeli President Under Fire After Reports of Big Gifts
description: President Ezer Weizman, a crotchety outspoken political veteran, faces pressure to resign after his endorsement of an Israeli withdrawal from the Golan Heights and disclosures that he has accepted substantial undisclosed financial gifts from a French executive.

title: In the Backyard, a Potent Source of Pollution
description: Household trash burned in one backyard barrel may release more dioxins, furans, and other chlorine-containing pollutants to the air than tons of trash burned by a municipal waste incinerator serving tens of thousands of homes, according to a report being made public today.

title: American Leadership at the U.N.
description: This month is America's turn to preside over the United Nations Security Council. That duty rotates among the body's 15 members. While the powers of the council presidency are limited, the job involves close coordination with Secretary General Kofi Annan and considerable control over the council's agenda. Washington can use this opportunity to press for action on a global front.

title: India Is Accusing Pakistan Of Being Behind Hijacking
description: Facing sharp criticism of his government's decision to negotiate with the hijackers of an Indian commercial jetliner, Prime Minister Atal Behari Vajpayee today accused Pakistan of being behind the incident and called on major nations, including the United States, to declare Pakistan a terrorist state.

title: New Species In Kingdom Of the Mouth
description: People may believe that their mouths are pristine after a good brushing and flossing. But the truth is that the human mouth is home to so many microbes that some researchers compare it to a rain forest for the diversity of life and vast territory yet to be explored.

title: A Hijacking's Dangerous Fallout
description: Less than a week after the release of 155 hostages from a hijacked Indian Airlines jet, India and Pakistan are firing dangerously inflammatory charges and countercharges at each other over the incident. Though no evidence has come to light to support the allegations, each side is accusing the other of masterminding the hijacking or somehow aiding those who carried it out. The danger of an escalating confrontation between two nuclear powers is once again present, this time only a few months before President Clinton's scheduled visit to the Asian subcontinent.

description: Buoyed by revenues from a strong economy, states have accumulated large surpluses, are cutting taxes and plan to increase spending for education and health care this year.

title: 3TEC ENERGY ACQUIRES RIVAL COMPANY FOR $24.5 MILLION
description: The 3TEC Energy Corporation, which explores for oil and natural gas, agreed yesterday to buy closely held rival Magellan Exploration L.L.C. for about $24.5 million in stock. 3TEC will issue 3.3 million common shares to Magellan's owners, plus warrants to buy 1 million more at $10 each for four years. 3TEC also will issue 1.875 million shares of preferred stock, each valued at $8 and with a dividend of 5 percent a year. Both companies are based in Houston. Magellan had reserves of 20 billion cubic feet of natural-gas equivalent, valued at $38.3 million, as of Oct. 1, 3TEC said. 3TEC, which changed its name from the Middle Bay Oil Company last month, operates in Texas, Louisiana and Oklahoma. It had sales of $15 million in 1998.

title: Village Voice's Sale Turns Gadfly Into Chain Flagship
description: The Village Voice, the 44-year-old alternative newspaper that became an icon of journalistic iconoclasm, has been sold to a group of investors who are installing the current publisher, David Schneiderman, as chief executive of a new company, Village Voice Media.

description: ZUCKER-Norma. Loving and beloved wife of the late Leonard. Cherished mother of Marian Waldman and Laura Lakin. Devoted aunt of Peter and Paul Kazaras. Memorial service private. Contributions to Doctors Without Borders would be appreciated.

description: The nagging question today, as Russian officials began laboriously assembling the machinery for Russia's second post-Soviet presidential election, was not how or when the vote would be held. It was why.

description: Bell Atlantic will begin offering long-distance service today in New York for as little as 5 cents a minute without the monthly fees typically charged by rivals like AT&T and MCI WorldCom.

description: Worldwide sales of semiconductors in November climbed 25 percent, to a record $14.2 billion, lifted by rising demand for memory chips for computers and mobile phones, the Semiconductor Industry Association said today.

title: Small and Family-Run, Yes. Homespun, No.
description: RESTAURANTS are routinely compared to the theater, but sometimes film seems like a better analogy. There are major studios, like Restaurant Associates or the Smith & Wollensky Restaurant Group, that combine class and mass. Drew Nieporent's Myriad Group, which includes TriBeCa Grill, Montrachet and Berkeley Bar and Grill, does a convincing impersonation of Miramax, a big-bucks company with the soul of an independent. There are star chefs like Jean-Georges Vongerichten who can green-light a restaurant merely by wiggling an eyebrow. And on the margins are hundreds of small restaurants that, like small independent films, express a highly personal vision.

title: Coaching Arrow Spins Right Back to Parcells
description: Three years ago, Bill Belichick was the Jets' head coach for one week. It was simply a ploy. He held the seat warm until Bill Parcells could be freed from the New England Patriots and then Belichick took his customary role as defensive coordinator.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ZUMWALT, ELMO R., JR

title: Museum Chief in Cleveland
description: In a choice that seems sentimental as well as practical, the Cleveland Museum of Art is to announce today that Katharine Lee Reid will become its new director. Ms. Reid, director of the Virginia Museum of Fine Arts in Richmond, is the daughter of the Cleveland's legendary director, Sherman E. Lee, a Chinese-art scholar who ran the museum from 1958 to 1983 and built it into a leading showplace for Asian art.

title: People
description: Laura McEwen was named publisher at YM magazine, New York, part of the Gruner & Jahr USA Publishing unit of Bertelsmann A.G., succeeding Kristine Schreiber, who left. Ms. McEwen had been publisher at New Woman magazine, New York, part of Rodale Press, which closed.

title: BITS AND BYTES; Shopping a World of Cheeses
description: IN this new era of the farmer at the Dell, the mouse definitely takes the cheese. Never has so much information on cheese -- varied, nutritious and one of life's most delicious staples -- been nearer to hand, on the Internet.

title: Computer Technicians Learn They Are Indispensable Parts
description: The managers of the Phoenix Home Life Mutual Insurance Company's Chicago office know how to butter up the corporate V.I.P.'s. As a holiday gift, they flew a quartet of jazz singers to the Hartford headquarters last month to parade around in Mickey Mouse sweaters and sing Christmas carols to the people who hold real power over their professional lives.

title: Henry Fowler Is Dead at 91; Former Treasury Secretary
description: Henry H. Fowler, who as Treasury Secretary in the Johnson administration helped raise the money to meet the soaring costs of the Vietnam War and who proposed what turned out to be the last Federal budget surplus in a generation, died on Monday at a nursing home in Alexandria, Va. He was 91.

title: Sears Expects Robust Earnings, But Analysts Doubt a Recovery
description: Sears, Roebuck & Company said yesterday that its fourth-quarter earnings would sharply exceed expectations, but analysts cautioned against characterizing the anticipated profit increase as a sign that the troubled merchant had turned its fortunes around.

title: In Defense Of a Species, The Recorded Opera in Full
description: The soprano Renee Fleming first performed the role of the Marschallin in Strauss's opera ''Der Rosenkavalier'' in 1995 at the Houston Grand Opera. For a first try at a touchstone role with an imposing heritage of famous interpreters, Ms. Fleming's performance was reportedly impressive. She performed it again in 1997 at the Bastille Opera in Paris, with even greater confidence, depth and eloquence. That performance was a critical triumph, and word quickly spread that a remarkable new Marschallin had arrived among us. She sang the Marschallin in Munich last year, and will bring her portrayal to the Metropolitan Opera for the first time on Jan. 20.

title: Iowa Turns Its Presidential Caucuses Into a Cash Cow, and Milks Furiously

title: And the Nominees Are . . .
description: In 30 years of making music, the group Santana has never received a Grammy Award for its work. That seems likely to change this year.

title: Another Term for Mr. Greenspan
description: Most economists believe Alan Greenspan is more responsible for the economy's spectacular performance than Congress, Presidents Bush and Clinton or any other identifiable factor. Under his leadership the Federal Reserve Board has driven inflation and unemployment down to 30-year lows. Mr. Greenspan is widely regarded as one of the most successful chairmen in the history of the Fed. Yesterday President Clinton wisely nominated him to a fourth term, ending disruptive speculation that he might decide to appoint someone else.

title: Low Pay and Retirements Aggravate Teacher Shortage
description: Rita R. Josephson, a 34-year veteran of the New York City public school system, might have worked at least seven more years as a gym teacher at her school in Douglaston, Queens, if the pay was better. But she says the prospect of longer hours and possibly a longer school year without a pay increase has forced her to consider early retirement.

title: A Cancer Test Surpasses the Pap One, Studies Find
description: Two studies being published today in the Journal of the American Medical Association show that a newer laboratory test is better than the old standby Pap test at detecting cervical cancer and precancerous changes in women over 40.

title: Pro-Western Opposition Defeats Croatia's Ruling Nationalists
description: Croatia's center-left opposition won a sweeping victory in parliamentary elections on Monday, official results indicated today. The elections delivered a rebuke to the governing party and opens up the prospect of much warmer ties with the West.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOTTSEGEN, KATHERINE MARK HAFNER
description: GOTTSEGEN - Katherine Mark Hafner. Died peacefully January 3, 2000 in NYC, age 82. Beloved wife of the late Irving, her husband of 54 years. She was born November 14, 1917 in Brooklyn and lived most of her life in Bedford Hills, NY. She was a partner at Tobe Associates in Manhattan for many years and since the mid-1970's worked at The Katonah Museum of Art in Katonah, NY, and as a voluteer for the American Cancer Society, among other organizations. Katherine was a generous, vital life force and a friend to many people, all of whom will miss her. She is survived by her sister, Marylin, of Cambridge, Mass; her sons, Mark David of Climax, N.C. and Matthew Charles of Manhattan; their wives, Emilie and Susan; and her grandchildren, Katherine, Samuel, and Sarah. A memorial service will be held at a later date. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made in her name to the American Cancer Society, The Katonah Museum of Art, The Fashion Institute of Technology in NYC, or to any other charity.

title: Sports of The Times; Flashy Warrick Scores 20 Points of Light
description: EVER since that fateful afternoon last September when he soiled a stellar reputation, Peter Warrick has tried to live down the humiliation of a felony count of grand theft that was reduced to a misdemeanor count. Warrick became the latest poster boy for the evils of big-time college sports and triggered debates that were so intense that the deeds that elevated him to prominence were obliterated.

title: At Home, Even if Only From Afar
description: I have three business trips looming in the next five weeks. In addition to the usual arrangements -- plane reservations, hotel reservations, car rental, driving directions -- I find myself worrying about one thing more: Will there be access to a fax machine at about 5 o'clock Eastern Standard Time, so my third grader can fax me his homework?

title: First Listen, Then Teach
description: In high school, I wanted to be a history teacher. My favorite teacher, Mr. Batchelder, had us read the Federalist papers and newspaper articles from the 1780's, not some boring textbook. He made history come alive.

title: Attacks on Encryption Code Raise Questions About Computer Vulnerability
description: Members of the computer security industry -- the folks who keep credit card numbers safe from prying eyes on the Internet, among other things -- can be a contentious bunch. title: FORD LOOKS HARDER AT DAEWOO
description: The competition intensified between the General Motors Corporation and the Ford Motor Company over which automaker will get the Daewoo Motor Company, an affiliate of the ailing conglomerate Daewoo Group. Ford said its top Asia executive and a newly hired former Daewoo official would meet this week with representatives of the Korea Development Bank, the main creditor of Daewoo Motor, as part of its assessment of the South Korean automaker, which owes about $16.4 billion. G.M. has announced that it wants to buy Daewoo Motor.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: SPECIALTY FOODS CORP., Deerfield, Ill., the third-largest cookie manufacturer in the nation, has agreed to buy Lew-Mark Baking Co., Perry, N.Y. Terms of the transaction were not disclosed.

title: Money Games in the Senate Race
description: It is a reality of modern campaigns that contests for important offices often become struggles for publicity, and candidates are driven to find ways to use their existing public positions to increase their favorable exposure to voters. So there was nothing particularly surprising, or for that matter offensive, about Mayor Rudolph Giuliani's high profile during the televised New Year's Eve festivities in Times Square, or about the White House's decision to have Hillary Rodham Clinton join President Clinton in delivering a televised greeting to the nation from the Oval Office on New Year's Day.

title: JOHN HANCOCK BUYS BELGIAN-DUTCH FINANCIAL COMPANY
description: The Belgian-Dutch financial company Fortis A.G. said yesterday that it would sell its long-term care insurance business to the John Hancock Mutual Life Insurance Company of Boston. Financial terms were not disclosed. Fortis, based in Amsterdam and Brussels, said the long-term business had $90 million in earned premiums in the first nine months of 1999. The integration with John Hancock will take up to 18 months, Fortis said. Fortis products will continue to be sold through the same brokerage firm that sold them before the deal. John Hancock, which is expected to start trading as a public company later this year, had total assets of $123.4 billion as of Sept. 30.

title: Land Rover Puts Account in Review
description: Land Rover North America in Lanham, Md., part of BMW A.G., said yesterday that it had placed the creative part of its account in review. Billings were estimated at $30 million.

title: Concerns About Guns Put New Pressure on State Legislators
description: With a succession of mass shootings as a backdrop and the November elections ahead, political wrangling over gun control has emerged in many states as lawmakers gather this week for the start of the 2000 legislative sessions.

title: Ecuador's Currency Falls as the Government Examines Its Options
description: Ecuador's volatile currency, the sucre, tumbled more than 10 percent today on concerns that President Jamil Mahuad's government is failing to take steps to defend the currency as the economy rapidly deteriorates.

title: Lijiang Journal; A Dying Culture, as Seen Through Aging Eyes
description: The two old men live in a small research center in this stunning mountain town, translating religious scriptures of their minority culture from a pictographic script that almost nobody else can fully decipher anymore.

title: Jets Are on a Losing Streak: 2 Coaches in 2 Days
description: One day after he was named to succeed Bill Parcells as the Jets' head coach, Bill Belichick made a sudden reversal today and resigned instead. Belichick informed the team of his decision only minutes before a news conference intended to introduce him as the new coach.

title: Securities Dealers Group Approves Plan to Sell Nasdaq Stake

Commerce One will issue 870,000 shares and pay about $10 million in cash. Mergent, which is based in Mountain View, Calif., and is closely held, makes software to compile and search product information. Commerce One, based in Walnut Creek, Calif., will use Mergent's technology to manage catalogs from thousands of suppliers on Web sites.

title: Reckonings; A Leap in the Dark
description: Economists have a rather Zen-like view of stocks. They believe that investors are rational, and that stock prices are therefore unpredictable. It sounds peculiar, but the logic is ironclad. Rational investors would take into account everything they know -- all the information available about where profits, interest rates, technology and so on are going -- when buying or selling stock. So stock prices would already reflect all available knowledge, and would change only when new information came in. And new information is, by definition, unpredictable -- otherwise it wouldn't be new -- which means that changes in stock prices would be unpredictable too. Q.E.D.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BERGEN, KATRINA
description: BERGEN-Katrina., of London and Menorca, Spain, who had also been a resident of Manhattan and West Cornwall, CT for many years, died December 22 in Ft. Pierce, FL, where she had arrived to vacation with her family. A memorial service was held at St. Mark's Church in Ft. Pierce. Born in Berlin to a family of printers and publishers, Katrina emigrated to New York from Paris in 1941 with her husband, the late Dr. Otto Bergen, and her young son, Thomas. An active volunteer and fund-raiser for French-American charitable organizations in New York, she was also a director and long-time member of the American Women's Club of London and the American chapter of the Royal National Lifeboat Institute. Memories of our marvelous adventures together will be held always by her beloved Guy Foster, her children, Dr. Thomas Marill and Josephine Marie-Christine David, her grandchildren, Christine, Alexandra and Edward David and Nina and Anthony Marill and her greatgrandson Nikolas Marill-Fakuda. Burial will be at Oak Lawn Cemetery in Fairfield, CT. In lieu of flowers, memorial contributions can be made to The Brearley School, 610 E. 83rd St., New York, NY

title: FREEMARKETS TO LOSE GENERAL MOTORS AS CLIENT
description: Shares of Freemarkets Inc. plunged yesterday after reports circulated that a client, the General Motors Corporation, was switching to another online auction service. Freemarkets' chief executive, Glen Meakem, said the loss of G.M.'s business to Commerce One Inc. should not affect its performance in 2000. But the company's stock fell $63.375 a share, to $279, in Nasdaq trading. Freemarkets' initial public offering of $48 a share in December was one of the most successful of 1999. David Garrity, an analyst for Dresdner Kleinwort Benson, said in a research note Monday that Freemarkets would probably lose the G.M. account. Commerce One's shares rose $14.875, to $218.50, in Nasdaq trading yesterday.

description: France's second-largest carmaker, Renault, said it was in talks to acquire all or part of Samsung Motors Inc. as it seeks to expand its alliance with the Nissan Motor Company across Asia. Samsung Motors is the smallest of South Korea's automakers, capable of producing 180,000 cars a year.

title: ANGLO AMERICAN BUYS ZIMBABWE MINE

With the acquisition, Anglo, the world's largest mining company, will control all of Zimbabwe's ferrochrome production and a significant part of the country's platinum output. Anglo owns slightly more than 50 percent of the world's biggest platinum producer, the Anglo American Platinum Corporation, and 40 percent of the world's biggest ferrochrome producer, Samancor Ltd.

description: President Clinton nominated Alan Greenspan today to a fourth four-year term as chairman of the Federal Reserve, insuring that a familiar hand will continue steering the economy even as a new administration takes office next year.

title: Cox Buys Hawaii Stations

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROWLEY, LOUIS N. JR
description: ROWLEY-Louis N. Jr. The Board of Trustees, President David Chang, Chancellor George Bugliarello, the Faculty, Alumni, Staff and Students of Polytechnic University note with profound regret the passing of Louis N. Rowley, Jr., a 1931 graduate in mechanical engineering and 1976 Honorary Doctorate recipient, who served his alma mater proudly, generously and wisely as former chairman of the Board of Trustees, former president of the Alumni Association and trustee for more than 40 years. In 1973, as board chairman, he presided over the merger of the New York School of Engineering and Science into the Polytechnic Institute of Brooklyn, now Polytechnic University. His commitment and success in the field of mechanical engineering is evidenced in his service as former president of the American Society of Mechanical Engineers, recipient of Polytechnic's 1963 Distinguished Alumnus Award and his work at McGraw-Hill Publcations, where he was editorial chairman of ''Power'' and ''Electrical World'' magazines. The Polytechnic community expresses its heartfelt condolences to his family and friends.

title: A Year When Pop Genres Took Turns in the Limelight
description: The pop charts last year were a game of rock, scissors, paper. Three very different forces were at work, each one briefly supplanting the other. There was the rock of rap-metal bands like Limp Bizkit and Kid Rock; the sharp, angular minimalist hip-hop that emerged from the South with J T Money and Juvenile; and the paper was the lightweight pop of the Backstreet Boys, 'N Sync, Britney Spears and Ricky Martin. Rock smashed scissors, paper smothered rock, scissors cut paper.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LIPPMANN, ZILLA
description: LIPPMANN-Zilla. The New Dramatists Community of Playwrights, Board members, staff and friends deeply mourn the passing of our President Emerita, Zilla Lippmann on December 27, 1999. Zilla was our guiding spirit over three generations. Through the John Golden Fund, named for her beloved uncle and mentor, Zilla fostered the support and production of new American playwrights in New York. She made possible the purchase of New Dramatists' beautiful home on West 44 Street, a mecca for playwrights from around the world, giving hope and inspiration to hundreds of theatre artists. She was a writer's champion for much of the 20th century. We will miss her always. Our heartfelt condolences to her daughter, Jill Allgauer, and to her grandchildren Sarah, Dina and Jorg, and to her friends and colleagues everywhere, and to her fellow Board members of the John Golden Fund. New Dramatists will host a memorial service for Zilla on Wednesday, January 19th at 5PM. In lieu of flowers, contributions in Zilla's memory may be sent to New Dramatists, 424 W. 44 St, N.Y., N.Y. 10036.

title: On Closing the Gap In School Spending
description: FOR nearly 30 years, state courts have ordered more equitable spending between school districts. Yet this within-state focus has meant that an even greater inequality has been ignored: the difference in education expenditure between rich and poor states. New Jersey, for example, spends two and a half times as much per pupil as Mississippi. In general, even after within-state spending has been equalized, poor districts in rich states spend much more than rich districts in poor states.

title: CROSS TIMBERS CANCELS ITS PUBLIC OFFERING FOR TRUST
description: The Cross Timbers Oil Company said yesterday that it had canceled a public offering for its Texas Permian Royalty Trust because energy stocks are depressed. The company will instead sell the oil and natural gas fields in Texas and New Mexico that it had intended to include in the trust. Bids for the fields will be accepted next month, and Cross Timbers expects to complete the sale by the end of March. Daily production for the fields averages 15 million cubic feet of gas and 1,050 barrels of oil.

The gamble paid off in every way for the network, first with 24 hours of coverage that mostly lived up to ABC's expectations, then with ratings that proved that millennial viewers believed ABC was the place to be. A band shell sits on its main square, and families walk to the theater on weekday nights. Guantanameros attribute their cultural life in part to the work of Elfriede Mahler, an American dancer who arrived in Havana in the summer of 1960.

title: PINNACLE PLANS TO BUY TELECOMMUNICATIONS TOWERS
description: Pinnacle Holdings Inc., which leases space on telecommunications towers in the southeastern United States, agreed to buy 329 tower and rooftop-based sites for $95 million. Pinnacle is buying the sites, which are situated throughout the United States, in 29 separate transactions. In another move, the company and several shareholders filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission their intention to sell eight million shares valued at about $302 million. The acquisitions are the latest in a series of purchases made since Pinnacle went public in February and bring the total number of sites that it owns or manages to 3,850. It leases space to wireless communications companies. Pinnacle's shares fell $2.28125, to $37, in Nasdaq trading.

title: FELCOR LODGING EXPANDS ITS STOCK BUYBACK PROGRAM
description: FelCor Lodging Trust Inc. said yesterday that it expanded its stock buyback program by $200 million. The hotel and real estate investment trust, based in Irving, Tex., said that the increase came after the repurchase of about 5.8 million common shares for about $98.4 million. FelCor's announcement prompted a downgrade of its senior unsecured debt to Ba2 from Ba1 by Moody's Investors Service. Moody's said that the additional stock repurchases -- to be financed primarily with debt -- would result in a ''weakened credit profile.'' The company has about 65.9 million shares outstanding shares. FelCor owns 188 hotels in 35 states and Canada. They include the Embassy Suites, Crowne Plaza, Holiday Inn, Doubletree, Sheraton and Westin chains.

title: MARKS & SPENCER SPECULATION

Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette, reviewing opportunities at Marks & Spencer for the investor Philip Green, made informal contact with Mr. Leighton, the head of Wal-Mart's European operations, the newspaper said, without disclosing sources. Mr. Green, who bought the British retailer Sears P.L.C. a year ago, said in December that he was considering an offer for Marks & Spencer.

Moreover, by setting a Jan. 14 return date, the immigration service allowed Elian's American relatives time to test the ruling in court.

Mrs. Booss is survived by a daughter Claire Booss of Brooklyn, a son Dr. John Booss of Bethany, CT., and two grandchildren, Christine and Daniel Booss. She was predeceased by two sisters Edith Gaukrodger and Dorothy Rodger. A memorial service is planned for a future date in Brooklyn. Donations in her memory may be made to Spanish Refugee Aid, 122 East 42nd St, NY, New York 10168. For information West Haven Funeral Home at the Green, West Haven, CT.

title: Croatian Victors Fret About What Awaits Them
description: In the midst of the euphoria and high expectations following their convincing victory in parliamentary elections on Monday, leaders of Croatia's democratic opposition are growing concerned about when they will be able to take power and what they will find when they do so.

title: Two Musicals, One Source: Is It a Duel?; Shrugging, Producers Say The Shows Must Go On
description: So is that ''The Wild Party'' featuring Mandy Patinkin or ''The Wild Party'' featuring Taye Diggs? ''The Wild Party'' written by Andrew Lippa or the one by Michael John LaChiusa and George C. Wolfe? ''The Wild Party'' produced by Manhattan Theater Club that opens off Broadway on Feb. 24 or ''The Wild Party'' presented by the New York Shakespeare Festival/Joseph Papp Public Theater and several commercial producers that opens on Broadway on April 6?

title: In No Hurry, Israel-Syria Talks Edge Toward Specifics
description: On the third day of talks, Israeli and Syrian officials today slowly began tackling specific questions of how they might normalize relations.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: BASEBALL

title: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
description: THE YEN SLIDES. The dollar rose against the yen as traders avoided selling dollars on speculation that Japan's central bank might soon sell yen again. In New York, the dollar settled at 104.35 yen, up from 103.28 on Tuesday.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  OTTAWAY, JAMES HALLER SR.
description: OTTAWAY-James Haller Sr.. The trustees and administration of Bard College mourn the passing James Ottaway, Sr., a distinguished and active member of the Hudson Valley community and father of Bard College trustee James H. Ottaway, Jr. His deep commitments to journalism and to civic duty are evident throughout the region, and his generosity and kindness will be remembered and cherished far into the future. We send our deepest condolences to his wife, Ruth Blackburne Ottaway, his daughter Ruth Ottaway Sherer, his sons James H. Ottaway Jr. and David Blackburne Ottaway and the rest of his family. Leon Botstein, President David E. Schwab II, Chairman, Board of Trustees
