description: To the Editor:

title: Worthy of the Fanciest of Bows
description: Silk ribbons, velvet and chiffon ribbons, fake fur ribbons, pleated ribbons and ribbons sewn into flowers, buds and leaves. Ribbon fanciers, rejoice. On Tuesday, Mokuba, a Japanese ribbon manufacturer, is opening its first American retail store, with 43,000 items in stock. In 1954, Shoichi Watanabe, Mokuba's founder, then a 21-year old Kyoto ribbon merchant, saw a collection of 19th-century French ribbons. They fueled his passion. In 1985, his daughter, Keiko Watanabe, took over the company, which has shops in Tokyo, Paris, Toronto and Barcelona. Prices for ribbons start at 35 cents a yard and go up to $58. They're used for home furnishings (think valances, pillows and slipcovers) as well as for dresses. Mokuba is at 55 West 39th Street; (212) 869-8900.

title: Chechen Rebels Fiercely Attack Russian Forces
description: Encircled by Russian forces and subjected to constant bombardment, Chechen rebels in Grozny have begun to lash back, forcing furious firefights on the outskirts of the city.

title: The Neediest Cases; Helping a Refugee Along the Long Road to Citizenship
description: Liza Pasternak, 71, survived the Holocaust and decades of anti-Semitic harassment by the Soviet government by never losing the hope that someday she would escape to America and become a citizen here.

title: Levine, Ex-Deputy Mayor, Is Named Yankee President
description: The Yankees formally announced yesterday that Randy L. Levine, who left his post as a deputy New York City mayor this week, has been hired as the club president. Levine, once a member of baseball's Players Relations Committee, management's labor relations unit, has known George Steinbrenner for years, and he joins the Yankees without any specific responsibilities.

title: U.S. SAYS IT AGREES TO RETURN BOY, 6, TO FATHER IN CUBA
description: Hoping to end an emotional diplomatic and political battle over a 6-year-old Cuban boy who survived the capsizing of a refugee boat, the Clinton administration decided today that the youngster should be sent back to his father in Cuba.

title: Political News Site on Net Turns Its Clock Back to 1900
description: Political News Site on Net Turns Its Clock Back to 1900

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: Williams, Leg Weak, Delays His Return
description: This was the day when Jayson Williams was supposed to rush into the Champion Center and add heart, fire, spirit and humor to the resurgent Nets and their push toward a .500 record. For the past several months, the Nets and Williams, who has been on the sideline since breaking his right leg last April 1, had looked forward to his return in the first week of January.

title: Syracuse Is Perfect, With an Asterisk
description: It was difficult to know what to make of the Syracuse men's basketball team so far this season. The Orangemen were 9-0 and ranked seventh in the nation -- a highly touted and deeply experienced team -- entering tonight's Big East Conference opener against Rutgers, but for several weeks they were followed by snickers about their absurd schedule.

title: New Broadway Tryout Town: The QE2
description: In terms of sheer mileage, it may turn out to be the longest out-of-town run ever. Beginning in May the Cunard Line plans to present new musicals on its flagship, the Queen Elizabeth 2, with the goal of eventually transferring those productions to commercial runs in New York.

title: For Doomsday Hoarders, What Now?
description: IN the 1950's, a small cult led by a suburban housewife believed that on a given day, a flood would wipe out all mankind, but for a few true followers who would be spared. In preparation, many sold their homes and possessions or quit their jobs. When the world didn't end as predicted, members of the sect still rejoiced: obviously the world had been saved to reward their faith.

title: INSIDE
description: A Departing Chancellor

title: Vacuum Cleaner Will Convince Your Dog the Aliens Have Landed
description: Come spring, vacuuming the house may suddenly become fun. You'll be able to eat bonbons while a rotund little robot does the work. In April, James Dyson, an industrial designer in Chippenham, England, will introduce his robotic vacuum cleaner, the DC06, to the international market, including the United States. The round robot, at 14 inches in diameter and 20 pounds, starts cleaning at the perimeter of a room, then spirals inward. It is equipped with 55 sensors to help it go around furniture and avoid stairs.

title: Let Them In, to Work
description: To the Editor:

title: Bugs in the Bug Fixer
description: To the Editor:

title: Political News Site on Net Turns Its Clock Back to 1900
description: The conventional reactions to the Year 2000 problem were fear and optimism. The staff at Evote.com, a political news site, took a third approach: parody. Pretending that the two-digit debacle had taken place, it turned back the clock on the Web site to Jan. 1, 1900. Instead of being greeted with articles about Al Gore and George W. Bush, viewers found articles about President William McKinley, women's suffrage and a young Senator Strom Thurmond.

title: The Comeback Curmudgeon? Parcells Says No
description: Bill Parcells said yesterday that he would not return as the Jets' coach, even though Bill Belichick suddenly quit Tuesday, just one day after being named Parcells's successor.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  EDWARDS, RICHARD S.
description: EDWARDS-Richard S.. On January 4th, loving father of Richard, Dorothy Shaw, Judith Berg, and Steven. Grandfather of ten. Visitation Thursday 2-5 and 7-9 P.M. at Dimiceli & Sons Funeral Home, 182 Lexington Av, NYC. Interment Fri. Calverton National Cemetery.

title: Graves Gives Rangers a Hint of Hope
description: An overtime goal by Adam Graves gave the Rangers a 3-2 victory over the Toronto Maple Leafs last night at Madison Square Garden, ending the Rangers' seven-game streak without a victory, offering their jubilant fans hope for better things in the second half of the season and showing the world what hockey can be like when the coaches let players have fun.

title: An Auteur Is Born, Via iMac
description: OPENING Scene: Interior. Zoom in on a man sitting alone at a personal computer in a heavily fortified, well provisioned bunker, surfing the Internet, browsing for recipes that call for lots of canned tuna and peanut butter.

title: Those Dominant Yankees Fight for a Domain Name
description: The fight over an Internet address for the New York Yankees, depending on whom you talk to, is either the story of a giant sports franchise seeking to crush a hapless fan or one of an unprincipled ''cybersquatter'' hoping to cash in on the team's popularity.

title: ECUADOR RULES OUT FREEZE
description: Facing rising pressure to act to halt the collapse of the nation's currency, the sucre, which lost 67 percent of its value against the dollar in 1999 and has fallen 15 percent this week, Ecuador's government said it had decided not to fix the exchange rate to the dollar or to freeze bank accounts and would continue the current system of letting the currency float at market value. Ecuador's economy contracted 7 percent last year, and inflation exceeded 60 percent. Larry Rohter

title: Visions of Greener Pastures Reinvent the Lower East Side
description: TENEMENTS, yes. Luxury housing? It's not what leaps to mind about the Lower East Side.

title: Journey to Amerzone: Keep Your Ears Open
description: PLAYING Amerzone is like watching a silent movie: you appreciate its expressiveness, but you can't help thinking how far the medium has progressed since the early days. With CD-ROM's, early days means 1994, the heyday of the point-and-click adventure epitomized by Myst.

title: Settling the Attica Case
description: The proposed $8 million settlement of the class-action lawsuit arising from the 1971 Attica prison uprising may at last close a shameful chapter of New York State history. The lawsuit was filed more than 25 years ago on behalf of 1,281 inmates who were at Attica during the riots. Those who can be located will have a chance to comment on the fairness of the settlement before a federal court approves it. Lawyers for the inmates would receive $4 million separately in fees.

title: Murphy Leads Irish In Upset Of UConn
description: Most of tonight's Big East opener between Notre Dame and Connecticut was a head-to-head battle between the leading scorers for both teams -- the 6-foot-10-inch Troy Murphy and the 5-10 Khalid El-Amin. The UConn guard won that battle, outscoring Murphy by 34 points to 33 points. But Notre Dame won the game, 75-70, stunning the defending, second-ranked national champions.

title: HOUSE PROUD; Fixing Up An Adobe Hacienda Manana
description: During our fourth year of spending time in the Mexican mountain town of San Miguel de Allende, I and my wife, the artist and photographer Masako Takahashi, were taken to see a derelict house with an interior courtyard, a stable and a small attached house. Ravished by the possibilities, but daunted by the house's condition and its price ($65,000), we nonetheless took the plunge. With five years of worktime, we came to understand that this house in fact completed us as much as we completed it.

title: Crime Kindles Rights Debate In South Africa
description: Angered by several bombings in Cape Town and frustrated by the difficulties in solving such cases, South Africa is considering constitutional changes that would curb the rights of suspected terrorists.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ALLEN, ROSA LEE
description: ALLEN-Rosa Lee. December 31, 1999. Survived by by her daughter Elaine, son-in-law Elbert Hines, grandchildren Kendall, Mark, Kelly and loving family.

title: Croatia's Democratic Message
description: The stinging electoral defeat inflicted on Croatia's ruling party this week is encouraging news for the entire Balkan region, especially if it is followed by the election of a reform-minded president in separate votes later this month.

title: Japan's Investors Become Bullish On Merrill Lynch; Focus on the Personal Touch
description: The ''ginza,'' or shopping street, of this quintessential Japanese town on the island of Shikoku looks much like the ginza of any other moderately sized city here.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HUREWITZ, HELEN (NADELMAN)
description: HUREWITZ-Helen (Nadelman). On January 5, 2000. Beloved wife of the late Dr. Morton. Devoted mother of Michael and Adam. Cherished grandmother of Vanessa and Stephanie. Services Friday 10 AM, ''Gutterman's Inc.,'', 175 Long Beach Road, Rockville Centre, Long Island.

title: Capitol Hill Memo; Dueling Agendas Herald Fight for Control of Congress
description: The battle for control of Congress officially began today.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''This little boy, who has been through so much, belongs with his father.''

title: 20 Teams Are After a Title First Contested by Only 2
description: When the contest for the Venice Trophy begins on Sunday in Bermuda, 20 teams will take part, including two from the United States. They will be among the favorites, together with China and six from Europe: Britain, Austria, France, Netherlands, Germany and Denmark. The other participants are Argentina, Australia, Bermuda, Brazil, Canada, Colombia, Egypt, Hong Kong, India, Indonesia and New Zealand. Note the surprising shortage of countries in arrears alphabetically.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HELLER, MORTIMER
description: HELLER-Mortimer. Formerly of Northport, NY. Died in Seattle, WA on January 4, 2000. He is survived by his wife Gayle in Seattle, WA; son David Heller, Sea Cliff, NY and daughters Lanie Liepow, Cherry Hill, NJ, Debra Heller, Millheim, PA, Sharen Leibowitz, West Windsor, NJ and Lauren Heller of Sea Cliff, NY; sister Tauby Shimkin of Urbana, IL., and six grandchildren. Services will be held at WhiteVoltz Funeral Home, 364 East Main Street, Bay Shore, New York at 1 P.M., on Friday, January 7.

title: School Board Hires Veteran Political Adviser
description: The Board of Education, struggling to assert itself in a time of transition between chancellors, disclosed yesterday that it had hired a veteran political adviser to help with planning and policy development.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  O'KEEFE, ROBERT
description: O'KEEFE-Robert. A memorial service will be held at 5PM Friday, January 7 at the Blarney Cove, 510 East 14 St., for Robert and Lee O'Keefe. Robert, 66, died on December 31 in his apartment in Stuyvesant Town. His wife Lee died June 13. Robert, a graduate of Georgetown University, worked for the Child Welfare Bureau of the City of New York.

title: Michelin Has Awarded Its Marketing Account
description: Michelin North America in Greenville, S.C., said yesterday that it has awarded its first relationship marketing account, covering duties like direct marketing, database marketing and retail partnerships, to the Chicago office of Lowe Lintas & Partners Worldwide, part of the Lowe Group unit of the Interpublic Group of Companies. Billings have not been determined.

title: PEROT SYSTEMS SELLS STAKE IN SWISS SOFTWARE COMPANY
description: The Perot Systems Corporation, the computer services company founded by the billionaire Ross Perot, plans to sell its 40 percent stake in Systor A.G. for about $55 million to UBS A.G. of Zurich. UBS, which is Europe's No. 2 bank, already owns 60 percent of Systor. Perot Systems, of Dallas, expects to gain $40 million from the sale of its stake in Systor, a Swiss-based software maker. The sale enables Perot Systems to pursue plans to extend its presence with Internet-based businesses and invest in electronic-business ventures, said Mr. Perot, the company's chairman. Mr. Perot said in May the company planned to invest in technology start-ups.

title: Luongo Quickly Gets Back On the Ice
description: The lights were still dimmed at Nassau Coliseum this morning when Roberto Luongo skated onto the ice, a little more than 12 hours after the final goal had whizzed past his glove in the Islanders' 7-3 loss to Boston.

title: Music to Download By
description: To the Editor:

title: In America; The Comfort Zone
description: On July 8, 1984, police officers in Albany invaded the apartment of a 35-year-old mentally ill man named Jessie Davis. The officers were responding to a report of a disturbance at the third-floor apartment on Clinton Avenue in the city's predominantly black Arbor Hill neighborhood.

title: Soon: Computers That Know You Hate Them
description: WHEN it comes to emotions, computers are about as warm and understanding as, well, a pile of plastic, silicon, glass and metal. But if a gadget sitting in an office at I.B.M.'s Almaden Research Center in San Jose, Calif., ever makes it to the assembly line, people may develop a new, warm relationship with their electronic companions.

title: Exhibitions, Tours, Talks and Workshops
description: An Architect's Designs

title: The State of New York State
description: Gov. George Pataki, offering an intriguing wish list in his State of the State address yesterday, focused on public education, the environment and boosting the lagging upstate economy. The New York governor's opening proposal on education shifts attention to a hot political topic that has seldom appeared high on his priority list. While the tendency is to see this speech as a semaphore signal to Gov. George W. Bush of Texas to consider Mr. Pataki as a running mate, the worth of some of these proposals makes such assessments secondary, especially if Mr. Pataki follows through.

title: McCain Team Goes the Distance for Enough Signatures in Enough Places
description: With 36 hours to go before the deadline for filing petitions to get presidential candidates on the primary ballot in New York State, the tallies plastered on the walls of John McCain's local headquarters told a grim tale: the Arizona senator, it seemed, would fail to collect enough signatures to be listed in more than half of the state's 31 Congressional districts.

title: Mandalay Forecasts a Fall
description: Mandalay Resort Group, which owns and operates casinos in Nevada, said late today that it expected to report fourth-quarter earnings that are less than the 16 cents a share it earned last year. The company's earnings projection is also below the average estimate of 25 cents a diluted share among 19 analysts surveyed by First Call/Thomson Financial. Mandalay said that customer volumes in Las Vegas were below expectations ''as negative Year 2000 media reports discouraged the public's travel plans.''

title: Spending Cap In Campaigns Gains Support In Connecticut
description: Reacting to a scandal that has prompted much soul-searching about the effect of big money on politics, two top Democratic legislators proposed changes today that would, if adopted, give Connecticut the most restrictive campaign finance laws in the nation.

title: Leading Financial Services Companies Form Lobbying Group
description: Now that the banking, securities and insurance industries have finally stopped battling over how to change Depression-era laws that separated their businesses, they are going to give cooperation a chance.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HEITNER, EMANUEL
description: HEITNER-Emanuel. After 97 joyful years. Husband of the late Rose Smolin Heitner; and survived by his son and daughter-in-law, Michael and Susan Heitner of Brooklyn, N.Y., and by his grandson Samuel Kip Heitner and his wife Vanessa Guibert Heitner of Arlington, VA. Following a happy boyhood on the streets of Brooklyn and graduation from Boys High School, Manny Heitner later became owner and chief executive of Gotham Carpet Corp and was prominent in the decorator floor covering industry in New York City for many years. He was truly devoted to and beloved by his family, friends and associates.

title: BIOTECHNOLOGY COMPANY SELLS GENOMICS CENTER STAKE
description: Ariad Pharmaceuticals Inc. sold its stake in the Hoechst-Ariad Genomics Center to Aventis S.A. in exchange for rights to drugs and technologies developed by the center and $40 million in cash. Shares in Ariad, a biotechnology company, rose 75 cents, to close at $3.75 in Nasdaq trading. Ariad, based in Cambridge, Mass., said in October it would sell its 50 percent stake in the center. Completion of the agreement was announced on Tuesday. Ariad founded the center with Hoechst A.G., which later merged with Rhone-Poulenc S.A. to form Aventis. Ariad said it sold its stake to focus on its own products.

title: CHINA INTERNET POLICY
description: China may allow foreign investors into its Internet business more quickly than expected, according to the minister for the information industry, Wu Jichuan. Mr. Wu said the government would allow foreigners to take up to a 50 percent stake in Internet service providers in three cities in the first quarter of this year. He had taken a hard line against allowing foreign ownership of Internet-related companies, but in an interview in The Shanghai Daily, Mr. Wu said foreigners could own such stakes in Guangzhou, Beijing and Shanghai. Mark Landler

title: Seeking Simplicity
description: To the Editor:

title: Russians to Vote March 26 to Choose a Successor to Yeltsin
description: A truncated presidential campaign opened in Russia today, after the Parliament's upper house confirmed March 26 as the day when voters will choose a successor to Boris N. Yeltsin.

title: Rally Ends Abruptly in Asia As Stock Markets Plummet
description: Stock markets across much of Asia plummeted today, abruptly ending a post-millennium rally, as investors here reacted with alarm to Wall Street's stumble on Tuesday.

title: Ex-New Jersey Police Chief Who Ran a Corrupt Force Is Sentenced and Fined
description: The former police chief of West New York, N.J., who pursued a second career as a bribe taker and protection racketeer for decades while on the force, was sentenced today to four years in federal prison and fined $50,000.

title: Security Is Unusually Heavy for Speech
description: For 28 years, State Senator Frank Padavan has passed through the glass archway to the Capitol building to take his place for the governor's annual speech to the Legislature. But today, his way was blocked by a uniformed state police officer, who politely, but firmly, asked to see some identification.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MATSIL, IRVING
description: MATSIL-Irving. Died January 4, 2000. Beloved husband of Sherry. Devoted father of Amy Seltzer and Joelle Mehr. Adoring grandfather of Haylee, Matthew, Jonathan and Wesley. Loving brother to Roz, Milton, Reginald, Annette and Estelle. Services Thursday, January 6, 12PM at Nassau North Chapel, North Station Plaza, Great Neck. He was loved and will be greatly missed.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SALTZMAN, RENNY B.
description: SALTZMAN-Renny B.. Of New York and East Hampton, January 2, 2000. Beloved husband of Ellin. Loving father of Elizabeth and David. Devoted father-in-law of Elizabeth Doyle. Cherished grandfather of Jack and Teddy. Dear brother of Kenny. Renny died peacefully, surrounded by his family, after a heroic struggle with leukemia. In lieu of flowers please send donations to the Saltzman Leukemia Research Fund at Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center. Memorial service Thursday, January 6, 6:30pm, Solomon R. Guggenheim Museum.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MARCUS, HAROLD THEODOR
description: MARCUS-Harold Theodor. Born in Berlin, Germany; died after a brief illness in his 86th year. Beloved husband of Betty; devoted father of Nancy and Teddy; Opa to Jennifer and Jesse. Friends are welcome at the family residence as there will be no service.

title: New York Experts Taking Wider Role in Terror Inquiry
description: Attorney General Janet Reno summoned top prosecutors and law enforcement officials from New York and Seattle today to a strategy meeting on terrorism, government officials said. The move follows last month's arrest of a man trying to enter the United States from Canada carrying explosives and timers.

title: While Calling for a Positive Campaign, McCain Is Accused of Being Negative
description: Senator John McCain urged presidential candidates today to ''help turn the practice of politics toward a higher plane.'' But his own campaign was soon accused by aides to Gov. George W. Bush of practicing negative politics.

title: On the Net, It's Genghis Who? Sparse Glory for a Conqueror
description: POOR Genghis Khan. Work your way up from up tribal nomad to world's most successful warlord, conquer large parts of Asia, laying the groundwork for the largest contiguous empire ever known, even become a political byword. And what does it get you? Precious little on the Internet.

title: Corrections
description: An obituary on Tuesday about Jeshajahu Weinberg, former director of the Holocaust Memorial Museum in Washington, referred incompletely to the institution's founding leadership. Mr. Weinberg, who was also know as Shaike, served from 1989 to 1995, a period that included the museum's opening in 1993. Arthur Rosenblatt was its director from 1986 to 1988.

title: Ex-Governor of Massachusetts, Back in New York, Talks of a 2nd Statehouse
description: Is it something in the water?

title: Britain's Gun Laws
description: To the Editor:

title: Sports of The Times; Is Warrick's Nightmare Now Over?
description: NOW we know why Bobby Bowden kept Peter Warrick on the Florida State team: Warrick is a phenomenal wide receiver.

description: NEWS

title: Technology May Ease Air Traffic Choke Points
description: IT is so congested at airports these days that planes coming from the West Coast to New York often start lining up around Chicago.

title: In China's Legal Evolution, The Lawyers Are Handcuffed
description: Liu Jian was an idealistic new lawyer when his Nanjing firm sent him to a rural town 200 miles away to represent a local official accused of taking bribes.

title: Family Disputes, Global Politics; New York Custody Case Shows Fine Line Parents And Judges Must Walk
description: As one round in the angry tug of war over a young Cuban boy ended yesterday with a decision to send him back to his father, another international custody battle was being waged in Federal District Court in Manhattan.

title: McCain Urged F.C.C. Action On Issue Involving Supporter
description: Senator John McCain, who has made fixing the corrosive influence of money in politics the cornerstone of his campaign, twice demanded in recent weeks that a regulatory agency take action in a matter that ultimately benefited a major contributor to his presidential campaign.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FULLER, ROBERT GARFIELD
description: FULLER-Robert Garfield. Of West Palm Beach, FL, aged 95, on December 31, 1999, following a brief illness. Devoted husband of the late Gwendolen Sherwood Ferrey, dear father of Robert Ferrey Fuller and the late Daphne Sherwood Fuller, beloved grandfather of Julie Fuller Thornton and Gordon McIntosh Fuller, greatgrandfather of Robert and Sarah McIntire and of Zachary, Andrew and Matthew Fuller. Born in Minneapolis, he was graduated from the University of Minnesota in 1923 and in 1925 from Harvard Business School, where he was a Baker Scholar. Following graduation he joined First National Bank of New York and remained with that bank and its successor, First National City Bank, until his retirement in 1966 as a Senior Vice President. He was associated from 1941 until 1968 with the Delaware, Lackawanna & Western RR Co. (later the Erie Lackawanna RR Co.) as a director, as a member and then chairman of its executive committee, and as chairman of the board. In 1968 and 1969, he was a director and chairman of the voting trustees of the former REA Express. At various times, he served on the executive committees of the boards of Seaboard Surety Co. and Metal & Thermit Corp. and as a director of American Sugar Co., Discount Corporation of NY and other companies. For many years a member of The Riverside Church (NY), he served it as president of its board of trustees and in other capacities, and had also served as a trustee and on the finance committee of the Ministers & Missionaries Benefit Board of the American Baptist Convention and as a director of the United Negro College Fund. A former resident of Scarsdale, NY, Lost Tree Village, FL and Greenwich, CT, he had been president of the Lost Tree Club, a 50-year member of the Scarsdale Golf Club and active in community affairs. At his death he was a member of The Everglades Club and The Beach Club (Palm Beach), the Lost Tree Club (North Palm Beach) and The Harvard Club of New York City. He was a member of Phi Beta Kappa and Psi Upsilon, and had been awarded the Gold Medal of the University of Minnesota. Funeral services were held on January 4, 2000 at Royal Poinciana Chapel, Palm Beach, FL. A memorial service is planned for a later date in Greenwich, CT, as is private burial in Scarsdale, NY. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made in his name to First Presbyterian Church, 18 Lafayette Place, Greenwich, CT 06830.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BUTSON, THOMAS G.
description: BUTSON-Thomas G.. The entire Beth Israel Medical Center family acknowledges with sadness the passing of Thomas G. Butson, former editor at the New York Times, owner and editor of The Villager newspaper, and beloved husband of our dear friend, Elizabeth. To the entire Butson family and all who loved him, our heartfelt condolences. Matthew E. Fink, M.D. President and CEO

title: Swooning Or Sober, The Waltz Is King
description: No matter what time it may have been elsewhere, it was always three-quarter time at the New York State Theater on Tuesday night. The New York City Ballet opened its winter repertory season with a program called ''Waltz Into the Millennium,'' which featured choreography based on waltzes. Why waltzes?

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BOHM, RENEE
description: BOHM-Renee. The Officers, Board of Directors, and staff of UJA-Federation of New York mourn the loss of Renee Bohm, a dedicated leader who was deeply devoted to the Jewish community. She was a cherished friend who served as a board member of our Women's Campaign in Brooklyn. We extend our sincerest condolences to her daughter and son-inlaw, Julie and Jacob Schorr; her son-in-law, Melvin Shay; her five grandchildren; and two greatgrandchildren. Judith Stern Peck, Board Chair James S. Tisch, President John S. Ruskay, Exec. VP & CEO Sandra F. Cahn, Chair, Women's Campaign

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  BELLIN, NEWTON
description: BELLIN-Newton. You are always in our hearts. We miss you. Your loving family.

title: Radio Squeezes Empty Air Space for Profit
description: Rush Limbaugh said he noticed it about two months ago. Listeners to his daily radio show were sending in e-mail messages by the thousands, asking why there were more commercials on his three-hour talk-radio program.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MORRILL, MASON
description: MORRILL-Mason. Beloved husband of the late Pauline. Devoted father of William and Dorothy. Cherished grandfather of Paul and Jonathan. Peacefully, after 98 good years. Religious service today, 12:45 P.M., ''Parkside Memorial Chapels'', Queens Boulevard (corner 66th Avenue), Forest Hills.

title: A Long-Deferred Museum in Honor of Allende
description: Sometimes a museum is also a monument, to persistence, to a dream, to the durability of an idea. Rarely is that more the case than with the Salvador Allende Museum of Solidarity, which has opened here nearly 30 years after it was conceived.

title: Cell Phones Ruin the Opera? Meet the Culprit
description: ON a bright, crisp Friday morning in November, Martin Cooper was sipping orange juice in the dining room of the Essex House hotel on Central Park South when his well-planned day fell apart.

title: INDONESIAN GROWTH OUTLOOK
description: Indonesia's economy will expand 3 to 4 percent in 2000, after growing an estimated one-tenth of 1 percent last year, the central bank said. It warned, however, that problems including banking and corporate reorganization and rising debt could derail recovery. Indonesia is emerging from financial crisis and economic recession.

title: JAPANESE VEHICLE SALES FALL
description: Domestic new vehicle sales fell 1.8 percent in December from a year earlier and 8 percent for all of 1999 as the lingering effects of Japan's recession discouraged consumer spending. Automakers sold 294,397 new cars, trucks and buses for the month and 3,987,731 vehicles in 1999, the third straight yearly decline, the Japan Automobile Dealers Association said.

The Houston-based company sells software used on mainframes and in corporate computer networks, a market where some of the greatest Year 2000 business disruptions had been feared. The profit warning surprised analysts who had expected BMC to post a solid third quarter as corporate customers bought software for installation in 2000 and used up end-of-1999 budgets. title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ALSCHULER, EMILY
description: ALSCHULER-Emily. The Officers, members and staff of The American Jewish Committee have lost a dear and cherished friend and generous supporter with the passing of Emily Alschuler. Emily was a long-time member of AJC's National Board of Governors and of her local AJC Chicago Chapter. Devoted to the pursuit of human rights for all and driven by an abiding love for the Jewish people, she served for many years as a trusted and active member of AJC's Intereligious Affairs Commission, traveling extensively on AJC missions abroad. Her tireless efforts to encourage reconciliation between Jews and Germans & to fostering positive Catholic-Jewish relations in her beloved Chicago and around the world will stand as an enduring legacy. A noble and gentle woman, her warmth, compassion and wisdom will be sorely missed. We send heartfelt condolences to her sons William and David, their wives, and her four grandchildren. Bruce M. title: Paid Notice: Deaths  VICUNA, EDUARDO SAINZ DE
description: VICUNA - Eduardo Sainz de. Eduardo Sainz de Vicuna passed away on December 9, 1999 in Madrid, after a long illness. Mr. Vicuna was born in Madrid in 1922. After schooling in Downside, England, he attended university in Oviedo, Spain, M.I.T. and Harvard, where he graduated in 1948 with an MBA. Mr. Vicuna was married to Ines Bemberg Garcia Mansilla, whose family was the founder of a large Argentine brewery. He became involved in the multiple business affairs of his family where he held relevant executive charges, both in South America and Spain. He retired in 1993. During the exercise of his multiple world-wide business activities and his great interests such as sports, art, farm managing, as well as antique and rare book collecting (he was member of the Argentine Bibliophile Association), he made many friends that now miss him. Mr. Vicuna was an active supporter of several charities. Mr. Vicuna is survived by his wife, Ines, two daughters Beatriz and Ana, two sons Alvaro and Federico and eight grandchildren.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SALPUKAS, AGIS
description: SALPUKAS-Agis., a playful, ebullient father and grandfather who will be forever missed. A philosopher and artist devoted to looking deeply and passionately at life. A journalist and historian who sought truth and clarity. He graduated from Bayside High School in Queens, NY, and worked his way through Long Island University. He completed his M.A. degree in history at Columbia University with a thesis on the German Social Democratic Party from 1930-1933. After passing his orals for a doctorate, he turned his focus toward a career in journalism at the New York Times. Starting as a news clerk in 1963, he became a metropolitan area reporter in 1966. In 1970, he joined the national staff in Detroit, where he later became bureau chief. Besides writing about the auto industry, he covered the energy crisis of the early 1970s, as well as Watergate. For his investigation into the allegations against Spiro Agnew, he received a bronze medallion from the Sigma Delta Chi journalism society. In 1976, he joined the financial staff in New York, covering the steel, transportation and energy industries in succession. Soon after, he began studying art with Vincent Capraro and John Groth. He opened a gallery, Viva Galleria, and exhibited his paintings, drawings and prints there, as well as in the Jadite Gallery of Manhattan and galleries on the southern coast of Maine. In recent years, he served on the Guild-Times Scholarship Committee. In 1963, he married Mary Carrington Raymond of Tenafly, NJ. He is survived by his wife; by his children, Stephen Carrington Salpukas of Richmond, VA, Margaret Lesser of Tenafly, NJ, and Michael Raymond Salpukas of Somerville, MA; by his grandson, Max Gabriel Lesser; son-in-law Victor Lesser and daughter-in-law Jutta Deckert. Services will be held at 10 AM Saturday, January 8, 2000 at the First Congregational Church of Christ, 276 Haworth Avenue, Haworth, New Jersey, 201-384-1063.

title: MOTOROLA COMPLETES GENERAL INSTRUMENT ACQUISITION
description: Motorola Inc. completed the $17 billion acquisition of the General Instrument Corporation yesterday after it received shareholder approval at a special meeting. In September, Motorola agreed to acquire General Instrument, the nation's largest producer of cable TV set-top boxes, in an all-stock deal that valued General Instrument at $11 billion. In the following months, Motorola's stock price appreciated 47.7 percent, which raised the value of the deal to $17 billion. Motorola, which is based in Schaumburg, Ill., has formed a Broadband Communications Sector, to be led by General Instrument's former chairman and chief executive, Edward D. Breen. Shares of Motorola closed at $134.25, down $3.9375, on the New York Stock Exchange.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RUSH, STOCKTON
description: RUSH-Stockton. Of San Francisco, a businessman, actor and entrepreneur. Died New Year's Day at the age of 69 after a brief illness. Mr. Rush was born November 15, 1930, in Philadelphia. He graduated from Princeton University in 1953 and served as a first lieutenant in the U.S. Marine Corps from 1953 to 1955. He was a board member of Stockdale Oil and Gas. In the 1970s, he and his family moved to New Zealand to create Takaro, a hunting and fishing retreat with an emphasis on conservation. As founder, chairman and executive director of the Recovery Institute, he was a leader in the field of alcoholism education. He was vice president and a longstanding member of the Bohemian Club. Mr. Rush is survived by his wife, Nancy Stewart Rush of San Francisco, and three children by his first wife, the late Ellen Davies; Deborah of PA; Catherine of CT; and Stockton Rush Jr. of Seattle, and two grandchildren. Services will be held at 11 am today at Grace Cathedral, followed by a reception at 624 Taylor Street. Donations may be made to the Recovery Institute of San Francisco, 332 Pine Street, San Francisco, CA 94108 or the James A. Baker III Institute for Public Policy, Rice University, Houston, TX.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BRYSON, DAVID BRADY
description: BRYSON-David Brady, 58, passed away peacefully Christmas morning with his family by his side. He is survived by his beloved wife Anita; son Paul, a freshman at Princeton; daughter Hallie, an attorney in San Francisco; and son Ethan, a medical student in New York City. They are eternally grateful for his guidance and support. He is also survived by parents Mary and Brady; sister Linda; and brothers John and Tim. Born August 16, 1941, he grew up in Westminster, Maryland. He graduated cum laude from Princeton University in 1963, and summa cum laude from Columbia University Law School in 1966. He clerked for California Supreme Court Chief Justice Roger Traynor and taught law at the University of Ghana. The past 29 years he was committed to securing social justice for the poor through his work at the National Housing Law Project. He was honored with the California State Bar's prestigious 1999 Loren Miller Legal Services Award, and by the National Legal Aid and Defender Association, the National Low-income Housing Coalition, and the National Tenants Organization for his tireless efforts on behalf of those less fortunate. Never a smoker, his life was cut short by lung cancer. He fought the disease with the same dignity and integrity he exhibited throughout his life. At his request, donations may be made in his memory to the National Housing Law Project, 614 Grand Avenue, Suite 320, Oakland, CA 94610.

title: Editor's Note
description: A Times article from Moscow on Dec. 16 about a Russian attack on Grozny, the capital of Chechnya, cited a report by Maria Eismont of Reuters saying that she had counted more than 100 dead Russians at the end of a three-hour battle. The Russian death toll was the largest reported for any single battle of the war in Chechnya, and in further reporting on it, The Times asked Reuters if Ms. Eismont had personally counted that many bodies.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEEDS, EVELYN
description: LEEDS-Evelyn. On January 5, 2000. Beloved mother of Joel and Arthur. Cherished grandmother of Jonathan, Jason and Kate. Loving sister of Murray and Harriet.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOLDBERG, IDA (JADZIA)
description: GOLDBERG-Ida (Jadzia). 101 years of age. Beloved wife of dearly departed Moses Goldberg. Mother of two sons, Zelig and Schmulek, who perished in Treblinka, mother of dearly departed Miriam (Goldberg) Klein, motherin-law of John Klein. Grandmother of Ruth and Fred Schwalbe. Great grandmother of Evan and Jason Schwalbe. She was one of the oldest Holocaust survivors in the world. She was a heroic, loving, unusually strong woman who was devoted to her family and friends. We will miss her very much. Funeral services at The Riverside Memorial Chapel, 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue, Friday, 10:45AM. Donations may be made in her memory to The Friends of the Israel Defense Forces.

title: TALKS END ON DAEWOO DEBT
description: The South Korean government scrapped talks with a committee representing foreign creditors of the Daewoo Group and will instead hold debt-buyout negotiations with overseas lenders of each affiliate. Oh Ho Gen, the head of the government-led Corporate Restructuring Coordination Committee, said the move would lead the government to place the group's flagship, the Daewoo Corporation, into court receivership. Samuel Len

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  OPPENHEIMER, KATHE
description: OPPENHEIMER-Kathe. The Officers, Board of Trustees and Staff of Helen Keller Services for the Blind are saddened by the loss of Kathe Oppenheimer who through a long and remarkable lifetime of achievement served as an example to all that visual handicap need not be a handicap to a full and rewarding life. Her generosity to Hellen Keller Services for the Blind through the years was deeply appreciated and will be long remembered. Fred McPhilliamy, President

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MCMILLIN, GEORGE
description: MCMILLIN-George. 70, of NYC, died suddenly on Wednesday, January 5, 2000. George was a devoted neighbor, committed to the West 104th Street Block Association, a dear friend to many at the Interchurch Center where he worked for many years, and a great lover of classical music. His untimely death is a sad loss to all who shared his interests and pursuits. A memorial gathering will be held on Saturday, January 15, 11 AM at the Interchurch Chapel on Claremont Avenue between 119th and 120th Streets. Anyone wishing to assist with tributes should call Carol Goodfriend at 212-663-7095.

title: Accord in Hand, Officials May Take On Congress Next
description: After more than four years of warring over the future of Governors Island, the city and state officials who finally announced an agreement yesterday are now likely to find themselves allies in a new battle over the disputed turf. Their potential foe? Federal officials.

title: NEWS OF ABBOTT OPTION SENDS SUPERGEN SHARES UP
description: Shares of the biotechnology company SuperGen Inc. rose yesterday after Abbott Laboratories said it held an option to buy 49 percent of SuperGen for as much as $85 a share, almost triple the closing price on Wednesday. Shares of SuperGen rose $3.3125, to $33.25. Abbott said in a federal filing that it would buy $81.5 million of SuperGen stock at market prices. Abbott also holds an option to raise its stake to 49 percent of the outstanding common stock at $85 a share, making the total investment about $2 billion. The option is part of an agreement between the companies, announced in December, for the sale and distribution of SuperGen's cancer drug rubitecan.

title: Irwin H. Kramer, Investment Banker, 78
description: Irwin H. Kramer, a senior partner and managing director at Allen & Company, an investment bank in New York, died on Dec. 20 at his home in Palm Beach, Fla. He was 78.

title: EUROPEAN WEB SITE PLANNED
description: The Financial Times Group, a unit of Pearson P.L.C., and Marketwatch.Com said they would start a Web site for European investors, modeled on CBS.MarketWatch.com. The site will begin operation within six months. Andrew Ross Sorkin

title: CANADA GETS TOUGHER WITH TOBACCO
description: Canadian tobacco companies will soon be required to put stronger health warnings on cigarette packages. The Department of Health will propose regulations this month, but several labeling options are under consideration, a spokeswoman for Health Minister Allan Rock said. Timothy Pritchard

title: Irate Cuban-Americans Paralyze Miami
description: Energized by a new cause, hundreds of Cuban-Americans shut down much of Miami today with waves of civil disobedience, temporarily blocking access to the Port of Miami and choking traffic on dozens of busy streets to protest the Clinton administration's decision to return 6-year-old Elian Gonzalez to his father in Cuba.

title: ALBUM OF THE WEEK
description: JAY-Z: ''Vol. 3: The Life and Times of S. Carter'' (Roc-A-Fella/Def Jam). Remember those recent advertisements for the Gap with the slogan ''Everybody in khakis''? The frighteningly autocratic undertone of the phrase only reinforced the sense that people would, of their own free will, make it come true, adopting the chain's latest offering as a reliable uniform. The same aura surrounds the third album by the Brooklyn-based rapper Jay-Z. Even casual hip-hop fans will buy this album immediately, and its simple, sturdy tracks will soon make many others lay their money down.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SAMUELS, RUBEN
description: SAMUELS-Ruben. Of Englewood, New Jersey. Died on January 6. Beloved husband of Betty (nee Winter). Devoted father of Judith Tischler, David Samuels and Michael Samuels. Loving grandfather of Sara, Eliana, Ben, Rachel and Danny. Services will be held at Gutterman-Musicant in Hackensack on Sunday, January 9 at 11AM. Contributions may be made to: Ruben Samuels Teachers Resource Center, c/o Michael Samuels, 278 Ritchie Ave, Cincinnati, Ohio,45215 National Alzheimer's Association, or the Teaneck Jewish Center would be appreciated.

description: To the Editor:

title: Complaints Prompt Paper In Japan to Drop Racy Ads
description: For years, the ads have been a titillating, early week staple, anchoring the inside pages of the biggest newspaper in Japan with promises of photo layouts of nude women and scoops on the sex lives of the stars.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LOUCHHEIM, WILLIAM S. SR.
description: LOUCHHEIM-William S. Sr. The President, Chancellor, Boards of Governors and Overseers, faculty, administration and students of Hebrew Union College-Jewish Institute of Religion record with profound sorrow the death of William S. Louchheim Sr., a member of the Los Angles Board of Overseers for decades. A recipient of the Doctor of Humane Letters degree, honoris causa from the College-Institute, Mr. Louchheim was honored for his singular role in the founding and development of the Los Angeles School and for his devotion to Jewish values and ideals. The Jerome H. Louchheim School of Judaic Studies, named in memory of his father, personifies Mr. Louchheim's lifelong commitment to Jewish education and Jewish continuity. We extend our heartfelt sympathy to his family whose loss we share. May the family find comfort together with all those who mourn for Zion and Jerusalem. Rabbi Sheldon Zimmerman, Pres. Dr. Alfred Gottschalk, Chancellor Dr. Lewis M. Barth, Dean Los Angeles School Mr. Burton Lehman, Chair Board of Governors

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HEITNER, EMANUEL
description: HEITNER-Emanuel. After 97 joyful years. Husband of the late Rose Smolin Heitner; and survived by his son and daughter-in-law, Michael and Susan Heitner of Brooklyn, N.Y., and by his grandson Samuel Kip Heitner and his wife Vanessa Guibert Heitner of Arlington, VA. Following a happy boyhood on the streets of Brooklyn and graduation from Boys High School, Manny Heitner later became owner and chief executive of Gotham Carpet Corp and was prominent in the decorator floor covering industry in New York City for many years. He was truly devoted to and beloved by his family, friends and associates.

title: Married in Their Vision, But Not Their Styles
description: As expected, Ruth Orkin's classic picture ''American Girl in Italy, Florence'' (1951), in which a tall American beauty braves the stares and lusty crudity of men loitering at a street corner, takes pride of place at an exhibition of her work and that of her husband, Morris Engel, at the Howard Greenberg Gallery in SoHo.

title: COMPANY BRIEF
description: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS MACHINES CORP., Armonk, N.Y., sold most of its home-networking business to Spencer Trask & Co., an investment firm based in New York. Terms were not disclosed.

description: Here is a selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy movies and film series playing this weekend in New York City. * denotes a highly recommended film or series. Ratings and running times are in parentheses. An index of reviews of films opening today appears on Page 12.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SULLIVAN, PEARL STEINHAUS
description: SULLIVAN-Pearl Steinhaus. Died on Jan. 5, 2000, at age 87. Survived by her brother Henry Steinhaus of Sarasota, Florida, and Leawood, KS, nephews Richard Z. Steinhaus Jr., of New York, Peter M. Steinhaus of Orlando, FL, Stephen Steinhaus of Chicago, IL, and niece Dana Lipsig of New York. Predeceased by her husband Paul Wilson Sullivan and siblings Dr. Florence Lipsig, Stanley Steinhaus and Richard Z. Steinhaus. A graduate of the College of the City of New York, she was production manager of the ''Saturday Review of Literature'' (under Norman Cousins) for many years. She was well respected in the periodical and magazine field. In accordance with her wishes there will be no funeral.

title: Ivoirian's Birthplace Recalls Its Brief, Shining Moment as a Would-Be Capital
description: In midswing, the construction hammers have fallen silent in this small town surrounded by the West African forest.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BARSH, JACK
description: BARSH-Jack. Age 87. In his sleep on January 6, 2000. Susan, his beloved wife of 36 years, and his family mourn his passing. ''Jake the Flying Tiger'' served in the Pacific during WWII and went on to hold several leadership positions in both the Greater Dental Society of New York and the ADA. From Jack's graduation from NYU to his last day of practice in 1986, he was an extraordinary dentist, a caring father and a loving husband. His sharp wit, intelligence, integrity and capacity for jokes will be sorely missed. Memorial services will be held January 9, 2000, 11AM at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81 Street. Interment at Kensico Cemetery on Sunday.

title: A Rangers Goal Is to Open Up on Offense
description: Fifteen months ago, when John Muckler began his first full season as coach of the Rangers, he said his players would use attack-zone pressure and puck pursuit. They would skate at high tempo to create exciting scoring chances in the manner of the Edmonton Oilers of the 1980's and early 1990's. Those Oilers won the Stanley Cup five times with Muckler on the coaching staff, the last as head coach in 1990.

description: The DaimlerChrysler Corporation, the American unit of DaimlerChrysler A.G., said tonight that it was leaving the Global Climate Coalition, a group of heavy- industry companies that lobbies against regulations restricting emissions of gases linked to global warming.

title: Ewing Says Injuries Are No Longer An Issue
description: Patrick Ewing was about to leave the Knicks' practice site when the subject of his rehabilitated Achilles' tendon was raised on Wednesday afternoon. He put down the bags he was carrying and asked for a bottle of water, realizing that when the subject is his health, he cannot escape quickly.

description: His first major league start was in Houston and Dwight Gooden, then 19 years old, was so nervous that he walked from the team hotel to the ballpark -- four miles, as he remembers it -- and arrived at the Astrodome about six hours before game time.

Graduated from Yale School of Architecture, 1947. Served as a Lieutenant in the U.S. Navy during World War II. Executive Vice President of Mineral Insulation Manufacturers' Association until his retirement in 1986. Memorial service on Saturday, January 8, 4PM at St. Mark's Episcopal Church, Basking Ridge, New Jersey. Interment in Swan Point Cemetery, Providence, R.I.

title: The Political Whirl; Very Different Democrats
description: Campaign debates may be a familiar form of political theater, but there is something rare and compelling -- even admirable -- about the unscripted psychodrama of the encounters between Vice President Al Gore and former Senator Bill Bradley. Seldom have two candidates from one party put before the voters such starkly contrasting personalities and such different visions of what a president ought to be. The suspense of the exercise is that neither the candidates nor commentators know whether the voters will prefer an argumentative master of detail (Mr. Gore) or a self-contained generalist (Mr. Bradley).

title: Delving Into the Surreal, All Senses on Red Alert
description: Almost everyone who writes about Cildo Meireles labels him a conceptualist, but he might better be called a producer of magic theater. Mr. Meireles, a prominent Brazilian artist, is not one of those intimidatingly cerebral people who want to reduce all visual experience to verbal abstractions. Anything but reductive, his enveloping installations -- five are included in a retrospective at the New Museum of Contemporary Art, and one is at Galerie Lelong -- are like waking dreams, closer to Magritte than to Duchamp.

title: DINER'S JOURNAL
description: With the city's daily allotment of sun shrinking to a Nordic portion, Isla (pronounced EESS-lah) has arrived like a small, self-contained heat wave. The place looks like a cabana, with a sleek, blue-tiled facade and a long, louvered window facing the street. Inside, the decor blends beach, 50's kitsch and Miami modern in one highly inviting package, with a deep-blue concrete floor, aqua Formica tables and white-leather banquettes that feel like the back seat of a 1960 Lincoln Continental. The place is cool.

title: Precinct's Rosy Crime Rate Was a Distortion, the Police Say
description: On the surface, last year's crime statistics in Fort Greene, Brooklyn, appear alarming: Bucking a trend spanning years, the landmark neighborhood of classical brownstones and leafy streets had recorded a 19.2 percent jump in crimes while reported crime citywide had dropped 8 percent from 1998.

title: Serta Names Doner to Account
description: Serta Inc. in Itasca, Ill., said yesterday it had awarded its account to Doner in Southfield, Mich., replacing the Chicago office of Publicis & Hal Riney, part of Publicis S.A. Billings were estimated at $20 million.

title: AUTOS ON FRIDAY /Safety; Whey (Hold the Curds) For Icy Winter Streets
description: DEPENDING on the weather for the rest of the winter, highway crews will spread 10 to 15 million tons of salt to melt ice and snow on highways in the United States and Canada. But the salt will also corrode the metal on bridges, guardrails and steel reinforcing bars, as well as break down the concrete itself and damage the vehicles that travel those roads.

description: One of Himalayan Buddhism's most important lamas has escaped Chinese-controlled Tibet in a weeklong undercover flight across Nepal and into India.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article in Business Day yesterday about the resignation of the publishing executive Michael Lynton referred to his company incorrectly. He was chief executive of the Penguin Group, the worldwide consumer publishing arm of Pearson's; Penguin Putnam is the group's United States division.

title: Foreign Affairs; The Spirit of Y2K
description: Who would have thought that the biggest stories out of Y2K would be newborns, not nightmares? Let's see, there were the Wallman twins in Indianapolis, who were born two minutes and one millennium apart -- Jacob at 11:59 p.m. on Dec. 31, 1999, and Jordan at 12:01 a.m. on Jan. 1, 2000. Their mother, Julie, told reporters: ''We got the best of both years: the first baby of the millennium and a tax deduction.'' There were two babies born in Korea, just after midnight, whose births, according to The Financial Times, were carried live on the Internet. (Both babies were called ''Truman,'' I assume.) And then there was the story that the first new millennium baby born in Silicon Valley's El Camino Hospital was to receive $500 in high-tech stocks. (How many babies do you suppose will be named ''Nasdaq'' this year, and will it be a boy's name or a girl's?)

title: BRISTOL-MYERS SQUIBB SAYS IT WILL SELL ITS MATRIX UNIT
description: The Bristol-Myers Squibb Company said yesterday that it planned to sell its upscale Matrix Essentials hair care products unit and concentrate on its Clairol retail and professional beauty care business. Bristol-Myers, the New York-based maker of health and personal care products, had sales of $14.81 billion for the first nine months of 1999. Matrix Essentials, which makes upscale hair care products sold in salons, had more than $340 million in sales in 1999. Bristol-Myers Squibb stock rose 87.5 cents, to $59.50, on the New York Stock Exchange.

title: Sales of Licensed Items Set Record in 1999

title: Detention Given in Theft of Secrets
description: A Taiwan executive who paid an employee of the Avery Dennison Corporation to pilfer corporate secrets from the company, a United States adhesives maker, was sentenced on Wednesday to six months home detention in the first case tried under a United States law aimed at combating trade-secret thefts.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MALKIN, SHELLEY

May the family be comforted among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Ronald S. Lauder, Chairman Malcolm Hoenlein, Executive Vice Chairman

title: REFCO GROUP TO BUY DISCOUNT FUTURES BROKERAGE FIRM
description: Refco Group, one of the leading United States futures brokers, said yesterday that it would acquire the discount broker Lind-Waldock to reach more individual investors who trade online. Refco, which is based in Chicago, did not disclose the purchase price. The combined companies will have United States customer equity of about $2.1 billion, which would rank it sixth among futures brokers. The two hold a combined $800 million in additional equity for overseas clients. Lind-Waldock, based in Chicago, will remain a separate entity. Lind-Waldock bills itself as the world's largest discount futures firm.

title: Part Martha Stewart, Part RuPaul; 'Brini Maxwell Show' Offers Household Tips in Drag
description: Brini Maxwell, the svelte and stylish creation of Ben Sander, is a drag queen's answer to Martha Stewart. Dressed in a meticulously coiffured blond wig, patent leather pumps and an array of vintage dresses, she gushes over obscure household tips, etiquette and recipes on her weekly television show.

title: Rocker Agrees to Undergo Testing Immediately
description: John Rocker traveled to Baltimore yesterday to begin the psychological testing that was ordered by Major League Baseball a day earlier following the disparaging comments that he made last month about gays and minority-group members.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CURSON, ALFRED

title: APPLIED INDUSTRIAL TECHNOLOGIES ENTERS CANADIAN DEAL
description: Applied Industrial Technologies Inc., a distributor of bearings and components, said yesterday that it planned to buy the industrial distribution businesses of the closely held Dynavest Corporation to enter the Canadian market. The Cleveland-based company said it would buy Dynavest's 24 bearing and power transmission service centers, 15 HyPower fluid power service centers, 3 All Agro agricultural distribution centers and a warehouse, all in western Canada. Terms of the all-cash purchase from Dynavest, based in Saskatoon, Saskatchewan, were not disclosed.

title: 2 Funds With Higher Limits Mean Extra Cash for Giuliani
description: In preparing a run for United States Senate, Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani has paid for much of his political operation by collecting money through two little-known political committees that are subject to more lenient fund-raising restrictions than an official Senate campaign committee.

title: Abroad at Home; 'This Has Got Me in Some Kind of Whirlwind'
description: Mary Anne Gehris was brought to this country from Germany when she was a little over a year old. She is 34 now, lives near Atlanta and sounds like Georgia.

title: The Greening of Corporate America
description: At last, shared interests are producing signs of cooperation between two warring forces in our society, business and environmentalists. On the one hand, bad environmental policies are ultimately disastrous for businesses and their employees. On the other hand, conservationists can't make the environment healthy without the help of businesses.

title: Justices Again Delay a Plan to Require Work for Shelter
description: Two State Supreme Court justices yesterday once again delayed the Giuliani administration's effort to bar homeless people from shelters if they fail to meet work requirements and other welfare rules. A hearing was set for next Friday to examine the plan's effect on children.

title: Beliefs; The list of the world's major religions looks as it did at the dawn of the last millennium.
description: The big news, in religion, is often that there is no news. That is a dirty little secret journalists writing about religion would prefer to keep from their editors and the people who sign paychecks. To the extent that social science can measure religious attitudes and conduct -- rates of belief and membership, for instance, or frequency of worship and prayer -- what stands out is how glacial the changes are over decades.

title: Safir Says Civilian Panel Exceeds Its Authority in Citing Officers for Lying
description: Police Commissioner Howard Safir said yesterday that the independent city agency that investigates civilian complaints of police misconduct is overstepping its authority when it formally cites officers for lying.

title: Britain's Granada Says It Is Considering Bids for Media Rivals
description: A battle to rule Britain's commercial television industry began today when the Granada Group said it intended to spoil the recently planned $6.6 billion merger between Carlton Communications and United News and Media by trying to buy one of the media companies.

title: STRONG JOB MARKET IN CANADA
description: Canada's unemployment rate remained at 6.9 percent in December, unchanged from November, the lowest level in 18 years, Statistics Canada reported. The country's strong economy added 42,300 full-time jobs last month, almost double some economists' expectations, with most of the gain in the service sector. A comparable increase in the number of people looking for work left the jobless rate unchanged. Some economists expect the unemployment rate to dip further in next few months but to rise above 7 percent in the second half. Timothy Pritchard (NYT)

title: Man Arrested in Assault Is Questioned in Murder
description: Miguel Figueroa, 29, who was arrested in Tampa, Fla., on Thursday night and charged with sexually assaulting a 14-year-old girl in Camden in 1995, is being questioned in the rape and murder of another Camden girl, Shaline Sequinot, 13, whose naked body was found on Aug. 4 of that year near her Camden home, the authorities said.

title: Police Demote Commanders Of 2 Precincts
description: Police Commissioner Howard Safir has demoted two police precinct commanders who failed to bring down crime in the Brooklyn and Queens neighborhoods patrolled by the officers under their supervision, officials said yesterday.

title: Clinton Offers Israel and Syria 7-Page 'Working Paper' to Study Golan Heights Control
description: President Clinton intervened in the peace talks between Israel and Syria today by presenting leaders of both countries with a seven-page ''working paper'' defining their differences over a deal that would return the Golan Heights to Syrian control.

title: ADIDAS TESTING SHIRTS
description: One day after German retailers pulled Nike soccer shirts off shelves on suspicions they contained a dangerous chemical, Adidas Salomon A.G., the German sporting goods manufacturer, said it was testing its soccer shirts for contamination. Thomas Galert, public relations manager for Adidas Germany, said the company did not believe that its products were affected but that the company was taking the report very seriously. Earlier this week, a television program said researchers had found traces of tributyltin, a fungicide used on boat hulls, in Nike soccer shirts. Adidas, which was not mentioned in the report, expects the results of its tests by Tuesday. Christian Baumgaertel (NYT)

title: OFFICE SUPPLIES RETAILER EXTENDS STOCK REPURCHASES
description: Office Depot Inc. said yesterday that it had approved a $100 million increase to its previous $500 million stock repurchase program. The company, an office supplies retailer based in Delray Beach, Fla., said it had completed the initial buyback in the third and fourth quarters of last year, repurchasing 46.7 million shares. The new $100 million authorization does not have an expiration date. The company, which operates 825 superstores in the United States and Canada, has 329.2 million shares outstanding. Office Depot's shares rose 25 cents, to $10.75, on the New York Stock Exchange.

A thick file of correspondence-questions, comments, offers to help-testifies to his involvement. We will miss him. Frederick A.O. Schwarz, Jr., Chair Christopher Stone, President

title: Flying Through Time On a Violin's Wing
description: The violin, surrogate of choice for the singing human voice during the first 200 years of its existence, entered the 20th century both as friend and enemy. Keepers of the Romantic flame were grateful for its lyrical qualities. Makers of a new order were mistrustful. The instrument has endured, indeed prospered, because the music that Mendelssohn, Mozart, Bach and Tchaikovsky wrote for it has endured as well. Newer composers deeply suspicious of older forms of sentiment have explored its rhythmic and percussive qualities with wary enthusiasm.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOLDER, STANLEY C.
description: GOLDER-Stanley C. It is with profound sadness that the officers, members and staff of the American Jewish Committee note the passing of Stanley Golder, an enormously generous and gracious man who sought to leave the world a better place than he found it. Stan was a member of the AJC family for many years, serving on our Board of Governors and Board of Trustees, as a National Vice President, President of our Chicago Chapter and most recently as an Honorary National Vice President. In 1994 we honored Stan and his wife Joan with AJC's Human Right Medallion. In every endeavor, he personified the very best of what AJC stands for-integrity, compassion, and a resolute commitment to human rights, intergroup harmony and Jewish values. Stan earned the affection and esteem of all who knew him and we will greatly missed his guidance and his friendship. We send our deepest condolences to Joan, his sons David and Kenneth, his daughter Nancy, their spouses and his many grandchidren. Bruce M. Ramer, President David A. Harris, Exec Director

title: Sports of The Times; Jets' Debacle Is Not Above Suspicion
description: THERE are some in the National Football League who stare at the Jets' coaching debacle and see nothing but conspiracies. They are educated people, with advanced degrees, who do not believe in little green men or the grassy knoll theory. But when it comes to Bill Parcells, who is about as trusted by the league office as a shark in a pool of bluefish, or even Bill Belichick trying to escape his ironclad contract as if he's Harry Houdini, all logic goes flying out the window.

Died peacefully at New York Hospital following a 4 month battle with cancer. Gordon McCollum was a lover of New York City and an avid student of its history, art and architecture. Following a career as a successful executive in commercial real estate he acquired the American Architectural Archives, a collection of books and documents on the city which he made available to scholars and writers. His curiousity and enthusiasm for life and his surroundings never abated and will remain a source of joy and inspiration for all who knew him. Plans for a memorial service will be announced at a later date.

title: A Plan for Governors Island
description: Governors Island in New York City's busy harbor has remained tantalizingly off limits for years while city and state officials decided how best to use it. A developer's fantasy island and a park lover's open-air dream, the 172 acres include antique fortresses, vintage all-American houses and a patch of distinctly ugly buildings constructed more recently on the leftover fill from construction of the New York subway system. Now, after suggestions for using the outpost for everything from an artists' haven to a casino complex, Gov. George Pataki and Mayor Rudolph Giuliani have agreed on a plan that seems to meet the approval of a wide range of normally contentious New Yorkers. While the proposal should be regarded as a work in progress, it is a promising start, worthy of the effort it will take to get the White House and Congress to go along.

In an all-stock transaction, it will swap one of the new shares for every two shares in Worldwide Semiconductor.

title: Make Giuliani the Education Mayor
description: It's time to give the mayor something he has asked for. We should dissolve the New York City Board of Education. The public schools should report to the mayor -- Rudolph Giuliani now and his successors later. The schools should become a city department led by a commissioner. This is a step Boston, Cleveland, Chicago and Detroit have taken.

title: NO RATE CHANGE SEEN
description: The European Central Bank's vice president, Christian Noyer, said yesterday that the bank had no reason to alter its interest rate policy for the moment. In an interview with the Italian daily newspaper Il Corriere della Sera, Mr. Noyer was quoted as saying: ''The markets have their expectations, and we have ours. And since the last meeting Nov. 4, when it was decided to raise the refinancing rate by a half percentage point, no new factors have matured that would lead us to change, for the moment, our evaluation.'' The central bank's refinancing rate currently stands at 3 percent.
