title: Merrill Lynch Reimburses Client For Loss Linked to Ex-Employee
description: Merrill Lynch & Company said today that it reimbursed money to a client and was pursuing prosecution of a former Egyptian employee who may have misappropriated the funds. Merrill Lynch paid back about $40 million, The Financial Times reported today.

title: The Radio Monster
description: To the Editor:

title: Suspect Pleads Not Guilty In Brick Attack on Woman
description: The man charged with attacking a woman with a brick in Midtown Manhattan in November pleaded not guilty yesterday and said he was in his girlfriend's apartment in the Bronx at the time.

title: Excerpts From Debate Among the Republicans
description: Following are excerpts from a Republican presidential debate last night, involving Gary L. Bauer, Gov. George W. Bush of Texas, Steve Forbes, Senator Orrin G. Hatch of Utah, Alan Keyes and Senator John McCain of Arizona, as recorded by The New York Times. The debate was in West Columbia, S.C.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOLDBERG, IDA
description: GOLDBERG-Ida. A true Eshes Chayil. May she rest in peace. Very sincere condolences to John Klein, Fred, Ruth, Evan and Jason Schwalbe. We all hope for happier days to come. Partners of Hilson Management Corporation

title: U.S. Troops on the Golan Heights?
description: To the Editor:

title: Short Takes
description: Stuck with piles of Spam? Don't know what to do with the 50 cases of cereal stockpiled for a Y2K catastrophe that never occurred? Call a charity.

title: Assisi Journal; When in Assisi, Don't Feed Saint's Flock
description: The gentleman from Verona reared back guiltily when asked why a horde of pigeons were pecking around his feet.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MICHAUD, RALPH WM
description: MICHAUD-Ralph Wm. Age 92. Died Sunday December 13, 1999 at home in Garden City, NY. Beloved husband of Marie Ann and father of Carole McLoughlin of Garden City, NY and Susan Jamieson of Fredericksburg, Va. A Wall Street Securities Analyst for over 50 years. A Vice President of Dean Witter and Paine, Webber, Jackson and Curtis, he was also a past Vice President and Director of The New York Society of Security Analysts, a past Director of the Financial Analysts Federation, member of the Paper Industry Analysts Group, the American Institute of Mining Engineers, The Bankers Club of America, and the author of ''The Investors Handbook; A Guide to Sound Investment Principles and Practice''. He will long be remembered for his honesty, quick wit and intelligence.

title: Kerrey Considers Leaving Senate To Lead University in New York
description: Senator Bob Kerrey, an influential Nebraska Democrat and one of the party's brightest stars, is considering leaving the Senate to become president of the New School University in Manhattan.

title: The Debate Over Gay Troops
description: Both Democratic presidential candidates, Vice President Al Gore and former Senator Bill Bradley, said strongly and unequivocally this week that they would allow gays to serve openly in the military. That is the only fair and rational course now that five years of experience has shown the compromise policy of ''don't ask, don't tell'' to be a failure that should be abolished.

title: Steeper Fines Considered For Tobacco Sales to Minors
description: In what would rank among the nation's toughest laws to prevent minors from smoking, a City Council committee yesterday approved increasing fines against merchants who sell cigarettes to children to $1,000 on a first offense, more than triple the current amount.

title: Cyclist Fatalities Increased 75% in 1999, Puzzling Police
description: A steep jump in the number of bicyclists killed in collisions with cars and trucks in New York City in 1999 has the police puzzled and cycling advocates demanding action.

title: Trips to Renew Jewish Ties Set Off Debate Over Costs
description: As loudspeakers blared a welcome at Ben-Gurion Airport, Michael Sherman stepped off a jumbo jet one recent morning with more than 400 other American Jewish college students.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BARSH, JACK
description: BARSH-Jack. Age 87. In his sleep on January 6, 2000. Susan, his beloved wife of 36 years, and his family mourn his passing. ''Jake the Flying Tiger'' served in the Pacific during WWII and went on to hold several leadership positions in both the Greater Dental Society of New York and the ADA. From Jack's graduation from NYU to his last day of practice in 1986, he was an extraordinary dentist, a caring father and a loving husband. His sharp wit, intelligence, integrity and capacity for jokes will be sorely missed. Memorial services will be held January 9, 2000, 11AM at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81 Street. Interment at Kensico Cemetery on Sunday.

title: Following NBC's Lead, ABC Outlines Minority Hiring Plan
description: Two days after NBC announced an agreement with the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People intended to increase minority hiring, ABC yesterday announced its own ''statement of understanding'' with the organization.

title: NEW UNICOM-PECO MERGER TERMS INCLUDE STOCK BUYBACK
description: The Unicom Corporation and the Peco Energy Company said yesterday that they would buy back up to $1.5 billion of common stock under revised terms for their merger into a power-industry giant to be called the Exelon Corporation. Unicom shareholders will receive 0.875 of an Exelon common share and $3 in cash for each Unicom share held. Peco shareholders will receive one Exelon share for each Peco share. The companies said they adjusted the terms of the deal to reflect the drop in their stock prices. Under the revised deal, Unicom will buy back $1 billion of its shares and Peco $500 million.

title: A Soprano's Debut and a Conductor's for 'Madama'
description: For all its familiarity, Puccini's ''Madama Butterfly'' is a hard opera to cast. When we meet her in Act One, Cio-Cio-San, the title character, is a worldly 15-year-old, overcome with love for Lieutenant Pinkerton, the hearty American naval officer who has swept into her life and hastily arranged a marriage, rescuing her from a humiliating life as a geisha.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HANFLING, HERMAN M.
description: HANFLING-Herman M. On January 6. Devoted father and fatherin-law of Robert and Phyllis, Martin and Natalie. Dear grandfather of six grandchildren and two great grandchildren. Brother-in-law of Betty. Graveside service Sunday, 2 P.M. at the New Mount Carmel Cemetery.

title: Persistent War in Angola
description: Fueled by oil revenues, diamond smuggling and a disregard for civilian lives on all sides, Angola's ruinous civil war has stubbornly outlasted the cold-war machinations that ratcheted up the death toll in the 1980's. Upward of a million Angolans have died in 25 years of fighting and famine, and tens of thousands have been maimed by land mines. Unicef recently called Angola the worst place on earth for children -- a country where 30 percent of them will die before the age of 5.

title: Harald Hermann Rossi, 82, Innovator in Use of Radiation
description: Dr. Harald Hermann Rossi, a biophysicist who improved the ability to measure minute amounts of ionizing radiation and their effects on living things, died Jan. 1 at his home in Upper Nyack, N.Y. He was 82.

title: GORE, IN REVERSAL, SHUNS LITMUS TEST OVER GAY TROOPS
description: Vice President Al Gore backtracked tonight on comments he made in a debate on Wednesday when he said he would require any appointee to the Joint Chiefs of Staff to agree in advance to support a policy allowing gays to serve openly in the military.

title: New Access to America Online E-Mail
description: America Online Inc. said this week that it would give its more than 20 million subscribers access to electronic mail using hand-held organizers made by the Compaq Computer Corporation, the Casio Computer Company and the Hewlett-Packard Company.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Monday about Hungary and the Sacred Crown of St. Stephen referred incorrectly to the Hungarian Truth and Life Party; it is not a member of the governing coalition. The article also misspelled the name of the site where St. Stephen is entombed; it is Szekesfehervar, not Szekesfehervom.

title: Lucent Shares Remain Under Pressure After Poor Earnings Report
description: January 7, 2000

title: Now Drivers Can Spend Less Time Dodging the Grim Sweeper
description: A staple of life for drivers in New York City -- the three-hour alternate-side parking regulation -- is being radically altered in many parts of the city, as officials reduce the period to only 90 minutes in an effort to make the rules less burdensome.

title: SYSCO AGREES TO BUY FRUIT AND VEGETABLE DISTRIBUTOR
description: The Sysco Corporation, North America's largest food service distributor, agreed yesterday to buy the closely held FreshPoint Holdings Inc., just months after the Fresh America Corporation canceled plans to buy FreshPoint, a fruit and vegetable distributor. Terms were not disclosed. FreshPoint, based in Dallas, is one of the leading distributors of wholesale produce in North America, with annual sales of about $750 million. Sysco, based in Houston, had sales of $17.4 billion in fiscal 1999. In September, Fresh America scrapped plans to acquire FreshPoint, without explanation.

title: Orthodox Branches Join for Holy Day
description: In a parade of patriarchs and presidents, mitered metropolitans and gray-suited prime ministers, religious and civil leaders from throughout the Eastern Orthodox world filled the fourth-century Church of the Nativity today for a Christmas service that may have been the most inclusive Orthodox Christian gathering of modern times.

title: Border Stays Closed To Mexican Trucks
description: Saying it is concerned about safety, the Clinton administration has decided to delay opening all 50 states to Mexican trucks and buses, as is called for by the North American Free Trade Agreement.

title: Namibia Death Toll Rises With Encroaching Angolan Civil War
description: The death toll in Namibia is mounting as Angola's protracted civil war spills across its border, resulting in a spate of killings, kidnappings and violence on Namibian soil, Namibian authorities and foreign diplomats say.

title: INSIDE
description: U.S. Drafts a Mideast Text

title: Florida Passes Bill to Quicken Execution Pace
description: Florida lawmakers made sweeping changes today in the way the death penalty is carried out, approving a bill that they say will speed the appeals process so that death row inmates can be executed more quickly.

title: Corrections
description: An obituary on Dec. 30 about John J. Geoghegan, book publisher and editor, omitted a surviving son. He is John J. Geoghegan III of San Francisco.

title: Left and Right Switch Hats On Homeless
description: IT was a classic battle between liberals and conservatives -- a dispute over rights versus responsibilities -- in court yesterday when the Coalition for the Homeless challenged the city's attempt to impose work requirements in all of its homeless shelters. But it raised a novel question: In this case, are the liberals the hard-headed pragmatists?

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STANLEY, STANFORD A.
description: STANLEY-Stanford A. Beloved husband of Estelle. Loving father of Marion and Elliott Kahn and Charles Stanley. Devoted grandfather to Stephen and Jeffrey, Brigitte and Michelle. Adoring greatgrandfather of Martine, Andrew and Sydney. He was a graduate of NYU and St. John's Law School. Services: Community Synagogue, 150 Middleneck Road, Sands Point, at 1:30 P.M., Sunday, January 9.

title: Manchester United Star Suspended
description: David Beckham escaped yesterday with just a one-game suspension and $1,250 fine for his latest violent kick.

title: George and Titans on the Inside Looking Out
description: Near the end of the previous three seasons, Eddie George and his Tennessee Titans teammates would talk in the locker room about plans for the off-season. Travel and families and social events would be discussed. So would the reasons that George and the bunch finished with an 8-8 record in each of those years.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ZWEIG, RICHARD A.
description: ZWEIG-Richard A. December 26, 1999. Outstanding son of Harriet and Sol Zweig, loving brother of Peter and wife Linda, uncle to Julie and Lea. Memorial services Sunday, January 9, at Glades Clubhouse of Boca Lago Country Club, Boca Raton, FL, at 1:30 PM. There are no words adequate to describe our heartfelt loss of an extraordinary human being-creative, courageous, loving, and sweet.

title: Highway to Success Leads a Coach Astray
description: When Mike Nolan, the defensive coordinator of the Washington Redskins, held the same position with the Giants from 1993-96, some people in the team's front office thought that one day Nolan would be a head coach. A few other teams felt the same way. Nolan appeared to be on the fast track for stardom.

title: COLLEGES: WOMEN'S BASKETBALL
description: ILLINOIS 86, IOWA 60

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HARNEY, ELEANORE T.
description: HARNEY-Eleanore T. Beloved wife of the late John Francis Sr. Devoted mother of John (Jack), Brian, Michael, Peter and Christopher. Survived by 14 grandchildren. Reposing at Castle Hill Funeral Home, 1528 Castle Hill Ave., Bronx, New York, Saturday and Sunday, 2-5 and 7-9 PM. Funeral Mass on Monday, Holy Family Church, 11 AM. Interment Gate of Heaven Cemetery.

title: Matthaus to Report To Camp March 10
description: Lothar Matthaus of Germany, whose 25 World Cup appearances are more than any other player, will join the MetroStars' training camp on March 10, the team announced yesterday.

title: Clinton Outlines Plan and Money to Tighten Computer Security
description: President Clinton proposed new measures today to combat unauthorized intrusions into the nation's essential computer networks, including a monitoring program for government computers that was scaled back amid criticism and a subsidized training program for cybersleuths.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  REESE, WILLIAM WILLIS II
description: REESE-William Willis II, died suddenly of a heart attack on December 29th at his home in West Palm Beach. A native of New York, he was 59. Beloved husband of Sonia van Voorhees Reese; son of the late Willis Livingston Mesier Reese and Frances Gallatin Stevens Reese; he is also survived by his sister, Frances Reese Olivieri; his brothers John Rathbone Reese, George Bliss Reese and Alexander Stevens Reese. Recently retired from Morgan Guaranty Trust, he had a B.A. from Trinity College, and M.B.A and J.D. degrees from Columbia University. He was admitted to the New York Bar in 1972. He served as Captain of the U.S. Air Force. He was on the Board of Directors of the New York City Ballet and President of its Ballet Guild. He was also a benefactor of the Metropolitan Opera, the Counseling and Human Development Center, the Third Street Music School Settlement, and the Youth Foundation, Inc., and was a Trustee of Milbrook School among others. He was a Past Master of Holland Lodge #

title: Boy's Transfer Is Complicated By Question of Guardianship
description: The wrangling over a 6-year-old Cuban boy shifted today from the streets to the courthouse, where a Miami judge said she would decide early next week whether to grant custody to the boy's great-uncle, with whom he is living.

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about the Board of Education's search for an interim chancellor referred incorrectly to John Jay Iselin, president of Cooper Union, whom officials mentioned as one possible candidate.

title: Jets Sit in Limbo, but Thoughts Fly
description: The unsettling situation revolving around the Jets -- a team currently without an owner or a head coach -- moved into its fourth day yesterday with no resolution in sight.

title: King David as a Metaphor for Flawed Humanity Shaping Its Fate
description: How are the mighty chosen?

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: U S WEST INC., Englewood, Colo., a telecommunications services company, acquired a minority stake in Netpliance, an Internet appliance services company based in Austin, Tex. Financial terms were not disclosed.

title: America One Beats Stars and Stripes and Moves Into the Lead
description: The legal implications of Stars and Stripes' decision to use a rudder manufactured in Australia earlier in this round remain uncertain, but as racing resumed today in the America's Cup challenger semifinals, at least the pecking order looked clearer.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MORGANSTERN, MILDRED
description: MORGANSTERN - Mildred. Be loved wife of the late Abraham. Mother of Daniel, Ann and Lucy. Grandmother of Matthew. Mother-in-law of June. Sister of Lilly & Morty. Loving aunt and friend. A shining light and inspiration to all who knew her. Services Sunday, at 10:45AM, Sherman's Flatbush Memorial Chapel, 1283, Coney Island Avenue, Brooklyn (Avenue J).

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SWANSON, HARRY W.
description: SWANSON-Harry W., of Aquebogue, L.I. (formerly of South Jamesport and Lynbrook, L.I.) on January 6, 2000. Proud U.S. Marine, Retired Principal-New York City Schools and avid wood carver. Beloved husband of Elizabeth (nee Wheeler). Loving father of Michael of Miller Place, L.I., Lynda Davis of Toano, Va., Kenneth of Madison, N.J. and Douglas of Kings Park, L.I. Fond brother of Donald Swanson and cherished grandfather of ten. Friends may visit the DeFriest Funeral Homes, Inc., Main Road (Route 25), Mattituck, L.I. on Sunday 2-4 and 7-9 P.M. Celebration of the Liturgy of Christian Burial, Monday 9:30 AM, St. John the Evangelist R.C. Church, Riverhead. Interment Calverton National Cemetery. Should friends desire, donations may be made to either Memorial SloanKettering Hospital or Riverhead Free Library.

title: Early Flu Outbreak Has Hospitals Overflowing
description: This year's wave of influenza has become widespread across the nation, overwhelming emergency rooms in cities from Boston to Los Angeles, filling hospital beds and forcing postponements of operations as staff members turn to treating the rising number of flu patients.

title: A Peacemaker for the Germans
description: The historian weighs his words. Because his subject is Germany and the modern history of that nation is a minefield, this precision is understandable. Yet it is evident that in the crafted phrases of Fritz Stern, in the sentences that circle a subject like a hunter closing on his prey, a personality as well as a calling are revealed. He is a man of nuances; when he defines himself, it is with a kind of fastidious detail.

title: Bermuda Bowl Play Begins For World Team Supremacy
description: Exactly half a century after it was first played on this island, the Bermuda Bowl, symbol of the world team championship, will be in play here Saturday.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RAPPAPORT, HANNAH
description: RAPPAPORT - Hannah. Honey was the loved wife of Martin. Mother of Caren and Roger Weiss, Joan and Douglas Krantz. Grandmother of Robin and Michael Wendt, Wendy and Keith Gordon, Gregory and Rachel Weiss, Jonathan Isacoff, Jennifer Isacoff and Ben Krantz. Great-grandmother of Nicholas Carey and Jake Gordon. Sister of Muriel and Irving Berlin, and Solomon and Eda Aaronoff. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to Congregation B'nai Yisrael, in Armonk, New York. Funeral Services will be for family only.

title: Relief Planned for Drivers Stuck in Inspection Lines
description: New Jersey drivers may have shorter and warmer waits while their cars are inspected: Federal regulators have authorized use of a speedier emissions test, and the testing company agreed yesterday to install heated waiting areas at inspection stations.

title: $15 Million Bail in Murder Case With a Celebrity Glow
description: The glamorous world of Miami Beach celebrity culture collided yesterday with the gritty workings of what prosecutors called a Brooklyn Mafia crew, as a South Florida nightclub impresario charged with murder was ordered released from custody on $15 million bail.

title: Big Night Spirals Downhill With Nets Left in Rubble
description: Early in the second half tonight, center Jim McIlvaine of the Nets threw his hands over his face and walked quickly to the bench, never to return to the game against the Vancouver Grizzlies at Continental Arena. Many of the home fans probably felt like doing something similar as the Nets lost, 101-91, to one of the worst teams in the National Basketball Association.

title: DIMINISHED BRAZILIAN INFLATION
description: Concern over Brazilian price increases eased after inflation showed signs of slowing in Sao Paulo, the nation's largest city. A widely watched survey from the University of Sao Paulo's Institute of Economic Research showed inflation rose at an unexpectedly tame rate of 0.49 percent in December, for an annualized rate of 6 percent, the lowest in five months. Subdued inflation could provide leeway for the central bank to resume gradual reduction in rates to stimulate growth in Latin America's largest economy. Simon Romero (NYT)

title: Brazil Group Protests 2 Banks' Free Web Access Plans
description: Drawing attention to the growing concentration of power among large companies in Brazil's Internet industry, a group representing several hundred of the country's Internet access providers protested today over plans by two prominent banks to offer free access to the World Wide Web.

title: Forbes Takes the Offensive
description: Several months of ''will he or won't he'' questions about whether Steve Forbes would unleash negative advertisements against Gov. George W. Bush of Texas ended yesterday when the Forbes campaign begin using a 30-second spot in New Hampshire attacking Mr. Bush's stand on taxes. The commercial comes just a day after Mr. Bush pledged to cut taxes ''so help me God,'' and the Forbes spot accuses him of breaking a no-new-tax pledge he made in Texas in 1994.

title: Trump Speaks Out on Just About Everything
description: Taking potshots at Ed Koch, all the Republicans running for president, North Korea, Fidel Castro, Japan, Russia and candidates of humble background, Donald J. Trump today brought his presidential exploratory campaign to Minnesota, where he outlined his vision of a Trump administration and helped raise money for his Reform Party ally, Gov. Jesse Ventura.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Unemployment Rate Stayed At 4.1 Percent in December

title: Motivating Investors; Anthony Robbins Makes An Internet Play
description: At first glance, Dreamlife appears to be just another Internet company with high hopes and hazy prospects.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WASSERMAN, ROBERT A.
description: WASSERMAN-Robert A. All of us at Owens Group mourn the loss of our friend and partner. Bob was a unique insurance professional whose advice and counsel were deeply valued by our clients. His dedication throughout the past 33 years has been extraordinarily inspiring. Even when afflicted by illness, he never ceased caring about the interests of his clients and colleagues. We will miss him. We thank his wonderful family for sharing him with us and pray that they will find comfort together with all the mourners of Zion. Herbert and Robert Owens

title: TIVO AND BLOCKBUSTER TO JOINTLY DEVELOP VIDEO SERVICE
description: TiVo Inc. of Sunnyvale, Calif., said yesterday that it was joining with Blockbuster Inc. to develop a video-on-demand service. TiVo's television set-top receivers record and store video content. The deal will allow TiVo subscribers to obtain movies for viewing on those receivers. The companies said they want to begin the service by year's end. Consumers will eventually be able to reserve movies for pickup at Blockbuster stores or for viewing through their TiVo receivers. TiVo's shares jumped 31 percent yesterday, gaining $11.9375 each, to $50.375, in Nasdaq trading. Blockbuster's shares were up $1.625, to $11.625, on the New York Stock Exchange.

description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  OPPENHEIMER, KATHE
description: OPPENHEIMER - Kathe. Kathe Oppenheimer's obituary that ran January 4, should have asked that contributions go to Helen Keller Services for the Blind, 1 Helen Keller Way, Hempstead, N.Y. 11550. 516-485-1234.

title: W. W. GRAINGER WARNS ABOUT FOURTH-QUARTER EARNINGS
description: W. W. Grainger Inc., a distributor of compressors, pumps and hand tools, warned yesterday that its fourth-quarter earnings might be as much as 45 percent less than estimates because of higher costs and inventory troubles. The company had been expected to earn 54 cents a share, according to analysts polled by First Call/Thomson Financial. W. W. Grainger, which sells more than 550,000 repair and maintenance items, said it had experienced slowdowns and had had problems processing transactions during the quarter. It also had trouble keeping track of inventory because of a resource planning system it installed in 1999. The company said it had higher employee compensation costs because of the new system. W. W. Grainger shares fell 68.75 cents each, to $44.375.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  NECKMAN, ARNOLD SAMUEL
description: NECKMAN - Arnold Samuel. Passed away at his home in Hollywood, FL January 1, 2000 shortly after his 67th birthday. Husband to his great love of 50 years Shelley. Beloved father of Chuck, Steven and Beth. Loving grandfather of Andrew, David and Allison. He will surely be missed. Arnold was born in the Bronx, educated at the Peddie School and Tufts Univ. He established himself as a builder and contractor in the northeast and in Florida before entering the retail business with his son. After many years on the water, he became an avid golfer. Of his many successes, he was proudest of his children and gained his greatest joy from his family and close friends. He will be remembered by all as a gentleman and a gentle man.

title: Rejecting Hijacking Charge, Pakistan Directs It Back at India
description: One day after India presented its case that Pakistan sponsored the hijacking of an Indian Airlines jet, Pakistani officials said today that the charges were baseless and that India was making them in an attempt to persuade other nations to declare Pakistan a terrorist state.

title: Porn Site Ordered to Drop Magazine Name
description: Porn Site Ordered to Drop Magazine Name

title: Defanging the Great Inflationary Forces
description: WHEN oil prices double or triple in less than a year, that is a momentous event in America. Or at least it once was. The stock market would plunge. The economy would slow, or fall into recession. Presidents wearing sweaters would ask the public to turn thermostats down. And the inflation rate would rise alarmingly.

title: Sports of The Times; Postseason Lounge Acts Can Be Exciting (in Their Own Way)
description: SO confident is the National Football League of its hold over the house-bound populace in January that it offers a series of warm-up acts for the first round of the playoffs.

title: Spirits and Spirituals
description: Is it possible to develop character while living in Animal House? ''Colleges That Encourage Character Development,'' a new guide to 400 institutions with programs fostering honesty, integrity and all-around good character, has made room for the State University of New York at Albany. Singled out for a peer counsel-ing program, Albany was also ranked No. 1 party school last year by another organization, the Princeton Review.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEVIEN, EDWARD
description: LEVIEN-Edward. Longtime resident of Miami Beach, 1520 West 22 Street, Sunset Island #

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GRECO, LOUIS V.
description: GRECO-Louis V. On January 7, 2000. Beloved husband of Marie (nee Principe). Devoted father of Luanne Mannix, Joseph V, Louis V, Thomas F, Gloria R, and the late Mary V. Also survived by ten grandchildren and one greatgrandson. Loving brother or Rosemary J. Billies. He was a Fourth Degree Knight and past Grand Knight of The Knights of Columbus (Spellman Council). A Trustee and former president of Saint Stanislaus Parish Council, former president of The Holy Name Society, and Cub Master of Pack 312. Reposing at the Hess-Miller Funeral Home, 64-19 Metropolitan Avenue, Middle Village, NY until 9am Monday. Mass of Christian Burial Saint Stanislaus Kostka Church, Maspeth, NY, Mon. 10am. Interment Saint John's Cemetery.

title: Clinton Aide Attacks Use Of Donations By Giuliani
description: The chief spokesman for Hillary Rodham Clinton's Senate campaign said yesterday that Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani's use of two little-known political committees to raise money presents ''serious questions that demand further investigation.''

title: Parking Space At a Co-op
description: Q About three and a half years ago, I bought a co-op apartment and when I inquired about parking, I was told that it takes about a year to get a space. I am still on a waiting list and now my neighbors tell me that it takes a minimum of five years to get a space. I've reviewed the list of rentals and have discovered that some people rent two or more spaces while many of us have none. Since a part of everyone's maintenance pays for property taxes, I see this as a violation of the rights of those who don't have spaces. The manager told me there are no rules and that the board of directors are well aware of this inequity but do nothing about it. What can be done? . . . Camille Amato, Flushing, Queens.

title: A Comic Strip Illuminates a Serious Issue
description: A NUMBER of readers have said they were confused or offended by the Jan. 2 installment of Stan Mack's Dispatches titled ''A View From Another Window.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HOLTZMAN, LEE
description: HOLTZMAN-Lee A, 90, passed away on December 27, 1999 in Florida. Wife of the late Wolfe. Loving mother of Ellen (Arnold) Cohen and Samuel (Judy). Cherished grandmother of Ilyssa, Devra (Steven) Dubroff, William Holtzman and great-grandson Jordan. Devoted sister of Sophie Gerard and the late Bernard Altschuler and Sylvia Silver. Burial has taken place at Knollwood Park Cemetery, Ridgewood, New York.

title: A Comic Strip Illuminates a Serious Issue
description: A NUMBER of readers have said they were confused or offended by the Jan. 2 installment of Stan Mack's Dispatches titled ''A View From Another Window.''

title: Food; Mother Hubbard
description: Nobody in our upstate town could talk about anything but the Hubbard squash. Every morning at the post office from late December to early January last year, the widows recounted its vital statistics: 20 inches high and 25 pounds, if it weighed an ounce.

title: January 2-8; New Arrests In Suspected Terror Plot
description: Two more Algerians were arrested, one in Brooklyn and the other in Seattle, in the broadening investigation of a terrorist bomb plot that the authorities say was interrupted last month with the arrest of Ahmed Ressam as he crossed into the United States near Seattle.

title: Gore Attacks Bradley on Agriculture Votes and Medicare
description: Setting aside the bitter sarcasm of their previous encounters, Vice President Al Gore and former Senator Bill Bradley today made direct appeals to farmers and senior citizens, two important voting segments in Iowa, in the first of their series of debates to be held in this state.

title: Haleh Bakhash, John Warden Jr.
description: Haleh Farah Bakhash, the daughter of Haleh Esfandiari Bakhash and Shaul Bakhash of Potomac, Md., was married in Washington yesterday to John Lehman Warden Jr., a son of Mr. and Mrs. Warden of Bedford Hills, N.Y. The Rev. Margaret Graham performed the Episcopal ceremony at St. John's Church, Georgetown.

title: Residential Sales
description: In the following reports, the ''listed at'' price is the asking price when negotiations began that ended in the sale. Time on market is from the most recent listing to contract.

title: Easing Removal Of Ice
description: ANYONE who has been to a hardware store in winter knows that there are scores of products on the market designed to make ice- and snow-removal less of a backbreaking chore. But sorting through the various chemicals, compounds, combinations, concentrations and price-per-ice-melting-pound computations is better suited to a chemist with a degree in economics than to a homeowner with an inch of ice on his driveway.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KELLNER, WARREN
description: KELLNER-Warren. The family of Warren Kellner will hold a memrial service on Thursday, January 20, 2000, at 4 PM, Congreation Emanu-El of the City of New York, 5th Ave at 65th St.

title: Q&A/Lea Lane Stern; Writer Who Is a Traveler but Not a Tourist
description: DURING her three decades as a travel writer, Lea Lane Stern has seen parts of the world that look no different from what they must have looked like in the distant past and areas that have been overbuilt to accommodate tourists. She has also seen a strange mixture of old and new -- reindeer herders in Lapland with laptops and nomads in Tunisia on cell phones.

title: POSTINGS: Hell's Kitchen and Hamilton Heights; A Children's Photo Show
description: The photographs show historic row houses in Harlem's Hamilton Heights and streetscapes in Hell's Kitchen. One features a horse tied to a chain-link fence, another a fish store on Ninth Avenue. All were taken by children from low- and moderate-income families who participated in a course last summer on architecture, urban planning and, to record it all, photography.

title: Crime
description: Go. Run. Hide. Escape. The little voice that promises adventure and danger in Thomas Perry's hide-and-seek thrillers sends out another irresistible summons in BLOOD MONEY (Random House, $24.95). ''Everybody wants to go somewhere,'' says Jane Whitefield, a Seneca Indian guide who helps fugitives disappear into the wild blue yonder. But ''the only one who wants to go everywhere,'' she knows, ''is somebody who's been locked up for a long time. . . . Or a kid.''

title: Word for Word/Dylanology; Keats With a Guitar: The Times Sure Are A-Changin'
description: ANDREW MOTION, the British poet laureate, created quite the stir this fall when he hailed Bob Dylan as one of the greatest artists of the century and proclaimed ''Visions of Johanna,'' from Mr. Dylan's 1966 album ''Blonde on Blonde,'' the best song lyric ever written.

title: Political Briefing; For Bush, It's About Meeting Expectations
description: As for the Republican contest in Iowa, it seems rather bland by comparison. The Register poll published today had Gov. George W. Bush of Texas continuing to hold a comfortable lead of just under 30 points over his only serious challenger, Steve Forbes, the publisher.

title: Hewitt and Enqvist In Adelaide Final
description: The former champion Lleyton Hewitt, the hometown favorite, will play 1999 winner Thomas Enqvist of Sweden in the final today of the AAPT championships in Adelaide, Australia.

title: After a Troubled Year for Bonds, a Way to Play the Gap in Yields
description: WHEN people in the bond market talk about spread products, they don't mean peanut butter. They are referring to issues like corporate and mortgage-backed bonds that consistently yield more than United States Treasuries of the same maturity. The difference in yields is the spread, and it exists because these bonds, unlike Treasuries, are thought to pose a more-than-trivial risk of default.

title: Kadi Diallo's Trial
description: We knew her first from her grief. The sight of Kadiatou Diallo stepping from a police van last February in front of 1157 Wheeler Avenue in the Bronx, seeing the place where police officers had killed her unarmed son and helplessly crying, ''Amadou, Amadou,'' until she collapsed in the arms of other West African Muslim women in traditional robes, was a haunting spectacle, replayed endlessly on television. Her grief attached poignancy to what until that moment had simply horrified: the unbelievable fusillade of bullets mistakenly aimed at this particular dark-skinned man. It let the world know that this victim was beloved, would be missed; it focused our horror, unease and anger in the person of one small mother from a tiny nation in Africa to whom New York had done such a grievous wrong.

title: Editorial Observer; History Lessons From the Slaves of New York
description: While New Yorkers celebrated a new century, a team of biological anthropologists at Howard University in Washington were intensely focused on a most grisly aspect of New York City's past. Led by Dr. Michael Blakey, the team has spent several years examining the skeletal remains of more than 400 African slaves whose graves were accidentally uncovered during the construction of a federal office tower in lower Manhattan nine years ago.

title: Wine Advocate Says Glass Is Half Empty

title: In Defense of a Plan To Bolster Fire I. Beaches
description: Contrary to its critics, the proposed Fire Island Interim Project [''Army's Fire Island Study: Send In the Sand,'' Dec. 26] is indeed a short-term solution to erosion problems. Placement of sand on the beach can cease at any time. No groins or jetties are contemplated. The new sand will replace material lost in storms, but more importantly, it will replace sand lost in groin fields and stabilized inlets to the east.

title: Brightening a Winter Dish With a Dash of Color
description: THERE is nothing like a splash of color on the plate to brighten up food in winter. Chefs like to decorate their plates with dots and squiggles of sauces and oils, often made from herbs or vegetables. These sauces are not necessarily as complex as they look. One of the prettiest of all, a luminous green, takes seconds to make. All you do is puree chives in a blender with olive oil and a dash of salt. This makes a lovely sauce for fish or chicken and can be sprinkled over mashed potatoes. It also keeps for four or five days in the refrigerator.

Then our friends reminded us that this tucked-away space, entered from a parking lot behind Main Street, was formerly home to MacAndrew's, a hangout of the Wesleyan University crowd.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  BARBANELL
description: BARBANEll At the dawn of a new century and millenium, we respectively honor our dear departed parents...Rose & Hyman Barbanell and Rose & Nathan Siegel. Born in Poland, our parents came to America in search of a brighter future as young, single pioneers in the 1920's. Rose & Hyman met and married in New York, and raised five children. Rose & Nathan also met and married in New York, and raised three children. They worked hard and struggled financially to accomplish their goals. We, Marilyn (Barbanell) Siegel, and Harold Siegel were privileged to be amongst their offspring. As with our parents, we also met and married in New York. As a part of the first generation of Americans born to the Barbanell-Siegel families union, we have much to be thankful for...life in the greatest country in the world...two beautiful daughters...two respectful sons-inlaw...and four healthy grandchildren. As we pay tribute to our parents and their great accomplishments, we pray that future generations of our family-tree will continue to dedicate themselves to country and family. title: The Placebo Prescription
description: In the summer of 1994, a surgeon named J. Bruce Moseley found himself engaged in an elaborate form of make-believe. Moseley had 10 patients scheduled for an operation intended to relieve the arthritis pain in their knees. The patients were men -- most of them middle-aged, all former military guys -- and they weren't ready to consign themselves to the rocking chair yet. So they had decided to take a risk and volunteer for a study that must have sounded, when Moseley first told them about it, rather peculiar. All 10 would be wheeled into an operating room at the Houston Veterans Affairs Medical Center, draped, examined and anesthetized. All 10 would be dispatched to the recovery room and sent home from the hospital by the next morning equipped with crutches and a painkiller. But there the similarities ended. For while two of the men would undergo the standard arthroscopic surgery for their condition -- the scraping and rinsing of the knee joint -- and three would have the rinsing alone, five would have no recognized surgical procedure at all. Their surgery would be a placebo, an exercise in just pretend.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KINAS, HELEN YIANNARI
description: KINAS-Helen Yiannari, Dr. A prominent radiologist and longtime member of the American Medical Associaiton died Thursday morning at her home in Old Brookville, NY, following a short illness. Dr. Kinas, 72, was the wife of Arthur N. Kinas. Dr. Kinas was born in Iraklion, Crete, on June 5, 1927, a daughter of Julia Katematzoglou Yiannari of Athens, Greece, and the late George Yiannari. A 1947 graduate of the University of Athens, she received her medical degree in 1952 from that university's medical school. In 1960, Dr. Kinas received her radiologist's license from New York Polyclinical Medical School in Manhattan. Following residencies at Kings County Hospital, Brooklyn; Memorial Sloan-Kettering, Manahttan; and Long Island Jewish Community Center, Dr. Kinas joined the staff of Lincoln Hospital in the Bronx in 1963. Dr. Kinas subsequently held staff positions at Queens Hospital Center in Jamaica, NY, and at Beth Israel Medical Center in Manhattan. Most recently she was a radiologist at Women's Imaging Center of Queens, Long Island Medical Group. Over the years, Dr. Kinas was an assistant professor of radiology at several local colleges, including Albert Einstein College of Medicine, Yeshiva University, Manhattan; Mount Sinai Hospital, Manhattan, and the School of Medicine at SUNY-Stony Brook. Dr. Kinas was a member of the New York State Medical Society; Queens College Medical Society; the New York State Chapter of the American College of Radiology, and the New York Roentgen Society. In addition to her mother and husband, Dr. Kinas is survived by her sister, Elizabeth Plakides, of Athens; her children Nickolas and Louiza Moussouris Kinas, of Bronxville, NY, and a granddaughter Eleni Elizabeth Kinas. Services will be held Wednesday, at 10 AM, at Holy Trinity Greek Orthodox Church, 10 Mill Road, New Rochelle. Calling hours are Tuesday from 2-4 and 7-9, at Westchester Funeral Home, 190 Main Street, Eastchester, NY. Interment will be at Mount Hope Cemetery, Hastings-on-Hudson, NY. title: Bookend; How Our Crowd Got Lonely
description: IN an age that revels in complacency and fragmentation, viewing books as quaint artifacts on the fringe of the entertainment business, we may find it hard to recall that books ever guided national conversations in this country. Sometimes the impact on history has been direct. Upton Sinclair's 1906 polemical novel, ''The Jungle,'' galvanized public sentiment in behalf of the Pure Food and Drug Act. In the early part of the 1960's, ''The Other America,'' ''Silent Spring,'' ''The Feminine Mystique'' and ''Unsafe at Any Speed'' helped the antipoverty, environmentalist, feminist and consumer movements get under way. Sometimes books have mattered not by provoking action but by recognizing patterns, offering big interpretations of life, providing names for what, until the volumes appeared, were nothing more than vague perceptions or diffuse sentiments. A book comes out, crystallizes a fear, a knack or a hope into a big idea, a sweeping interpretation of reality that strikes a collective nerve in a large general public. As in the case of Milton Friedman's ''Capitalism and Freedom'' (1962), a book may become a handbook for a major ideological turn. Rarest of all is the book that penetrates into popular consciousness so deeply that its insights become cliches, its wisdom conventional -- to borrow a phrase devised, in fact, in one such book, ''The Affluent Society'' (1958), by John Kenneth Galbraith.

title: Books in Brief: Fiction & Poetry; More Deadly Than the Male
description: Many of the female characters in WOMEN AND OTHER ANIMALS: Stories (University of Massachusetts, $25), Bonnie Jo Campbell's ambitious collection of short stories, are desperately hungry for love or freedom -- or just a good meal. In ''Eating Aunt Victoria,'' a hugely obese woman keeps her food padlocked from her dead lover's adult live-in children and carries ''a purse the size of a roast beef.'' In ''The Perfect Lawn,'' a young man obsessed by a former classmate is seduced by her alcoholic mother, whose body ''threatened to devour not just his personal part, but all the rest of him too.'' These women live trapped in their run-down farms and cabins as if, as the mother in ''Sleeping Sickness'' puts it, they're in jail. The women long to escape their shabby dwellings, to ease or animate their impoverished lives. Instead, they drink, eat or smoke too much and are either frantically or desultorily promiscuous. The men they know are predators: absent, indifferent or casually brutal. When a man does behave kindly, as Michael does toward Gwen in ''The Fishing Dog,'' his unexpected decency cannot dispel her animal wariness. In ''Gorilla Girl,'' a 17-year-old girl finds an outlet for her ferocity by playing a gorilla in a sideshow. ''Occasionally,'' she says, ''a woman rattles with laughter or else sobs in the dark -- she has recognized, in my form, the monster of her own wasted strength.''At another point, she speaks of a pit bull that seems ''to embody the turbulence of my own corporeality.'' It's a wonderful story, despite the incongruity of a girl who growls for a living and snacks on grasshoppers addressing the reader so loftily. But there are only a few such lapses in these hard-hitting stories, which are bitter but sweetened with humor. Janet Kaye

But these days, not only the fringes of political life support it. This year, every Republican candidate but one -- Alan Keyes -- supports a version of flatness, and even the cautious George W. backs simpler, lower rates. One of Al Gore's core strengths against Bill Bradley is that he is less likely to raise taxes than his more liberal rival. Compared with 25 years ago, when pre-Reagan tax rates clobbered anyone even faintly successful, or even 16 years ago, when Walter Mondale quixotically campaigned for a fiscal hike, the tax climate may not be flat but it's surely flatter.

description: Attention all seekers of doctorates or M.B.A.'s: Don't send your applications to Gabelli University just yet. Yes, there is a Gabelli University Press. It is the publisher of ''Deals, Deals and More Deals,'' a risk-arbitrage guide just out. And there is a Gabelli (as in Mario, the money manager). But a Gabelli University? ''I don't think you'll get a Ph.D. there,'' said Regina M. Pitaro, a managing director of Gabelli Asset Management and author of the risk arbitrage book. ''I don't think Columbia has anything to worry about'' -- Columbia being where Mr. Gabelli earned his own M.B.A.

title: Corrections

title: If You're Thinking of Living In/Mountainside, N.J.; A Rural Borough of Single-Family Homes
description: THE dense concentration of retail stores and strip malls along New Jersey Route 22 turns to greenery and office buildings for 2.7 miles as the highway threads through the Union County borough of Mountainside. Under a 50-year-old zoning ordinance designed to preserve the beauty of the borough, retail services, except for restaurants and a multiplex movie theater, are banned along the highway.

title: Ideas & Trends; A Role Model for Executions

No state has executed as many people with such efficiency, yet that is exactly why Gerges Scott stopped by in September. Mr. Scott works for the Corrections Department in New Mexico, which expects in the next few months to hold its first execution in 40 years.

title: Correction

title: Resisting Those Ugly Americans; Contempt in France for U.S. Funds and Investors
description: WHEN Elf Aquitaine, France's largest oil company, surrendered last summer to a hostile takeover from a domestic rival, Elf's departing chief was rewarded with stock options worth $38 million. Not long thereafter, Michelin, the highly profitable French tire maker, announced that it would eliminate 7,500 jobs across Europe. Scarsdale high schoolers who are in the virtual yearbook or the ibook, as it is called, and who check its pages regularly for postings and updates, say they feel that they have breached a time warp of sorts, re-awakening teenage memories while forging new or renewed adult connections.

It led to the ejection of a key offensive lineman, an official getting hit in the back of the head, and an embarrassing situation in which the microphone of Referee Bob McElwee remained stuck open and he could be heard referring to one of the fighting players as ''a clown.''

title: Low Times at McKinley High
description: IT'S 1980 at McKinley High School in Michigan. A handsome young football player tells a beautiful cheerleader, ''Ashley, I love you so much it scares me,'' and they embrace. It's like a perfect moment on one of those WB teenage dramas, and it is the only such moment we will ever see on ''Freaks and Geeks.''

title: Our Towns; A Downtown Too Decaf For Starbucks

A stroll down Main Avenue reveals an ordinary, if aging, suburban downtown with a shoe repair shop, a couple of dry cleaners, a luncheonette here, a bakery there, a computer store. I presume that for Sullivan, this eliminates his need to know with respect to Donna Shalala, Janet Reno, Donna Brazile or Rosie O'Donnell. As for Ed Koch, Richard Simmons and Ricky Martin -- well, Andrew, thank goodness that you've been forthright: I'm sure they know how to get in touch with you if they're interested.

title: Children's Page Turners to Linger Over
description: THE artwork in children's literature can be worth more than a thousand words. These images can be the whole story for a young audience, while the artwork -- referred to on the dust jacket as pictures, illustrations or paintings -- also attracts adults. ''The Art of Children's Books'' is an intimate and fascinating exhibition that focuses on six artists from Hunterdon to Atlantic Counties, whose successes in the field of illustration extend well beyond New Jersey. The show was organized by Melissa Killeen, program coordinator of the Hopkins House Gallery, who acknowledged that this exhibit could easily have represented more than 20 artists as there were so many accomplished illustrators who maintain studios throughout the state.

title: An Emotional Scatchard Powers Islanders

No hurried pass-around of the hors d'oeuvres tray. No embarrassing questions about old credit card problems. And only rarely does anyone shake their hand.

Kwajewski's computer class at West Middle School in Andover, Mass., take a break from spreadsheets and word processing to do head rolls and arm stretches. And every so often, Mr. Kwajewski turns on music and the children do the chicken dance, flapping their arms like barnyard dancers at a wedding.

title: The Artistic Mind Unveiled in Letters, Illustrations and Portraits; Sketching for 'Mad,' and for Slightly More Adult Publications
description: THE scene at the Woodbury train station is grim. Panic-stricken Long Island residents are lined up to catch the next train out of town. Others are boarding planes, helicopters and even air balloons to escape the terror from the sky: giant red tomatoes that hover overhead. But there's no need to worry. This scenario is just a page from ''Tomatoes From Mars,'' a children's book by Arthur Yorinks that tells the story of alien tomatoes that threaten to cover the United States in sauce. The book is skillfully illustrated by Mort Drucker, who is best known for his humorous caricatures of celebrities in Mad magazine.

title: For Bradley, Innovative Money Train
description: Last summer, Adrienne Arsht, chairwoman of TotalBank in Miami, read Bill Bradley's book, ''Values of the Game.'' A fan of women's sports, Ms. Arsht liked what Mr. Bradley, a former New York Knick, had to say about teamwork, discipline and responsibility. So she volunteered to help his insurgent campaign for president.

title: Bedside Story
description: Movies like ''A Christmas Carol'' and ''It's a Wonderful Life'' have sentimental endings designed to create ersatz feelings of good will in the holiday season. None, however, can emulate the spirit and determination of Jack Cutler. The painful ordeal of this child has taught us all the true lesson of the season -- and of life.

title: Books in Brief: Nonfiction; Horton Saves the World
description: Before Theodor Seuss Geisel became Dr. Seuss, teller of inventive tall tales for children, he spent 17 years writing advertising copy for a bug spray, then became a political cartoonist for the liberal publication PM from 1941 to 1943. Richard H. Minear, a professor of history at the University of Massachusetts, Amherst, has chosen 200 cartoons, about half of those Geisel drew, for a fascinating collection, DR. SEUSS GOES TO WAR: The World War II Editorial Cartoons of Theodor Seuss Geisel (New Press, $25). Most take aim at Hitler, Mussolini and unnamed Japanese leaders. Franklin D. Roosevelt, whom Geisel admired, is neither depicted nor mentioned in Minear's excellent text. But Charles A. Lindbergh, whose isolationism offended Geisel, is second only to Hitler in appearances. Some cartoons are funny and others vitriolic. And, as Minear writes, one at least is regrettable: it depicts Geisel's agreement that Japanese-Americans should be incarcerated during the war. The book is divided into four sections -- ''The Home Front,'' ''History and Nazi Germany,'' ''The Rest of the World'' and ''Winning the War.'' The cartoonist Art Spiegelman writes in the introduction that ''one of the great pleasures of this collection of drawings . . . is the affirmation of just how good the good Doctor really was. . . . He called 'em as he saw 'em, and most of the time he was on the side of the angels.'' Peggy Constantine

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MURPHY, EDMOND C.
description: MURPHY-Edmond C. Age 79, of Baldwin, NY, died Friday, January 7. Beloved husband of the late Blanche Murphy and devoted father of three children and seven grandchildren. Dear brother of Patricia and Richard. Distinguished career as Chief Clerk of Family Court for City of New York. Highly respected college basketball official and former President of the American Association of Basketball Officials. An avid golfer, he will be remembered for sharp wit, compassion for others and devotion to his family. Friends may visit at Vanella's Funeral Chapel, 2860 Long Beach Rd., Oceanside, NY, on Sunday, January 9, 2-5 PM, and 7-9 PM. A Mass of Christian Burial will be held on Monday, January 10, at St. Christopher's, Merrick Rd, Baldwin, NY, at 10:30 AM. Interment at St. Charles Cemetery, Farmingdale, NY. Contributions in his memory may be made to the Alzheimer's Association, 919 North Michigan Ave., Suite 1000, Chicago, IL 60611-1676.

description: GRADY-William J. of Chatham Twp, NJ on January 7, 2000. Husband of the late Shirley Jean Grady. Father of Kathy Grady and her husband Alan Godchaux of New Orleans, LA, Mike Grady and his wife Margaret of Chatham, NJ and Trisha Grady and her husband Richard Lieberman of Sunnyside, NY. Brother of Ben Grady of O'Neill, NE and Jack Grady of Washington, DC. Also survived by his grandchildren: Sara and Madeline Godchaux, Morgan Lieberman and Zachary, Nicole, and Samuel Grady. title: Nietzsche and Math, Together Again
description: In the latest effort to convert the mathematically squeamish, Dartmouth College has developed a new program, ''Math Across the Curriculum,'' that integrates the subject into some very unlikely places -- art and literature, for example.

title: And Baby Makes Friends
description: ONE recent day at La Guardia Airport, travel was disrupted by the unauthorized landing of a jumbo diaper bag. It fell from the stack of luggage in my son's stroller, which I'd been pushing along the corridor to our plane. The rest of the stack quickly followed: his car seat, my carry-on bag, a shopping bag, assorted jackets. Desperate to retrieve everything, I dropped to my knees with baby David strapped to my chest. What had I been thinking, taking him on this trip without my husband? Behind us waited dozens of New York commuters -- not a famously patient breed. I braced for the worst.

title: History: the Condensed Version
description: In his introduction to ''Souper Tomatoes,'' (Rutgers University Press, $24) Andrew F. Smith writes that he set out to confirm the story that ''Robert Gibbon Johnson ate the first tomato in America on the courthouse steps of Salem, N.J.'' to prove the fruit was not poisonous. Didn't happen, Mr. Smith found. Nonetheless he became consumed with tomatoes, writing books on the history of the tomato in America and of ketchup in America. His third tomato tome, on tbe history of tomato soup in America, will appear in bookstores this month. Not surprisingly, the Garden State figures in much of that story, especially with the development of condensed soup by the Campbell Preserve Company in 1897. Mr. Smith goes on to discuss the marketing of tomato soup, the breeding of soup tomatoes, the establishment of tomato soup as American icon (Andy Warhol's mother served him tomato soup for lunch for 20 years), and finishes with a collection of old recipes. ''Take a dozen unpealed tamatas,'' begins an 1846 recipe for Tamata Soup.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KRASNE, CHARLES J.
description: KRASNE-Charles J. On January 6th after a long illness and a brave fight. Loving husband of Mickey (Marie-Rose) nee Kramer for 49 years. Devoted father of Robert A. and Andrew S. Krasne. Dear brother of Margo T. Krasne. Chuck Krasne was the youngest Naval Officer to serve in the Pacific in World War II. A graduate of the Wharton School of the University of Pennsylvania. For more than 20 years Mr. Krasne headed the largest agency for Connecticut Mutual Life Insurance Company. During his leadership the Krasne Agency was the first to produce $100 million of insurance in one year. Mr. Krasne and his associates were repeatedly recognized with top awards for their outstanding performance. Memorial service at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81 Street, Sunday at 3:30 PM. In lieu of flowers contributions in his memory may be made to MDS, P.O. Box 477, 464 Main St, Crosswicks, NJ 08515

In the final minutes, though, he shed the suit jacket, even as his team pushed ahead, because that's what head coaches do.

description: WESTCHESTER taxes were reduced in the county's 2000 budget, but taxpayers in three municipalities may be seeing a property tax increase anyway.

title: What's Doing In; Atlanta
description: This time last year, Atlantans harbored fantasies that Super Bowl XXXIV would be just another home game for their red-hot Atlanta Falcons. The Falcons, one of the National Football League's least successful franchises, had finally put together a season to remember, featuring their ''Dirty Bird'' end-zone dances and a trip to the 1999 Super Bowl, which they lost to the Denver Broncos.

description: Officials, health workers and nightclub owners have been arguing for months over developing a municipal policy to get the denizens of the freewheeling night life mecca here to obtain and use condoms.

title: It's Sound, It's Art, and Some Call It Music
description: WHEN the performance art genre appeared in the 1970's, the playwright and novelist William Hogeland commented cynically, ''We already have a performance art: it's called 'theater.' '' One could similarly dismiss the term ''sound art'' as just a vaguely glorified name for weird music. And yet ''sound art'' has served as a useful historical euphemism, a safe harbor for works too outre for the ever-conservative classical music world.

title: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: NEW YORK UP CLOSE; The Face of Hunger Changes, With More Families at Soup Kitchens
description: On a typical Saturday afternoon, 200 people line the sidewalks at Ninth Street and Avenue C in the East Village, where a soup kitchen hands out groceries and hot lunches. Most are homeless men. But mingled with them are about 40 children and their mothers, also waiting for their daily meal.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  NECKMAN, ARNOLD
description: NECKMAN - Arnold Samuel. Passed away at his home in Hollywood, FL January 1, 2000 shortly after his 67th birthday. Husband to his great love of 50 years Shelley. Beloved father of Chuck, Steven and Beth. Loving grandfather of Andrew, David and Allison. He will surely be missed. Arnold was born in the Bronx, educated at the Peddie School and Tufts Univ. He established himself as a builder and contractor in the northeast and in Florida before entering the retail business with his son. After many years on the water, he became an avid golfer. Of his many successes, he was proudest of his children and gained his greatest joy from his family and close friends. He will be remembered by all as a gentleman and a gentle man.

description: LEEDS-Evelyn. On January 5, 2000. Beloved mother of Joel and Arthur. Cherished grandmother of Jonathan, Jason and Kate. Loving sister of Murray and Harriet.

description: Bishop James Stuart Wetmore, the longest serving suffragan bishop of the Episcopal Diocese of New York and a staunch advocate of ecumenism, died Dec. 28 at the Lutheran Care Center in Poughkeepsie, N.Y. A resident of Millbrook, N.Y., he was 84.

(Moshe) Green, who held leadership positions on the boards of YU and its affiliated Rabbi Isaac Elchanan Theological Seminary. Mr. and Mrs. Green furthered a variety of programs at the University. title: ART; 20 Photographic Portraits Denote a Generation of Artists
description: THE exhibition of 20 portrait photographs by Richard Leslie Schulman is titled ''Generations of Artists,'' but the emphasis is heavily on the older generation, which is appropriate, for it is at the Hebrew Home for the Aged here.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MARKS, EDWARD L.
description: MARKS-Edward L. 85 of Palm Beach, FL and Woodmere, NY on January 5. Loving father of Steven and Patty, grandfather of Spencer and the late Alison, brother of Marjorie, Robert and Melvin. He leaves behind and outstanding career of creative leadership in the menswear retail industry. He will be remembered for his charity, compassion, understanding and wonderful sense of humor . He lived each day to the fullest and will be greatly missed.

title: The Idyllic Isle of Staten
description: A STATEN ISLAND of green hills, pastures, lakes and streams is what you will find in ''Another Country: 19th-Century Staten Island Landscape Paintings,'' opening Saturday at the Staten Island Institute of Arts and Sciences. The watercolor shown above by Henry Farrer shows Prince's Bay at sunset in 1875. It is one of more than 25 works taken from the institute's permanent collection and from other collections. There are views of the Alice Austen House, the Vanderbilt farm and the quarantine station. Many of the works depict the rural simplicity of an era when figures like Cornelius Vanderbilt, the industrialist, and Daniel D. Tompkins, who was vice president under President James Monroe, went to Staten Island to escape Manhattan's congestion.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CURSON, ALFRED I.
description: CURSON-Alfred I. age 77 years, after having waged a successful (sic) battle against cancer, died unexpectedly Friday at 12:30pm. His life was one of a Jewish American success story which included fighting in WWII and the 1948 Israel war of independence. He is survived by his wife Ruth and son Marshall and will be missed by all who knew him. Services Sunday 12:30pm at ''Temple Beth-El of Great Neck'', 5 Old Mill Rd.

title: Prime Meats in Seaford at Budget Prices
description: UNTIL now the territory between blue-ribbon steakhouses like Bryant and Cooper and the red-meat chain operations like Outback was arid country. Then about five months ago the Gold Angus Grille appeared at 3935 Merrick Road in Seaford (516-409-0505) and everything changed. The Gold Angus is that rarest of birds, a restaurant that serves large portions of quality steaks, chops, chicken and seafood at budget prices. The biggest bargain of all is the $14.95 every-night dinner. It consists of a choice of four appetizers -- portobello mushrooms, pasta bascaiolla, grilled calamari or roasted peppers and mozzarella; five entrees -- 14-ounce sirloin steak, 6 lamb chops, a mixed grill of filet mignon, pork chop and chicken, salmon and prime ribs of beef or snapper oreganato -- as well as potatoes (steak fries or mashed), green beans and a salad.

title: Ideas & Trends; Leif to Lars: Drop Dead, Neighbor!
description: TO the untrained observer, Swedes and Norwegians (a.k.a. the Olsons and the Olsens) may seem interchangeable. Both are prosperous, blue-eyed and reserved. On the world stage, they hand out peace prizes and preach global cooperation while saving their aggressions, if any, for the ski slope.

title: The Turmoil Behind the Screen at Value America
description: NAGGING question lingers as one new Internet company after another bursts into public view, offering glittering Web sites, charismatic founders, innovative business models, surging sales and soaring stocks. What, exactly, is going on behind the screen?

title: New York City Weather: A Century-Long Warming Trend
description: Over the century just departed, the earth became warmer, with the average global surface temperature rising by about one degree Fahrenheit. The world is five to nine degrees warmer now than during the depth of the last ice age 18,000 to 20,000 years ago.

title: Traffic Deaths in 1999 Reported at a 20-Year Low
description: There were 713 traffic fatalities in the state in 1999, a 20-year low, according to the State Police. The 713 deaths were 3.8 percent below the 741 in 1998, and the third consecutive decrease. Fatalities had reached a high in 1981 with 1,160.

title: Bid to Reclaim 'Lost Park' Shows Even Traffic Islands Can Turn Green
description: Along the bustling byways of America, traffic islands often amount to little more than concrete or asphalt patches. But in New York, even such an inglorious piece of real estate can be haunted by the ghosts of former incarnations: a flower market, a public square, a verdant park designed by a famous architect.

title: Williams and Saints Disagree

It's understandable. He went through the Saints' terrible three-victory season. He said he was treated poorly, at times, by Coach Mike Ditka, and it turned out that his rookie contract with the Saints was so one-sided in favor of the team that he might try to restructure it.

title: On the Road Again
description: Whether transferring within or between companies, today's workers are finding that the moving vans are often at their doors, the rented trailers regularly hitched to their cars. Mishaps - in packing and moving out, in traveling, and in finding, fixing up and moving into new lodgings - are inevitable. What has been your best, worst or most remarkable experience? Send your stories to On the Job, Money & Business, The New York Times, 229 West 43rd Street, New York, N.Y. 10036. Or send them by e-mail to onthejob@nytimes.com. Include your name and telephone number. All submissions become the property of The Times and may be republished in any medium.

title: In a Mood for Winter Wondering
description: LONG ISLANDERS are deeply committed to a catastrophic view of life. As the millennium demonstrated, we love preparing for disasters that will never happen. Now we have a thousand years to wait for the next round of millennial hysteria, we need something else to worry about. And here it is, right on cue, winter.

title: Aristocrat, Democrat and Suffering Wife
description: TO her admirers, she was manna from heaven, an unwavering voice for the downtrodden and oppressed. To her detractors, she was a dangerous meddler, a dilettante, a traitor to her class. On one point, however, these opponents shared the same view: for more than 30 years, Eleanor Roosevelt was the most powerful woman in America.

title: What's in A Name: The Allure Of Labels
description: AMERICANS spent an estimated record $185 billion this holiday season, on dolls and games, sneakers, power tools and skateboards. In effect, they bought brands.

title: The Shepherdstown 'Slows': Can Clinton Prevail?
description: From hilltops in this pre-Civil War town where Israel and Syria have negotiated all week, you can just make out the farm across the Potomac River where Abraham Lincoln met Gen. George B. McClellan in a tent and complained that he suffered from ''the slows'' after the battle of Antietam.

title: TRAVEL ADVISORY: Correspondent's Report; New Life in London's Financial District
description: NO matter how expensive it becomes, how snarled its traffic or how seedy its public transportation, London just keeps on pulling in the crowds, especially to the central areas most beloved of visitors -- the West End, for instance, and the well-trodden routes that lead from museums to monuments.

title: POSTINGS: 20-Story Rental Between Second and First Avenues; Factory-Built Facade on 38th St.
description: The Montrose, a 20-story luxury rental building just beginning to peer above its excavation site on East 38th Street, will offer some unusual architectural features when it is completed, probably by the fall -- tile and aluminum panels to create the facade and a cantilivered wing over an adjacent building.

title: Political Briefing; Playing Name Game In Illinois Race
description: Since Representative John Edward Porter, Republican of Illinois, announced he was giving up his 10th District seat on the state's North Shore, only one Democrat has expressed interest in replacing him. But on the Republican side, at least a dozen hopefuls have surfaced.

title: Forget That Midnight Buffet
description: Taking a cruise to follow a diet may seem like a study in conflicting purposes. But on Holland America's Ryndam from March 4 to 11, Kat James, a fashion and beauty consultant, will conduct a weeklong version of her beauty program called Total Transformation, a regimen that includes a low-glycemic diet as well as motivational workshops and consultations. The cruise, including the program, starts at $1,709 a person, double occupancy. It leaves from Fort Lauderdale and calls at Grand Cayman, Playa del Carmen and Key West. Call Cruises of Value: (800) 247-8984.

title: Looking for Cupid at the Heart of a Renaissance Show
description: A SCHOLARLY show that couches a detective story, albeit one of a rarified kind, is being played out on the fourth floor of the Yale University Art Gallery in New Haven. Visitors who pay close attention -- and there is really no other profitable way to look at this exhibition -- might feel momentary frustration when they realize that no definite solution is arrived at, but they will have had an enriching experience that is the complete opposite of a fast look.

Service on Sunday, 11:15 AM, at ''The Riverside'', 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: BackTalk; Jets' New Owner Will Climb Over Mountains For Parcells
description: All those early American Football League club owners must be chuckling. They remember chipping in a few thousand dollars to save the Jets' ancestors, the New York Titans, when the players' paychecks from the original owner, Harry Wismer, were bouncing higher than the Polo Grounds' roof. Now, nearly four decades later, the Jets' franchise is about to be bought for more than $600 million.

title: Evelyn Dooley, Samuel Seidman
description: Dr. Evelyn Patricia Dooley and Samuel N. Seidman are to be married today at the University Club in Manhattan. Msgr. Joseph Zammit will officiate, with Rabbi Charles D. Lippman taking part in the ceremony.

title: Turning Circles and Squares Into Noise
description: THE 20th century was, in musical terms, a noisy one. I don't mean loud or even discordant, the customary complaints of audiences encountering new music, whether Igor Stravinsky's ''Rite of Spring,'' John Coltrane's ''Ascension'' or Jimi Hendrix's Woodstock rendition of the national anthem. I'm referring, rather, to the way that 20th-century composers have embraced sounds -- environmental, industrial, often random -- and thereby laid siege to inherited notions of musical order. If last century's avant-garde taught us anything, it is that such disturbances can be the stuff of art.

title: Plaid Tidings
description: The signature Burberry beige-and-red plaid, often seen lining trench coats, has come out of hiding to become a fashion force on the outside of winter coats for both women and their pets. The British tailor Thomas Burberry, who opened his shop in the mid-19th century, specialized in waterproof gaberdine overcoats lined in the distinctive plaid. Today, it is on everything from wallets to ball gowns.

title: A Garden Full of Furniture, A House Full of Plants
description: The summer before David Protell went to college, he worked for a landscape architect. In the years since then, he has opened Chelsea Garden Store at 207 Ninth Avenue (at 22nd Street), Chelsea Garden Center East at 321 Bowery (at Second Street), and most recently, on Dec. 1, Chelsea Garden Center Home at 435 Hudson Street (at Morton Street).

title: A Visionary Who Deserves a Fuller Portrait
description: CRADLE WILL ROCK,'' Tim Robbins's hectic try for an epic film treatment of the brief rise and sudden fall of the Federal Theater Project, ends on what is meant to be a rousing note: the premiere of Marc Blitzstein's 1937 opera, which gives the movie its name. After the work's opening was censored by Washington, ostensibly as part of cutbacks in financing, the first-night New York audience of several hundred journeyed 21 blocks uptown along with Orson Welles and John Houseman, that formidable director-producer team, from a padlocked theater to a bare one, where Blitzstein, alone at a beat-up piano, occupied the stage, while cast members, ordered by Equity not to set foot behind the footlights, rendered their lines from seats in the orchestra.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BORNSTEIN, LEAH
description: BORNSTEIN-Leah. Of Berkeley, CA. at 82, peacefully left this life December 30, 1999 surrounded by her children. She is also survived by Thelma and Sylvan Moskowitz of NJ and Al Zablow of NY.

title: Regulating Dietary Supplements
description: The dietary supplement industry, freed from strict regulation by the 1994 Dietary Supplement Health and Education Act, has made a vast variety of herbal remedies as readily available on supermarket shelves as ordinary vitamins. Millions of consumers now take supplements, like ginkgo, kava and St. John's wort, that were largely unknown in mainstream markets even a few years ago. Although some research suggests that some supplements can produce positive health effects, there have also been cases where people have been made ill by supplements, or their conditions have become worse while they tried to use ineffective dietary supplements to treat a medical disease.

title: The Quiet Battle for Congress
description: As the presidential contest heads toward the showdowns in Iowa and New Hampshire, the battle to control Congress is shaping up with considerably less attention from the public. That is understandable, since only about 30 of the 435 campaigns for House seats are expected to be close. Yet even in this early phase, the Congressional election offers some important clues about the public mood and the hopes and fears of party leaders. Democrats, convinced they have a good chance of recapturing the House, plan a series of confrontations this year on health care, education and other issues. House Republicans, the onetime revolutionaries, are trying to soften their contentious image. Last week they even dropped their tried-and-true strategy of pushing sweeping tax cuts as the centerpiece of their electoral approach.

title: Reinventing the Variable Annuity, With More Bells and Whistles
description: BRUCE JONES is holding forth in a small conference room in the John Hancock tower in downtown Boston, talking about new features of a product that receives a lot of negative comment from experts -- variable annuities. Among other benefits, the annuities may now offer guaranteed returns, even in market downturns, and money for nursing home care.

title: John Low Baldwin, 76, Conductor of the University Glee Club

title: Rivera's Thirds Count for a Lot
description: Short relievers are a relatively new phenomenon in baseball, a result of the evolution of the manner in which starting pitchers have been used. It has been only 31 years since the rule for determining saves was defined. But in the coming season, a statistical standard seemingly possible only for starters may be challenged by a reliever.

That's what happened, however. I found it quite wondrous, because in earlier years the same shrubs had sailed through unremitting spring rains.

title: Ossining Fire
description: A Dec. 30 fire in Ossining Village that left 300 people homeless was caused by a faulty extension cord, and it spread because of a 15-minute delay before 911 was called, Chief Bruce Goble of the Ossining Fire Department said last week.

Suddenly, this redoubtable 35-year-old seems everywhere on CD, capturing the interest of music lovers throughout Europe and America. And though some mavens have demurred, the hype has been buttressed by albums remarkable for both artistic quality and repertorial variety.

She has planted 1,200 peach trees on a 10-acre plot along Montauk Highway, creating a retail niche with the only peach orchard in the area.

title: No More Hurricane Carters

Mr. Carter's unjust 1966 conviction for a triple murder in New Jersey was reversed by a federal court in 1985, he was released from prison, and he moved to Canada, where he now works to free others wrongly convicted of crimes. One of his saviors was a young teenager, Lesra Martin, who read Mr. Carter's jailhouse autobiography, became convinced of his innocence, and marshaled help.

title: No, They Didn't Take Away That Hall's Lovely Sound

But it has just undergone an ambitious 22-month, $36.7 million restoration and expansion that included a complete reconfiguring of the stage. title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CARPENTER, RALPH, T. REV., CSP.
description: CARPENTER-Ralph, T. Rev., CSP. On January 8, 2000, in San Francisco at age 88. Born in Olean, NY, he was ordained a Paulist priest on March 25, 1944. Father Carpenter spent 10 summers serving in trailer mission work throughout Tennessee. He served at Good Shepherd parish in NY and as procurator at both Sts. Peter and Paul, formation houses for the training of aspiring Paulists. During that period he was Community Vice President. His base of operations moved to Saint Paul the Apostle parish, Los Angeles, in 1968, then on to hospital chaplain work at UC San Diego. Father Carpenter served for six years as State Chaplain for the Catholic Adult Clubs of California which had its center where the Paulists have served for over 100 years, Old Saint Mary's in San Francisco. Thousands of the center's alumni worldwide recall the friendly atmosphere that brought them to a full understanding and appreciation of their Catholic faith. On Tuesday, January 11, 2000, a wake will be held at Old Saint Mary's Cathedral, 660 California St, San Francisco, CA, from mid-morning until a vigil service at 7:30 PM. His Funeral Mass will be celebrated at 10 AM, on Wednesday at Old Saint Mary's. Burial will be at Holy Cross Cemetery.
