title: Mr. Clinton's Land Legacy
description: Having lost to Ronald Reagan in the 1980 elections, Jimmy Carter was more or less on his way out the door when, on Dec. 2 of that year, he signed the Alaska Lands Act, protecting 100 million acres of Alaskan wilderness from commercial development. The act remains one of Mr. Carter's proudest achievements. Like Mr. Carter, President Clinton now finds himself headed for the exit, with one more year as a lame-duck president burdened by a hostile Congress. Yet he may find the legacy he seeks and needs just where Mr. Carter found it -- in the preservation of the American landscape.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KRENTS, MILTON
description: KRENTS-Milton. The American Jewish Committee is deeply saddened by the death of Milton Krents, a beloved colleague whose career with AJC began in 1937 and spanned more than four decades. Milton served as Director of Radio and Television and, in 1969, established and directed AJC's William E. Wiener Oral History Library until his retirement in 1977, when his wife Irma became the Library's Coordinator. Milton remained as a consultant to the Library until 1986. A unique treasure under his loving guidance, the Library transcribed nearly 2000 memoirs, recording the 20th Century American Jewish experience through the recollections of those who had contributed, directly or indirectly, to the evolution of American Jewish life. In 1990, AJC donated the collection to the New York Public Library where it is housed in its Jewish Division. We send our heartfelt condolences to Irma, his children and grandchildren. David A. Harris, Exec. Director Shulamith Bahat, Assoc. Exec. Dir.

title: SCHLUMBERGER TO TAKE $113 MILLION CHARGE
description: Schlumberger Ltd., the second-biggest oil-service company, said yesterday that it would take fourth-quarter charges totaling $113 million, including $50 million for costs of the spinoff and merger of its Sedco Forex unit. Another $37 million will cover costs of revamping its land-drilling operation, and $26 million will pay for reducing its seismic fleet. Schlumberger needs to cut costs after merging Sedco Forex, its offshore drilling business, with Transocean Offshore Inc. on Dec. 31, analysts said. Schlumberger, which has headquarters in New York and Paris, is expected to earn 23 cents a share in the quarter, according to analysts polled by First Call/Thomson Financial. It earned 50 cents a year earlier.

title: CAROLINA FIRST AGREES TO ACQUIRE ANCHOR FINANCIAL
description: The Carolina First Corporation agreed yesterday to acquire the Anchor Financial Corporation for $300 million in stock. The transaction, expected to close in the spring, will result in creation of a new holding company to be called the South Financial Group. Based on Carolina First's closing price on Friday, the deal values each Anchor share at $35.89. Anchor Financial stock changed hands at $31.9375, up $5.8125, in Nasdaq trading, where Carolina First slipped 93.75 cents, to $15.5625. Carolina First, based in Greenville, S.C., has 75 banking offices in South Carolina and Florida. Anchor Financial, of Myrtle Beach, S.C., has 33 banking offices in South Carolina and North Carolina.

description: FISHER-H. Ray passed away January 7, 2000 surrounded with love. He was born January 27, 1959 in Lancaster, Pennsylvania. Ray was an enormously talented man with an innate sense of style. He was also a beautiful human being inside and out. He was meticulous, insightful and a relentless perfectionist. He balanced it all with a mischievious sense of humor. He had a soft spot for children and animals, both of whom always gravitated toward him. His curiosity about people and places led him to travel the world. He soaked up beauty like a sponge wherever he went. He was profoundly affected by Bali which will be, in accordance with his wishes, his final resting place. Those who wish to make a gesture in his behalf may make a contribution to the ASPCA. Ray is survived by his mother, Bertha Cassler; sisters, Helen Wagner, June Kohl, Karen Winter, Kathy Marshall; brothers, Ronnie and Gary Cassler; and his extended family, Tyler, Harley, and John Thomas.

title: Coping With Teacher Shortages
description: Educators have been warning for years that the country would face a crippling teacher shortage unless it raised teacher salaries and attracted fresh talent to the profession. But as the Secretary of Education, Richard W. Riley, noted in Washington Sunday, the country has fallen so short of qualified teachers that ''schools have been forced to put any warm body in front of the classroom.'' Faced with public outrage over failing schools -- and the need to fill more than two million teacher vacancies over the next 10 years -- the states, Congress and the presidential candidates are floating proposals to attract more people to the profession. The problem will require a great deal more resourcefulness.

title: Conservationists Win Battles but Fear War Is Lost
description: The peregrine falcon, California condor, American alligator and bald eagle pull back from the brink of extinction. Governments and conservation groups cut deals with private landowners -- and buy more and more land outright -- in a drive to save the natural landscape or at least preserve its essence. Once-putrid rivers and streams are restored to health. Vanished ecosystems are reassembled and brought back to life. Keystone predators like wolves are restored to the wild.

title: Woman and Boyfriend Sentenced in Girl's Death
description: A Bronx woman and her boyfriend were sentenced to 25 years to life in prison yesterday for the murder of Sabrina Green, a 9-year-old girl who was beaten, burned and wasted by gangrene in her final weeks.

title: TELSTRA TO BUY OZEMAIL
description: Australia's largest telecommunications concern, the Telstra Corporation, plans to buy all the residential Internet service provider assets of OzEmail Ltd., a unit of the telecommunications giant MCI WorldCom, for about $196 million. The Australian Competition and Consumer Commission said it would closely examine the proposed acquisition. Analysts said a number of Australian Internet concerns are likely to oppose the takeover bid as anticompetitive. OzEmail is Australia's No. 2 Internet service provider, trailing only Telstra. MCI WorldCom's UUNet Holdings paid $322.8 million for OzEmail in February. The company's consumer operations were separated and called OzEmail Internet in mid-1999.

title: One Bronx School Will Close as State Adds 24 to Its List of Poor Performers
description: The state's education commissioner announced yesterday that he was placing 24 more schools on a list of poorly performing schools, and said that he would close and reorganize one such school in the Bronx.

title: Review/Fashion; In Milan, a 'Fight Club' Mood, But Real Men Suit Up
description: Last fall, back in the 1900's, America had a talk about men. Were they suffering a collective loss of self-worth, as Susan Faludi argued in her book ''Stiffed: The Betrayal of the American Male''? Had the shallowness of contemporary culture robbed men of any sense of real masculinity beyond stylish posturing? Are these the reasons the world is now stuck with Maxim magazine?

title: Gore Presides Over Rare Security Council Debate on AIDS
description: Vice President Al Gore, presiding over an unusual Security Council session called to debate the AIDS crisis in Africa, said today that the United States would add $150 million to next year's budget to help combat that and other infectious diseases in the poorest countries.

title: Software Company Sold
description: Primus Knowledge Solutions Inc., which makes software for online customer service, agreed today to buy the closely held 2order.com Inc. for $90 million in stock, gaining a product to help shoppers use the Internet. Additional terms were not disclosed. Primus, based in Seattle, develops software that gives customers access to information about products and services online and over the telephone. The Atlanta-based 2order.com creates software that acts as a personal assistant to Internet shoppers. Primus shares rose 6.875 cents, to $36.75, on Nasadaq.

description: President Clinton plans to announce on Tuesday a $1.28 billion emergency aid program for Colombia to help that country fight the growing narcotics trade and to prop up its democracy over the next two years, a senior administration official said today.

title: 'Extreme' Cosmic Images Start Flashing Into View; Telescopes Use X-Ray Vision To View Hearts of Galaxies
description: Deep-space phenomena that emit X-rays are the cosmic equivalent of extreme sports. Electromagnetic waves that are thousands of times more energetic than the visible and ultraviolet light given off by lazy nebulas and placidly burning stars, and invisible to the naked eye, X-rays stream from gigantic explosions, matter smashing together at nearly the speed of light, and gases so hot that they cannot be detected with ordinary telescopes. If the visible universe is a relaxing bridge match, its X-ray counterpart is sky surfing from 30,000 feet.

title: Emerson Is Selling a Unit

BI Technologies is a unit of Emerson's Astec International Holdings Ltd. and makes electronic components, including resistors, automotive sensors and inductors. TT Group, which is based in Surrey, England, makes navigation and air-conditioning systems.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROSE, O. ALAN
description: ROSE-O. Alan, M.D., age 90, died on January 10, 2000 at Lenox Hill Hospital. He leaves behind his beloved wife Frances of over 50 years and also his loving daughter Susan and two grandsons. He was a graduate of Yale University and Columbia College of Physicians and Surgeons and one-time President of its Alumni Association. Following his internship, he did research in cardiovascular drugs at the New York University College of Medicine. This was interrupted by WW II in which he served with Lenox Hill Hospital Unit for three years. On his return, he devoted himself to teaching and to the practice of medicine and cardiology until days before his death. He was an Associate Professor of Clinical Medicine at the New York University College of Medicine. He was devoted to three generations of patients and they to him. He was a man of wide interest and loved beautiful things, views, photography, sailing and music. He sang and travelled with the Yale Glee Club. Above all, he loved life. title: Potentially Big Effect Seen on Varied Units Of AOL Time Warner

title: VIGNETTE, A SOFTWARE MAKER, TO BUY DATASAGE
description: The Vignette Corporation, a maker of software to manage Web site content, agreed to buy the closely held DataSage Inc. for about $553.6 million in stock to add software that personalizes electronic-commerce transactions. The company, based in Austin, Tex., said it would exchange 3.16 million of its shares for DataSage, which is based in Reading, Mass. It expects to take charges in the first and second quarters. Vignette said the acquisition should help it get a larger portion of the electronic-business software market. Vignette's shares rose $14.6875 each, to $189.875, in Nasdaq trading. The company first sold shares to the public in February at $19 each.

title: The Biggest Media Merger Yet

Their proposed marriage will be the largest corporate merger in history. The implications of this merger are big too, for the way stocks are valued, for the way information services reach consumers, and perhaps for the way entertainment, politics and journalism evolve in a 21st-century corporate environment.

title: McKESSON HBOC TO SELL WATER UNIT TO DANONE

The McKesson Water Products Company is the third-largest distributor of bottled water in the United States, with brands that include Crystal and Alhambra. Shares of McKesson HBOC, based in San Francisco, jumped $3 each to $27. With brands including Evian and Dannon Natural Spring Water, Danone is the world's second-largest bottled water distributor behind the Swiss food giant Nestle S.A. The shares of the French company that are traded on the New York Stock Exchange fell 43.75 cents, to $48.25.

title: Sports of The Times; Uncertainty Comes With New Owner
description: THIRTY-ONE years ago today, an upstart team from an upstart league in a relatively new event called the Super Bowl shook the sports world with one of the great upsets in pro football history. The New York Jets of the American Football League upset the heavily favored Baltimore Colts, 16-7, in Super Bowl III at the Orange Bowl in Miami.

title: COUNTEROFFER MADE FOR ESAT
description: As had been expected, British Telecommunications P.L.C. said it would acquire Ireland's second-largest telephone company, Esat Telecom Group P.L.C., for $2.46 billion in cash, rescuing it from a hostile bid from Telenor of Norway. Telenor's bid totaled $1.9 billion. The British telephone company's foray into Ireland would give it a foothold in a country where telephone usage, especially mobile phone use, is exploding. British Telecom said it would pay $100 per Esat American depository receipt, 6 percent over the closing price on Monday. Andrew Ross Sorkin

title: Rice Is Set to Play In Garden Feature
description: Instead of being stuffed with major college prospects, it now has three. Instead of pummeling every opponent, it has shown its vulnerability by losing two games.

title: PINOCHET IS RULED UNFIT FOR A TRIAL AND MAY BE FREED
description: Britain declared tonight that Gen. Augusto Pinochet was medically unfit to stand trial in Spain and that it was now inclined to abandon the extradition case against him.

title: Nackey Scripps Loeb, 75, Former Newspaper Publisher
description: Nackey Scripps Loeb, former publisher of two influential conservative newspapers, The Union Leader and The New Hampshire Sunday News of Manchester, N.H., died on Saturday at her home in Goffstown, N.H. She was 75.

title: DeVry Gives Career Training the Old College Try
description: A knit cap on his head, his long legs encased in baggy jeans, Issan Duke was perched on a stool in the computer laboratory at the DeVry Institute of Technology, an upstart college in Long Island City, Queens, that believes it has created a practical and efficient form of career-oriented liberal arts education.

title: A Crackdown Is Promised By Hong Kong
description: Alarmed by a surge of smuggling in which Chinese migrants are carried to the United States and Canada in the containers of cargo ships, Hong Kong pledged today to crack down.

title: Novell Plans to Move Its Domestic Account
description: Novell Inc., the software company, is moving its domestic account to Sicola Martin in Austin, Tex., from the San Francisco office of Young & Rubicam Advertising. Billings were estimated at $20 million.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FELSHIN, DOROTHY
description: FELSHIN-Dorothy. Died January 2, 2000. Beloved mother of Annie O'Neill of Gardiner, NY, and Nina Felshin of NYC, and cherished wife of the late Seon.

title: The Big City; St. Francis Had It Easy In the Forest
description: PIGEONS have been much in the news, which is gratifying to those of us who see their inner beauty, but as usual the publicity is a little awkward, too. It brings up that ethical quandary that has been troubling urbanites since pigeons strutted outside ancient Mesopotamian temples: to feed or not to feed?

title: Commercial Real Estate; Web Companies Can See Expanding Downtown
description: Internet-related companies decided to relocate to the lower tip of Manhattan in recent years to take advantage of bigger spaces, lower rents and a variety of incentive programs. And a new survey has found that these technology companies are prepared to stay there and grow, and perhaps even pay higher rents, provided landlords invest to make their buildings technologically reliable.

title: U.S. to Propose New Criticism of Rights in China
description: The Clinton administration said today that China's human rights record had continued to deteriorate and that the United States would again sponsor a United Nations resolution criticizing the Beijing government for its crackdown on political dissent and religious freedom.

title: Clinton Wants $2 Billion Expansion in Tax Credit for Working Poor
description: President Clinton plans to propose a substantial expansion in the program of tax credits for the working poor on Wednesday as he kicks off a broader effort to focus this year's federal budget debate on issues related to low-income people, White House officials said today.

title: INFOSYS PROFIT SOARS
description: India's second-largest software developer by market value, Infosys Technologies Ltd., said its third-quarter profit rose 96 percent, buoyed by demand from new customers -- especially for e-commerce. Profit rose to 737.9 million rupees ($16.9 million) before an extraordinary gain of 23.5 million rupees in the three months that ended on Dec. 31, from 377.4 million rupees in the year-earlier period. Infosys said its earnings per share on its American depository receipts rose to 12 U.S. cents from 8 cents. Infosys, whose stock was the first from India to be listed on the Nasdaq stock market, writes custom software.

title: Slicing Budget Numbers: Just What Do They Mean?
description: Gov. George E. Pataki's proposed new state budget is $76.8 billion, a 5.5 percent increase. Right? Well, sort of.

title: When One Successful Place Deserves Another
description: THINK you're seeing double sometimes? You probably are, at least when it comes to restaurants.

title: Bias Law Is Debated
description: Hearing arguments on the Violence Against Women Act, five of nine Supreme Court justices expressed skepticism about whether Congress's power to regulate interstate commerce was an adequate basis for allowing victims of violence that is ''motivated by gender'' to sue their attackers in federal court.

title: An Upstart From Down Under
description: WHEN a restaurant announces that it will be serving Australian cuisine, you expect good comic material, not good food. At Eight Mile Creek, a brash newcomer wedged into a narrow SoHo storefront, the joke stops when the kangaroo salad arrives.

title: Late-December Lull Tallied for Airlines
description: United Airlines, American Airlines and eight other major United States carriers lost as much as $300 million in revenue in late December as fewer people traveled before the 2000 rollover, analysts estimated today.

title: Devils Sweat Out a Victory in Tampa Bay
description: On paper, it figured to be a mismatch. The hottest team in the Eastern Conference was facing off against the coldest. But this is why they actually play games and not just argue about them in bars.

title: On CBS News, Some of What You See Isn't There
description: If you were watching the ''CBS Evening News'' broadcast live from Times Square on New Year's Eve, you might have seen a billboard advertising CBS News out in the square behind Dan Rather. You might have looked at the well-placed billboard and wondered just exactly how it was that CBS was able to place its ad so fortuitously.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROSE, O. ALAN., M.D.
description: ROSE-O. Alan., M.D. The Board of Trustees, Medical Staff and Employees of Lenox Hill Hospital express their profound sorrow at the loss of O. Alan Rose, M.D., Emeritus Physician, an esteemed member of our hospital family. Dr. Rose joined our Cardiology staff in 1941 and was formerly Chief of the Cardiac Clinic. He was an accomplished physician whose commitment to providing the finest possible medical care was evident throughout his illustrious medical career at Lenox Hill Hospital. A medical pioneer, Dr. Rose investigated medications used in the treatment of heart & vascular disease and published the first clinical evaluation of the now universally used digitalis ingredient digoxin. During World War II, he joined a team of Lenox Hill Hospital physicians who volunteered to participate in the Hospital's 12th Evacuation Hospital that cared for American troops and served under General George Patton from the time of the invasion of Germany through the Battle of the Bulge. A gifted and compassionate physician who loved the art and science of medicine, he was unwavering in his devotion to his many patients, including several generations of individual families. Dr. Alan Rose leaves an exceptional legacy of service to medicine, to his Country and to Lenox Hill Hospital. The entire hospital family honors the memory of this kind and gentle man who truly exemplified the highest standards of his profession. We extend our deepest sympathy to his wife Frances B. Rose, MD, and family. James S. Marcus, Chairman, Board of Trustees Gladys George, President & CEO Allen H. Collins, MD, MPH, President, Medical Board

title: Unashamedly a l'Orange

With dishes like duck a l'orange and boeuf bourguignon, served without retro irony or nostalgia, the menu is stuck in the era when adventurous midcentury diners were discovering Dijon mustard, chocolate mousse and Brie.

title: BANK DEAL IN PORTUGAL
description: In a deal that would further winnow the number of Portuguese banks, Banco Comercial Portugues, Portugal's second-biggest bank, said it would pay 1.26 billion euros, or $1.3 billion, for 51 percent stakes in Banco Mello, the nation's fifth-largest bank, and the insurer Companhia de Seguros Imperio. Both are important assets of the Jose de Mello group in Lisbon. Banco Comercial, based in Lisbon, has bought three other Portuguese rivals since 1995. With the Mello properties, Banco Comercial's assets would grow to about 8 billion euros, or $8.24 billion. Al Goodman

title: Exodus and KeyLabs In $43 Million Deal
description: Exodus Communications Inc., which manages computer centers that run corporate Internet sites, agreed today to buy the closely held KeyLabs Inc., a Web-site testing company, for $43.5 million in stock.

title: Plan Urges New Bridge to Replace the Tappan Zee
description: The Tappan Zee Bridge has become so dilapidated and is so congested that it should be torn down and replaced with a new eight-lane bridge with commuter rail tracks, a state task force recommended today.

title: Robber Gets Away by Leaping From a Tall Building in a Single Bound
description: A man suspected in eight recent knifepoint robberies in Midtown Manhattan, one of which included a stabbing, led the police on a movielike foot chase yesterday, leaping between office towers and ultimately escaping disguised as a sandwich deliveryman, police officials and awed eyewitnesses said.

title: Making It Here and Making It There: The Income Sweepstakes
description: It may come as consolation to Manhattan residents that though they endure some of the highest rents in the country, they also make more money than people elsewhere. Their average annual pay of $62,838 in 1998 was almost twice the national figure of $31,908 and smartly ahead of the nearest challengers in Fairfield, Conn., and Santa Clara, Calif., according to preliminary data released last week by the Bureau of Labor Statistics.

title: By Any Measure, a Big Deal
description: There is no question that the deal proposed on Monday by America Online Inc. and Time Warner Inc. would be the biggest corporate combination in American history. How much it would be worth is a different matter.

title: Established Media Companies Are Nervous in Wake of Pact
description: In the dizzy aftermath of a deal that made Time Warner, an established media company, the prospective junior partner of a new media giant, America Online, executives of other older media companies are proclaiming that the value of their information has been vindicated.

title: INTERNATIONAL PAPER TO CUT 2,000 MORE JOBS
description: The International Paper Company, North America's biggest paper and wood-products maker, said yesterday that it would eliminate 2,000 more jobs, and it took a fourth-quarter charge of $111 million for the cost-cutting move. The cuts represent about 2 percent of the company's work force and are in addition to the 1,600 jobs that International Paper eliminated last year after buying the Union Camp Corporation in April. The company also expects to close unprofitable plants or ones that make products already in excess supply, an International Paper spokesman, Jack Cox, said. The company has informed its workers of fewer than 25 percent of the cuts, Mr. Cox said.

title: CYBERSOURCE TO BUY WEB GIFT CERTIFICATE COMPANY
description: The CyberSource Corporation, which provides Internet transaction services, said yesterday that it had agreed to acquire ExpressGold Inc., a closely held provider of Internet gift certificate systems to online merchants, for about $72 million in stock. Under the agreement, CyberSource will pay 1.6 million common shares. The purchase price is based on CyberSource's Monday closing price of $45.25. Shares of CyberSource closed Tuesday at $44.75, down 50 cents. CyberSource, based in San Jose, Calif., said the purchase of ExpressGold of Westlake Village, Calif., would enable it to offer gift certificate services.

title: Corrections

It was a complaint with the Justice Department, not a lawsuit.

description: President Jamil Mahuad's plan to replace the nation's currency with the United States dollar won approval early today from a rump board at Ecuador's central bank after the bank's three highest officials resigned to protest what they called an irrational change of policy.

title: DOW CHEMICAL TO BUY POLYURETHANE SUPPLIER
description: The Dow Chemical Company said yesterday that it had agreed to acquire the Flexible Products Company, a privately held polyurethane supplier in Marietta, Ga., with annual sales of more than $140 million. Terms were not disclosed for the deal, expected to close this winter. Flexible Products also develops custom polyurethane foam formulations. Dow Chemical, based in Midland, Mich., said the deal would expand its reach into the polyurethane market and help it develop new, related technology. Dow Chemical, which makes chemicals and agricultural products, had $13.73 billion in sales in the first nine months of 1999.

title: CORNING TO SELL SHARES TO PAY FOR ACQUISITION
description: Corning Inc., the No. 1 maker of glass used in fiber optic telecommunications cable, plans to sell 13 million shares to pay for its $1.4 billion acquisition of the fiber optic businesses of Siemens A.G.. The proposed sale will increase Corning's shares outstanding by 5.3 percent, to about 257.8 million. The company, which is based in Corning, N.Y., plans to set a price for the issue later this month. Proceeds left after paying for the businesses will be used for corporate purposes. Corning shares fell $10.5625 each, to $107.4375.

title: SOCIETE GENERALE TO LIST
description: The No. 3 French bank, Societe Generale S.A., plans to list its shares on the Tokyo Stock Exchange on Feb. 1, becoming the first company to join the foreign section of the exchange in three years. Societe Generale will sell 200,000 existing shares on Jan. 27 and 28, the Tokyo Stock Exchange said. Societe Generale has 103.98 million shares issued and outstanding. The last foreign company to be listed on the Tokyo Stock Exchange was the Henderson Land Development Company of Hong Kong, in February 1997.

title: Round One at Shepherdstown
description: The first round of peace talks between Israel and Syria got off to a grindingly slow start in Shepherdstown, W.Va., before adjourning this week. But there is still a good chance of meeting the deadline, set by Israel's prime minister, Ehud Barak, for a broad peace agreement late this year. For that to happen Syria will have to do more to show that it is prepared to offer Israel friendly relations and special security guarantees in exchange for the return of all or most of the strategically valuable Golan Heights. Thus far, Damascus has wanted to talk only about territory. Its attitude toward these other essential dimensions of peace has been chilly and unpromising.

title: Corrections

He is Bernard Perlmutter, not Pearlmutter.

title: Outsider? Insider? A Lawyer Wins as Both
description: WITH the nonchalant elegance of Astaire, the lawyer Ted Wells tap dances at the edge of the abyss for his clients -- C.E.O.'s and politicians, mostly. On behalf of a national cabinet secretary he addressed a jury for three days, without notes; on behalf of another, Mr. Wells, after having had his way with the 70 witnesses the federal government had put on the stand, didn't bother putting on any of his own.

title: George Pataki, Centrist
description: With his new $76.8 billion budget for the next fiscal year, Gov. George Pataki has proposed again to tap New York State's huge surpluses for modest spending increases and tax cuts, building on his increasingly centrist politics of the last couple of years. The major exception to that approach is in school aid, for which Mr. Pataki recommended a package that shortchanges New York City and is certain to provoke a battle in the Legislature. In a welcome gesture to fiscal prudence, the governor also recommended setting aside more than $2 billion in surpluses generated by boom times as reserves for future use, and he endorsed a constitutional amendment to curb state borrowing and restore the state's abysmal credit rating.

title: COLUMBUS McKINNON CONSIDERS SELLING COMPANY
description: The Columbus McKinnon Corporation, an industrial parts maker, said yesterday that it had hired the investment bank Bear, Stearns & Company to help it explore options, including a possible sale or merger, to help raise its lagging stock price. Columbus supplies parts like hoists and steel-welded chains used in industrial and consumer markets. Its stock has slumped 40 percent in the last 12 months. Columbus McKinnon, based in Amherst, N.Y., has been battling a group of dissident shareholders led by Jeffrey Schwarz, chief executive of the New York-based Metropolitan Capital Advisors Inc., who in October called for the sale of the company.

title: Nuns, Bicycles and Berries
description: Someone who's had much influence on my life is Sister Marcellina, my eighth-grade teacher. She would say, ''For you to get 100 on a test is average, so you have to do extra work.'' I thought this was grossly unfair. I told her she was ruining my life. But I did it. She taught me to go the extra mile. I still write her at least once a year. When we talk, it's not about business. It's about what I'm doing as a human being. This summer when my mother died, she was incredibly helpful to me. When I received the Sara Lee Front-Runner Award this year, I took Sister Marcellina with me to the White House.

title: MANPOWER TO BUY ELAN, AN EMPLOYMENT CONCERN

The deal, which includes a deferred payment of $44 million, will enable Manpower to merge its information technology staffing operations across Europe under the Elan brand. The company will begin the integration process by merging Manpower's information technology staffing operations in Britain into those of Elan. Manpower, based in Milwaukee, provides workers and management services at more than 3,300 offices in 52 countries.

title: Yearning For Paris, Finding It Just Around The Corner

No-nonsense waiters in white aprons threaded among the crowded tables with platters held high. The mood was convivial, with the clink of glasses and silverware against the happy buzz of conversation. Plateaus of oysters glistened on the bar, charred steaks with golden fries were being delivered to diners all around me. And I started on one of the dishes I love most in the world: frisee aux lardons, a salad of bitter curly endive, poached egg and chunks of bacon.

The chunky 768-page paperback has beautiful photographs and an informed, if somewhat dry, text by Charlotte and Peter Fiell. title: DELTA TO BUY BACK STOCK AND TAKE CHARGE FOR AIRCRAFT
description: Delta Air Lines Inc., the No. 3 United States carrier, said yesterday that it would buy back as much as $500 million of its shares and take a pretax $320 million second-quarter charge for the early retirement of 24 aircraft. The airline's stock rose 62.5 cents, to $52, meaning the company could buy back about 9.6 million shares. The stock can be purchased through June 30, the Atlanta-based company said. In July 1998, Delta said it would buy back as much as $750 million of its shares. Delta said it would retire 16 MD-90 and 8 MD-11 planes within nine years as part of a plan to reduce the number of models it flies. Such a change cuts maintenance and training costs. The company would not provide an after-tax figure for the charge.

title: BELL & HOWELL TO SPIN OFF ITS INFORMATION ACCESS UNITS
description: The Bell & Howell Company said yesterday that it planned to spin off its information access operations to stockholders as a separately traded company. Its remaining businesses will retain the Bell & Howell name and consist of the Skokie, Ill., company's mail and messaging technologies and imaging segments. Before the spinoff, Bell & Howell will sell a minority interest in the new company to the public through an initial public offering. The businesses to be spun off provide periodicals and scholarly publications online to libraries and schools. They also sell equipment for storing and processing technical documents. As a result of the spinoff, the company will record a restructuring charge of about $30 million. Shares of Bell & Howell jumped $4.75 each, to $34.8125, on the New York Stock Exchange.

title: Editorial Observer; Does It Matter Who Owns What?

That's the question that comes to mind after yet another largest-ever media merger, AOL's $165 billion acquisition of Time Warner. Does it make a difference that all the entities once owned separately by AOL and Time Warner will soon be owned by them jointly? Put that way, the answer seems to be no. It isn't hard to see the logic in this deal, nor is it hard to sense the enormous forces that pulled these companies together. With such a high degree of consolidation in the media and Internet sectors, it's possible to argue that a little more merging isn't going to do much harm.

title: Mamet? Innocence? Perversity Has Changed
description: David Mamet's work doesn't generally elicit feelings of nostalgia. Still, when Deborah and Danny, the briefly coupled characters in his comedy of manners from the 1970's, ''Sexual Perversity in Chicago,'' go to bed together shortly after they meet (they arrange a dinner date afterward), the play, even with its wicked humor and gleeful vulgarity, creates a strangely innocent aura. In 1975, when it was first performed in New York, this one-act was shocking in its portrayal of the war between men and women as played out between 20-somethings in Chicago. The selfishness and suspicion, the fornication as foreplay, the extreme ungentleness with which the four characters -- two men and two women -- assault one another's self-esteem (and undermine their own) constituted a vicious satire of a world run amok with permissiveness.

title: When Smart Houses Turn Smart Aleck
description: THE Christmas party at the new Manhattan town house of Robert Soros and his wife, Melissa Schiff-Soros, was in full swing. As adults sipped Champagne in the candlelighted parlor, children raced upstairs to experience the electronic high life in its latest flowering: a home theater screening of the Disney classic ''Peter Pan.''

title: The Assets Of 2 Concerns Tied to Those In Big Deal
description: If the fortunes of Time Warner and America Online are tied up in the success of their proposed merger, the assets of at least two other media companies will be directly affected by the deal.

title: Savings Plan For College Sees a Surge At End of '99
description: For some, it was the lure of the tax deduction. For others, it was the opportunity to save for the college education of a son, daughter or grandchild.

title: The Retro Glamour of Vanities
description: VANITY or glamour? Only decorators know for sure why dressing tables are back. ''Hollywood in the 40's -- now that was glamorous,'' said Barbara Barry, a furniture designer, who has a new vanity for milady's bathroom. ''Who doesn't want to feel glamorous?''

title: COMPANIES TO INVEST IN INTERMEDIA AND ITS DIGEX WEB UNIT
description: Intermedia Communications Inc. is getting $300 million in investments from the Microsoft Corporation, the Compaq Computer Corporation and Kohlberg Kravis Roberts & Company to help it expand its telephone and Web services. Microsoft, the world's largest software maker, and Compaq, the biggest computer maker, will each buy a $50 million stake in Intermedia's 81 percent-owned Digex unit, which manages Web sites for other companies. Kohlberg Kravis, the No. 1 buyout firm, will invest $200 million for an Intermedia stake of about 8 percent. The agreement gives Digex access to Compaq's servers for its data centers and Microsoft software to run the sites. Intermedia's shares rose $1.75 each, to $40, in Nasdaq trading. Digex climbed $3.9375 a share, to $69.50, on the Nasdaq stock market.

title: From the Belly of the Buddha, A Friendlier Sight in the Corner
description: Keith Haring would have approved of the anthropomorphic, Buddha-shaped Minipod speakers designed by Simon G., a London D. J. Produced by Blueroom Loudspeakers, a unit of a London music label, and distributed through it in San Francisco, the 19-inch-tall Minipods buck the trend for the plain black-box speaker that has been the audio industry standard since the 1980's. Suitable for use with amplifiers between 10 and 100 watts a channel, the Minipods are available for $399 a pair in silver, white, blue or black at Namazing.com (a store, not a Web site -- go figure), 347 West Broadway (Grand Street); (212) 941-1126.

title: MARKS & SPENCER DECLINE
description: Britain's largest clothing retailer, Marks & Spencer P.L.C., whose stock has lost a quarter of its value in a year, reported better-than-expected holiday sales. The company's same-store sales fell 5.3 percent in the 15 weeks that ended last Saturday. Total sales fell 2.8 percent, led by a 6.7 percent slump in clothes. Some analysts had predicted an even worse drop. The chief executive, Peter Salsbury, who took over last year, is trying to lead a turnaround for the company.

title: The Pop Life; Favorite CD's You Nearly Missed
description: At least 27,000 recordings were released last year around the world. Somewhere within them was one CD that was just right for you: it was filled with the kind of music that speaks to you most, that sets your heart on fire with the selfless, nameless excitement that only art and love can inspire. It was a recording you would play day and night, and for every friend and relative within earshot. But sadly you never heard it. How could you? The odds were against you: 27,000 to 1.

title: Sites Track Trumpeter Swan's Comeback
description: SINCE you're already rereading ''Stuart Little,'' do yourself a favor and reread another E. B. White masterpiece, ''The Trumpet of the Swan'' (Harper & Row, 1970). Mr. White's perfect sentences are alive and well. (''Almost everything delights a chickadee.'') And so, thankfully, are trumpeter swans, the largest waterfowl in North America and one of conservation's great success stories.

description: The judge in the treason and hijacking case against the ousted prime minister of Pakistan, Nawaz Sharif, abruptly quit the proceedings today, complaining that government intelligence agents were menacing his courtroom.

description: With its traditional form and Windows-based software, Van Koevering's Interactive Baby Grand joins the Old World and the new. It can teach beginners to play and intermediates to refine their technique. Composers can document and edit their work.

description: In universities, as in real estate, location and timing are everything. Fortunately for Dr. William Potter, an indefatigable promoter of arms control and American-Russian cooperation, his Center for Nonproliferation Studies has enjoyed both.

title: Europe Plans Advisory Unit on Food Safety
description: Following a series of food scares on this continent, the European Commission today proposed the creation of an all-Europe food safety agency.

title: Video, Audio and AOL TV
description: EACH year at the Consumer Electronics Show in Las Vegas, hundreds of companies show the new products they plan to offer in the coming year, and tell lies about when the products will be available, how well they will work and how they will magically transform our lives.

title: PACIFICARE HEALTH SYSTEMS TO CUT WORK FORCE 5 PERCENT
description: PacifiCare Health Systems Inc. said yesterday that it would cut its work force by about 450 employees, or 5 percent of its approximately 8,300 workers. The cost-reduction plan will immediately result in 90 layoffs. About 160 other employees will be let go in the next 12 months, said the Santa Ana, Calif., managed care company. About 200 additional jobs will be eliminated through attrition. PacifiCare said it expected to record a restructuring charge of $7 million to $8 million for severance and related employee benefits in the first quarter. Shares of PacifiCare closed at $50.0625, down $1.4375, in Nasdaq trading.

title: DAEWOO NET WORTH LOWER
description: The 12 core units of the struggling Korean conglomerate Daewoo Group are worth 3.64 trillion won ($3.2 billion) less than previously estimated, according to the final results of a study of the units released by the government. The study was an assessment of their value as of June 1999, and preliminary estimates were released in November. The net worth of the units as of June 1999 was 43.37 trillion won less than their units' nominal value, the Financial Supervisory Commission said.

description: A leading technology consulting and research company says that Microsoft, to resolve its antitrust case with the government, should pre-emptively break itself up into four or five companies.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  THOMAS, GEORGE M.
description: THOMAS-George M. Died January 10, 2000. Age 84, of New York and Longboat Key, FL. Devoted husband of Bernice. Loving father of Joan Ellen Thomas and Philip Shale Thomas of New York and Dr. Edward Seth Thomas of Rhode Island. Adored grandfather of four and brother of Reuben Thomas of Englewood, NJ. Graduated City College of NY and New York University Law School 1939. Member of the NY Bar Association since 1941, the Washington DC Bar Association since 1943 and the American Bar Association since 1946. A principal of Susan Thomas Inc., a womens wear apparel company. Subsequently in private law practice and involved in philanthropy through a family charitable foundation and New York Community Trust. Admitted to the Senior Lawyers Division of the Supreme Court in 1997. Services will be held at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81 St, Thursday, January 13 at 11:30AM.

title: DIXONS'S SHARES FALL
description: The shares of Britain's biggest consumer-electronics retailer, Dixons Group P.L.C., fell after the company said lower prices had eroded profit margins during its first half and into this year. Dixons shares suffered their biggest one-day drop in more than 11 years, after the company said gross profit margins at its retail outlets fell 0.7 percent in the first half. That overshadowed a 15 percent rise in profit from operations reported for the period. The company, which owns PC World, Currys, the Link and other retail chains, increased sales volumes by discounting some products, a strategy it plans to continue. That worries some analysts.

title: Choice of Global Strategist Is Affirmed by Merrill Lynch
description: Merrill Lynch & Company made it official yesterday, naming David Bowers to take on some of the responsibilities of its longtime chief investment strategist, Charles I. Clough, who is retiring this week.

title: Judge Rejects Return of Two Children to France
description: A federal judge in Manhattan refused yesterday to order the return of two children to France, saying that their mother had been abused by their father in Paris and that forcing them to return would expose them to a grave risk of psychological harm.

title: Bob Lemon, 79, a Hall of Fame Pitcher, Dies
description: Bob Lemon, who pitched his way to the Hall of Fame with the Cleveland Indians, then managed the Yankees in their memorable pennant-winning comeback of 1978 when they overtook the Boston Red Sox in a division playoff, died Tuesday night at a nursing home in Long Beach, Calif. He was 79.

title: Apartment Rentals Deal
description: The Cendant Corporation's CompleteHome.com unit said today that it had acquired MetroRent, a San Francisco apartment rental services company. Terms were not disclosed. CompleteHome, the Internet portal for Century 21 and Cendant's other residential real estate brokerage businesses, said it would offer MetroRent's content and services via its branded Web site. MetroRent provides a database that brings together more than 10,000 property owners, managers and agents with would-be renters. In addition to Century 21, New York-based Cendant owns Coldwell Banker, ERA, Rent.net and Senior Housing Net.

title: Edward R. Cony, 76, Former Top Editor of The Wall Street Journal
description: Edward R. Cony, a former managing editor of The Wall Street Journal, who won a Pulitzer Prize in 1961 as a reporter for the paper, died on Sunday in Santa Cruz, Calif. He was 76.

title: Disney Studio Chairman Decides to Step Down
description: Joe Roth, who has been in charge of Walt Disney Motion Pictures since 1994 and chairman of Walt Disney Studios since 1996, said today that he was leaving Disney to form his own mini-studio, a company that will both make and distribute movies. He is being replaced by Peter Schneider, his second-in-command and the longtime head of the lucrative animation division.

title: NICKEL COMPANY'S STOCK FALLS
description: Shares in the Canadian nickel giant Inco Ltd. dropped on the news that it would delay development of its rich Voiseys Bay deposit in Labrador, on Canada's northeast coast. Inco's shares dropped $1.50, to $22.3125, on the New York Stock Exchange. After months of negotiations with the government of Newfoundland, which includes Labrador, Inco said it would not start work on a mine this year because the province wanted assurances that a processing plant would also be built to provide more jobs. Timothy Pritchard

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MARBY, DAVID, M.D.
description: MARBY-David, M.D. We are deeply saddened by the untimely death of our esteemed colleague on January 8, 2000. As a Pediatric Emergency Medicine Attending Physician and Assistant Clinical Professor of Pediatrics, Dave established himself as a dedicated and committed Pediatrician who tirelessly served children in need, particularly those in the Washington Heights community. He was a highly motivated basic science researcher and made important contributions to the field of infectious desease. Most significantly, he was a true friend to, and supporter of his colleagues at work. He will be sorely missed by all of us who worked along side him. We extend our deepest condolences to his familiy and close friends. Division of Pediartric Emergency Medicine Dept of Pediatrics Babies & Childrens' Hospital of New York New York-Presbyterian Hospital

title: A World Without End For Fans of Jane Austen

For years, publishers have sought to capitalize on the craving for more Austen prose with a steady stream of sequels to her mere six completed novels. Many of these ''continuations,'' unsurprisingly, have been found wanting by Austen devotees and literary critics alike.

title: KOREA CARMAKER FALTERS IN AFRICA
description: The southern Africa automotive sales operation of the South Korean conglomerate Hyundai, Hyundai Motor Distributors, has been placed into liquidation after its banks halted lending to the troubled dealership network, which owes more than $120 million. The action by a high court in South Africa has left uncertain the future of the operation, its 1,000 employees and its new assembly plant in Botswana. With all 64 of the company's dealerships and all 32 of its service centers shuttered, at least for now, the thousands of Hyundai owners in the region are wondering who will service their cars.

title: SPRINT SELLING INTELIG STAKE

The Communications Minister, Joao Pimenta da Veiga, said Sprint and its partners in Intelig, National Grid Group and France Telecom, had one week to propose Sprint's exit strategy. National Grid had won an earlier court decision forcing Sprint to sell its 25 percent stake in the company. Simon Romero

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HAMMOND, MILDRED
description: HAMMOND-Mildred, age 90, of Mattapoisett died suddenly on January 5 while in London, England on a theatre tour. Miss Hammond, the daughter of Mattapoisett native Joseph I. Hammond and Mary A. Hammond, was born and raised in New York City. As a youth she spent her summers in Mattapoisett. A graduate of both Hunter College and Columbia University, she was a career librarian. During the 1930's she worked first with Goldman Sachs and then Standard & Poors in New York. At the start of World War II she began a 20-year stint as a civilian librarian for the U.S. Army. Ever adventurous she accepted a position at a base in Alaska & later worked at bases in the New York area. Her last position was a librarian with the Federal Aviation Administration in New York. She retired to Mattapoisett in 1982. Miss Hammond was an active member of St. Anthony's Catholic Church in Mattapoisett, and the Mattapoisett Historical Society and served as a Trustee of the Mattapoisett Public Library. She traveled constantly throughout the world. She was one of the first women to visit Antarctica and in the 1970's and 80's, traveled to Costa Rica to fish. Right up to the end of her life she regularly visited museums, attended plays and did the New York Times crossword puzzle...in ink. A member of a family that lived in the Mattapoisett/ Rochester area for many generations, she was the last Hammond to live in Mattapoiset. Her grandfather, John S. Hammond was an architect and builder there. Her father's twin brother, Eugene, was noted for his pioneering 1903 San Francisco-to-New York trip in a 4-1/2hp Oldsmobile with Lester Whitman. Theirs was the third transcontinental automobile trip. She is survived by numerous cousins of 4 generations throughout the U.S., including John S. Hammond of Lincoln, MA, co-author of ''Smart Choices: A Practical Guide to Making Better Decisions''. Funeral services will be held at 10:00 AM on Sat., January 15 at St. Anthony's Catholic Church, Mattapoisett. A wake will take place on Friday, January 14, 2:00-4:00 PM, Sanders-Dwyer Funeral Home, 50 Country R. (Rte. 6), Mattapoisett. In lieu of flowers, contributions in her memory may be sent to the Mattapoisett Historical Society or the Mattapoisett Public Library.

Mr. McInerny was born in South Bend, Indiana, and graduated with a B.S.C.E. degree from Notre Dame University in 1937. He worked for several construction companies during his career including Burly Construction Corp., Resonant Pile Corp., Raymond International, Merritt, Chapman & Scott, and Conduit and Foundation Corp. Preceded in death by his beloved wife of 55 years, Elizabeth Anne, he is survived by 7 children, Denis McInerny of Melbourne Beach, Suzanne Phillips of Fairfax, VA, Kathy McInerny of Oxnard, CA, Mary McInerny of Long Beach, CA, Sally McInerny of Tuscaloosa, AL, Michael McInerny of Marshfield, MA, Peggy McInerny of Takoma Park, MD, and sister Nancy Wagner of Accokeek, MD. He is also survived by fifteen grandchildren and two great-grandchildren. No calling hours are scheduled. A memorial Mass will be held January 15, at 11:00 am at Immaculate Conception Catholic Church. The family requests no flowers. Donations may be made to Immaculate Conception Church, 3780 Highway A1A, Melbourne Beach, FL 32951, Notre Dame University, or the National Kidney Foundation.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  REA, ELIZABETH (BETTY)
description: REA-Elizabeth (Betty). Former Broadway actress, retired daytime TV casting director and social activist died December 23, 1999 of respiratory failure in Santa Monica, CA, she was 82. She was born Elizabeth Wilson in Montreal to Morris Wilson, President of the Royal Bank of Canada, Chanellor of McGill University and Clara Leone Wilson. In New York while appearing on Broadway in ''Media'' she met her future husband Oliver Rea who helped found The Gutherie Theater. Subsequently she worked as a talent agent for The Tranum Agency before landing the position of casting director of the soap opera ''Guiding Light''. Rea was the casting director for the Guiding Light from 1970-1996 and concurrently casting director for ''As The World Turns'' from 1979-1983. In 1997 Rea was recognized for her work and inducted into the Soap Opera Hall of Fame. She previously won the Soap Opera Digest Editors Award in 1994 and received the Casting Society of America's Hoyt Bowers Awared in 1995. Rea's many charitable contributions included service as President of the New York Junior League of which she is a lifetime member and on the boards of The Fountain House and The Maternity Center of New York. Rea is survived by two daughters, Edith Rea and Margaret Rea of Los Angeles and a son Peter Rea of Princeton, NJ and seven grandchildren. In lieu of flowers donations in Rea's name can be made to the Alzheimer's Association or to the Actors Fund. A memorial service will be held in New York on January 31st at 7 PM, at the Second Stage Theater, 307 West 43 Street.

title: Lore of a Legend And His Blues
description: No one is sure about the death of the blues musician Robert Johnson, except that it was in 1938 at the age of 27. In Robert Mugge's documentary ''Hellhounds on My Trail: The Afterlife of Robert Johnson,'' Willie Coffee, a childhood pal of Johnson's in Mississippi, says the cause was pneumonia. Another source contends that Johnson was poisoned in a juke joint by the husband of one of his lovers. The death certificate says syphilis. Mr. Coffee reiterates that it was pneumonia. Anyway, no one knows where Johnson, enigmatic and mercurial, is buried. Supposedly there are two graves.

title: A Bill Protecting Patients' Rights Will Pass, House Republican Says
description: The House majority leader, Representative Dick Armey of Texas, predicted today that Congress would pass a patients' bill of rights this spring and send it to President Clinton by Easter, April 23.

title: BRITISH RADIO DEAL
description: Britain's fifth-largest commercial TV broadcaster, Scottish Media Group P.L.C., agreed to buy Ginger Media Group to enter radio, the fastest-growing British advertising medium. Scottish Media will pay $110 million in cash and assume $75 million in debt from Ginger Media, owner of Virgin Radio. Ginger's management will also receive $40 million in shares. Scottish Media, based in Glasgow, owns newspapers and TV stations in Scotland. Last year it bought companies in movie and outdoor advertising in England.

description: Manhattan's office vacancy rate is at its lowest point in a decade, according to a new study.

description: The bodies of a 19-year-old woman, bound by her hands and feet, and her two young children were discovered yesterday on a mattress that had been set on fire in a basement apartment in East New York, the police said.

title: Accounts
description: * Hill, Holliday, Connors, Cosmopulos, Boston, part of the Interpublic Group of Cos., was named the first agency on four accounts with combined billings estimated at more than $50 million: Assets2Auction, Charlotte, N.C., an online auction site; Isky, Columbia, Md., a customer loyalty manager, to handle its business-to-business account; Shoebuy.com, Boston, a Web-based footwear retailer, and Voter.com, Washington, a political Web site.

description: In front of a lush, eye-popping backdrop of the Times Square New Year's Eve celebration, Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani delivered a theatrical State of the City address yesterday that was both a reprise of what he considers his greatest triumphs and an effort to impose his legacy on New York City far into the next decade.

title: For Front-Runners and Underdogs Alike, Iowa Caucuses Could Be Crucial
description: Over the years, the Iowa caucuses have made some presidential candidates (like Jimmy Carter in 1976) and unmade others (like Steve Forbes in 1996). But this time, they have seemed like a warm-up bout compared with the ballyhooed main event in New Hampshire.

title: As Wicked As Ever
description: ''The Sopranos,'' the series that has grown from an easy joke about a mob boss with a midlife crisis to a critical hit and a pop-cult phenomenon, resumes Sunday night on HBO with a new episode starring James Gandolfini (above), the greatest of the show's many wicked delights.

title: Safir Says Police Bonuses Could Curb Mass Exodus
description: Police Commissioner Howard Safir said yesterday that the city, facing a possible mass exodus of seasoned police officers eligible for retirement, should consider awarding bonuses or other incentives to those who agree to stay on.

title: Bruno Zevi, Architecture Critic With Populist Flair, Dies at 81
description: Bruno Zevi, editor of the Italian magazine L'Architettura and one of Europe's most prominent architecture critics for five decades, died on Sunday at his home in Rome. He was 81.

title: Conner's Stars and Stripes at Last Runs Out of Lightning
description: They were jeered as they left the Viaduct Basin in the morning by a group of New Zealanders who questioned their ethics, and what happened on the racecourse in the afternoon did little to lift the spirits of Stars and Stripes' experienced and ultimately beleaguered crew.

title: In the Very Distant Universe, Objects Even Older Than Light
description: In a discovery that could help explain the origin of the earliest galaxies, a new astronomy satellite has detected the first discrete objects in the mysterious glow of X-rays that pervades the distant universe.

title: Republicans and the Confederate Flag
description: Both leading Republican candidates for president, Senator John McCain and Gov. George W. Bush, are being too clever by half in the perennially inflammatory debate over the Confederate battle flag in South Carolina. By declining to take a principled stand in this key primary state, the candidates are pandering to bias and perpetuating an outdated and ignoble practice from past Republican campaigns.

title: The Bad Business of Media Mergers
description: When Steve Case of America Online announced his purchase this week of Time Warner, he listed the new company's activities in the following order: First there was entertainment. Then there was e-commerce. Down the list a ways came journalism.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''Last year, I advocated burning it down. All right, well, I'm softening up. I'm becoming an easier guy.''

title: Mexican Star in Sex Case Is Arrested in Rio
description: The last time that the pop star Gloria Trevi performed on television in Mexico, she pranced and tossed her mane of wavy hair with the carefree defiance that made her an icon of rebellion among young girls.

title: JAPAN'S SURPLUS SHRINKS
description: Japan's current account surplus shrank in November, as demand for raw materials drove up imports at triple the pace of exports. The stronger yen is also making imports cheaper and slowing export growth. The current account surplus fell 15.2 percent from October, to 982.7 billion yen ($9.3 billion), the Ministry of Finance said. The surplus was down 31 percent from a year earlier. Imports rose 14.1 percent from October, the biggest monthly jump in more than two years. Companies are buying more raw materials and parts from abroad as they expand production. Exports increased 4.5 percent.

title: Conglomerate, Accused of Allowing Spills to Cut Costs, Is Fined $30 Million
description: One of the nation's largest pipeline operators quit inspecting its lines for much of the 1990's and instead found flaws by waiting for the pipes to break, the government said today, announcing that the company, Koch Industries, had agreed to pay a fine of $30 million, the largest civil environmental penalty to date.

title: ANTIMISSILE TEST VIEWED AS FLAWED BY ITS OPPONENTS

description: Six weeks after the German government prodded banks to provide a $2.2 billion bailout of Philipp Holzmann A.G., a construction company plagued by losses, prosecutors raided corporate offices to search for evidence of fraud and embezzlement by former executives. Holzmann's current executives, who took over in 1997, say their predecessors concealed huge real estate losses for years. But many investors say the current management is also at fault. Edmund L. Andrews

title: A Safe Place to Make Mistakes
description: It's not exactly as complicated as the cockpit of a jet. It has two handles: one for the brake and one for the speed. It has a little button for the horn, a digital speedometer and a brake pressure gauge that looks like something from the boiler room of the Mauretania.

description: BRUNSWICK CORP., Lake Forest, Ill., a maker of recreational products like bowling balls, Bayliner boats and Igloo coolers, said it was halting bicycle production in North America and cutting 1,075 jobs.

title: Spanish Phone Giant to Buy The Rest of 4 Latin Providers
description: Spain's dominant telephone company, Telefonica S.A., said today that it would offer $21.5 billion in stock to buy out four big phone companies that it already controls in Latin America, tightening its grip on the region.

title: Microsoft Names a New Chief Executive
description: William H. Gates stepped aside today as chief executive of Microsoft after a quarter-century of running the company day to day and gave that role to his longtime partner Steven A. Ballmer, the company's president.

title: When What Masters Do Is Not What They Say
description: The words of famous artists can become so well known that they nearly congeal into platitudes, at least where the art world is concerned. One such phrase is Barnett Newman's exuberant Abstract Expressionist battle cry, ''We are making it out of ourselves.'' Another is Jasper Johns's understated studio prescriptive, familiar to every artist of a certain age: ''Take an object. Do something with it. Do something else with it.''

title: WEEKEND WARRIOR; No Hustlin', Chicken Man, We're Playin' on the Square
description: To me, the pool hustler has always been the epitome of cool. A gunslinger who carries a cue instead of a sidearm, a poker player who bluffs with a rack of balls, the hustler has imperturbable concentration, a sledgehammer break and a nickname like Chicago Tony or the Chickenman.

title: Mayor's Tough Medicine For the Schools System
description: It sounded like an offhand joke, but Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani insisted yesterday that he was serious.

title: A Guerrilla Grows Up During A Mission
description: Malli (Ayesha Dharkar), the title character of Santosh Sivan's remarkable new film, is a 19-year-old who lives in a guerrilla camp in the South Indian jungle. Aside from her occasional execution of a traitor and the constant threat of a government ambush, her life seems in many respects perfectly ordinary. She could almost be the heroine of a sweet, wholesome Hollywood coming-of-age story. She and her girlfriends engage in friendly banter, brush each other's hair and do their best to ignore the appraising looks of the local boys. When Malli is chosen for a suicide mission, her peers respond with envy and admiration, as if she had been elected prom queen.

title: For Sale: A Chunk Of History
description: If you love French antiques, you are out of luck. January is Americana month. Museum curators, scholars and collectors fly into New York from all over the United States for the Winter Antiques Show, the Americana sales at the auction houses and gallery shows.

title: Harrods Loses Prince Philip's Seal of Approval
description: Buckingham Palace announced today that it was withdrawing the royal warrant awarded by Prince Philip, the Duke of Edinburgh, to Harrods, the London department store that is owned by Mohamed al-Fayed.

title: CRITIC'S CHOICE/Film; Dance and the Camera Celebrating Together
description: Dance, film and video and the new media are exploring one another with increasing fervor. This year the Dance on Camera festival has tripled in size. The weeklong festival begins today at the Walter Reade Theater at Lincoln Center, continues with three programs at Anthology Film Archives in the East Village and ends next weekend back at the Walter Reade. The variety is dizzying, including narrative and conceptual art-dance shorts, documentaries and discussions. The documentary subjects alone range from glittering old and new international dance stars in Russia, France and England to Nebraska railroad builders and a choreographer exploring her American roots at the Jacob's Pillow Dance Festival.

title: Political Memo; Hillary Clinton Is Coming Out of Her Cocoon
description: As Hillary Rodham Clinton was leaving a news conference in White Plains earlier this week, she noticed a small group of reporters gathered on the street. Mrs. Clinton walked past her Secret Service contingent and, with no aides in sight, struck up a conversation about how, by her account, she had just mishandled a question about gay marriage. Mrs. Clinton chatted for nearly five minutes before retreating to her motorcade.

title: ALBUM OF THE WEEK
description: SONIC YOUTH: ''Goodbye 20th Century'' (SYR). To send off the 1900's Sonic Youth acknowledges its roots in a distinctly 20th-century phenomenon: experimental composers who embraced improvisation, noise, repetition and the workings of chance.

title: FOR CHILDREN
description: Theater

title: U.S. Is Returning 84,000 Acres to Indians
description: In the largest return of public land to American Indians in the continental United States in more than 100 years, the federal government is giving back 84,000 acres in northern Utah that it took from the Utes in 1916 to secure the rights to oil shale reserves.

title: CYPRESS GROUP IS ACQUIRING MAJORITY OF HOMERUNS.COM
description: The private equity firm Cypress Group said yesterday that it had agreed to acquire a majority stake in HomeRuns.com, an online grocery delivery service, for $100 million. HomeRuns.com, which is based in Somerville, Mass., is a wholly owned subsidiary of the food retailer Hannaford Brothers. The site serves about 40,000 customers in the Boston area. Under the agreement, Hannaford will retain a significant investment in HomeRuns.com and will continue to provide discounted inventory. Cypress Group, based in New York, manages two private equity funds with more than $3.5 billion in assets.

title: Leaving the Cocoon
description: Whether by prearrangement or on the advice of Walter Cronkite, David Letterman was extremely gentle to Hillary Rodham Clinton as she took her first steps this week into the real world of New York's brand of performance politics. Mrs. Clinton should be pleased with the good reviews she got for composure and humor. But she should also know that this was only a small step in the direction of conducting an open campaign. Now that she is a resident of the state, it is time for Mrs. Clinton to emerge fully from the White House cocoon.

title: Treasures of a Collector With an Eye for a Deal
description: As the story goes, the art-collecting financier J. Pierpont Morgan (1837-1913) was once offered a group of 30 miniatures by the dealer Joseph Duveen. Most were fairly routine, but to sweeten the pot Duveen had scattered six rare objects among them. Morgan glanced at the lot, then asked the overall price. When Duveen named it, Morgan unerringly picked out the six best, pocketed them, then divided the price by 30 and multiplied it by six, paying the same per unit for the rarities as he would have for the lesser pieces.

title: FAMILY FARE
description: A Brief Life, Burning Bright

title: Wall Street's Bright Lights, Circa 2000: Electric Companies
description: BOND prices began this year by continuing the 1999 swoon, as Wall Street worried that the Federal Reserve might tighten the monetary noose until the economy -- or the stock market -- cried uncle. But even as interest rates ratcheted up, something strange happened. The woebegone electric utility stocks began to rally.

title: NBC Internet Forms Joint Venture in Asia
description: NBC Internet Inc. and Asiacontent.com Ltd. said today that they had formed a joint venture to offer Internet portal, shopping and other services throughout the Pacific Rim.

title: Nasdaq to Unveil European Trading System
description: The Nasdaq stock market will introduce an Internet-based trading system on Friday that will be used in its new pan-European stock exchange.

title: Michael Jordan Is in Negotiations to Run the Wizards
description: Michael Jordan and Abe Pollin, the Washington Wizards' majority owner, moved closer to an agreement to have Jordan take over the team's basketball operations, a person with knowledge of the discussions said late last night.

title: McCain Urges Bush to Halt New York Ballot Challenge
description: Invoking images of Communist repression, Senator John McCain called today on Gov. George W. Bush to stop Bush supporters in New York State from challenging Mr. McCain's petition to appear on New York presidential primary ballots.
