description: To the Editor:

title: What Me an All-Star? Devils' Gomez Is on the Squad
description: Scott Gomez's hockey fantasy expanded to a new horizon today. He initially dreamed of becoming the first Hispanic player to be drafted in the first round by the National Hockey League, and then fantasized about becoming a regular with the Devils. Now, the 20-year-old Gomez is going to the All-Star Game in his rookie season.

title: Wheelchair Racers Win the Battle For Own Division
description: The New York Road Runners Club has agreed to establish a separate division for wheelchair athletes for this year's New York City Marathon, settling out of court with a group of disabled athletes who sued the club for discrimination last year. Details of the four-page agreement were not made public, but lawyers for both sides said yesterday that the Road Runners would announce the rules for the new division soon and that they would include a separate start for wheelchair athletes as well as a ceremony after the race with trophies for top male and female finishers.

title: For Richter, Team First Counts Most
description: Mike Richter contends that victories and defeats mean more to a goalie than save percentages and goals-against averages. Does this mean a goalie would rather win by 7-6 than lose by 2-1?

title: MOVIE GUIDE
description: Here is a selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy movies and film series playing this weekend in New York City. * denotes a highly recommended film or series. Ratings and running times are in parentheses. An index of reviews of films opening today appears on Page 12.

title: Public Interests; Now Playing: The Perfect Campaign
description: The presidential primary is in full bloom, and never have we seen a campaign more focused on the issues. At this very moment, John McCain and George W. Bush are trading ferocious faxes about whether it's better to expand the 15 percent tax bracket or create a new one at 10 percent. Turn on TV and you'll find the Democratic candidates arguing whether Bill Bradley's health care plan has a cap or a weighted average.

title: Turkey Postpones a Hanging
description: Turkey made the right choice in deferring the execution of Abdullah Ocalan, the Kurdish rebel leader, until the European Court of Human Rights hears his appeal. The decision took political courage in a country where passions against Mr. Ocalan run high. But it will help smooth Turkey's path into the European Union, and may permit a solution to the Kurdish conflict, Turkey's most vexing internal problem. Turkey is not obliged to follow the court's ruling, but has obeyed its decisions in the past.

title: Jack E. Brown, 72, a Computer Industry Lawyer
description: Jack E. Brown, a lawyer prominent in several early cases concerning the computer industry and intellectual property, died on Jan. 6 at his home in Paradise Valley, Ariz. He was 72.

title: THEATER GUIDE
description: Here is a selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy Broadway and Off Broadway shows this weekend. Approximate running times are in parentheses. * denotes a highly recommended show.

title: Fugitive Held On '92 Count Of Fixing Gotti Jury
description: Bosko Radonjich's life has been marked by international intrigue, including, by his own account, days as a Serbian freedom fighter, a C.I.A. operative and a close adviser to Radovan Karadzic, the former Bosnian Serb leader and fugitive war criminal.

title: KOREAN AIR HIRES EXECUTIVE
description: After a series of major accidents, South Korea's flagship airline, Korean Air, said it had hired a foreign aviation specialist as its vice president. Harry Greenberg, former aviation division chief for Delta Air Lines, became Korean Air's vice president for safety and aviation. Meanwhile, the South Korean government said it would conduct special safety inspections on all 107 aircraft owned by the airline. Samuel Len

title: The Mayor's Political Rendering
description: Mayor Rudolph Giuliani's State of the City speech yesterday was in part a summation of his now-familiar list of successes over the last six years. Mr. Giuliani sought to define and secure his legacy in what ''could be my last'' such annual accounting at New York's City Hall. But it was also a highly political campaign speech for his Senate race against the first lady, Hillary Rodham Clinton. The mayor burnished his tax-cutting credentials by agreeing to push for some $2 billion in business and income tax reductions to spur economic growth. And he sought to distance himself from the city's school crisis with proposals on privatization, vouchers and tenure that might score points with the Republicans' core constituencies but would cause more harm in the schools than good.

title: Fate of the Tappan Zee
description: To the Editor:

title: WILLIS STEIN PAYS $282 MILLION FOR MAJORITY OF ORIUS
description: Willis Stein & Partners, a leading private equity investment firm based in Chicago, has acquired a majority stake in the Orius Corporation of West Palm Beach, Fla., for $282 million and merged it with LISN Inc., in which it already had a controlling interest. Orius is a provider of infrastructure services to the telecommunications and cable television industries, and LISN is the largest independent provider of engineering, furnishing and installation services to the telecommunications industry. The combined entities will have 1999 revenue of about $500 million. The management of both Orius and LISN, which had its headquarters in Amherst, Ohio, will remain substantial shareholders in Orius.

title: Critical of Administration, Iowa Farmers Are Cool to Gore
description: Vice President Al Gore appealed today for support from Iowa farmers and staged an event that attacked his opponent, former Senator Bill Bradley, as unconcerned with the problems of American agriculture.

title: DRUG MAKERS DROP THEIR OPPOSITION TO MEDICARE PLAN
description: Drug company executives asked the White House today for a cease-fire in their war over drug prices and said unequivocally that they wanted to work with President Clinton and Congress to establish Medicare coverage of prescription drugs this year.

title: Considerate Coughing
description: To the Editor:

title: Puffy Combs Is Indicted In Club Case
description: A Manhattan grand jury yesterday indicted Sean Combs, the rap performer better known as Puff Daddy, for possession of two illegal handguns as part of its investigation into shootings that wounded three people on Dec. 27 at a Times Square nightclub.

title: Tyson Is Cleared To Fight In Britain
description: Two days after three London mayoral candidates raised a furor over his entry into the country, Mike Tyson has been cleared by the Home Office to visit Britain for his Jan. 29 heavyweight fight against Julius Francis in Manchester.

title: The Ziti's in the Oven and the Matriarch's Still Not Dead
description: ''She's dead to me,'' Tony Soprano says about his mother, spitting out the word ''dead'' as if it were a bullet. He says this not once but twice in the opening episode of the new season of ''The Sopranos.'' Each time is a reminder of how magically James Gandolfini embodies this likable, despicable character, and why he is the greatest of the series' many wicked delights.

title: F.D.A. Forces Drug Maker to Keep the Flu in Ad for a Remedy
description: Television viewers who have seen the advertisement for Relenza, a new flu medication, know that it ends with a woman who has taken the drug sitting in her kitchen while her husband fixes chicken soup and the flu, personified by an actor, mills about.

title: Horne Keeps Hustling, and the League Takes Notice
description: There has always been some hustle in Tony Horne, whether back in Boston or in Queens, where he grew up stressed out by seeing friends jailed and killed, and families, including his own, ripped apart. Or later in Rockingham, N.C., in high school and at Clemson in college, where he lived in sleepy towns but found a way to be awake, aware and prone to mischief.

title: DINER'S JOURNAL
description: No one goes to Daniel for home cooking, but there's a homey instinct behind a new lunch menu being served in the restaurant's lounge. It has its roots in Lyon, Daniel Boulud's hometown, where the cherished sub-bistros known as bouchons have pleased diners for generations by offering down-to-earth fare and a couple of house wines for a price that wouldn't buy an appetizer in Paris. Sometimes there's a menu, but more often the owner stops by the table and runs through a list of three or four entrees. The meal might start with a salad mixed at the table, followed by a plate of charcuterie and a pate that travels from table to table in the course of the evening.

title: 3-Year Loss at Lloyds Forecast at $1 Billion
description: As the result of incurring high claims, Lloyds of London, the world's largest insurance market, will post losses of $1 billion, or $1.6 billion, in its next three reporting years, according to Chatset Ltd., an insurance market analyst.

title: Monkey Is Created by Embryo Splitting
description: Scientists in Oregon have divided an eight-cell monkey embryo into quarters, creating identical quadruplet embryos. One of them survived and resulted in the birth of a baby monkey.

title: A new joint venture aims to recreate synergies between Hollywood and Madison Avenue.
description: IN a significant step toward bringing Madison Avenue and Hollywood closer together, a giant agency is forming an alliance with a powerful company specializing in talent management and television and movie production. The affiliation is intended to help advertisers exploit the puissant potentials inherent in entertainment marketing.

title: Spitzer Files Suit Against Supermarket
description: Attorney General Eliot L. Spitzer today sued the Food Emporium stores and a group of delivery companies, charging that African immigrants who deliver groceries for shoppers at an Upper West Side supermarket are paid less than the minimum wage.

title: RETURN OF AN IMAGE
description: Until now, something essential had been missing from the campaign in New Hampshire: snow. But starting yesterday morning, there was a steady snowfall throughout the state, and by the time lunch was over, Gov. George W. Bush of Texas was able to hold his first wintry news conference. It wasn't much, but for the first time in this race there was the familiar image from campaigns past of a front-runner in the flakes.

title: For Hess's Estate, It's a jets.com
description: One way to assess the impact of Robert Wood Johnson IV's $635 million purchase of the Jets is to see how it enriched the Leon Hess estate.

title: The Pop Diva as Would-Be Jazz Singer
description: ''We're attempting to kiss the skirt of the lady named Jazz,'' Chaka Khan pronounced grandly from the stage of the Blue Note on Tuesday night. But in a quick and troubled early set, Ms. Khan ended up eating the lady's dust instead.

title: AOL Merger Is Unlikely to Reshape Asian Internet Business
description: It was hardly Paris, but Shanghai played a part in the brief, intense courtship between America Online and Time Warner.

title: Un-Flamboyant Prosecutor for Diallo Case
description: HEAVY is the reputation that hangs upon us in middle age.

title: LIBERATE AGREES TO BUY TV TECHNOLOGY FROM 2 COMPANIES
description: Liberate Technologies Inc., a maker of software that lets cable companies provide interactive television services, agreed yesterday to buy the interactive television technology jointly owned by Source Media Inc. and Insight Communications Inc. for about $182 million in stock. Insight, a cable television operator based in New York, and Source Media, a provider of interactive programming based in Dallas, will get preferred-content agreements with Liberate in return for selling the technology, which is known as VirtualModem. Shares of Liberate, based in San Carlos, Calif., fell $13.50, to $218.75. Source Media fell $4.125, to $16.875, and Insight rose $1.50, to $28.4375.

title: Shareholders Back Bid by Royal Bank
description: Royal Bank of Scotland P.L.C. said today that its shareholders had approved a hostile bid of $:22 billion ($36.2 billion) for National Westminster Bank P.L.C., Britain's No. 3 bank.

description: London's 'Rose' Likely for Spring

title: CABARET GUIDE
description: Here is a selective listing of new or noteworthy cabaret shows in Manhattan this weekend. * denotes a highly recommended show.

title: Bell Microproducts in Deal With I.B.M.
description: The International Business Machines Corporation said this week that it would sell data-storage products and flat-panel screens through Bell Microproducts Inc., bringing in as much as $2 billion.

title: Mets Expected to Trade Yoshii to the Rockies
description: The Mets are expected to announce today that they have traded pitcher Masato Yoshii to the Colorado Rockies for pitcher Bobby Jones and the minor league pitcher Lariel Gonzalez, a National League official said last night.

title: Corrections
description: A brief report in the Footlights column of the Arts section on Wednesday about Pan-Americana, a series being presented by Jazz at Lincoln Center, reversed the dates of two programs. The Jazz for Young People programs on Afro-Cuban jazz will take place on Jan. 28 at the Apollo Theater and on Jan. 29 at Alice Tully Hall.

title: Rocker Is Off Base In ESPN Interview
description: John Rocker's agents chose the reporter they wanted to interview him for the first time following his disparaging remarks about gays and minority group members last month. They also chose the place where Rocker would be interviewed. Unfortunately for Randy and Alan Hendricks, Rocker's agents, they could not pick someone else to speak for their client.

title: G.E. Joining Effort on 'Smart' Appliances
description: The General Electric Company, the No. 1 maker of appliances for new homes in the United States, said it had agreed to develop standards with the Microsoft Corporation to connect so-called smart appliances with other consumer devices.

title: Holiday on Monday; Martin Luther King Jr.'s Birthday
description: NEW YORK

title: Corrections
description: A television review on Dec. 29 about ''Investigative Reports: The Survivor,'' an A&E program about Binjamin Wilkomirski, whose claim to being a Holocaust survivor has been challenged, referred incorrectly to Majdanek, where Mr. Wilkomirski said he had been confined. It was set up and run by the German occupiers of Poland; it was not a ''Polish death camp.''

title: Who's the Real Beltway Candidate?
description: The press seems to think it has found a template for analyzing the Democratic presidential race. The contest, we're told, is a contrast of ''leadership styles.'' The candidates' positions on the hot issues of health care and gun control are fed into the analysis machine, and the contending caricatures pop out: Bill Bradley is a bold dreamer with a few big ideas. Al Gore is a pugnacious pragmatist with lots of incremental ideas.

title: Laidlaw to Delay Sale of Stake
description: The chief executive of Laidlaw Inc., John Grainger, said this week that the company would delay the planned sale of its $287 million stake in the Safety-Kleen Corporation until shares of the company, a hazardous-waste concern, rebound from a recent plunge.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article yesterday about The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund referred incorrectly to the director of the Children's Aid Society's programs at Public School 8 in Washington Heights. The director, Chris Caruso, is a man.

title: HILFIGER SAYS EARNINGS WILL FALL SHORT OF EXPECTATIONS
description: The Tommy Hilfiger Corporation said yesterday that it expected its fiscal third- and fourth-quarter earnings to be below analysts' expectations because of slower-than-expected sales and price cuts during the holiday season. Earnings for the quarter ended Dec. 31 may be in the range of 58 to 64 cents a share, compared with 61 cents a year ago, the company said. Analysts surveyed by First Call/Thomson Financial had projected earnings at 73 cents. Hilfiger, which sells apparel, accessories and fragrances, said it expected earnings for the quarter ending March 31 to be 35 cents to 45 cents a share. Analysts had projected 58 cents. Shares of Tommy Hilfiger fell $3.1875, to $16.

title: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
description: THE DOLLAR RISES. The dollar gained on evidence that the economy was growing without a pickup in inflation. In New York, the dollar settled at 106.13 yen, up from 105.98; the euro traded at $1.0254, down from $1.0311.

title: Marbury Dampens Odom's Return
description: There were 21.6 seconds left on the clock and just 4 seconds on the shot clock as the Nets, who were clinging to a 3-point advantage over the Los Angeles Clippers, got set to inbound the ball. Just minutes earlier, it seemed as if Stephon Marbury would be resting on the bench by now, with the team coasting along with a double-digit lead. But now the game was up for grabs, and there was no doubt that the ball would be put in his hands.

title: AUTOS ON FRIDAY/Technology; Carmakers to Put 'Smog-Eating' Radiator in Some Models
description: VERYONE knows that cars contribute to smog. But what if you had one that actually reduced pollution as you drove? For five years, that has been the tantalizing promise of a technology developed by the Engelhard Corporation. Now, after some initial disappointments, Engelhard's ''smog-eating radiator'' is finding its way into new cars.

title: Henry Pleasants, 89, Spy Who Knew His Music
description: Henry Pleasants, a music critic and author who doubled as a top American spy in postwar Germany, died at a hospital in London on Jan. 4. He was 89 and lived in London.

title: Restrictions Are Lifted at Two Prisons
description: New York State correction officials have ended lockdowns at two prisons where inmates were accused of plotting a statewide strike that was to begin on New Year's Day, officials said yesterday.

description: Winter has finally begun flexing its somewhat atrophied muscles, with a frigid air mass over Canada pushing an arctic blast across the northeastern United States. Temperature sank into the 20's and below throughout the New York region last night, and the wind made it feel far colder.

description: Beginning next week, people accused of driving recklessly in New York City will face misdemeanor charges and the forfeiture of their cars, Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani said yesterday.

description: Faced with rising labor and fuel costs, the UAL Corporation, the parent company of United Airlines, said yesterday that its 2000 earnings were likely to be as much as 28 percent below expectations.

title: A European Identity: Nation-State Losing Ground
description: Deriding the bureaucracy, the bungling and the banana wars of the European Union has long been a pastime on this fractious Continent. But abruptly a serious sense of European citizenship, along with the rights that go with it, seems to be laying the basis of a supranational identity here.

title: Now, Mayor Says, Is Time to Build Up, Under and All Around
description: In using his annual State of the City address to offer a shopping list for economic development, Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani yesterday ranged across a spectrum of projects, real or only dreamed of, including such diverse public works as improvements to the East River Park and tax incentives for new offices in Brooklyn, the Bronx and Queens.

title: ART GUIDE
description: Here is a selective listing by critics of The New York Times of new or noteworthy art, design and photography exhibitions at New York City museums and art galleries this weekend. Addresses, unless otherwise noted, are in Manhattan. Most galleries are closed on Sundays and Mondays, but hours vary and should be checked by telephone. Gallery admission is free.

title: Devil Rays Sign Trachsel for a Year
description: In the latest move of their busy offseason, the Tampa Bay Devil Rays agreed yesterday to a $1 million, one-year contract with pitcher Steve Trachsel, contingent on the right-hander passing a physical.

title: Eartha Kitt, Growling and Purring
description: Billie Holiday's forlorn masochist and Eartha Kitt's comic sex kitten are musical personae that may seem poles apart. But as Ms. Kitt demonstrates in her new show at the Cafe Carlyle, they are really two sides of the same coin.

title: Leak of Negotiating Document Puts Focus on Golan Settlers
description: A leak of an American working draft of an Israeli-Syrian peace treaty has created something of a stir here with the suggestion that Israel is seeking to keep its settlers in the Golan Heights after a military pullback from the area.

title: Fed Chairman Discusses the 'Limits' to the Economy
description: Alan Greenspan, the Federal Reserve chairman, warned last night that there were limits to how long the economy could continue barreling along without igniting inflation, and appeared to confirm the assumption on Wall Street that the central bank will raise interest rates next month.

description: The two-day slide in the shares of America Online reversed yesterday as its stock jumped 7.5 percent, to $64.50.

title: Barrow to Head First Tee Group
description: Joe Louis Barrow Jr., former chief executive of Izzo Systems, has been named national director of the First Tee, a World Golf Foundation initiative dedicated to providing access to affordable golf to those who might not have that opportunity, with a special emphasis on youngsters.

description: Throughout the deficit-plagued 1980's, the Treasury Department struggled to find novel ways of financing the government's ballooning daily expenses even as tax receipts fell further and further behind.

description: The sand woman came out of the blackness of the village master's house into the desert light, bearing a bowl of sand her hands had scooped from the doorway and would deposit several feet away.

title: Brunell Closes In on Starting
description: Quarterback Mark Brunell said today that his left knee continued to improve and that he expected to have full mobility despite wearing a brace on each knee when the Jaguars play the Miami Dolphins on Saturday in an American Football Conference division playoff game.

title: In Trade-Off With TV Networks, Drug Office Is Reviewing Scripts
description: Over the last two years, the White House has reviewed some scripts and advance footage of such television shows as ''E.R.'' and ''Beverly Hills 90210'' under a little-known financial agreement with the networks that encourages them to include anti-drug messages in plots of programs.

title: In Iowa, Bush Gets a Little Help From Dad
description: Gov. George W. Bush put out a call for Dad today. And Dad, the former president, came running, telling Iowa voters that they should vote for his son in the Republican presidential caucuses on Jan. 24 because he was tough enough and experienced enough to occupy the White House and would ''serve with honor.''

description: To the Editor:

title: Using a Caribbean Base For Jazz Improvisations
description: David Murray's Creole, which performed at the Knitting Factory's Old Office last Friday night, is a jazz-Caribbean hybrid split down the middle. Its jazz half is Mr. Murray on tenor saxophone, Santi DeBriano on bass and Pheeroan ak Laff on drums, working with three singers and percussionists from Guadeloupe: Guy Konket, Francois Ladrezeau and Klod Kiavue, Mr. Murray's brother-in-law and the group's co-director. Creole is an openwork, bare-bones group that unleashes improvisation on tunes in an old Guadeloupean style called ka, after a traditional drum.

title: Police Union Trying to Undo Pay Deal With Nassau County
description: Nassau County's police union moved today to kill an agreement that municipal unions reached last month with County Executive Thomas S. Gulotta to temporarily inject $20 million into the cash-strapped county's coffers.

title: U.S. Plays Down Meeting With Chechen Minister
description: The State Department said today that several ''working level'' officials would meet with the foreign minister of Chechnya after deciding that a session with senior administration officials would confer too much legitimacy on the Russian republic.

title: Redefining Herself, Without the Pedestal
description: Women: you can't live with 'em and can't live without 'em. They were confined to the kitchen, the nursery and the realm of sexual fantasies for centuries, till sprung from the first two by the march of history. But artists have most often put them on one pedestal or another, disguised as goddesses, queens, aristocrats, saints or courtesans.

title: He Kicks, Scores, Then Lets Loose
description: Martin Gramatica remembers his first extra-point attempt. It was six years ago when he was a high school senior in Florida.

title: AIDS Surges in Black and Hispanic Men
description: For the first time since AIDS was discovered nearly 20 years ago, AIDS was diagnosed in more black and Hispanic gay men than in white gays in 1998, Federal health officials reported yesterday.

title: THOMSON WILL BUY RACAL
description: The biggest European military electronics company, Thomson-CSF S.A. of France, agreed to acquire Racal Electronics P.L.C. of Britain for $2.17 billion in cash, in the latest round of consolidation in the European military industry. The combined company, with annual sales of $7.8 billion, will be listed on the London Stock Exchange. The deal will give Thomson a foothold in the key market, helping offset its defeat last year by BAe Systems P.L.C., which was then known as British Aerospace, in a bidding war for control of the Marconi Electronics division of the General Electric Company of Britain. John Tagliabue

title: Plotting Your Winter Days to Gather the Light
description: Two years ago, Joe, the man I lived with, suggested that we outfit our apartment with a light especially created to combat the winter blues. Seasonal affective disorder is its quaint moniker. In fact, the condition is nothing more than a hunger for daylight during the darkest days of winter.

title: For Vegetarians
description: Vegetarian food often conjures up an image of cuisine more suited to the soul than the palate. This need not be the case, as demonstrated by these 12 restaurants. Although not all are strictly vegetarian, they reflect the variety of rewarding tastes that can be savored from this fare. (These summaries are taken from dining reviews, columns and articles in The Times by William Grimes, Eric Asimov and others.)

description: Big Plans For Summer

title: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
description: CRUDE OIL RISES. Crude oil rose after Saudi Arabia indicated that OPEC might keep output limits in place for the rest of the year. In New York, crude oil for February delivery rose 41 cents, or 1.6 percent, to $26.69 a barrel.

title: Creative Testimony to a Time of Turbulence
description: The period from just after World War I until the end of World War II was the most tumultuous of the 20th century. There was catastrophic economic collapse, Fascism, genocide, the atomic bomb. But this was also the era of the Roaring Twenties and the New Deal, a time of collectivism, unrecedented cooperation between international allies and bold innovation in the arts.

description: Siu Tang, 17, said the worst thing about being homeless was the stares she got from passers-by, leering glances that said, ''What's wrong with you?''

description: Taking his campaign from town-hall meetings to the state Capitol, Senator John McCain of Arizona told the New Hampshire Legislature today that if he was elected president, he would create a cabinet post for a ''reform czar'' to oversee his efforts ''to restore a government of, by and for the American people.''

description: Shannon Miller was asleep last Wednesday night when the phone rang. It was 2:15 a.m. Must be Finland. Miller, the former Olympic and Canadian national women's hockey coach, leaned over, picked up the phone and switched on the light. The scene has become the norm for Miller over the past 18 months, while she has been recruiting a dazzling array of international stars for the fledgling program at the University of Minnesota-Duluth, where she is the head coach.

description: Allen K. Breed, a pioneer in air bag technology for cars and founder of one of the world's largest manufacturers of automobile safety systems, Breed Technologies of Lakeland, Fla., died Dec. 13 at a hospital in Orlando, Fla. He was 72.

description: Microsoft's top executives said today that they were still hopeful of settling the government antitrust case against the company before a federal judge issues his final ruling. And they said company officials had had far-reaching internal discussions about their options.

title: SLIGHT GAIN FOR FORBES
description: Gov. George W. Bush's lead over Steve Forbes, his nearest competitor in Iowa, has narrowed but remains commanding among likely Republican caucus-goers, a poll has found. The poll, conducted for a group of Midwestern television stations, put Mr. Bush at 46.3 percent and Mr. Forbes at 17.3 percent. That margin is six points less than a similar poll in November. The poll of 300 likely Republican caucus voters on Monday by PSI Research of Alexandria, Va., has a margin of sampling error of six percentage points. Senator John McCain, who has not campaigned Iowa, had 9.7 percent according to the poll. John Files (NYT)

title: Fleet Boston Shifts Agency Roster
description: Fleet Boston is reducing its agency roster, shifting assignments for the brokerage firm Quick & Reilly that had been handled for three years by Publicis in New York, part of Publicis S.A., to other roster agencies. Spending has ranged from $2 million to $5 million over the last two years.

description: After three quarters of results that disappointed investors, the Intel Corporation posted fourth-quarter earnings today that exceeded Wall Street's expectations because of strong demand for personal computers and a shift toward higher-performance chips with better profit margins.

title: RAWLINGS SPORTING GOODS SAYS ACQUISITION TALKS FAILED
description: The Rawlings Sporting Goods Company said yesterday that talks about being acquired by an investor group led by the Bull Run Corporation had failed. Rawlings said it had invited the Bull Run group last week to make a cash offer of $10 each for the 7.9 million Rawlings shares outstanding. But Bull Run declined, and acquisition talks will cease, Rawlings said. Rawlings, which is based in Fenton, Mo., manufactures team sports equipment. It reported $165.4 million in revenue for the last 12 months. Its stock fell $1.375 a share, to $5.25, in Nasdaq trading. Bull Run, based in Atlanta, sells computer printers. Its Total Sports affiliate in an online sports media company.

title: Penney Issues Review Invitations
description: The J. C. Penney Company has invited five agencies to take part in a review for assignments that include its national corporate account, with billings estimated at $115 million or more. The review began last week when Penney dismissed its agency of almost nine years, Temerlin McClain in Irving, Tex., a unit of True North Communications.

title: Prada Gains Challenger Finals
description: And now it is America One against Prada.

title: SANDISK TO RECORD $344 MILLION GAIN FROM MERGER
description: The SanDisk Corporation said it would record a first-quarter pretax gain of $344 million from the merger of United Silicon Inc. and the United Microelectronics Corporation. SanDisk, which is based in Sunnyvale, Calif., said it had invested $51 million in United Silicon, a joint-venture semiconductor manufacturing operation headed by United Microelectronics in Taiwan. After taxes, the gain will be $204 million, SanDisk said. SanDisk shares gained $2.75, to $88.375.

title: Merger Talks By SmithKline And Glaxo
description: Two British pharmaceutical giants, SmithKline Beechham P.L.C. and Glaxo Wellcome P.L.C., are near agreement on an $80.7 billion merger that would create the world's largest drug maker, executives close to the talks said here tonight.

title: Herb Graff, 74, Film Devotee And Preservationist, Is Dead
description: Herb Graff, who devoted most of his life to collecting, preserving and showing movies, especially early talkies of the 1930's, and a cinephile whose calling card read simply but accurately ''Film Resource,'' died on Sunday at his home in Manhattan. He was 74.

description: Responding to statements by Lothar Matthaus, who has contended that he has been deceived by the MetroStars, the team's new general manager, Nick Sakiewicz, said he would travel to Spain and meet with the internationally known soccer defender on Monday.

description: KAHN-Evelyn M. On January 13, 2000. Loving daughter of the late Harris and Rose Kahn and her late brother Murray. Cherished aunt of Richard and Michael Kahn. A memorial service today, Jan 15th, 12 noon, St. Peter's By The Sea Episcopal Church, Central St., Narragansett, R.I. In lieu of flowers donations in his memory to either the Lighthouse for the Blind, 111 E. 59 St., NY,NY 10022 or Hospice South Team, 143 Main St., Wakefield, R.I. 02879 would be appreciated.

title: AOL and Time Warner Retreat As Wall Street Reviews Outlook
description: The shares of America Online declined $1.3125, or 2 percent, yesterday, to $63.1875, while Time Warner's fell 75 cents, to $83.25, as investors struggled to figure out the financial outlook for the $165 billion merger that the two companies announced on Monday.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KAPLAN, SHIRLEY F.
description: KAPLAN-Shirley F. Of Old Westbury, LI and Jupiter, FL. Born in Worcester, MA. Beloved wife of Robert. Devoted mother of Linda Kaplan, Deborah Kaplan Brooks, Edward and Barton Kaplan. Cherished mother-in-law of Joel Brooks and Penny Kaplan. Dear sister of Marvin Zebrak and Jeanette Simon of Worcester, Ma. Loving grandmother of Heather and Lee kaplan and Stephanie, Michael and Hilary Brooks. Services Sunday, 12 Noon, at ''Gutterman's'', 8000 Jericho Turnpike, Woodbury, L.I.

title: Connick and Crew, Smooth Yet Aggressively Abstract
description: ''When I play my music, I start it with a roux,'' sang Lucien Barbarin, trombonist, in ''Luscious,'' a show-stopper written for him by his band leader, Harry Connick Jr. Mr. Connick's lyric gave the secret to his tasty work at Radio City Music Hall on Thursday.

title: Sermons on the Climb to the Mountaintop
description: The sermon, an enduring genre of American literature, began in the Puritan settlements and continued through the centuries as a public ritual to express spiritual and moral concerns of the day. As a rule, the sermon uses a text from Scripture to educate listeners. Each century has had its impassioned orators -- from John Winthrop and Cotton Mather to Jonathan Edwards, Ralph Waldo Emerson and Aimee Semple McPherson -- and its issues, from religion and politics to pro- and antiwar sentiments. Below are excerpts from a new collection, ''American Sermons'' (The Library of America), including sermons about slavery and ''I've Been to the Mountaintop'' by the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr., whose birthday is today.

title: State Bailout to Rescue Financially Troubled Newark School District
description: When the New Jersey Department of Education took control of Newark schools in 1995, one goal was to improve the district's troubled finances. Five years later, the state still runs the district, which faces a $58 million deficit that accumulated under the former state-appointed superintendent.

Giuliani gave what may have been his last ''State of the City'' address on Thursday, and it was clear from the paeans to himself that he has no doubts about his place in history. But New Yorkers not blessed with his omniscience are only starting to decide where he ranks.

title: School District Still Suffering After Settling L.I. Tax Fight

title: E-CAMPAIGNING

Besides free e-mail and chat rooms, the service will give members customized Web pages that will provide updates on Republican developments, as well as what party officials called an ''anti-smut filter'' and unbiased reporting about news events. The service is intended for ''people who want freedom FROM the press,'' according to an advertisement. Don Van Natta Jr. (NYT)

description: The price of oil, which had been stuck in a trading range since it popped above $27 a barrel once in November, topped $28 a barrel yesterday after an OPEC committee recommended extending current production cuts beyond March's expiration date.

title: Winter in New York: Something's Missing; Absence of Snow Upsets Rhythms Of Urban Life and Natural World

title: Kursumlija Journal; Serbs at Border Complain of Attacks From Kosovo
description: The Serbian chief of police here looks weary. For him the war in Kosovo is not only not over, but has come closer. He says Albanians from Kosovo are crossing the border into his district in the adjacent part of Serbia and attacking villagers and the police.

title: The Searing Pain of Chile's Past
description: To the Editor:

title: Flamenco With an Irish Lilt
description: A production called ''Flamenco!'' offered fascinating examples of Spanish music and dance on Saturday night at the Kaye Playhouse. The program, presented by the World Music Institute in association with Miguel Marin Productions, made especially effective use of Italian opera and Irish fiddling.

title: The Cozy World of Judges and Lawyers
description: Political patronage is so deeply entrenched in some corners of New York State's court system that well-connected lawyers consider it a personal entitlement to receive lucrative legal assignments from the judges they help elect. The public got a revealing glimpse of this sleazy culture earlier this month through disclosure of a candid letter written by two officials of the Brooklyn Democratic Party to protest being excluded from patronage spoils. The two officials complained about being frozen out of legal work by another well-connected lawyer who funneled the work to his own firm instead, notwithstanding their ''unquestioned loyalty'' to the party.

title: U.S. Fights Tide on a Move to Raise the Military Service Age
description: The United States, which wants to keep the option of sending soldiers into combat at 17, found itself with few allies in negotiations this week on an international agreement to set a new minimum age for recruitment and active military service.

title: War Crimes Court Convicts 5 Bosnian Croats in '93 Massacre
description: The international war crimes tribunal in The Hague, in its largest case to date, convicted and sentenced five Bosnian Croat militiamen today for taking part in the massacre of more than 100 Muslims in a Bosnian village in April 1993.

title: RPC TO SPIN OFF CHAPARRAL, A BOAT BUILDER
description: RPC Inc. disclosed plans to spin off its Chaparral Boats Inc. unit, which makes fiberglass power boats, to shareholders in the third quarter to focus on its service and equipment business for oil fields. The companies will trade separately on the New York Stock Exchange, RPC said. The company, based in Atlanta, has a market value of almost $184 million. The tax-free transaction is subject to approval from the Internal Revenue Service. Chaparral, whose boats range in length from 18 feet to 35 feet, accounted for 42 percent of RPC's sales of $244.3 million in 1998. RPC said the spinoff would set the stage for acquisitions and allow its boat and oil field businesses to tailor strategies for their different markets. RPC shares rose 75 cents, to $6.4375.

title: Onetime Wise Guy Rates Another Kind of Mob Hit
description: Tommy Del Giorno will be watching critically when the much-hyped television mob series ''The Sopranos'' begins its second season on HBO tomorrow night at 9. ''I get a kick out of the show,'' said Mr. Del Giorno, who has lived the mob life.

title: Gay Troops in Europe
description: The British government has bowed to a ruling of the European Court of Human Rights and ended its ban on gays in the military. Nearly every NATO member has now ceased discrimination against gay men and women in the armed forces. Britain's defense department, like that of the United States, long maintained that the presence of openly gay troops would hurt morale and discipline. But there is ample evidence from other European nations, like France, that this is not true.

title: EQUITY RESIDENTIAL TO ACQUIRE GLOBE BUSINESS RESOURCES
description: Equity Residential Properties Trust, a real estate investment trust based in Chicago, said yesterday that it had agreed to acquire Globe Business Resources Inc., a housing and furniture-rental company in Cincinnati, for about $65 million. Under the agreement, Globe stockholders will receive $13 a share at closing and as much as an additional 50 cents a share later, based on a determination of costs relating to potential breaches of certain representations and covenants. Globe shares rose 31.25 cents, to $12.1875.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption on Wednesday with a Critic's Notebook article about the Metropolitan Opera's ''Great Gatsby'' misidentified the singer at the left. He was Dwayne Croft, not Mark Baker.

title: Dr. Paul B. Sigler, 65, Scientist Who Studied Organic Structure
description: Dr. Paul Benjamin Sigler, a molecular biologist at Yale and a pioneer in the study of the organic structure of organisms, collapsed and died on Tuesday on a walk from his home to his laboratory on the campus in New Haven. He was 65.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BARTHOLOMEW, DANA TREAT
description: BARTHOLOMEW-Dana Treat. 93, of Old Lyme, CT. Died December 31, 1999. Born in Ansonia, CT in 1906, he graduated from Choate School and Yale University, class of 1928. After attending Harvard Business School, he worked for Tricontinental, then Alcan/Aluminium Ltd. He retired to Old Lyme, CT. His wife died October 29. They leave three children, Dwight Bartholomew of Wenatchee, WA, Adela S. Wilmerding of Princeton, NJ, and Andrew Bartholomew of Montecatini, Italy; 11 grandchildren and 9 great grandchildren. There will be a memorial service at the First Congregational Church in Old Lyme, on Saturday January 22, at 2pm. Contributions in his memory to: The Old Lyme Phoebe Griffin Noyes Library, the Old Lyme Conservation Trust.

title: Harder Nuclear Arms Policy Is Now Official Kremlin Line
description: Underscoring its darkening view of the West, the Kremlin issued a national security strategy today that inveighs against an expansionist Europe and United States and contemplates the use of nuclear weapons in war ''if all other means of resolving the crisis have been exhausted.''

title: South Korea Pursues A Space-Age Future
description: South Korea, setting its sights on conquering outer space, plans to develop a rocket capable of ferrying satellites into orbit within the next five years. Its space agency estimates the costs at $500 million to $1 billion although independent experts say it could run as high as several billion dollars.

title: CAMPAIGN BRIEFING: JOHN McCAIN; OWN MEDICINE?
description: Senator John McCain has upbraided the Republican establishment in New York, which is allied with Gov. George W. Bush, for considering a challenge to Mr. McCain's nomination petitions to get him thrown off the ballot. But in 1998, Mr. McCain's Senate campaign challenged the petitions of a Republican candidate named Bert Tollefson. Mr. Tollefson was effectively forced to withdraw, leaving Mr. McCain with no primary opponent. But a McCain campaign spokesman, Howard Opinsky, said yesterday that the laws in Arizona were far more forgiving than those in New York. Clifford J. Levy (NYT)

title: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
description: THE EURO FALLS The euro fell to a two-week low against the dollar after a report on consumer prices indicated inflation remained under control. In New York, the euro settled at $1.0143, down from $1.0254 Thursday.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DREXLER, LYNNE MAPP
description: DREXLER-Lynne Mapp, 71 died December 30, 1999 at her Island home. Born at Newport News, VA, May 21, 1928, educated at Richmond Professional Institute, College of William and Mary and at Hunter College Graduate School. Was a prolific painter, exhibited her work in New York, Los Angeles, Honolulu, and Maine. Survived by husband John Hultberg of New York City. Funeral service January 31 at the Monhegan Community Church. Donations to: Lynne Drexler Memorial Fund, PO Box 366, Monhegan Island, ME 04852. Information: Davis Funeral Home, 35 Knox St., Thomaston, ME 04861.

title: 'Pay to Play' Justice
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DENISH, ARTHUR
description: DENISH-Arthur, 73, on January 13, 2000. Husband of Peggy. Survived by three children, four grandchildren and one brother. Friends are invited to the memorial service Sunday 2PM at Bradley Funeral Home, Marlton, NJ. 856983-1005. Donations may be made to either the American Cancer Society or the Parkinsons Disease Association.

title: Deal Struck to Save Upper East Side Hospital
description: Ending an odd and acrimonious power struggle over the future of the Manhattan Eye, Ear and Throat Hospital, the hospital on the Upper East Side has struck a deal to be taken over by Lenox Hill Hospital and continue to offer everything from eye surgery to tummy tucks.

title: The Neediest Cases; Vacation Turns Into a Penniless Exile
description: Maritza Maldonando thought, back in August 1995, that it would be just an innocent, uneventful two-week vacation to New York City. What she got instead, she said, was ''instability'' and exile from her native Dominican Republic.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HYMOWITZ, STANLEY
description: HYMOWITZ - Stanley. Beloved husband of Zelda. Devoted father of Ronni and Jeff Roth, Jeffrey and Carri Hymowitz. Adored grandfather of Heather, Jacob and Ari. Dearest son of the late Hyman and Anna Hymowitz. Fond brother of the late Bernard. Services were held Tuesday at Weinstein Memorial Chapels, Yonkers. He was deeply loved and will be greatly missed, one in a million.

title: Justice Dept. Is Investigating Poll Closings in South Carolina
description: Alerted to the closing of polling places in black neighborhoods in South Carolina's last Republican presidential primary, the Justice Department has begun asking pointed questions about both parties' coming primaries, political officials around the state said today. The inquiry raises the possibility that the primaries could be challenged by the government under the Voting Rights Act.

title: Attica Reparations
description: To the Editor:

title: TEXANS BACK BUSH
description: No surprise, but Gov. George W. Bush's fellow Texans support him overwhelmingly, according to a new Dallas Morning News/Houston Chronicle poll. Mr. Bush leads Vice President Al Gore 59 percent to 32 percent and former Senator Bill Bradley 62 percent to 28 percent. Mr.Gore led Mr. Bradley 54 percent to 24 percent in the poll, which had a margin of sampling error of six percentage points. Ross Milloy (NYT)

title: Rise in Death Rate After New Year Is Tied to the Will to See 2000
description: As the year 2000 approached, most Americans thought mainly of New Year's revelry or the possibility of widespread computer failure. But some apparently were focused on something much more basic: drawing breath on Jan. 1.

title: For Knicks and Hornets, A Day to Mourn Phills
description: When the league decided to postpone tonight's game between the Knicks and the Hornets, it gave the Knicks a reprieve of one game from being placed in the awkward position of playing a team in mourning. On Saturday night, they will face Charlotte at Madison Square Garden, as scheduled.

title: Bigotry as Mental Illness Or Just Another Norm
description: In 1851, Dr. Samuel A. Cartwright, a Louisiana surgeon and psychologist, filed a report in the New Orleans Medical and Surgical Journal on diseases prevalent among the South's black population. Among the various maladies Dr. Cartwright described was ''drapetomania'' or ''the disease causing slaves to run away.''

title: New York and 7 Other States to Be Spared Medicare Cuts
description: Hospitals in New York and seven other states will be spared cuts in Medicare payments under a decision announced today by the secretary of Health and Human Services, Donna E. Shalala.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ANDERSON, JERVIS
description: ANDERSON-Jervis. We will sorely miss our beloved Jervis, genial companion, gifted writer and historian, lover of Vermont. Beverly Sanders, Michael T. Gilmore, Deborah Valenze, Marya, Johs. and Kaia Huseby, and Andrew Mathews will cherish the memories of our years of friendship.

title: Both Hands and Forearms Transplanted for First Time
description: An international team of surgeons performed the world's first double hand-and-forearm transplant on Thursday in Lyon, France, on a 33-year-old Frenchman who lost his hands in a fireworks accident in 1996.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DAFFNER, BEATRICE IVRY ERNST
description: DAFFNER-Beatrice Ivry Ernst. Age 95. On January 11, 2000. Loving mother and mother-in-law of Naomi and Stuart Paley, Judith and Victor Linn and Howard Ernst. Devoted sister of Billie Ivry. Dear grandmother of Adam and Rachel, Jane and Andrew, Gregory and Lisa and Jason. Greatgrandmother of Jeffrey, Emily and Zachary Linn and Hannah Paley. Wife of Phillip and the late Abraham Ernst. Service Friday 12 noon at ''The Riverside'', 76 Street and Amsterdam Avenue. Visiting at ''The Riverside'' Thursday 79PM. Contributions in her memory may be made to Sutton Place Chapter of Hadassah.

title: 3 of 4 United States Teams Advance in Bermuda Play
description: Three American teams survived a week of qualifying play in the Orbis world team championships here this afternoon, but a fourth just failed to reach the playoffs starting Saturday.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BERGEN, FLORENCE V. (NEE KUPIEC)
description: BERGEN-Florence V. (nee Kupiec). Beloved wife of the late Harry. Loving mother of Thomas and Harry. Devoted grandmother of Manuel, Matthew, Michael and Christopher. Dear great-grandmother of Stephanie. Reposing Michaels Funeral Home, Inc., 79-22 Metropolitan Avenue, Middle Village, NY Sunday and Monday 25pm & 7-9pm. Mass of Christian burial Tuesday at 9:45am at St. Margaret's R.C. church. Interment Calvary cemetery.

title: Marist's Dunbar Eases Way Back
description: About a month after a near-fatal car accident left him in a coma for 10 days, Rashid Dunbar stood at the free throw line in a gym in Children's Specialized Hospital in Mountainside, N.J.

title: Journal; Two 21st Century Foxes Elope
description: C.E.O. of the United States may be a big job, but the White House, like everything else, looks smaller this week next to the new AOL Time Warner. The most mega mega-merger in history reduced the imminent presidential primaries to quaint sideshows, relics of a distant age flickering along the fringes of the evening news. Press and public alike instinctively recognized that the first (though hardly the last) consummated marriage between new media and old is going to shape our lives long after we've forgotten which politician had which health or tax-cut plan.

title: Corrections
description: The Classical Music and Dance Guide in Weekend yesterday misstated the site for ''Regina'' by the Bronx Opera Company. It will be performed tonight at 8 at the John Jay College Theater, 899 10th Avenue, between 58th and 59th Streets, in Manhattan, not at Lehman College in the Bronx.

title: Scientists Discover Black Hole That Is Both Cool and Nearby
description: Looking into the deep sky with new eyes, the Chandra X-Ray Observatory has taken the temperature of a surprisingly ''cool'' black hole at the core of the nearby Andromeda galaxy, examined stars in infancy and death and tracked the debris from an exploded star, the stuff out of which planets may take shape.

title: Gay Scout Leaders
description: The Supreme Court will decide whether the Boy Scouts have a right to exclude gay Scouts from positions of leadership.

title: BACK IN NEW HAMPSHIRE
description: Patrick J. Buchanan yesterday made his first campaign stop in New Hampshire since a brief appearance on Oct. 25 when he announced his bid for the Reform Party presidential nomination. Mr. Buchanan said of the Democrats and Republicans, ''The two Washington parties have become Xerox copies of one another. But he called himself ''the defending champion of the New Hampshire primary,'' referring to his defeat of former Senator Bob Dole in the 1996 Republican contest there. Brian E. Zittel (NYT)

title: Telesco Knows All, Reveals Nothing
description: If David Telesco was concerned about his match tonight against Roy Jones Jr., the undisputed light heavyweight champion of the world, his eyes did not betray him.

title: Redskins and Buccaneers Will Not Rely on Gimmicks
description: Tony Dungy, the coach of the Tampa Bay Buccaneers, is considered the best defensive mind left in the National Football League playoffs. Norv Turner, the Washington coach, is the offensive guru, who, under much duress this season, brought the Redskins back to the playoffs for the first time in seven years.

title: LUCIO TAN'S BANK HOLDING
description: The Philippine investor Lucio Tan says he controls almost half of the shares in Philippine National Bank, the nation's third-biggest lender, making him the single biggest stockholder. He did not provide details on the price paid for the stock or the timing of the share purchase. In December, the bank disclosed that Mr. Tan, who has airline, pig farming and tobacco businesses, controlled 35 percent of the bank's total outstanding stock. Mr. Tan is among potential buyers of a 30 percent stake in the bank to be auctioned by the government later this year.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption yesterday about Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani's arrival in the City Council chamber for his State of the City address misidentified the man in the foreground applauding. He was William C. Rudin, the real estate developer, not George McDonald, president of the Doe Fund social services agency.

title: Mannesmann Says Offer Is Not in Its Best Interest
description: Facing an uphill fight to ward off the biggest hostile takeover in history, the chairman of Mannesmann A.G. sought to fortify his defense against Vodafone AirTouch P.L.C. today with both sweet talk and intransigence.

title: Both Mysterious and Nutty
description: If there had been an applause meter on the premises, the needle would very likely have swung off the high end for the Condors, one of four troupes making their American debuts in ''Emerging Dance From Japan'' on Saturday night at the Japan Society. Hilarious short takes flashed by at dizzying speed in Ryohei Kondo's ''Conquest of the Galaxy: Jupiter,'' danced to a musical collage that included what sounded like Hollywood movie music.

title: Alfred Nzo, 74, Leading Figure In African National Congress
description: Alfred Nzo, who helped lead some of the earliest battles against South Africa's apartheid regime and decades later became the country's first black foreign minister, died on Thursday in a clinic here. He was 74.

title: St. John's Needs Speed To Beat Huskies' Press
description: Erick Barkley collapsed to the floor as the buzzer sounded after St. John's victory over Georgetown this week. Weary and whipped from playing all but one minute of the game, Barkley was helped up by his teammates, took his seat behind the microphones and said he could go another 10 minutes of overtime if he had to.

title: Agreement Is Signed on Return Of 84,000 Acres to Ute Indians
description: As good fortune for Utah, it might not equal Salt Lake City's winning the right to stage the 2002 winter Olympics, but it seemed it was not far off.

title: Jaguars Planning Conservative Game Against Redskins
description: Mark Brunell, the Jacksonville quarterback, could manage only a rueful chuckle at the question: With braces on both knees, would he ask for tips on how to operate with such restrictions from Miami's Dan Marino, who is so notoriously immobile that an omnipresent brace hardly affects his movement?

description: Medicare Boon for New York

title: FAMILY OUTINGS
description: Governor Bush's campaign is bringing out the big-name surrogates. His father, former President George Bush, who stumped for his son in Iowa on Thursday, will campaign for him in South Carolina on Saturday, the Bush campaign announced yesterday. Governor Bush's brother Jeb, the governor of Florida, will work in New Hampshire for him on Saturday, and Elizabeth Dole will make three appearances on his behalf in Iowa on Saturday and another three in South Carolina on Sunday. Frank Bruni (NYT)

description: The Supreme Court agreed today to decide, in a closely watched case from New Jersey, whether the Boy Scouts have a constitutional right to exclude gay youths and adults from positions of leadership.

description: As the hymn music ushered in the mourners, a restless 3-year-old boy in the first row of pews noticed the bright orange bouquet arranged in the shape of a basketball.

description: THE AMERICAS

title: Tourism Diamond in the Rough; South Africa's Beauty and Its Beasts Are the Draw
description: South Africa's name is famous around the globe, a legacy of the apartheid era that etched the country into the conscience of the world but left it a foreboding and unfamiliar place to many of the travelers it would now like to attract.

title: NIKE SHIRTS CALLED NOT HAZARDOUS
description: Germany's consumer protection office says the Nike soccer jerseys that were pulled from store shelves last week after reports they contained a dangerous chemical do not present any health hazards. At the same time, the office said the chemical, tributyltin, or TBT, which was used in the shirts to reduce odors from sweating, should be banned. Over the years TBT has been used for anti-barnacle paint on the hulls of ships, but British and Dutch tests have shown it causes mutations in marine snails, and the World Wildlife Fund wants a global ban.

title: THIS WEEKEND'S SCHEDULE
description: BILL BRADLEY -- Campaigning in Cedar Rapids, Iowa, today and in Waterloo, Iowa, tomorrow.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROSE, O. ALAN
description: ROSE-O. Alan. The Lenox Hill Hospital, Department of Medicine mourns the loss if its esteemed colleaque O. Alan Rose, MD, a member of the Department since 1941. Dr. Rose served as the Chief of the Cardiac Clinic for years, was a clinical investigator of cardiac drug therapy and an active member of our teaching faculty. A gifted and compassionate physician, his devotion to his many patients was unwavering. He leaves behind a legacy of service to this Department and its programs in patient care and medical education. We extend our heartfelt sympathy to his wife Frances B.Rose, MD, and his family. Michael S. Bruno, MD Director/Medicine Ira R. Hoffman, MD Associate Director/Medicine

title: Breast Cancer Study Points To Difference in Recurrence
description: Women under 45 who have lumpectomies for an early form of breast cancer are more likely than older women to have the disease come back, and that may be in part because surgeons are not removing enough breast tissue, researchers are reporting today.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  COLANGELO, MARIA
description: COLANGELO-Maria. In loving memory of our beloved sister-inlaw and friend. Life won't be the same without you. With much love Vincent, Marcy, Michael and Bennett.

title: James P. O'Neil, 55, President Of Financial Printing Company
description: James P. O'Neil, the president and chief operating officer of Browne & Company, believed to be the country's second-oldest publicly traded company and one of the world's leading financial printers, died on Thursday in New York City. He was 55 and lived in Wayne, N.J.

title: OLD MUTUAL WEIGHS ACQUISITION
description: South Africa's biggest insurance company, Old Mutual, is in talks about acquiring the Gerrard Group, a British fund management and specialty banking company, for a cash price that could total $887 million. Old Mutual, which moved its headquarters to Britain last year, has said it wants to expand into European markets. Henri E. Cauvin

description: With a Sunday deadline looming, Security Council differences hardened today over whom to appoint as the new chief arms inspector for Iraq.

description: GOLDMAN-Janis. Lovingly remembered today and every day.

title: Unraveling Family Secret, Man Admits Role in '58 Murder of Officer
description: A 61-year-old Pennsylvania man pleaded guilty today to acting as an accomplice in the murder of a Rahway police officer 41 years ago, implicating his cousin as the gunman and revealing a pact of silence about the killing that many of his relatives carried to their graves.

title: Devereux Milburn, 82, Sportsman and Lawyer
description: Devereux Milburn Jr., a sportsman and Wall Street lawyer who was a skilled performer both on polo fields and in courtrooms, died on Monday at his home in Narragansett, R.I. He was 82.

title: Coachless, Jets Await Coming Decisions
description: The Jets begin another uncertain weekend today. This time, at least, they know who their new owner is, but still unsettled is the identity of the next head coach. And the team may face another bitter dispute with the New England Patriots over the price for snatching away a coach who is already under contract.

title: Standing Up For Republicanism
description: This morning there will be a memorial service for the Republican Party's man for all seasons: Elliot Richardson. In a pantheon of distinguished public servants of the century, Richardson holds a special niche for his role in upholding the rule of law. He understood that allegiance to the Constitution supersedes loyalty to party or person.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HALL, CHARLOTTE
description: HALL-Charlotte. The Officers and Members of the Transport Workers Union of America, AFL-CIO mourn the death of Charlotte Hall, 87, mother of TWU International President, Sonny Hall. Our profound condolences go out to President Sonny Hall and the Hall family. Viewing Sunday, 7-9 PM and Monday 2-5 and 7-9 PM at the Williams Funeral Home, Broadway and 232nd Street, Bronx. Funeral Mass, Tuesday, 10 AM at St. Margaret of Cortona Church, 260th Street and Riverdale Avenue, Riverdale, NY. Donations may be sent to St. Patrick's Nursing Home, 660 Van Cortlandt Park South, Bronx, NY 10463. Frank McCann, TWU Executive VP John Kerrigan TWU Secy/Treasurer

title: Republicans Open a Big Drive to Appeal to Hispanic Voters
description: After the lights had dimmed in a hotel meeting room here, Republican officials introduced a 60-second television commercial that they say will help court Hispanic voters, whose rapidly growing population makes them a political force that could swing the largest states in the presidential election this fall.

description: Hollywood Studios Join Legal Battle To Stop DVD Copying

title: Corrections
description: A map in Circuits on Thursday with an article about the high-speed Internet service called D.S.L. showed its availability in the Los Angeles area incompletely. The areas shown as covered or soon to be covered were for Pacific Bell, the region's largest company; they did not include those of other companies.

title: 'Traviata' Lumbers Back to the Met
description: When a new production at the Metropolitan Opera gets lambasted by critics, the company obviously cannot afford to toss out the whole show and start over. But often the Met will fix the most egregious problems when the production returns.

title: What Provokes a Rapist to Rape?; Scientists Debate Notion of an Evolutionary Drive
description: Rape is primarily a crime of violence and power, not sex. Or so a generation of social scientists and feminist scholars have argued.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RINGSTAD, JACK
description: RINGSTAD-Jack. 75. On January 13, 2000. Born May 26, 1925. Survived by wife, Connie Clarke; sons John Jr. and Geoffrey Ringstad. A celebration of his life will be held at the S&P Oyster House on the Mystic River, Connecticut on January 17 from 2-5 p.m.

title: New Twist in the Pinochet Case
description: Britain's declaration that Gen. Augusto Pinochet is medically unfit to stand trial should not be the final word on this matter. More information is needed, and it can be provided under a reasonable plan proposed yesterday by the Spanish judge who is seeking to prosecute the former Chilean dictator for human rights abuses.

title: Suing on Nature's Behalf
description: The Supreme Court acted decisively this week to preserve one of the nation's most valuable tools for protecting the environment -- the ability of citizens to enforce federal anti-pollution laws through private legal actions. By a surprisingly lopsided 7-to-2 margin, the court voted to pull back from its own recent rulings, and those of lower federal courts, that had significantly narrowed the ability of environmental groups to pursue polluters in court.

title: Heater May Have Led to Fire That Killed 2
description: A Bangladeshi couple who were trying to keep warm with a portable heater in an apartment where the heat had been turned off were killed yesterday morning in a fire that destroyed the Queens residence, friends and relatives said.

title: Wal-Mart's Chief Steps Down; Trusted Lieutenant Is Successor
description: David D. Glass, who aggressively expanded Wal-Mart Stores Inc. from a rural discounter into a worldwide powerhouse during his 12-year tenure as chief executive and president, announced yesterday that he would step down immediately. As expected, he will be succeeded by his long-trusted lieutenant and chief operating officer, H. Lee Scott Jr.

title: Investing's Longtime Best Bet Is Being Trampled by the Bulls
description: Investing in the stock market for the long term, the strategy that has made the most sense and the most money for people over the years, is all but dead.

title: Artery Blocked, Letterman Has Heart Bypass Surgery
description: David Letterman, host of CBS's ''Late Show with David Letterman,'' had successful quintuple bypass heart surgery yesterday at New York Presbyterian Hospital, according to his publicist.

description: As border wars go, it's not India and Pakistan.

description: The Spanish judge behind efforts to try Gen. Augusto Pinochet for human rights abuses asked Britain today for a second medical examination of the former Chilean dictator to determine if earlier tests erred in ruling him unfit to stand trial.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  THOMSON, LUCIEN
description: THOMSON-Lucien, age eighty-six of New York City, died Tuesday, January 11, 2000. Survived by his first cousins Isabel D. Thomson of Atlanta, GA and Albert D. Thomson of Cotton, GA. Harpist, composer, author and teacher of the harp in New York City since 1946. Long-time member and past President of The American Harp Society, Inc. Memorial service to be announced. Contributions in lieu of flowers may be sent to American Harp Society Foundation-Marcel Grandjany fund, c/o Jan Bishop, 624 Crystal Ave, Findlay, OH 45840.

title: A Blend of Cuban Rhythms, Romanticism and Ragtime
description: With a handful of well-placed notes, the 78-year-old Cuban pianist Frank Emilio conjured a world of bygone elegance when he performed at the Kaplan Penthouse on Thursday night. Mr. Emilio was opening a two-week series of Latin jazz events for Jazz at Lincoln Center. In duets with William Rubalcaba on bass, he sketched a history of 20th-century Cuban music, mingling Afro-Cuban rhythms with imported notions from Romanticism to ragtime to boogie-woogie.

title: NYT Article
description: Sunbeam and Maytag to Make Internet Appliances

title: AMES DEPARTMENT STORES PLANS LAYOFFS AND NEW HIRING
description: Ames Department Stores, the discount retailer, said it planned to cut 493 jobs at three distribution centers while adding 100 positions at a fourth. It expects to lay off workers in Columbus, Ohio; Leesport, Pa., and Mansfield, Mass., and to add employees in Westfield, Mass. Ames, based in Rocky Hill, Conn., said that it was restructuring the four centers into one network by eliminating duplication of processes and that it expects to increase productivity and reduce shipping expenses. The company operates 455 stores in 19 states.

title: Corrections
description: A subheading in Business Day on Dec. 7 about the cracking of a code protecting some wireless telephone transmissions referred imprecisely to the achievement. Although cracking the code could jeopardize the security of phone calls, the ability was thus far theoretical; no occurrence was reported.

title: EXPORT GROWTH SLOWS
description: Exports from China increased at their slowest pace in six months in December, though economists say that they expect shipments to resume their rapid climb this year. Exports totaled $20.2 billion last month, a gain of 2.1 percent from the corresponding month a year earlier, according to the International Business Daily, which is published by the Ministry of Foreign Trade. That figure is far short of the 28.8 percent surge recorded in November and was the slowest pace since June, when exports fell 1.6 percent. Compared with the previous month, though, exports rose 3.6 percent in December, and they are expected to extend their expansion in 2000.

title: Books in Brief: Nonfiction; Realer Than Themselves
description: Richard Avedon's portraits have such iconic power that they are interchangeable with their subjects -- like that of Andy Warhol displaying the Frankenstein tracks of his abdominal scars after his shooting in 1968 or the solarized, acid-laced images of the Beatles. Half of the photographs in the 30-year retrospective volume THE SIXTIES, by Richard Avedon and Doon Arbus (Random House, $75), have never been published before. Avedon's signature technique of impeccably printed silver-process black-and-white images of his subjects against a seamless blank studio backdrop draws attention to textural details of skin, hair and costume to create portraits of class as well as of individuals. Nattily suited members of an American mission to Saigon are juxtaposed with a Vietnamese napalm victim whose face has been recontoured like melted candle wax. The viewer's gaze lingers over the embroidered battle ribbons of Lt. Joe Hooper, ''the most decorated American soldier in Vietnam,'' as well as his eerily tombstone-like teeth. The images are powerfully placed and selected by Doon Arbus, daughter of the photographer Diane Arbus, but the dated interviews are often hilariously disjointed. Avedon, with his level gaze both at the exhilaration of the era and the toll it took on people's lives, shows that anyone who merely romanticizes the 60's didn't live through them. Eric P. Nash

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DUBOIS, JOHN
description: DuBOIS-John. John ''The Cajun Balladeer DuBois'', a singer who will be posthumously inducted into the Louisiana Music Hall of Fame, died January 8, 2000 from a stroke at his home in the French Quarter. He was 74. Mr. DuBois was born in Vermillion Parish and lived for many years on the East Coast. He returned to Louisiana in the early 1980s where he took an active part in the state and New Orleans music scene. A popular and beloved performer and friend to many, Mr. DuBois' life spanned at least three careers in entertainment. After performing in summer stock and as a singer and actor in early television in New York City on the ''Colgate Comedy Hour'', with such stars as Jimmy Durante, Fred Allen, Eddie Cantor and Milton Berle, Mr. DuBois spent two decades in the hotel and hospitality industry, but never stopped performing. While residing for many years in Stockbridge, MA., he introduced the Cajun culture of his youth to the Berkshires with ''La Fete Acadienne'' and recorded Cajun ballads for the Folk Music Archives in the Library of Congress. When he returned to Louisiana, Mr. DuBois entered enthusiastically into the state's music world, performing in festivals ranging from New Orleans to Paris, France and leaving a legacy of classic Cajun music on popular CDs: ''Dans Le Creux DuBois'' and ''Rendev-Vous Louisianais''. His third ''Bayou Ballads'' contains a rare collection of ancient, almost forgotten French tunes passed on to him by his grandparents and his childhood music teacher, Catherine Brookshire Blanchett. Referring to his creatively expanded instrumentation, Bruce Boyd Raeburn of Tulane University wrote ''He has infused these songs with a new vitality, not only rescuing them from obscurity but also adding l'esprit DuBois.'' Mr. DuBois' dedication to preserving historic music led to his inclusion in the Louisiana Music Hall of Fame. Induction ceremonies will be April 16, 2000 in Lafayette. To be released this Spring, a fourth CD ''It's Never Too Late: John DuBois Celebrates the music of John Wallowitch'' is a collection of cabaret songs and show tunes composed by Mr. DuBois' longtime New York friend and colleague who was best known for his song ''New York, New York''. All Mr. DuBois' CDs are distinguished not only by authenticity of arrangement but also by the ensemble work of some of South Louisiana's finest traditional and contemporary musicians. He wrote of his recording works: ''I came to rejoice in the present by a return to the past. I am lucky to have had a past worth sharing with future generations. I now sing my songs everywhere. I must sing them, I must share them with you.'' Survivors include his wife, Christina DuBois, three sons Andre DuBois of Salt Lake City, UT., Michael DuBois of San Francisco and Christopher DuBois of Stockbridge, MA. and a sister Mary DuBois. The family requests that in lieu of flowers, memorials be sent to one of the following charities: Dr. Tommy Comeau Memorial Fund, to endow a chair in traditional music at the University of Louisiana at Lafayette, c/o Acadiana Arts Council, POB 53762, Lafayette, LA. 70501.
