Knapp of Vero Beach, Fla., and Karl W. Weisenbacher of Hampton Bays, N.Y. The Rev. Arthur Venezia will perform the ceremony at the Roman Catholic Church of St. Paul of the Cross in North Palm Beach, Fla.

title: Roosevelt Raceway: Last Lap
description: Nearly 12 years after its last race, the grandstand at Roosevelt Raceway, once a popular trotting-horse track but now a victim of declining interest in the sport, is finally being dismantled.

title: His Life Is a Movie, and He's the Star
description: JAMES TOBACK brought two props to lunch at the Fine & Schapiro deli on the Upper West Side last month. One was Raymond Durgnat's recent biography of King Vidor, which contained a picture of Mr. Toback and Mr. Vidor on the set of Mr. Toback's 1982 movie ''Love and Money.'' The other was ''Immobilarity,'' a CD by the rapper Raekwon, a member of the Wu-Tang Clan, with a dedication in the liner notes to ''James 'The Music Man' Toback.''

title: Laughing, and Not Amused, About Drugstore Remedies
description: To the Editor:

title: Sports of The Times; A Night to Behold At Hoops Central
description: IT is quite enough just to walk into the spacious, new, high-tech fieldhouse of Conseco Arena, with its serious basketball jones -- in one of the display cases, Oscar's jersey from Crispus Attucks High.

title: Substandard Behavior
description: Randy Cohen says that the ''desperately poor, the insane'' deserve ''more understanding on certain small transgressions'' like urinating in subway stations (The Ethicist, Dec. 26).

title: Conference Seeks Ways To Reduce Heroin Deaths
description: Larry W. Campbell, chief coroner of British Columbia, where deaths from drug overdoses have risen tenfold in the last decade, to 407 last year, said he came to Seattle this week for one reason.

title: Early Results of Bridge Tournament
description: The quarterfinal playoffs in the Orbis World Bridge Championships began here this afternoon, and three American teams were in hard battles.

title: An Attempt To Recapture The Elusive Piaf Mystique
description: WHERE singers are concerned, imitation is often the insincerest form of flattery. Imitating the sound of someone else's voice is never solely an act of homage, however inspired by admiration. Rather, it is a kind of cannibalization, with one singer feeding on a more singular existing voice and saying: ''Hey, I can do that. But this way.''

title: Push for Powerball: High Odds, but Don't Count It Out
description: Would anyone turn down a lottery jackpot worth $124 million a year? Certainly not all those frenzied New Yorkers who flock to Connecticut for a shot at a bank-busting payout from the Powerball lottery.

title: Redskins Waited for the Kick That Never Came
description: Many Washington Redskins players dressed quickly and scooted out the somber locker room, still stunned by the harsh ending to their season.

title: The Actors Who Have Two Faces
description: IN a tradition that runs from the early western star Broncho Billy Anderson to Clint Eastwood, from Charles Chaplin to Woody Allen, actors have used the movies to mold their own identities and contemplate their own images -- a necessary process whenever stars decide to direct themselves.

title: Debating Retirement's New Lines
description: ''On the Retirement Road, 65 Is Still Their Limit'' (Seniority, Jan. 2), by Fred Brock, suggested that raising the retirement age to 70 would be difficult for Americans whose jobs required hard physical labor -- construction workers, for example. The column drew varied responses from readers.

title: A Retailer Moves a Bit North With the Shoes Bearing His Name
description: Warren Edwards sells his upscale shoes not in department stores but at his own Manhattan shoe store, which moved to 107 East 60th Street (at Park Avenue) from 475 Park Avenue (between 57th and 58th Streets) on Jan. 3. The store now has a garden, room for Mr. Edwards's two fox terriers and options to expand to higher floors in the next few months.

title: Voyage of the Turtle Is Just a Prelude
description: William Shakespeare said that all the world's a stage, and Reid Stowe took him at his word. On a glorious day last week, Stowe sat in the sun-baked pilothouse of his 70-foot schooner, Anne, and took in the glistening Hudson River from the peace of his Manhattan berth. But his mind was still adrift with thoughts of his most recent adventure, a meandering six-month journey of offshore performance art that he and his bride, Laurence Guillem, theatrically dubbed the Odyssey of the Sea Turtle.

title: The Shattered Lives Left by a Street War; Wheeled Prisons Bear Legacy Of Violence of a Crack Epidemic
description: As a teenager in the 1980's, Andrew Aiken rhymed and danced his nights away as a master of ceremonies at house music parties in Crown Heights, Brooklyn. A son of Jamaican immigrants, he dreamed of glory as a rap and reggae star.

title: Law Students Aid Abuse Victims
description: WHEN a Westchester woman called the Pace Women's Justice Center here, her husband had accumulated 18 guns and 200 pounds of ammunition, and he was not even a hunter. He had mutilated the family cat and then bludgeoned it to death. He suffered from bipolar disorder, was an alcoholic and a wife beater.

title: Books in Brief: Fiction
description: DRAGON STRIKE

title: January 9-15; Impresario and Angel
description: With 18 of the 40 stages in London's West End up for sale and large American leisure-time groups said to be among the leading bidders, guardians of British culture feared for the future of the world's largest theater district.

title: Corrections
description: A report last Sunday about the wedding of Haleh Farah Bakhash and John Lehman Warden Jr. misidentified the couple's mothers at one point. As stated elsewhere in the report, the bride's mother is Haleh Esfandiari Bakhash. Phillis Warden is the bridegroom's mother.

title: A Minnesota Museum Moves to the Riverbank
description: Looming dinosaur skeletons, 3-D laser shows and a model of a human blood vessel are all on permanent display at the Science Museum of Minnesota. The 93-year-old museum, which reopened last month at its new location on the banks of the Mississippi in St. Paul, is home to the first convertible dome Omnitheater in the United States -- which can show movies on either a flat screen or a domed one -- and nearly two million artifacts.

title: French Bistro's Ambience Loyal to Region
description: MOST bistros have long ago abandoned the rich excess that was once the hallmark of French cuisine, preferring less elaborate, less disguised preparations, bold in their use of items like garlic, olives, olive oil, tomatoes, strong herbs and broths. With its name and unpretentious decor -- huge bouquets of sunflowers a particular delight -- Le Provencal announces its wholesome regional loyalty, and diners aspiring to virtue will find some worthy choices here.

title: The Joy of Jet Lag
description: IN every travel guide I've read, there's something about jet lag: how to fight it with drugs, diet or vitamins, or with pre-trip sleep engineering.

title: After 25 Soulful Years, a Final Serving of Fried Chicken
description: For nearly 25 years, Ms. Ann's Southern Style Restaurant served prodigious portions of fried chicken and black-eyed peas to diners seeking old-fashioned cooking and down-home personal service. But Ann Sealy, known to all as Miss Ann, has decided to retire and has closed her storefront restaurant on South Portland Avenue.

title: Contextually Correct
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BERMAN, LESTER T.
description: BERMAN-Lester T.. Died January 14, 2000. Beloved husband of Ruth. Loving father of Richard and Lee, and Donald and Robyn. Adored grandfather of Rachel, Lindsay, Russell, Matthew and Erica. Loving brother-in-law, uncle and friend. Decorated Air Force veteran of WWII and Korea. He was deeply loved and will be greatly missed. Services Monday, 9:30 AM, at ''Gutterman's,'' 175 Long Beach Rd., Rockville Centre, LI.

title: Food; Easy Does It
description: There are two ways to handle the grim reality of winter. You can conquer the cold, with its icy roads, unpredictable snowfalls and long frigid nights, by spending days in the kitchen simmering, baking and stewing. Or you can capitulate by conserving energy.

title: THE GUIDE
description: Best Bet

title: Marc Davis, Master Animator For Walt Disney, Dies at 86
description: Marc Davis, one of the top cartoon animators who have worked on Walt Disney films, died Wednesday. He was 86 and lived in Los Angeles.

title: Calhoun Puts Inconsistent UConn on Alert for St. John's
description: Connecticut Coach Jim Calhoun would seem to have good reason to be satisfied. Consider that his Huskies are 12-2 despite having lost the all-America forward Richard Hamilton and the superb defensive stalwart Ricky Moore, the catalysts in the Huskies' run to the national championship last year.

title: Bosnian Serb War Crimes via Camcorder
description: Technology has a habit of finding all sorts of unpredictable roles. ''Srebrenica: A Cry From the Grave,'' a documentary that will have its United States premiere on Monday night at 10 on PBS, suggests that the camcorder will turn out to be a kind of 21st-century conscience.

title: Union Square's Name
description: To the Editor:

title: At Tender Age of Four Fingers, a Green Thumb
description: Colette Parker, dressed in a Dalmatian-dotted winter coat, held up a bright bouquet of romaine lettuce to a stranger, who thanked her very much.

title: France Presses the U.N. to Help Poor Nations Get AIDS Drugs
description: As more international attention focuses on an AIDS epidemic spreading out of control, France is prodding the United Nations to find ways to make cheaper drugs available to poor countries, where treatment is beyond the means of most people who need it.

title: From France, a Red to Warm the Blood
description: A marker on the 45th meridian just south of Tain l'Hermitage, on the Rhone, announces ''Ici commence le Midi.'' The Midi -- southern France -- begins, too, in Paul Jaboulet Ain'e's's Parall'ele ''45.''

title: On the Road Again
description: Whether transferring within or between companies, today's workers are finding that the moving vans are often at their doors, the rented trailers regularly hitched to their cars. Mishaps -- in packing and moving out, in traveling, and in finding, fixing up and moving into new lodgings -- are inevitable. What has been your best, worst or most remarkable experience? Send your stories to On the Job, Money & Business, The New York Times, 229 West 43rd Street, New York, N.Y. 10036. Or send them by e-mail to onthejob@nytimes.com. Include your name and telephone number. All submissions become the property of The Times and may be republished in any medium.

title: The Big Peep Show
description: As one who finds sex infinitely more satisfying than shopping, I loved Michael Sorkin's article (The Way We Live Now, Dec. 26). On a recent return trip to New York, I was disgusted to see how corporate ''porn'' has taken over not only the real estate but also the soul of the city.

title: The Mad, Fat Days of March
description: CARNAVAL'' -- the word itself, for me, had always conjured tropical images, half-naked women swishing their hips and sweating, braceleted men beating drums while the sun shines hot on the white hats and wilting paper masks of the tourists.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  COHEN, NATHAN
description: COHEN-Nathan. Beloved husband of Florence. Loving father to Debra and Judith. Cherished grandfather of Christopher and Zachary. A retired labor arbitrator and attorney, he will be remembered for his wisdom, generosity and compassion. A memorial service is planned for March.

title: Fur's Progress
description: Take back your rich-looking, dolled-up mink, sable and chinchilla, and give me a goatskin coat lined in rabbit. That's the current status symbol of the fashion set, including some who a few years ago were protesting the wearing of fur. All it took was a fur design that didn't look extravagant. It has been a long time since fur coats were both stylish and reasonably affordable. The raccoon coat of the 1920's flapper and the mouton lamb coat of the 1940's bobby-soxer each captured its era's aesthetics and responded to its youth rebellion. Sure, the goatskin and rabbit shed a little, but what do you expect of a $4,790 coat ($4,070 for the men's version) designed by Tom Ford of Gucci? The cut is lean and mean.

description: EXPLOSIVE ACTS

title: Excerpts From the Republican Debate
description: Following are excerpts about taxes, including an exchange by Senator John McCain of Arizona and Gov. George W. Bush of Texas, during the Republican presidential debate yesterday in Johnston, Iowa, as recorded by The New York Times.

title: January 9-15; At Microsoft, a New No. 2
description: Twenty-five years after founding the world's most powerful software company, William H. Gates stepped down as chief executive, handing the reins to his longtime business partner and closest friend, Steven A. Ballmer. Mr. Gates is not going away, though; he will continue as the company's chairman and chief software strategist. Nobody is expecting a kinder, gentler Microsoft. JOHN MARKOFF

description: Re: ''Civics to You, Greek to Nassau'' [Jan. 2]

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KAPLAN, SHIRLEY F.
description: KAPLAN-Shirley F.. Of Old Westbury, LI and Jupiter, FL. Born in Worcester, MA. Beloved wife of Robert. Devoted mother of Linda Kaplan, Deborah Kaplan Brooks, Edward and Barton Kaplan. Cherished mother-in-law of Joel Brooks and Penny Kaplan. Dear sister of Marvin Zebrak and Jeanette Simon of Worcester, Ma. Loving grandmother of Heather and Lee kaplan and Stephanie, Michael and Hilary Brooks. Services Sunday, 12 Noon, at ''Gutterman's'', 8000 Jericho Turnpike, Woodbury, L.I.

title: CITY LORE; Passengers' Property: Forgotten but Not Gone
description: THE art of losing is not hard to master,'' wrote Elizabeth Bishop in her poem ''One Art.'' Yes, how effortless it is. And perhaps nobody recognizes the ease with which New Yorkers practice this losing art better than Charlotte Roseburgh, head of the Transit Authority's Lost Property Unit.

title: Blaming Nixon
description: America Divided

title: Your Home; Keeping Gains Tax-Free
description: THREE years ago Congress gave homeowners an extraordinary gift -- the ability to shield from taxation as much as $500,000 in profit from the sale of a primary residence. But the gift is of little use to homeowners who wish to continue living in their homes and leave them to their children when they die.

title: A Rare Hearing for a Strauss Opera That Nearly Vanished
description: A CONCERT performance of Richard Strauss's ''Liebe der Danae'' (''Danae's Love'') by Leon Botstein and the American Symphony Orchestra this afternoon at Avery Fisher Hall offers a rare hearing of the last of the composer's operas to take the stage.

description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  QUEEN, HAROLD
description: QUEEN-Harold. 83, of Lincolnville Beach, Maine, died Thursday, January 13, 2000 at Penobscot Bay Medical Center after a long illness. Born in New York City, January 22, 1916, he was the son of Samuel and Edith Binder Queen. He attended New York City Public Schools and the City College of New York. Mr. Queen was employed as a writer with RCA, where he worked more than 25 years. He moved here in 1979, following his retirement. Mr. Queen continued writing and had done so for local papers. He also enjoyed traveling in Europe, especially Italy. Mr. Queen is survived by his wife Ivanka ''Jeanne'' Queen of Lincolnville Beach, Maine; two sons, Alexander W.G. Queen and his wife Alison of Stone Ridge, New York, Richard I.S. Queen of Arlington, Virginia; one brother, Benedict R. Queen; one sister, Dorothy Q. Schimel both of Woodstock, New York; two grandchildren, Elias A. Queen and Andreas Queen. For more information, call Burpee-Strong Funeral Home, 110 Limerock Street, Rockland, ME.

title: Corrections
description: An obituary yesterday about James P. O'Neil, president and chief operating officer of a worldwide financial printing company founded in 1775 in New York, misspelled its name. It is Bowne & Company, not Browne.

title: THE GUIDE
description: Shows Just for Fun

title: Underage Drinkers Getting Younger And Drinking More
description: I did not take long for word to get out on the high school grapevine -- a party in Pound Ridge. Nor did it take much time for the scene to get out of hand. By the time the police arrived at the private home here last fall, more than 300 teenagers -- some as young as 14 -- had paid $5 for a cup that entitled them to all the beer they could drink.

description: To the Editor:

description: INTERNATIONAL 3-13

title: Up, Up and Away (Per Square Foot)
description: ON the East Side, near the subway platforms at 59th Street and Lexington Avenue, stands a maze of caves encased in 10-foot-high fiberglass walls supported by stainless steel studs. Copper tubes hang from the high ceilings, sending down light beamed through thousands of tiny pinholes. Inside the caves, computers hum.

title: The View From/Garrison; Building a Community on the Dream
description: THEY were a strange and frightening sight: men in vivid calico overblouses and pajama-like pants, their heads and faces covered by grotesque masks. To call one another to action, they blew on five-foot-long tin horns.

description: Derek Jeter said he was not concerned about the possibility of going to salary arbitration with the Yankees again this year, and even said he did not mind their seeming hesitance to offer him a multiyear contract.

description: SWAPPING HOMES

description: THE DELINQUENT VIRGIN

title: Main Street Braces For Another Assault
description: IT is about 1 p.m. on a Saturday, and there's a wait for a table at The Maple Leaf Diner in downtown Maplewood. In the meantime, people are checking out the window at Sweets and Treats by Jacqui, where gingerbread houses made by local Girl Scouts are on display.

title: What's Doing In; Palm Beach
description: Palm Beach is, to the visitor, a laid-back semitropical oasis of spotless streets, pristine white buildings, magnificent palm trees and manicured hedges, an island haven of wealth. It changes little from year to year -- perhaps a few less charity benefits and a few more scandals -- but the police still patrol unceasingly, real jewels are worn in the evening -- and not infrequently during the day -- coconut is spelled cocoanut on the street signs. Blond and tanned are de rigueur, and cashmere sweaters and navy blazers are a uniform.

title: Political Briefing; Why Iowa? And Why New Hampshire?
description: Should Iowa, which holds the nation's first presidential caucuses, and New Hampshire, which holds the first primaries, be allowed to dominate the early going in the nominating process?

title: Miss Stryker, Mr. Hazleton
description: Kristen Ann Stryker, a daughter of Suzanne W. Stryker of Greenwich, Conn., and the late Charles S. Stryker, was married yesterday to Christopher Alan Hazleton, a son of Mary Lou Hazleton and Richard A. Hazleton of Midland, Mich. The Rev. Paul A. Rasmus performed the ceremony at St. Paul's Episcopal Church in Key West, Fla.

title: No Stumping By Molinari? A Jolt for G.O.P.
description: Guy V. Molinari, the Staten Island borough president, has been the undisputed king of Republican politics on the island. When a Republican faced a tough race, Mr. Molinari's presence on the campaign trail was assured. Whether it was a race for the Assembly or Congress, his trademark was to knock on doors and stand in shopping centers to campaign for fellow Republicans.

title: Latino Immigrant Experience
description: The spring season of the New Jersey Film Festival, sponsored by the Rutgers Film Co-op and the New Jersey Media Arts Center, opens Friday with the New Jersey premiere of ''La Ciudad'' (The City), a debut film written and directed by David Riker. With a cast largely of Latino immigrants, the film portrays the fictional lives of immigrants in New York City.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  LEIGH, DOUGLAS
description: LEIGH-Douglas. A memorial service to celebrate the life of Douglas Leigh will be held at The River Club, 435 E. 52nd St, on Wednesday, January 19 at 5PM. To RSVP, call 212-751-2498.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WEENOLSEN, HEBE
description: WEENOLSEN-Hebe., 93, author of ''The Last Englishman,'' ''To Keep this Oath,'' ''The Forbidden Mountain,'' and ''The Trial of Jennie Sykes,'' died on December 19 in Manhattan. She was preceded in death by her husband, Robert Weenolsen, and her son, Robert Weenolsen, Jr. Surviving are her daughter, Dr. Patricia Weenolsen, and Melissa Sirovina of Seattle, Washington; Pamela, Valerie, and Jennifer Marott of California, and Anne, Dr. Stephen, and Sean Gray of Illinois.

title: With Rackets Comes Hope in Hartford
description: GABRIEL TORRES is an 18-year-old senior at Bulkeley High School in Hartford who immigrated from Argentina with his parents four years ago. Though Torres never played tennis until he arrived in America, he is now ranked No. 95 among the 300 boys in the 1999 New England 18 Singles Standings by the United States Tennis Association/New England and is likely to attend college on a tennis scholarship next year.

title: Insulating to Save Heat and Money
description: THERE are many different types of insulation available for the home: fiberglass, loose fill, rigid panels and expanding foam. Fiberglass is the most popular because it is easy to install and less expensive than the other types. It can, however, be confusing to buy because it is available in different widths, thicknesses and densities, and with or without a vapor barrier. Some stores even offer fiberglass insulation with features like low-irritation films.

title: It's Not Too Late or Irrational For Mr. Forbes to Aim Lower
description: Steve Forbes well knows the important dates of the new political season: Jan. 24, is the the Iowa caucuses; Feb. 1, the New Hampshire primary; Feb. 8, Delaware (could be good for him, but who's going to notice?); and Feb. 19, the South Carolina primary and the the start of the battle for the South.

title: Corrections
description: A program listing on Page 22 of the Television section today, for 6 p.m. tomorrow on Channel 13, has become outdated. ''Nightly Business Report Looks at 20th Century . . . and Beyond'' will be replaced by ''Bishop Desmond Tutu: Dreams of Freedom,'' a live broadcast of the bishop's speech on ''Global Challenges: Perspectives on Race Relations'' from the Playhouse Theater in Wilmington, Del.

description: SYLVIA LONG'S MOTHER GOOSE Illustrated by Sylvia Long. Chronicle, $19.95. (All ages)

title: A Respect for Context
description: To the Editor:

title: Artists Must Leave a Building They Saved
description: FOR the past year a group of South Norwalk artists have waged a frantic battle to save the Lock Building, the nearly 150-year-old building where they have lived and worked together for more than a decade.

title: Green Spaces Among The Paved
description: WHEN I was a kid growing up in Irvine, Calif., in the scrubby coastal hills of southern Orange County, I used to jump the barbed-wire fence behind my parents' house and wander off on long, rugged marches toward the sweet blue sea. With a few pals and a dog or two I'd blithely trespass over the cattle-grazing fields and streams of the Irvine Company -- owner of just about everything from Scotchman's Cove northward to the orange groves that once climbed the distant Santa Ana Mountains. Then we'd climb over the chaparral-covered ridges of the San Joaquin Hills and scramble through forests of sumac into Laguna Canyon, a deep and snaking rift through steep sandstone walls.

title: MOVIES: CRITICS' CHOICE
description: HIGH art, high adventure, high drama and low comedy, including a documentary on the motion picture industry, lend a special spice to this week's lineup of films.

title: Finding Partners, Alone or in a Group
description: IT'S impossible to create a group dance when no one will attend a rehearsal. But that was Jody Oberfelder's plight when she was stationed at her home in the far eastern reaches of Long Island last summer, and none of her dancers had the time to make the trip. The 46-year-old choreographer had no choice but to devise a solo, which ordinarily would have been a fine compromise; however, in this case, she was working on ''Social Dances,'' a suite of 10 short works that explore the yearning to move with and be moved by other people.

title: Bar to Home-Building Debated in Southampton
description: Officials in the Town of Southampton are considering a six-month moratorium on residential construction to halt the spread of second homes, which are rapidly transforming rural and semirural areas there.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KELLY, BLANCHE
description: KELLY-Blanche. On January 13, 2000. Retired J.R. Grace Co. Beloved wife of the late DeWitt Kelly. Dear sister of Lillian Filoramo, Hubert Bracken, Dorothy Willman and the late Walter and William Bracken and Grace Kelly. Also survived by many nieces and nephews. Friends may call at the Andrett Funeral Home, 353 Second Ave. (at 20th St.), NYC, Sunday 25:00 and 7-9:00 PM. Mass of Christian burial Epiphany RC Church, Monday 9:45 AM. Interment LI National Cemetery.

title: Books in Brief: Nonfiction
description: THE QUEST FOR COSMIC JUSTICE

title: Fromage Hommage
description: Burt Bacharach once remarked that while composing and arranging, he would think ''in terms of miniature movies,'' and today's pop experimenters -- from Stereolab to Yo La Tengo to the Flaming Lips -- seem to have seized on that as a manifesto. Their recordings are seldom built around big beats, as is rock or rap or techno. They may feature songs with verses and refrains, but what makes the music memorable is the deft plotting and suggestive character of the sound -- the melodic twists, the deep swells and ebbs of sonic intensity, the jump-cut shifts in musical texture and coloration.

title: Philadelphia Police Chief Borrows From Bronx Beat
description: ''Start locking them up,'' Police Commissioner John F. Timoney ordered as he saw enough of the latest crime statistics from a particularly rough southwest neighborhood. As he frowned, the depredations flashed onto a giant computer screen at his weekly meeting with field commanders.

title: Hornets Players Patiently Made Decision Not to Play
description: The National Basketball Association and its players were faced with a quandary last week: deciding when it is proper to play a game in the wake of tragedy.

title: Croton Violinist in Solo Concert
description: THE violinist Elmar Oliveira of Croton-on-Hudson is barely 50, but he has already played more than 2,000 solo concerts in 21 years. He travels so much you would think the classical music field is thriving, and by Mr. Oliveira's account, it generally is.

title: As the Good Times Roll, The Marxists Are Mellowing
description: IT is remarkable how a booming economy flattens ideology in this post-cold-war era. The good times in America have many economists rewriting their views, and none more so than those who see the world through Marxist eyes. Only the final outcome -- the Day of Reckoning -- sets the Marxists clearly apart from mainstream economics. And the Day of Reckoning has been postponed.

title: A Man for All Time
description: To the Editor:

title: Jones Keeps His Light-Heavyweight Title by a Unanimous Decision
description: Roy Jones Jr., the undisputed light-heavyweight champion of the world, made Radio City Music Hall his private playground last night and used David Telesco as a personal play toy.

title: The Passages of Paris And of Benjamin's Mind
description: SOME of us don't read fiction. We live on history, biography, criticism, reporting and what used to be called belles-lettres. We will be feasting on Walter Benjamin's ''Arcades Project'' for years to come. Just published in its first full English-language edition, ''The Arcades Project'' should also win readers with broader tastes. By any standard, the appearance of this long-awaited work is a towering literary event.

title: Correspondence/Jail-House Translator; Seeking Asylum, Some Immigrants Find A Fate Worse Than Criminal
description: I WAS, frankly, unprepared for jail in this country.

title: Children's Books; Werewolves and Worse
description: Jack Prelutsky, who has converted thousands of children to poetry, and Peter Sis, whose intriguing and mysterious artwork has earned him two Caldecott Honor awards, have teamed up again to go where none but Disney animators have dared to tread: the world of gargoyles. THE GARGOYLE ON THE ROOF (Greenwillow, $16; ages 6 and up), 17 poems about all manner of creepy creatures, including werewolves and trolls, follows the pair's enormously successful collaborations, ''The Dragons Are Singing Tonight'' and ''Monday's Troll,'' in bringing voice to fantastic fiends. Some strike closer to home than others. What brother wouldn't enjoy ''My Sister Is a Werewolf''?

title: Where the Deaf Are Prepared For Life in the Outside World
description: POISED and ready for the world, the well-groomed young woman sat in the busy cafeteria amid fellow students, animatedly telling about her hopes after she graduates from high school in June.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CONDRON, WILHELMINA ELIZABETH
description: CONDRON-Wilhelmina Elizabeth. On January 13, 2000. Beloved wife of the late Thomas J. Devoted mother of Thomas J. Jr. and Elizabeth Jerrilyn. Funeral from the Chas. Peter Nagel, Inc. F.H., 352 E. 87 St, NYC on Monday, January 17 at 9:30AM. Mass of Christian Burial St. Joseph's R.C. Church 10AM. Visiting hours on Saturday 7-9PM and 2-5 and 7-9PM on Sunday. She will be sorely missed by all who knew and loved her.

title: Nets Don't Do Enough As Walker Does It All
description: They have been lauded for getting off the mat and turning around a dismal situation, praised for the way they exploited their home-court advantage in December and accepted as a legitimate Eastern Conference playoff contender. But while the Nets are no longer a baffling group of underachievers, not all is well.

title: Norman Tops Chang
description: Sweden's Magnus Norman outlasted the American Michael Chang, 3-6, 6-3, 7-5, yesterday to win the Auckland Open in New Zealand.

title: Nicklaus Is Ready For Active Schedule
description: Jack Nicklaus will turn 60 years old Friday, but he has been working daily with a personal trainer and he feels healthier than he has in years. Completely recovered from last year's hip surgery, Nicklaus will play in the Senior Skins Game Jan. 29-30 with three other golf legends, Arnold Palmer, Gary Player, and Tom Watson. Nicklaus will also play in all four majors this year, as well as two early-season P.G.A. Tour events -- the AT&T Pebble Beach National Pro-Am, and the Doral-Ryder Open.

title: Style; The Denim Blues
description: Legend has it that in the 80's the fashion business ruined denim. Designers took blue jeans -- one of America's most genuine articles -- and made them an ooh-la-la embarrassment, then acid-washed their soul. The public was chagrined; the fashion crowd moved on. ''Denim just didn't look right in the early 90's,'' recalls Kal Ruttenstein, fashion director of Bloomingdale's. ''It went into the back of the closet.''

title: Fancy Frozen Meals From Web Site or Catalog

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WEAVER, GLENN
description: WEAVER-Glenn., 82, of Wethersfield, died Wednesday, January 12 at Hartford Hospital. He is survived by his wife, Emojean (Shulenberger) Weaver and two sons, John and Peter. He was born in Altoona, PA and received the AB from Catawba College, Salisbury, NC; the BD degree from Lancaster (PA) Theological Seminary; MA from Lehigh University; MA from Yale; PhD from Yale University as a Buckley Fellow. He taught History at Catawba College, Lehigh University, Connecticut College for Women and Albany State Teachers College. For 42 years, he lived in Wethersfield and taught History at Trinity College where he was the first Dana Research professor of History. In the past 42 years, he has written: Jonathan Trumbull: Connecticut's Merchant Magistrate; History of Trinity College Vol. I; History of Hartford; History of the Hartford Electric Light Company; History of the Hartford Steam Boiler Inspection and Insurance Company; History of the Hartford Foundation for Public Giving; The Italian Presence in Colonial Virginia; and for the Connecticut's Project for the Bicentennial, he chose 35 men to write the booklets on some aspects of Connecticut during the Revolution. This set of 35 booklets won the highest national award as the best project of all the 13 original states for the Bicentennial celebration. Professor Weaver was a very active member of the Connecticut Historial Society, The American Antiquarian Society, The Acorn Club of Connecticut, the Friends of the Franklin Papers, the Connecticut Academy of Arts and Sciences, and the Columbia University Seminars in Colonial History. While at Trinity College, he created the archives in the library to house all important documents and taught a former student to be the college archivist. One of Professor Weaver's elective classes, ''The City in America,'' had the highest number of students in a 1-teacher class (165 students). A funeral service will be held on Wednesday, January 19, 11:00 AM at the Trinity College Chapel, 300 Summit Street, Hartford, with the Rev. Bordon Painter officiating. Calling hours are Tuesday from 4 to 7:00 PM at the D'Esopo Funeral Chapel, 277 Folly Brook Blvd, Wethersfield. Burial in Cedar Hill Cemetery.

Among my biggest interests then were shipwrecks, Grand Prix racing and freakish anomalies. I furthermore thought that knowledge consisted of the accumulation of random facts, and that there were a finite number of these, so that with some application one could master all knowledge. Naturally, I bored people silly. The Guinness Book was a perfect ally and an inexhaustible well. It was a book that defeated sequential reading; it had no beginning and no end and even seemed to contain hidden chambers and buried passageways. No matter how many times I dipped into it, I would eventually find myself on pages I hadn't glimpsed before. It contained the whole world, and experiencing all of it demanded a rigorous exertion not unlike spelunking.

Other chapter headings are Outlets; Beyond the Supermarket (specialty food shops, bakeries, international foods, and so on); Museum Stores, Historic Sites and Craft Centers; Antiques and Artifacts; and One-of-a-Kind Wonders. The book will lead those who still sniff at malls to the Chisel and Quill Studio in Frenchtown, for hand-painted signs, and, in Lebanon, to the Dollhouse Factory.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''Most people don't want to talk to their car. They want their car to shut up and drive.''

title: For Serbs in Croatia, a Pledge Unkept
description: Almost five years after Croatia promised to allow refugees from the Yugoslav wars to return to their homes here, the authorities still put endless obstacles in the way of many of those who want to come back.

title: Political Briefing; Are Term Limits The Final Answer?
description: When Representative Tillie K. Fowler, a Republican from Jacksonville, Fla., said last fall that she was thinking about breaking her pledge to serve only four terms in the House, U.S. Term Limits, the leading term-limits advocacy organization, began saturating her district with sharply worded advertisements accusing her of political dishonesty.

title: Throwing A Beanball In Business
description: THE bigoted remarks that John Rocker of the Atlanta Braves made in a magazine interview have been widely reported. Mr. Rocker, a 25-year-old relief pitcher, slammed Asian drivers, the foreigners on Manhattan's streets, a subway-riding AIDS patient and a teammate whom he called a ''fat monkey.''

title: TRAVEL ADVISORY: Correspondent's Report; France Cleans Up After Uncommon Storms
description: FRANCE is not a country normally associate with lumberjacks, but French woodcutters are hard at work these days. Millions of trees were felled by back-to-back hurricanes that struck France on Dec. 26 and 28, and the cleanup is still going on.

title: Corrections
description: A review of Philip Ziegler's biography ''Osbert Sitwell'' in the Book Review on Dec. 19 located the stately home of the Sitwell family incorrectly. It is in Derbyshire, not Yorkshire.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOLDFRANK, FREDERICK
description: GOLDFRANK-Frederick. 58, survived by his loving and beloved wife Victoria Ettlinger, son Nicholas Goldfrank, parents Tom and Emma Goldfrank, brother Edward, and many other loving and beloved friends, relatives and associates. Fred was a beautiful person with an incisive and creative mind. He died January 10, 2000, a victim of cigarette smoking.

title: A (Barely) Organized Crime Family Returns
description: His favorite uncle tried to have him whacked, his terrified shrink skipped town, his best friend may have betrayed him, and his malevolent mother, whom he was about to suffocate with a pillow, has just had a stroke. And you think you have problems?

title: EVENING HOURS
description: Debuts, honors cultural and medical, and a fond farewell.

title: Stopping the Best Offense Will Take a Fine Defense
description: Like everyone else in pro football, the Giants' defensive coordinator, John Fox, is impressed with the Indianapolis Colts.

title: Polanski, the Once and Future Auteur
description: SEATED at a corner table at Il Matriciano, one of his favorite haunts during his dolce vita of the 70's, Roman Polanski was discussing his desire to make an important, lasting film. Almost impatiently, he explained that his latest release, ''The Ninth Gate,'' was not it.

title: Giving Proper Credit For Neonatal Care Unit
description: As a registered nurse in the Neonatal Special Care Unit at the White Plains Hospital Center, I feel compelled to write after reading the article ''Where the Premature Not only Survive but Thrive'' on Dec. 19.

title: Message Up In Smoke
description: I was astonished that among the young smokers featured in Ann Weathersby's photo essay (Dec. 26) not one mentioned having been cautioned or educated about the risk of lung cancer. All the comments focused on how and when they started to smoke. Did anyone ask them about health issues? Did anyone mention that smoking causes premature wrinkling?

title: It's Gore, No Longer Spelled With a B
description: The ordinary Iowans who turn up to see Vice President Al Gore have often been startled by the candidate they encounter.

title: Lavish Party for O'Connor
description: In a tribute unprecedented in his 16 years as archbishop of New York, hundreds of the most powerful figures in the city and in the Roman Catholic Church in America celebrated Cardinal John Joseph O'Connor's 80th birthday at a lavish fund-raising dinner last night.

title: Another Church Statue Damaged in Brooklyn
description: Another religious statue was vandalized in Brooklyn Friday night, the sixth desecrated there in a week, the police said.

title: Taking On Bush
description: In an Iowa debate, rivals for the Republican presidential nomination united against Gov. George W. Bush of Texas. Page 18.

title: Sports of The Times; In St. Louis, It's Alchemy For Two Eras
description: ST. LOUIS normally shivers in January, but this season the expectation of holding the city's first professional football playoff game generates a warmth that cuts the chill.

title: Tempest in CBS Logo
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DOWLING, BRENDAN W.
description: DOWLING-Brendan W.. The New York Times records with deep sorrow the passing of Brendan W. Dowling, associated with The Times since 1977.

title: American Pseudo
description: Many thanks to Frank Rich (Dec. 12) for his article on Patricia Highsmith and her most chilling creation, Tom Ripley. I had just finished reading a short story featuring a Ripley-like character in a collection aimed at teenagers. The story, ''Caring: The College Admissions Essay of Becky Sue Anderson,'' is a first-person narrative that reveals Becky Sue to be as coldhearted and clever as Ripley is. I was wondering if the author, Thomas McKean, was a Highsmith reader when, in a later story, I came across a character who refers to her teacher as someone with the surname Highsmith.

title: 'In Sickness, in Health' Gets a New Twist
description: THE best Christmas present I ever got'' was the way Bernard O'Neill described the kidney he received last month from his wife, Mary.

title: U.S. Courting India in Hope Of Restarting Trade Talks
description: Despite nuclear tensions and diplomatic false starts that have dogged United States relations with India in recent years, the Clinton administration plans to court India as an ally in trying to restart global trade talks that collapsed in Seattle last month.

title: Elizabeth Brackis And Adam Cott
description: Dr. Elizabeth Jill Brackis, the daughter of Toni and Frederick Brackis of New Rochelle, N.Y., was married there last evening to Adam Jon Cott, the son of Patti Cott of New Rochelle and Edward L. Cott of Bucharest, Romania. Rabbi Amiel Wohl officiated at the Glen Island Harbor Club.

title: January 9-15; Drug Trafficking Online
description: The Customs Service said its seizures of prescription drugs imported from abroad soared last year, as more and more consumers used the Internet to buy medicines from overseas pharmacies.

title: The Curse of Blood And Vengeance
description: In the interest of hooking Scott Anderson's article (Dec. 26) about Albanian blood feuds to the events in Bosnia and Kosovo, you assert in the article's subtitle that ''the deadliest horrors [in the Balkans] have been perpetrated by those who continue to live by ancient communal codes.'' Really? What connection precisely does the kanun have to the death camps in Bosnia or the slaughter in Kosovo?

title: Q. and A.; What Is A Colonial House?
description: Q. There are a wide variety of single-family houses that are advertised as being ''colonial.'' What are the identifying features of a colonial-style house? . . . Linda Repdon, Manhattan.

title: Some Lesson Plans That Will Teach a Lesson
description: To The Editor:

title: Backtalk; The Vanity of Human Wishes, Once Again on Display
description: One of my favorite sports philosophers, Willem Hendrik (Butch) van Breda Kolff, who coached Bill Bradley in college (''Bill is not hungry,'' he said at the time) and Wilt Chamberlain in the pros (he benched the Dipper as a quitter), liked to declaim that ''each man's strength is his weakness.''

title: Corrections
description: An article on Dec. 19 about living in Patterson, N.Y., misstated the name of a food store on Front Street. It is the Patterson Food Center, not Market.

title: The Way We Live Now: 1-16-00; A Useful Hero
description: Like so many Americans, I first met Martin Luther King Jr. on television. I was 9. He was dead. ''Martin Luther King Jr. has just been shot in Memphis, Tenn.,'' the news bulletin announced. I was sitting on the living-room floor watching a western with my father. As my mother joined us, the camera switched to King's last speech. ''We've got some difficult days ahead,'' King said as he peered intensely at his throng of followers. ''But it really doesn't matter with me now, because I've been to the mountaintop.'' The audience erupted in cheers and with shouts of ''Oh, yes!'' ''Go 'head!'' and ''Yes, sir!''

title: Flu Vaccinations
description: With the flu at epidemic proportions in New York State, the Westchester County Health Department is still urging people to consider getting a flu vaccination.

title: Correction
description: An obituary of Nicholas Shoumatoff in this section on Jan. 2 with a collection of life stories of county residents who died in 1999 after making a difference in the community, misstated his ties to two organizations. He was not a vestryman at St. Matthew's Episcopal Church in Bedford, although he was a member and a Sunday school teacher there. He was not a trustee of the Bedford Free Library.

title: McCain Leads the Way as Republican Rivals Attack Bush
description: In a determined drive to slow the front-runner only nine days before the caucuses here, Gov. George W. Bush's rivals today questioned his credentials as a tax cutter and ridiculed his centerpiece plan to pare taxes by $483 billion over five years.

title: January 9-15; Openly Gay in the Military
description: Britain unveiled a new code of conduct for its armed forces that ends its practice of barring gay men and lesbians from the military. The government said it had no choice after the European Court of Human Rights ruled last fall that Britain's ban violated the basic human right to privacy. The code, which applies to gays and heterosexuals, says ''unacceptable social conduct,'' including sexual harassment and overt displays of affection, will result in disciplinary action.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LAMSON, MARTHA
description: LAMSON - Martha. Soprano, Teacher, Artist. Died in Norwalk, CT on Friday, January 14, 2000 at the age of 95. Performed with The Columbia Opera Company of NY in Canada as Gilda in Rigoletto in April & May of 1943; was a member of the Philadelphia LaScala Opera Company for the 1941-42 season; sang opposite Jan Peerce & Robert Weede as Gilda in Rigoletto at the Mosque Theater in Newark on December 3, 1943. Her stage name was Marta Rosana. She was a pupil and follower of the late Maestro J.H. Duval of NY. She taught bel canto singing for over 40 years in her studio at the Hotel Ansonia, NYC. She leaves no living relatives but had a host of friends, former pupils in the world of opera and singing. Interment will be at Woodlawn Cemetery, the Bronx at 11am on Tuesday, January 18.

title: Taking Action to Find Her Own Female Identity
description: SOME 20 years before Karen Finley smeared herself with chocolate to express her outrage over the brutal treatment of women's bodies and 30 years before Eve Ensler started delivering her ''Vagina Monologues,'' Valie Export cut the crotch out of her jeans and walked into a Munich art-film house known for showing sexually explicit films. Parading up and down the aisles in a performance action titled ''Genitalpanik,'' she dared the cowering, mostly male devotees to look at a real body.

title: Gun Maker Tells Resellers To Avoid Firearms Shows
description: Sturm, Ruger & Company, the Connecticut firearms manufacturer, has instructed its distributors in its latest contracts not to sell its weapons at gun shows, company officials said yesterday.

title: The A B C's of P's and Q's on L.I.
description: DURING the party season, we attended a very decorous gathering not a million miles away from Poquott, on the North Shore. The party was disturbed by the local code-enforcement officer who informed the host, very politely, that in this corner of Long Island, you have to obtain a license before inviting your friends over for a drink.

title: It Takes a Big Man to Eat a Big Big Sandwich
description: I like meat, red neon and the name ''Cubby.'' So why did it take me so long to discover this humble haven? Certainly, it's easy for a restaurant to get lost in the jumble of fast-food joints along Route 17 in Hasbrouck Heights. And Cubby's architecture does nothing to distinguish it from your average McChain. But that's where similarities end and smiles begin.

title: Media Deal Signals Triumph of Internet
description: The merger to create AOL Time Warner was born of Stephen M. Case's single-minded belief that connecting people was the Internet's most addictive application and the stumbling efforts of Time Warner to harness the new media.

title: Suki Tepperberg and David Stolow
description: Dr. Sara Ann Tepperberg and David Stolow were married last evening by Rabbi David Wolfman at the Robert Treat Paine house in Waltham, Mass.

title: Sculpture With a Purpose Enhances a Public Garden
description: Rosa Valado, an artist from Greenpoint, Brooklyn, remembers the day last spring that she first saw Drew Gardens, a swath of green on West Farms Road near Boston Road in the Bronx. ''I thought, this is really perfect,'' she said. ''It's kind of a magical spot.''

title: Very Soon, Drive Time Can Become Work Time
description: Later this year, hundreds of thousands of drivers will be able to have conversations with their cars.

description: To the Editor:

description: Pilgrim

title: Jaguars Hurtle By, and Dolphins Cover Their Eyes
description: The pass fluttered out of Dan Marino's hand on Miami's first offensive play, like the first rock that slips down a cliff, portending a landslide. It was easily picked off -- the first of seven Miami turnovers in what became the second-most lopsided game in National Football League postseason history: Jacksonville 62, Miami 7.

title: For Golan Settlers, an Uncertain Future
description: Everybody here knows Moshe Zaidon, the white-haired manager of a local cafeteria, who walks the pleasant, orderly streets with a sense of ownership that many of the pioneer settlers possess. ''There goes Moshe from the cafeteria,'' people say, and they wave.

description: Jenny Harris, the daughter of Marie Masters and Jay Harris, both of New York, is to be married today to David H. Faber, the son of Belle B. Faber and Norman L. Faber, both of New York. Rabbi Judith Lewis will perform the ceremony at the Rainbow Room.

Cropp of Williamsburg, Va. The Rev. James M. Donald performed the Episcopal ceremony at the Washington Cathedral.

description: Kathleen Kennedy Townsend, Maryland's lieutenant governor and a daughter of Robert F. Kennedy, showed up in Des Moines the other day to campaign for an old political friend, Vice President Al Gore. And guess what?

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BERGEN, FLORENCE V.
description: BERGEN-Florence V.. (nee Kupiec). Beloved wife of the late Harry. Loving mother of Thomas and Harry. Devoted grandmother of Manuel, Matthew, Michael and Christopher. Dear great-grandmother of Stephanie. Reposing Michaels Funeral Home, Inc., 79-22 Metropolitan Avenue, Middle Village, NY Sunday and Monday 25pm & 7-9pm. Mass of Christian burial Tuesday at 9:45am at St. Margaret's R.C. church. Interment Calvary cemetery.

title: Feast of Burden
description: Margaret Talbot (The Way We Live Now, Dec. 19) correctly points out that the causes of childhood obesity are ''manifold and so basic as to be inseparable from the way we live.'' Why, then, use a photograph that reinforces the stereotype that obesity is a character flaw associated with gluttony and sloth? Why consider only the thoughts of diet gurus with simplistic answers to a complex problem and then bemoan the lack of solutions?

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  KELLNER, WARREN
description: KELLNER-Warren. The family of Warren Kellner will hold a memrial service on Thursday, January 20, 2000, at 4 PM, Congreation Emanu-El of the City of New York, 5th Ave at 65th St.

title: In Defense of Auditors
description: When PricewaterhouseCoopers catches a cold, James E. Copeland, chief executive of Deloitte & Touche, sneezes. And wonders how to keep employees from leaving to join public companies for the stock gains that private accounting and consulting firms cannot offer.

title: The World; Trying to Leap Across The Politics of Race
description: MIXING race and politics, everyone knows, often produces a volatile brew. But in South Africa, racial politics are the only politics. Despite all the talk of reconciliation and transformation during the first five years of democracy here, that reality remains virtually unchanged.

description: ASK deans and professors at America's leading business schools to weigh in on what has become the hottest controversy in management education, and some decidedly unacademic epithets start flying.

title: Suspect in Serbian War Crimes Murdered by Masked Gunmen
description: Zeljko Raznatovic, a notorious Serbian paramilitary leader known as Arkan who was wanted on war crimes charges in the Bosnian and Croatian wars, was shot and killed today in the lobby of the Intercontinental Hotel here.

title: Sunbathe Plants
description: Houseplants suffer from the low intensity of winter light. They refuse to flower, and new leaves are pale and puny compared with summer growth. Plants that were thriving in an eastern window during spring and summer may now be showing signs of light deprivation. Move them to a southern window or supplement existing light by full spectrum artificial light. PATRICIA JONAS

title: Reward Program Is Weapon Against Crime
description: IT was one of his program's better moments, the police detective said: a tipster called Nassau County police headquarters in Garden City to say that two men had just attempted to sell him a gun in Hempstead. The detective contacted the Hempstead Police Department. The tipster stayed on the line and guided the police to the location.

title: Custody Case Is Overshadowing Shift Among Cuban Immigrants
description: Wiry, wearing a red St. Louis Cardinals baseball cap, Carlos Rodriguez, 18, speaks in the vernacular of American youth. Just finishing high school, Mr. Rodriguez has lived in Miami for the 10 years since he and his parents fled Cuba, where he said his father was a political prisoner.

title: Passports in Yorktown
description: Northern Westchester residents in need of a passport can go to the Jefferson Valley Mall in Yorktown on Jan. 27. A mobile office of the Office of the County Clerk will be parked there to permit residents to apply for just about everything that the clerk's office offers in its headquarters in White Plains.

title: A Hub Once More?
description: THIS is New York's oldest and largest incorporated village. Now Hempstead is campaigning to become the state's newest city -- and that is only one of many changes afoot here.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KLEIN, PETER
description: KLEIN-Peter. Peter's sudden and untimely passing has saddened us all. We extend our heartfelt sympathy and deepest condolences to his beloved parents, Helga and John Klein. We are praying for you both in this time of sorrow and our thoughts are with you. Miriam and Ory Giberstein Gibertex Trading Exacta Industries

description: In its latest incarnation, designer denim is extremely ladylike, with all the attendant tailoring and detail you would expect.

description: To the Editor:

title: Swastikas and Klan Graffiti: One Arrest and Bafflement

There, next to the door, he saw a swastika and an obscene message spray-painted in red on a wall of the synagogue.

description: Weeks

title: The World: Falling Out; You've Got the Bomb. So Do I. Now I Dare You to Fight.
description: JUST after New Year's, when most of the world's leaders were welcoming the millennium like a flower about to bloom, the government in New Delhi was denouncing its neighbor, Pakistan, accusing it of masterminding the hijacking of an Indian airliner. Charges and countercharges of assorted evils have since followed as officials of the fledgling nuclear powers busy themselves with what often seems their preoccupation: hating each other.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ORENTZEL, JACK
description: ORENTZEL-Jack. Beloved husband of Barbara. Loving father of Anne Pfister, Richard and Franca Orentzel, Janet and Fred Goodman. Cherished grandfather of Michael and Lisa, Joshua and Warne. Service today, 12 noon, at the Sinai-Free Synagogue, 550 North Columbus Avenue, Mt. Vernon, New York.

title: With Visions of Food, Food and More Food
description: REFLECTING upon ''The Play's the Thing'' after last Sunday's matinee at the New Jersey Repertory Company's Lumia Theater here stirs dangerous culinary notions into a theater critic's notebook. Instead of providing food for thought, Stuart Vaughan's undernourished staging of what ought to be a delectable trifle summoned thoughts of food. Imagine the joys of writing about the joys of eating.

title: Ensemble to Perform 'Bach Family' Works
description: AUDIENCES can expect to be inundated with Bach in this 250th year since his death, but the Ars Antiqua Period Instrument Ensemble is taking an unusual detour to gain a greater understanding of Bach's genius.

title: January 9-15; A Buy for the Jets
description: The Jets may not have a head coach, but they have a new owner: Robert Wood Johnson IV. The great-grandson of Johnson & Johnson's founder agreed to pay the estate of the oilman Leon Hess a stunning $635 million for the team. The first item on his to-do list is persuading Bill Parcells to reconsider his resignation as head coach. RICHARD SANDOMIR

title: Political Briefing; A Virginia Democrat Thinks Independent
description: Representative Virgil H. Goode Jr., a Democrat from Virginia's solidly conservative Fifth Congressional District, often breaks party ranks and votes Republican. In fact, he breaks ranks so often that Republicans leaders, scrambling to keep their narrow edge in the House, are pressing him to seek re-election this fall as one of them.

title: Ideas & Trends: Lost in Cyberspace; Whistling Past the New Economy
description: WHEN America Online and Time Warner announced the biggest merger in history last week, it set off a furious, if predictable, debate that swept through the airwaves, chat rooms and hyperactive financial markets, which couldn't decide if it was a brilliant idea or a marriage made in cyberhell.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GREENE, WALLACE B.
description: GREENE-Wallace B.. Formerly of Newburgh, NY, died peacefully at age 88 on January 13 in Goshen, NY. After graduating from New York University in 1934, he founded the accounting firm of Robbins Greene and Sosnoff with offices in Newburgh and New York City (which firm subsequently merged into Citrin Cooperman and Company) and became active in the American Institute of CPAs and served as President of the MidHudson Chapter of the New York State Society of CPAs as well as Chairman of the Ethics Committee. Despite the demands of his accounting profession, he made a significant commitment to public service, serving as a member of the Board of Directors and as the President of St. Luke's Hospital in Newburgh, President of the Newburgh Lions Club and President of the Otterkill Country Club. He still managed to find time for his passion for photography, classical music and bass fishing in the St. Lawrence River. He is survived by his wife, Ruth, his son, Stephen, his daughter-in-law, Marilyn, his granddaughters, Lisa Mirsky and Jennifer Susser, and his greatgrandsons, Jack David Mirsky and Michael Drew Mirsky, all of whom he cherished and all of whom will miss him dearly. He was truly a class act. In lieu of flowers, donations in Wallace's name can be made to the Alzheimer's Association, New York Chapter, 360 Lexington Ave., NYC 10017.

title: Breast Cancer Cartoon: Reacting to the Reaction
description: I was deeply moved by Stan Mack's cartoon [''A View From Another Window,'' Jan. 2]. It was obviously heartfelt. It honored both the patient and the caregiver. I am amazed at the negative responses to it. It seemed a totally appropriate subject, especially for the sort of cartoon he draws. I thought it was an extraordinary tribute to his partner. And I was glad you published it.

title: SOAPBOX; To Your Health
description: THE pounding New Jersey communities took from Tropical Storm Floyd recalls an old public health fable. In this story, horrified onlookers stand on the bank of a raging river watching drowning people wash by. The bystanders jump in to save them. Some still flow by. Soon, everyone sets about building nets, constructing elaborate life-saving devices and learning water rescue. A few are saved, but many are lost. Finally, in desperation, the town's elders run upstream to find out why all these people are falling into the river so they can stop it. This act of prevention is what public health is all about.

title: Marc Posner and Abigail Kolodny
description: Abigail Sara Kolodny, a daughter of Dr. Nancy Kolodny and Dr. Gerald Kolodny of West Newton, Mass., is to be married today to Marc Jonathan Posner, a son of Barbara Posner Sisman of Rowayton, Conn., and the late Laurence Posner. Rabbi Jeffrey Rubenstein will perform the ceremony at the Boston Harbor Hotel.

title: The Way We Live Now: 1-16-00: Salient Facts: Flight Safety; How to Survive a Hijacking
description: 1. WHAT SHOULDN'T PASSENGERS DO?

title: 'Breathless' Turns 40, Its Youthful Impudence Intact
description: AN amiably cocky Frenchman in sunglasses steals a car, mugs people for petty cash to romance a cute American student and tries to collect money from shady characters so he can run away with her to Rome, but she seems more interested in flirting with contacts to secure a writing job, besides which she is pregnant by the Frenchman and he seems indifferent to this fact, while a police manhunt closes in on them both. No wonder they called it ''Breathless''!

title: Challengers Are Down to a Precious 2
description: The hammerhead sharks and fishermen who frequent the Hauraki Gulf will have a few days' respite from the television helicopters and the spectator fleet that have disrupted their routines of late.

title: POSTINGS: At School of Interior Design; Discovering A Doorway Into the Past
description: When the New York School of Interior Design began a $6 million renovation of its two Upper East Side properties in mid-1998, Inge Heckel, the school's president, had no idea that she and the architects would be embarking on a kind of archaeological dig.

title: January 9-15; Up in Smoke
description: Cigarettes not only pose deadly risks to smokers but are also the leading cause of residential fires that kill over 900 yearly. Philip Morris said it had designed a type of paper making cigarettes burn less hot, reducing the chance of igniting some fabrics.

title: Breast Cancer Cartoon: Reacting to the Reaction
description: I am sorry for the letter writers who were sadly reminded that their own battles with cancer can go badly. But I too nursed my wife while she was in home hospice care last summer. The cartoon said it all, what those even under treatment hope never to find out, but the loving caregivers discover. I smiled through the tears, and I am sure Stan Mack shed them while drawing it.

description: Congress might be forgiven for assuming that it was protecting state employees against job discrimination on the basis of age when it extended the federal age discrimination law to states in 1974.

description: To the Editor:

title: Rice's Big 3 Come Through Again
description: Rice High School of Manhattan did nothing yesterday in the Nike Super Six tournament to dispel the notion that it has been reduced to a three-man band with anonymous sidemen. But what a threesome.

title: Deborah Brener, Craig Zolan
description: Deborah Lee Brener and Craig Ralph Zolan are to be married this evening by Cantor Theodore Aronson at the St. Regis in New York.

description: Next summer, equestrians trying out for the Olympics will have to jump over the Norway spruce that was the Christmas tree in Rockefeller Center this holiday season. But, fortunately for them, the tree will no longer be standing upright.

description: I was disappointed to learn that David Letterman's producers slipped the first lady the contents of her New York pop quiz in advance.

description: LEHRER-Morton. We adored you. A special husband, father, friend and loving mentor. Memorial service was in Florida, Saturday, January 15. Wife Frieda Daughters Randy and Susan Grandchildren Eliza, Maggie Morgan, Cooper, Alison, James Sons-in-law Jim and David

description: Kwok Lum Lee, a father of two from Sunset Park, Brooklyn, thought he had found the perfect spot in Chinatown to peddle vegetables. By the time most New Yorkers bite into their morning bagel, Mr. Lee, a 45-year-old former chef, has already picked through his produce, arranged the scallions and made his first sale on the corner of Mott and Grand Streets.

title: Baton and Sacrament, Tools of Dual Career
description: GROWING up in Paterson in the 1950's, Alphonse Stephenson hated practicing the piano after his parents forced him to start taking lessons. But he loved music and wanted a career as a musician.

description: It's hard not to question the presence of two giant pink pigs, especially when they are floating outside your apartment window. Yet that is what the owners of 301 East 12th Street would like their tenants to do.

title: Back on Court, the Knicks Uneasily Command It
description: For three draining days, the Knicks were a support group for the Hornets. There was the players' union president, Patrick Ewing, fighting to get Friday's game against them postponed. There was each member of the team filing into a Charlotte, N.C., church, where they stood silently in front of Bobby Phills's polished casket and touched the No. 13 jersey folded on the silk-lined edge.

title: Ideas & Trends; We're Ready for Our Close-Ups Now

title: Renata Adler Is Making Enemies Again

Being photogenic helps. Having talent doesn't hurt. You must publish infrequently, but not so seldom as to be forgotten. And, when the occasional publication issues forth, it must resound like a salvo of artillery.

title: What No School Can Do
description: Last fall, the New York State Education Department released the results of a fourth-grade math test and eighth-grade math and language tests. It will come as no surprise to hear that the numbers for students in New York City were dreadful. About two-thirds of city eighth graders failed the English language arts test, and about three-quarters failed in math; half the fourth graders failed the math test. The results provided fuel for those who felt that New York City schools are underfinanced, that the city uses too many uncertified teachers, that academic standards are low, that junior high schools are neglected and that the tests themselves are unfair. There's some merit in all these notions. What was not said, however, was the obvious: that the city districts that performed poorly, like those that performed well, scored almost exactly as the socioeconomic status of the children in them would have predicted. You could have predicted the fourth-grade test scores of all but one of the city's 32 districts merely by knowing the percentage of students in a given district who qualified for a free lunch. Only a few dozen of the city's 675 elementary schools scored well despite high poverty rates. In other words, good schools aren't doing that much good, and bad schools aren't doing that much harm.

But during the last eight weeks, crews have been steadily razing the 90 buildings, vacant since 1983.

This week, he will preside over the five-day U.S. Healthcare Exhibition -- the first American trade expo in Cuba in more than 40 years.

title: In the Wilds of Malibu

I was just beginning to scamper up to a stony promontory when my 8-year-old daughter, Marina, called out and pointed to the green-blue surf, her 6-year-old brother, Sammy, already squealing with delight. I looked up just in time to see a pod of dolphins break the water, roll across the surface not 50 yards away and glide under again, and then rise a few more times before their leisurely ballet disappeared in the morning mist.

Instead of constraining creativity with full-blown dogmas, science erects signposts saying, Look here! Go there! Danger: sharp curves ahead!

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KARAMBELAS, JAMES J.
description: KARAMBELAS-James J.. died in Hollywood, FL on Dec. 26, 1999. He was born in Wilkes-Barre, PA, the son of the late John J. and Mary Dukas Karambelas. Jim graduated from Wyoming Seminary and Yale University, held graduate degrees from both Yale and Middlebury College, and completed a post graduate fellowship at Moscow University in Russia. Jim served as a Lt. aboard the USS Dixon in the Mediterranean, then taught at the Pingry School in Elizabeth, NJ. For almost 25 years, he worked as a simultaneous interpreter in Russian and French at the United Nations in NYC. He served as Pres. of the Community Church of NYC, a member of the President's Council of Wyoming Seminary, and a delegate to the Association of Yale Alumni. Surviving are his wife Evelyn (Evy), brother Clayton, sister Thecla Cassimatis, a niece, nephews and seven great-nieces. A private service will be held at the convenience of the family. Contributions may be made in Jim's name to Wyoming Seminary in Kingston, PA or the Multiple Sclerosis Society.

This will be their first visit from San Jose to Brooklyn and I worry. Will the kids be nice to them? Why didn't we buy a pullout couch? What are we going to do for a week, let alone this evening? But the car business is hardly so easy now; at this year's North American International Auto Show here, the companies seem to be trying to figure out whether to go online, off road, onto the racetrack or simply out of the box.

title: Books in Brief: Fiction; All Wars Are Local
description: ''What if all our lives are just a circle where at a certain point you cross an unseen tripwire that sets spinning the same process again?'' wonders Anne, the heroine of Sebastian Faulks's historical novel, THE GIRL AT THE LION D'OR (Vintage, paper, $12). ''One act of will, of self-restraint might break the circuit.'' Set in Janvilliers, France, in the 1930's, ''The Girl at the Lion d'Or'' is in part an exacting account of a young woman's descent into a psychological hell of her own making, a fall initiated and complicated by her troubled past and her blinding love for the wrong man. But Faulks's novel, first published in Britain in 1989, also has other things on its mind. With the Great War fresh in collective memory and the threat of another war darkening the horizon, the inhabitants of a small French town are shaped by the political landscape of their day. After her father's mutinous actions on the battlefield at Verdun and her mother's subsequent suicide, Anne Louvet is forced to piece together a new life. Charles Hartmann, her married lover, also served in the war, and it is his relationship with Anne that triggers in him the first stirrings of unadulterated compassion for another being. Anne fears that her life will keep repeating the cycle of abandonment begun in her childhood; Hartmann fears that his newly discovered capacity for sympathy will crack his hardened sense of self, much in the way that a new wine cellar he has commissioned has shaken the foundation of his ancestral home. At one point, the owner of the hotel where Anne works encourages her to visit the local war memorial, where the names of the dead are carved in stone. He asks her to imagine that each name has ''a face, a laugh, a look.'' Faulks engages in a similar intellectual exercise here, and he brings his characters to life with grace and vigor. Maggie Galehouse

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BIGELOW, JOHN B.
description: BIGELOW-John B. Of Woodstock, CT, died Friday, January 14 at the Day Kimball Hospital, Putnam, CT. He was 90 years old. From 1937 to 1974 he was the Headmaster of the Rectory School in Pomfret, CT, an independent elementary boarding school for boys and day school for girls and boys. After retiring, he and his wife Marga resided in Thompson and then Woodstock. He was a graduate from the Kent School in 1929 and from Harvard University (A.B.) in 1933. After college, he devoted his entire working life to the Rectory School founded in 1920 by his parents, the Reverend Frank and Mabel Bigelow. Frank was the rector of Christ Episcopal Church, Pomfret. The school started with two boys, John Bigelow and John Holt in the church rectory. ''Mr. John,'' as he was known by generations of students and faculty, first taught at Rectory and then when his father died became the Headmaster. The school grew in size and reputation. In the late 1940's, assisted by his wife Doris and with the guidance of Page and Laura Sharp, he initiated and developed a substantial tutorial program for students with dyslexia, a program to which Rectory remains committed. Although much larger now than in its early years, Rectory remains what his parents and he envisioned, a place that nurtures and develops both mind and character. He has been a member and vestryman of Christ Church, trustee of Rectory and other independent schools, member of the Harvard Clubs of Boston, Northern Connecticut and New York City, and member and treasurer (1959-1973) of the International Dyslexia Association (formerly the Orton Society). Revered and respected educator, devout Christian, and loving and beloved husband, father, friend and colleague, he is survived by his wife Margarete (Koenig) Bigelow, married 1969; two sons from his first marriage to Jean Ferguson Bigelow, John B. Bigelow, Jr., of Baltimore, MD and Blair Bigelow of Cambridge, MA; one step-son from his second marriage to Doris (Gardner) Bigelow, she died 1967, Robert Fisher of Pomfret; and five grandchildren and 11 great-grandchildren. He was predeceased by his sister Elizabeth Abbott in September 1999. Memorial service Saturday, February 19, at 11 AM in Christ Church Episcopal, Route 169, Pomfret, CT. Private burial in North Pomfret Cemetery, Pomfret. No calling hours. Memorial donations may be made in his memory to the Rectory School Scholarship Fund, Pomfret, CT 06258. For further information contact the Smith & Walker Funeral Home, 148 Grove St., Putnam, CT.

Some people, in a reversal of the norm, even left after the Penderecki in order to avoid hearing the second of the evening's two sweeteners, Strauss's ''Till Eulenspiegel.'' This was how the bass part sounded in the opening of the Mozart Requiem last Monday, when the hundred-plus participants in this year's Carnegie Hall Choral Workshop first came together to start preparing under Norman Mackenzie. For a decade, until his death a year ago, Robert Shaw regularly and majestically led these workshops, introducing his technique of ''count-singing.'' Mr. Mackenzie, his assistant and designated successor, described it on Monday as the surest way for a choir to gain strong metrical togetherness.

title: Republican Tax Cut Plans
description: With the release of Senator John McCain's tax cut plan, the profound differences between his priorities and those of the front-runner for the Republican nomination, Gov. George W. Bush, become clear. Nearly any proposal to cut federal income taxes benefits high-income families since they pay most income taxes. Mr. McCain's and Mr. Bush's plans are no exception. But Mr. McCain's version largely bypasses low-income and very rich families, focusing instead on families earning between $65,000 and $130,000 a year. Mr. Bush showers benefits on very wealthy families but also cuts rates for low-paid workers.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BECKER, SIDNEY B.
description: BECKER-Sidney B. Died January 15, 2000, at age 89. Beloved husband of Dorothy G. Becker for 57 years. Devoted father of Daniel, William and David. Loving grandfather of Sarah, Samuel, Michael, Ruth, Benjamin, Rachel, Jordan, Anne, James and Leslie. He graduated from Columbia College with a BA degree and from the Teachers Institute of the Jewish Theological Seminary. He served in the US Armed Forces from 1941 to 1946, advancing from the rank of lieutenant to lieutenant colonel. He was the recipient of the Legion of Merit, the highest non-combatant award for exceptional service. He served in senior executive positions with Schenley Industries and Willcox & Gibbs. He was a member of the Executive Committee of the Board of Trustees of the Reconstructionist Rabbincal College, a member of the Executive Committee of the Board of Trustees of the PEF Israel Endowment Funds, and a Life Member of the Board of the Associated Y's of New York. In recognition of his dedication and support, the Reconstructionist Rabbinical College presented him with the honorary degree of ''Keter Shem Tov'' (Crown of the Good Name), which is bestowed upon persons of academic and communal distinction. He will be remembered as a man of brilliant intellect, unimpeachable integirty and boundless generosity. Funeral services Monday, January 17, 10:45 AM, at ''The Riverside,'' West 76th St. and Amsterdam Ave. in lieu of flowers contributions may be made to the West End Synagogue, NYC, or the Reconstructionist Rabbinical Collge, Wyncote, PA. May his memory be for a blessing.

title: LUCENT SELLING $100 MILLION IN LASER PARTS TO TYCO
description: Lucent Technologies Inc., the No. 1 maker of telephone equipment, said yesterday that it would sell at least $100 million in laser components to a subsidiary of Tyco International Ltd. to increase capacity on an undersea communications network. Lucent's new laser modules, which are installed along a fiber optic cable route, deliver almost double the power of its previous products, allowing communications systems to carry more traffic. Sales of the new modules are expected to total at least $100 million in the next 18 months. Lucent, based in Murray Hill, N.J., has been supplying capacity-increasing components to Tyco's Submarine Systems unit since December 1998 under an initial contract that is expected to reach $150 million in May.

Employees will be transferred to a plant in Fort Collins, also in the northern part of the state. In addition, 165 Greeley-based employees will join Flextronics International Ltd. Flextronics is buying DII Group Inc., which agreed in November to buy Hewlett-Packard's tape-storage manufacturing business. Hewlett-Packard is closing the Greeley plant, where it makes scanners, tape drives and optical juke boxes, as part of a plan to shed real estate.

title: Gift Games in Albany
description: Curiously missing from Gov. George Pataki's recent State of the State Message were any proposals to elevate New York's dismal standards of government ethics. The governor may be under the impression that he fulfilled his duty on ethics when he consummated a deal with the State Legislature late last month to renew the state's expiring lobbying law. Yet that deal, concocted behind closed doors as New Yorkers were distracted by the holidays, was an act of bipartisan cynicism. Its purpose was to leave undisturbed the discredited system of legalized bribery that permits lawmakers to accept fancy meals, choice sports tickets and other personal financial favors from lobbyists seeking to gain influence over public policy.
