title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BORST, ALAN
description: BORST-Alan, formerly of Mamaroneck, NY died peacefully on January 11, in Hartford Connecticut. He graduated from Phillips Exeter Academy in 1941, and Yale University in 1945, majoring in physics. After serving three years of naval service in the Pacific as a Lieutenant in the Amphibious Corps, he entered Duke Law School (49). Mr. Borst practiced international patent and trademark law in New York City for over twenty-five years. In 1969, he represented Anderson's Black Rock, Inc. in a landmark patent infringement litigation decided in the Supreme Court of the United States. Mr. Borst married the late Frances Noble Sackett in 1956. They were divorced in 1978. Also an inventor, Mr. Borst focused on permanent magnetic devices and spent his retirement, in Hartford, Connecticut, pressing for an improved magnetic torque generator. He last traveled to the US Patent and Trademark Office in October of 1999 in support of his pending patent application. He is survived by his children Alan Jr. of Mamaroneck, John of Nyack, NY and Anna Borst Henry, of Brooklyn and three grandchildren.

description: Eberhard Diepgen, the mayor of Berlin, has decided not to attend a ceremony next week paving the way for a large Holocaust memorial near the Brandenburg Gate, a project he has long opposed.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  JOHNSTON, ROBERT EMMETT
description: JOHNSTON-Robert Emmett, 83, died 1-15-00 in Florida after a long illness. Mr. Johnston, formerly of New York, was retired president and chief executive officer of Harbor Distributing Corp. in Hicksville. Harbor distributed Anheuser Busch beers. Previously, he was president of Port Distributing Corp. of Long Island City. Mr. Johnston served in the Army in Europe with the 3rd Infantry Division from 1944 through January 1946. He was graduate of Pace University. In 1981 he was honored by the National Multiple Sclerosis Society, and in 1983 by the New York Kidney Foundation. He was predeceased by his wife, Patricia, (nee McCabe), in 1995. He is survived by three daughters, Patricia O'Hearne of New Hampshire, Stefanie Gugelot and Mary Morrell of Florida; five grandchildren, Brian O'Hearne, Mary O'Hearne, Jennifer Shepard, Deirdre Gugelot, and Caitlin Morrell; five great-grandchildren; devoted friends, Felicita Gimenez and Gus Camarasa; and many nieces and nephews. title: 2 Children's Prizes Go to African-American's Book
description: As the nation observed the birthday of the Rev. The novel, set during the Depression, is about a 10-year-old orphan who runs away from yet another foster home in Flint, Mich., in search of a legendary band leader in Grand Rapids who he thinks might be his father.

title: GRETAG COMPLETES ACQUISITION OF U.S. PRINTER MAKER
description: Gretag Imaging Holding A. G., Switzerland's largest maker of image-processing equipment, said yesterday that it had bought the rest of Sienna Imaging Inc. of Denver to strengthen its digital-imaging business. In June, Gretag bought an unspecified stake in the company, a maker of photo printers. Gretag said it would pay between $20.5 million and $29 million in cash for the stake, depending on Sienna's results in the current fiscal year. Gretag, based in Regensdorf, Switzerland, has made North American purchases to expand its product range and market share. Sienna's equipment is used in school, sport and wedding photography, and its products include software for image processing and semi-professional digital cameras. Sienna had estimated sales of $32 million in 1998.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STARK, RUTH
description: STARK-Ruth. Much loved and ever loving wife; confidante and life-long friend of Morton Stark, died peacefully on Sunday, January 16 after valiantly fighting a variety of ailments for years. Cherished sister of Paula Rabinow. Fond aunt of and role model for Hannah Scherer, Andrew Scherer, Claudia Slovinsky, Sara Whipple and Laura Whipple. Doting greataunt of Maya Rose Scherer and Eli Scherer. Co-creator, along with her dear friend Florence Valla, of Stark-Valla, their pioneering Greenwich Village shop. All are invited to share fond memories at a mememorial service to be held at 3:00 p.m., Thursday, January 20 at ''The Riverside'', 76th St. and Amsterdam Ave.

title: Television's Risky Relationship
description: For about two years the White House and the television industry have been engaged in a cozy little enterprise that, on the surface, seems to promise benefits for everyone. The administration's anti-drug campaign gets a boost. The television industry gets to add dollars to the bottom line. But on closer inspection, it is a deeply unhealthy arrangement that should disturb anyone who believes in the need for all media -- the entertainment industry as well as the networks -- to remain free from government meddling.

title: Handing Out Modern Art By the Bushel; A Couple Gives 1,000 Works To 29 Museums, Big and Small
description: Peter Norton, the California software entrepreneur, and his wife, Eileen, have announced that they are donating nearly 1,000 works by more than 450 artists to 29 institutions. Most of the works are from the 1990's. In sheer numbers, it is one of the largest gifts of contemporary art by a private donor.

title: Mentally Disturbed Man Is Fatally Shot by Police
description: An emotionally disturbed Queens man who had just slashed his mother in their apartment was fatally shot early yesterday morning when he lunged at police officers with a 15-inch knife, officials said.

title: REUTERS EXECUTIVE RESIGNS
description: The world's biggest financial information provider, the Reuters Group, said John Parcell, the 53-year-old head of its biggest unit, would leave the company this week after 30 years of service. Mr. Parcell had been chief executive of Reuters Information -- the division that supplies terminals to financial institutions -- for only a year. Reuters offered no explanation for the move. Mr. Parcell had apparently concluded that he was no longer under consideration as a potential successor to Peter Job, Reuters's chief executive, who plans to retire next year. The company's stock jumped 42.5 pence, to 943.5 pence, or $15.41. Alan Cowell

title: SIEMENS TO ACQUIRE MOORE PRODUCTS, INSTRUMENT MAKER
description: The German electronics giant Siemens A. G. agreed yesterday to acquire the Moore Products Company, a maker of instruments and control systems, for $170 million. Moore, based in Spring House, Pa., makes process-control systems and measurement instruments for the chemical, pharmaceutical and oil industries. In November, Moore said it had hired an investment banking firm to help plot alternative strategies. The Siemens offer of $54.71 a common share is more than double Moore's stock price on Nov. 23, before it announced it was seeking strategic alternatives. It also represents a 28 percent premium to Moore's closing price on Friday of $42.875. Siemens also offered $21.88 for each Moore preferred share.

title: Oliwa's Goal Brings His Mother To Tears
description: A mother crying after seeing her son score a goal in the first National Hockey League game she ever witnessed is a rare and emotional moment, especially when she traveled from overseas a day earlier. That was the case here tonight, when Krystyna Oliwa, who arrived in the United States from her native Poland on Sunday, saw her son, Krzysztof, score for the Devils.

title: Homage That Comes With Perils
description: FOR many weeks, two New York men with devoted followings warned Hillary Rodham Clinton that unless she came to them and made obeisance, her chances of going to the United States Senate were about as good as John Rocker's becoming the next commissioner of immigration. Now, in the span of six days, Mrs. Clinton has dutifully paid homage to both.

title: In Policy Shift, G.M. Will Rely On Alliances
description: In the first acknowledgment by the world's largest corporation that it cannot go it alone, the chairman of the General Motors Corporation said tonight that the company would rely more on partnerships and would better be described as ''the General Motors group.''

description: An article on Saturday about the roles of the Harvard scholars Cornel West and Henry Louis Gates Jr. in the presidential campaigns of Al Gore and Bill Bradley misspelled the surname of one figure whose writings Dr. West recalled having discussed in an informal group organized by Mr. Bradley. He was the presidential candidate and orator William Jennings Bryan, not Bryant.

It wasn't his style. Once he saw trouble brewing under the basket, once he glimpsed the Pistons standing their ground, Houston forced up a desperate layup that went splat against the glass and seemed destined to fall into the posse of Pistons.

title: Brazil's Economy Is Better, But Is the Recovery Lasting?
description: A year after Brazil's currency crisis took damaging hold, Belarmino Iglesias is toasting his good fortune. Business has rarely been better at his steakhouse, Baby Beef Rubaiyat, an old establishment here where businessmen put together deals over Argentine sirloin and French wine.

title: Spain Asks Britain to Test Pinochet Further
description: After a weekend of suspense, the Spanish government today sent to the British government a judge's petition that seeks a second medical examination of Gen. Augusto Pinochet to determine if earlier tests wrongly declared him unfit to stand trial for human rights abuses.

description: Growers in Florida are using digital cameras and the Internet to market their fruit far from the citrus groves and to resolve disputes when shipments arrive damaged.

title: Scientists Find Smallest Form of Life, if It Lives
description: Creepy things from beneath the sea are cliches of modern exploration, but the abyss has now produced a surprise so bizarre as to have touched off hot international debate: tiny, mysterious, apparently living creatures far smaller than any known bacterium -- so small as to strain the limits on what is needed for independent life.

title: SCANSOFT TO ACQUIRE CAERE, A DIGITAL IMAGING RIVAL
description: ScanSoft Inc., a maker of software that allows users to convert paper documents and photos for viewing on computers, agreed today to acquire the Caere Corporation for $143.4 million in cash and stock, buying out a competitor in the digital-imaging market. Shareholders in Caere, which is based in Los Gatos, Calif., will get $4 in cash and $7.75 in ScanSoft stock for each of their shares. The shares closed Friday at $7.4375. The ratio will be no lower than 0.91176 and no higher than 1.72222, ScanSoft said. The 54 employees of ScanSoft, based in Peabody, Mass., will join Caere's 295 workers in a company expected to have annual revenue of about $100 million.

title: One Who Got Away Returns to New Jersey
description: The first time Kevin Bannon saw Troy Murphy, Murphy was just a gangly freshman center at Delbarton High School in Morristown, N.J. A bit awkward and unpolished, Murphy seemed like a player that Bannon, who was then coaching at Rider College, might be able to land.

title: Collecting Art Plus Grudges
description: The British collector Charles Saatchi, whose ''Sensation'' exhibition has just closed at the Brooklyn Museum of Art, had a run-in with Peter Norton over a work that is part of Mr. Norton's current donation to 29 museums.

title: Clues but No Answers In the Snows of Everest
description: Tonight's installment of ''Nova'' on PBS tugs you into two real-life dramas that unfolded, 75 years apart, on the frozen slopes of Mount Everest. At times, the effort to keep the threads of the two untangled seem as dizzying as the thin Himalayan air, but you'll find the effort exhilarating.

title: ISRAEL  AND  SYRIA POSTPONING TALKS, THE  U.S.  REPORTS

Its president and chief executive, Daniel Gluck, an energetic, quick-talking 31-year-old former product manager for a software company, describes the museum, which does not yet have a home, as a center for the study of ''the history and evolution of human sexuality.''

title: CANADIAN MINING OFFER
description: In a bid to create a diversified base metal and gold producer with eight mines and exploration stakes in North, South and Central America, Aur Resources of Toronto made an offer of 170 million Canadian dollars, or $117.3 million, in stock for Cambior of Montreal. One share of Aur is being offered for 1.1 shares of Cambior, and Aur's shareholders would own 55 percent of the merged company. On the Toronto Stock Exchange, Aur shares lost 35 Canadian cents, to 2.30 Canadian dollars, while Cambior rose 54 cents, to 2.19 Canadian dollars. Primarily a gold producer, Cambior has been looking for a survival strategy since last fall. Aur is mainly a miner of copper and, in contrast to Cambior, has a strong cash position and no debt. Timothy Pritchard

description: The Supreme Court today left intact a lower court's ruling permitting Alabama prisons to segregate hundreds of H.I.V.-positive inmates and keep them from educational programs and even from religious services where they might mix with other prisoners.

title: U.S. Asking U.N. to Settle Aircraft Noise Dispute With Europe
description: The United States, deadlocked on another clangorous trade dispute with Europe, will ask the United Nations to resolve a battle over aircraft noise that Washington says has already cost American companies $2 billion.

title: Reckonings; Dollars and Desperation
description: Ecuador is a small, faraway country of which most Americans probably know nothing. (Hint: it's on the equator.) Last week, amid the hoopla of the AOL-Time Warner deal, one suspects that few noticed the surprise announcement by President Jamil Mahuad that he would abolish his nation's currency and replace it with the U.S. dollar. But there is an important story behind that story, which is not so much about Ecuador as about the great financial crisis that swept Asia in 1997-98, and the continuing debate over what to do when the next crisis strikes.

title: VIDEO GAMES FALL SHORT
description: Europe's largest maker of video games, Eidos P.L.C., warned that this year's results would be well below expectations because of product delays and Christmas sales that were poorer than expected. Shares of the company -- which created ''Tomb Raider,'' whose heroine, Lara Croft, is to be featured in a movie -- fell 32 percent after the company cut its full-year profit forecasts. Analysts said consumers might be delaying purchases until several next-generation game consoles, notably Sony's PlayStation 2, go on the market this year. Andrew Ross Sorkin

title: Court Rejects Appeal Of Eccentric Crime Boss

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CROWLEY, GEORGE
description: CROWLEY-George, engineer and inventor died in Pinehurst, NC on January 15, 2000. He was 80. He was born December 7, 1919 in Keansburg, NJ to George Reginald Crowley and Florence Jackson Crowley. He graduated from The University of Notre Dame in 1942 with a degree in electrical engineering and joined the US Navy. He was assigned by the Navy to work on wartime technical developments for General Electric. In August of the same year, ensign Crowley married Virginia Kozlowicz. He has four daughters, Ginger Scott, of Hobe Sound, FL, Susan Brewster, of Key Biscayne, FL, Karen Klein, of Cary, NC and Elizabeth Nielsen, of Avon Lake, OH; two stepdaughters, Katherine Higgins, of Sarasota, FL, and Ruth Joachim, of Milwaukee, WI; eight grandchildren, and five great grandchildren. He has lived in Connecticut, North Carolina, England, Winnetka, IL and Haverford, PA. In 1982, he married Barbara Talley and, after retiring as Executive Vice President of Research and Engineering at Northern Electric, they moved to Pinehurst, NC. Mr. Crowley was an engineer and inventor whose work resulted in more than 80 patent's. His role in the development of electrically heated flying suits for World War II pilots led to his invention of the first thermostatically controlled electric blanket for GE. He won the Coffin Award for his efforts and ingenuity in the development of a ''negative temperature coefficient electrical cable.'' He served as chairman of the Board of Trustees of St. Joseph of the Pines Hospital, Southern Pines, NC. A memorial service will be held Saturday, January 22, at 3 P.M. at Sacred Heart Parish Church, Pinehurst, NC. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to the Juvenile Diabetes Foundation. For information Powell Funeral Home and Crematory.

title: AKAMAI PLANS TO BUY CLOSELY HELD SOFTWARE COMPANY

Network24's Qcast software manages live and on-demand Internet broadcasts, like teleconferences and concerts. Akamai hooks computer servers to dozens of telecommunications networks to speed the delivery of customers' content. Shares of Akamai, based in Cambridge, Mass., fell $18.50, to $211.50, in Nasdaq trading.

Survivors include his parents, Jim Owen and Cheryl Owen of Gulf Shores; one sister, Jennifer Owen, Gulf Shores, AL; paternal grandparents, James R. and Jo Margaret Owen, Bay Minette, AL., and maternal grandmother, Dorothy Carlisle, also of Bay Minette. title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DORAN, A. BENEDICT
description: DORAN-A. Benedict, age 84, of Hanover, New Hampshire, formerly of Montclair, NJ, died at home Sunday, of cancer. Mr. Doran held an AB from Dartmouth College (1937) and an MBA from Harvard Business School (1939). He was Senior Vice President and a Director of Union Camp Corporation prior to his retirement in 1980. Mr. Doran served four terms as President of the Pulp chemicals Association. He served as Senior Warden of St. Luke's Episcopal Church in Montclair, was President of the Montclair Red Cross, Planned Parenthood of Essex County, and Youth Consultation Services in Newark, as well as being active in alumni affairs at Dartmouth. He is survived by his wife, Marjorie (Westgate) Doran; three daughters, Mrs. Robert (Marianne) Steinhacker; Mrs. Fred (Patricia) Schaum and Kathleen Brewer Doran; six grandsons; six great-grandchildren; and one brother, Francis F. Doran. Memorial donations may be made in his name to Dartmouth College, Stewardship Office, 63 S. Main St., Hanover, New Hampshire 03755.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DANZIGER, FRED. M.D.
description: DANZIGER-Fred. M.D. The Faculty and Staff of NYU School of Medicine mourn the passing of Fred Danziger, M.D., Associate Professor of Clinical Anesthesiology. Having joined the School's staff in 1975, he earned respect and admiration from his colleagues, students and patients for his clinical and academic expertise and for his humanity. He retired in 1994. From 1975-94 Dr. Danziger also served as Medical Director of the Ambulatory Surgery Unit at Tisch Hospital. While he was highly regarded for his wide ranging knowledge in his field, he will be most strongly remembered for his commitment to pediatric anesthesiology. While his loss will be felt throughout the NYU community, his contributions will be enormously appreciated well into the future. Robert M. Glickman, MD, Dean NYU School of Medicine Herman Turndorf, MD, Professor and Chairman Department of Anesthesiology, NYU School of Medicine

title: THE CHEF; The Most Succulent
description: ONE of the French dishes that have always amazed me is duck confit. I loved it as soon as I first tasted it, in 1988 when I came to work at La Caravelle as a saucier. At my previous restaurant job the cooking was very high-end nouvelle, and I had never encountered anything as rustic as these slow-cooked duck legs. They were a revelation -- how could duck be so tender and crisp at the same time, and so wonderfully flavored, with nothing to it but meat?

title: DOLE FOOD PLANS TO EXPLORE STRATEGIC ALTERNATIVES
description: The Dole Food Company said yesterday that it had hired the investment firm Goldman, Sachs & Company to explore strategic alternatives. The fruit and vegetable producer has been hampered recently by trade disputes over bananas in Europe. Last month, Dole, which is based in Westlake Village, Calif., said it expected fourth-quarter earnings from continuing operations to come in 2 cents to 4 cents a share below analysts' estimates. Since then, the estimate of five analysts surveyed by First Call/Thomson Financial for Dole's fourth quarter has fallen to 5 cents a share. Dole's stock slipped 31.25 cents yesterday, to $14.9375, on the New York Stock Exchange.

title: The Giants Are Cautious With Fassel
description: Days after their season ended two weeks ago, the Giants quickly decided they wanted Jim Fassel back as head coach. Just as fast, however, ownership and management decided to materially limit their endorsement of the coach.

title: Starting today: a global campaign to promote the Olympics
description: THERE are two ways marketers confront crises that threaten to tarnish the reputations of their brands. One is to frankly address the problem in advertising, acknowledge shortcomings and pledge reforms. The other is to pretend the problem never happened and introduce a warm and fuzzy campaign that hopes to woo consumers with emotional rather than rational appeals.

title: A Busy Man's Indulgence
description: BACK in the old days, when I thought no steps were too many in a recipe, I made a wonderful roasted monkfish with meat sauce. It was an understated dish, but absurdly tiresome to cook. The sauce alone was a reduction that began with meat bones, continued with roasted vegetables and required a total of four or five steps over two days. The result was delicious, but so ordinary looking that only the best-trained palates ever picked up on how ridiculously complex it was.

George W. Bush in the March 7 presidential primary. As Mr. Giuliani noted, a party that supports open elections ''ends up being a much more active and growing political party.'' Unfortunately, he does not speak for the powerful stealth wing of his own party.

At her previous job as an editor for an engineering society, she had earned $40,000. Navant offered her just $28,000. But so what? Here was her entree into the exciting new world of cyberspace.

Cherished sister of Paula Rabinow. Fond aunt of and role model for Hannah Scherer, Andrew Scherer, Claudia Slovinsky, Sara Whipple & Laura Whipple. Doting great-aunt of Maya Rose Scherer and Eli Scherer. Co-creator, along with her dear friend Florence Valla, of Stark-Valla, their pioneering Greenwich Village shop. All are invited to share fond memories at a memorial service to be held at 3:00 P.M., Thursday, January 20 at ''The Riverside'', 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

description: SOMETHING about Banania Cafe in Carroll Gardens, Brooklyn, feels very familiar. Maybe it's the copper wainscoting topped with a rack of wine bottles, or maybe it's the insouciant French charm of the host. Or maybe it's the enticing menu of reasonably priced bistro dishes.

Lifetime member of the Smithson Society, supporter of many museums. Survived by son Lee, grandchildren Lori, Matt and Amy and great-grandchild Illyia & brother and sister-in-law Saul and Chrisse Turner. Memorial service Saturday, January 29, 11 AM, at Walter B. Cooke-Kennedy Funeral Home, 117 West 72 Street, NYC. Donations may be made to the Whitney Museum of Art, NYC.

title: METLIFE OFFERS TO BUY REST OF CONNING FOR $54 MILLION
description: The Metropolitan Life Insurance Company said yesterday that it had offered to acquire the 39 percent of the Conning Corporation that it did not already own for $10.50 a share, or $54.6 million. As a result of its recent acquisition of the GenAmerica Corporation, MetLife owns 61 percent of Conning, a St. Louis-based provider of asset-management services to insurance companies and institutional investors. Conning said its board would evaluate the offer. In August, MetLife of New York, agreed to purchase GenAmerica for $1.2 billion after its General American Life Insurance Company unit was caught in a liquidity crisis. Conning shares closed at $10.40625, up $1.25, in Nasdaq trading.

title: Pressured by Suits, Gun Makers Turn To Political Effort
description: Feeling pressure from a succession of lawsuits against gun makers, the trade organization that represents them is collecting millions of dollars from its members for legal defense and this week announced plans to support candidates and to lobby at all levels of government to fight greater gun restrictions.

Gerrard Group owns the stock brokerage firm and fund manager Greig Middleton & Company, as well as a discount brokerage subsidiary and other fund-management operations. Old Mutual is South Africa's largest financial services company.

The diversified unit will also assume $9 million in debt. U.S. Industries, which makes plumbing products, garden tools and household products, said it expected to report a $15 million gain on the sale. title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STEVENSON, ANNE H.
description: STEVENSON-Anne H., 81, died of cardiac arrest in Norwalk Hospital, on January 15, 2000. Mrs. Stevenson, a long term resident of Manhattan, was born in Boston and spent her early life in Cincinnati. She moved to Manhattan in 1965. Always active in artistic and charitable affairs, Mrs. Stevenson was a past President of the Widows and Old Mens home in Cincinnati and the Womens Committee of the New York Zoological Society. She was at various times the coproprieter of a contemprary art gallery in Manhattan and on staff of the Hirschl & Adler Galleries. Mrs. Stevenson also maintained a residence in Watch Hill, Rhode Island. She is survived by her sons John of New Canaan, CT and Jay of Rye, NY. Six grandchildren also survive. A memorial service will be held at the Congregational Church of New Canaan at 11:00 AM on January 21, 2000. The family requests donations in lieu of flowers be made to the Watch Hill Light House Keepers Association.

OnDisplay, which is based in San Ramon, Calif., plans to issue about 1.92 million shares for closely held Oberon and will assume all of Oberon's options outstanding. Oberon, which is based in Cambridge, Mass., manufactures software that automates business processes by integrating different computer programs. If the laws were different, every table at Jack's Fifth would get a complimentary pack of Luckies, just for the visuals. It's that kind of restaurant -- a subterranean lair with a swanky bar, lots of circular booths and a retro sense of style that's part 1940's nightclub, part Rat Pack hangout.

title: SAP OPTION PLAN APPROVED
description: The world's largest maker of business management software, SAP A.G., won shareholder approval for a stock option plan that will give executives as many as 6.25 million shares worth 4.5 billion euros ($4.6 billion) to halt defections to United States start-ups. At an extraordinary shareholders meeting, SAP received approval for the plan, rare in Germany, after more than 30 top United States executives and managers left last year for a rival, Siebel Systems Inc. Under the new program, executives can opt for convertible bonds or stock options. In keeping with German law, SAP's growth in share price must outpace that of a benchmark index before executives can exercise their rights.

He was held in solitary confinement sporadically for a few months during his 19-year imprisonment, not for the entire time.

Transport, which is based in Eagan, Minn., is a truckload carrier and devotes an entire truck to one shipper's freight. Under the agreement, USFreightways will issue 0.412 share for each of Transport's shares. Shares of Transport jumped $3.0625 each, to $16.3125, and shares of USFreightways fell $1.625, to $42, in Nasdaq trading.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STONE, IRVING I.
description: STONE-Irving I. Yeshiva University and its affiliated Rabbi Isaac Elchanan Theological Seminary express profound sorrow on the passing of a foremost world leader of the Torah community and patriarch of the Stone-SapirsteinWeiss family. He was a longtime member of RIETS' Board of Trustees and recipient of its highest accolade, the Eitz Chaim Award; beloved husband of Helen and the late Beatrice; and father of Judith (and Morry) Weiss, Hensha (and Rabbi Hirsch) Gansbourg, Neil Stone, and Myrna (and Dr. Harold) Tatar. He played a singular role in professionalizing the field of Jewish education within our University and throughout America and Israel. Honorary alumnus and YU Benefactor, he established major endowments through the Irving I. Stone Support Foundation: the Stone-Sapirstein Chair in Jewish Education, Irving I. Stone Distinguished Professorship in Jewish Education at our Azrieli Graduate School of Jewish Education and Administration, and the Irving I. Stone Beit Midrash Program for undergraduates and, at RIETS, the Irving I. Stone Rabbinic Internship Program, Stone-Sapirstein Scholarship Internship Program in Jewish Education, and Stone-Sapirstein Center for Jewish Education. His legacy continues through the efforts of daughter and son-in-law Judith and Morry Weiss-YU trustee and executive committee member-who are Benefactors through the Stone-Sapirstein-Weiss Family Foundation and of grandsons Gary Weiss, alumnus and member, Yeshiva College Board of Directors, and Zev Weiss, alumnus and member of the newly formed Azrieli Graduate School Board of Directors. We extend our heartfelt condolences to Helen Stone, children, grandchildren, great-grandchildren, and the entire family. May they be comforted among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Dr. Norman Lamm, President Yeshiva University David S. Gottesman, Chairman YU Board of Trustees Judah Feinerman, Chairman RIETS Board of Trustees

description: Stephon Marbury's story is well documented. He grew up in the Coney Island section of Brooklyn, living basketball and dreaming of playing regularly at Madison Square Garden, where he envisioned leading the Knicks to several National Basketball Association championships.

title: Day of Olive Branch: Helms to Visit U.N.
description: Put it in the category of ''Nixon goes to China.''

title: Yanks Are Set to Pitch a Record Pact to Jeter
description: George Steinbrenner has always been reluctant to invest in long-term contracts for young Yankee players. But Derek Jeter is a special player who is getting very special treatment. The Yankees and the 25-year-old shortstop are close to completing a seven-year, $118.5 million deal that would be the richest in baseball history.

description: IF they didn't play their luck out in furniture, James Klein and David Reid could be making a lot of money in casinos.

description: OLSHIN-Arnold. The Managing Directors and staff of American Express TBS extend our deep sympathies to Ira and the family for the loss of Arnold Olshin, a man of extraordinary achievements for his family, profession and philanthropy.

title: Britain to Shrink the Ulster Constabulary and Broaden Its Ranks
description: Britain said today that the Royal Ulster Constabulary, the militaristic police force of Northern Ireland, would have its size reduced, its membership broadened to better reflect the population of the province and its politically charged name retired.

title: Resurgent Veterans Sparking Rangers
description: Two reasons for the recent resurgence of the Rangers have been the recovery of Valery Kamensky and the revival of John MacLean. The two veteran wings, centered by Alexandre Daigle, both scored Tuesday night in a 3-2 victory over the Carolina Hurricanes at Madison Square Garden. This lessened the burden of the all-Czech line of Petr Nedved, Jan Hlavac and Radek Dvorak, which did not produce for a change.

title: Moscow's Strange Bedfellows
description: By demonstrating a readiness to cut a deal with the Communists in the legislature, Vladimir V. Putin, Russia's current and perhaps future president, is evidently willing to forsake ideological allies and embrace ideological enemies to achieve his ends. The question remains: what ends?

title: Bush's Sweet Talk
description: ''It's government's role to create an environment where everyone can dream and flourish.'' ''The purpose of prosperity is to make the American dream touch every willing heart.'' ''The greatness of America is found in the loving and generous hearts of its people.''

description: A. M. Rosenthal, who departed The New York Times last November at 77, after 55 years as a reporter, foreign correspondent, editor and columnist, will be writing for a competitor in Manhattan, The Daily News.

title: Keeping Your Laptop Secure on Your Lap
description: It's a dirty little secret about laptops: they don't really fit well on a lap.

title: Passing Out the Cigars While Linking to Web Sites
description: Congratulations, it's a Web site. A new service called Thefirstday.com now offers newborns their first shot at a URL. It offers a free Web site to new parents at www.thefirstday.com; they can use it to post birth announcements and photographs. Relatives and friends can log in to send greetings and, of course, to buy gifts through Thefirstday.com's commercial sponsors. The site is maintained until the child's sixth birthday, by which time the little tyke should really have learned HTML.

description: WHEN Mamadou Camara scraped together the requisite $1,400 air fare to pursue personal improvement in New York and took off in 1994 from Bamako, Mali's impoverished capital city, he followed a path already taken by some 80,000 sub-Saharan Africans.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HIRSCH, HOWARD B.
description: HIRSCH-Howard B.. Died January 19, 2000. Survived by his sister Helene Mesquita and her children Felicia and Joshua, many cousins and Thomas Schoff, with whom he shared a home for 30 years.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LE BEAU, MADELEINE
description: le BEAU-Madeleine. Daniel, words cannot express our sadness over the loss of your dearest Madeleine. She was the light that shined on you for five wonderful years; a chef, a connoisseur, a lover of life and a life partner. Her warmth and caring will be sorely missed. Stephen and Karen.

description: NATMAN-Leonard., 1952-1987. Remembered with love everyday. Mister D

description: The Clinton administration said today that it was ''unwise in the extreme'' to allow the government of Saddam Hussein to exercise veto power over United Nations decisions on how to resume arms inspections in Iraq.

title: Elias Extends Scoring Streak to 12 Games
description: Patrik Elias extended his point-scoring streak to 12 games tonight when he got what proved to be the winning goal in the Devils' 4-1 victory over the Chicago Blackhawks at Continental Arena.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  UEBEL, TED AND KAY KERR
description: UEBEL-Ted and Kay Kerr. Jazz Memorial Celebration to honor their lives. Thursday, January 20, 2000 at 1:00. St. Peter's Lutheran Church 54th Street and Lexington Avenue, New York City.

title: Changes at Daily News Raise Questions About Partners
description: From one perspective, a series of executive and ownership changes at The Daily News and elsewhere in the publishing and printing empire of Mortimer B. Zuckerman and Fred Drasner is nothing special -- just a normal realignment of responsibilities by two executives around the age of 60.

title: Police Arrest 125 in Nighttime Raids on Homeless Shelters
description: The police swept through the city's homeless shelters before dawn yesterday, arresting at least 125 men and women on outstanding bench warrants, the authorities said yesterday.

title: They Know What You Listened to Last Summer on Your Car Radio
description: LIKE easy listening? Classic rock? Howard Stern? Next time you drive to a concert arena or down a freeway, your car radio could be transmitting some information of its own: your listening tastes.

title: Studying the Face of Japan As Seen From the West
description: Yoshiko Chuma and her School of Hard Knocks company have done a lot of hard knocking about during the troupe's 15-year history, both in vivid choreographed collisions and in improbable encounters. Ms. Chuma's new ''Reverse Psychology: Agenda No. 1: Japan,'' performed on Tuesday night as part of the Altogether Different festival at the Joyce Theater, is set to music by Marc Ribot that is full of comparable collisions of sound having overtones of music for Japanese theater. But Ms. Chuma is now more overtly interested in large philosophical and social themes.

description: To the Editor:

title: Russian Aim: Wind Up the War in Chechnya Before Election
description: Underscoring the political imperative to bring the war in Chechnya to an early close, the Russian generals plan to conclude their military campaign by Feb. 26, exactly one month before Russia's presidential election.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''He was rolling on the floor, trying to put out the fire on his back. My friend just froze and started crying, and we ran out.''

title: Knicks Give Marbury Something To Ponder
description: Maybe it was a mirage or wishful thinking, but the stoic point guard who generally hides his emotions as if playing a game of peek-a-boo seemed unusually revealing in his body language last night.

title: Keeping Holocaust Memory Alive
description: To the Editor:

title: Compassion of a Cardinal
description: Greeting marchers from the steps of St. Patrick's Cathedral in his bright red skull cap and cape, or delivering a homily from its lofty pulpit, Cardinal John O'Connor is an instantly familiar face, a grand and powerful public figure who exudes charm and grace.

title: Call That Never Came Leaves Nets Haunted
description: For the third straight time, a Nets game came down to the final moments. And for the third straight time, the Nets came up losers.

title: TESCO PLANS TO EXPAND
description: Britain's leading supermarket chain, Tesco P.L.C., said it would create 7,000 new jobs this year as it expands the number of stores offering home shopping on the Internet to 300 from 100 and widen its online offerings of nonfood items like books, clothes, furniture and banking services. Tesco's online service says it is the world's biggest Internet grocer, with 250,000 registered customers generating annual sales of more than $200 million. The expansion of its 170,000-member work force reflects an anticipated boom in e-commerce. Alan Cowell

title: A Political Backdrop Yields Surprises
description: The Chamber Music Society's concert at Alice Tully Hall on Tuesday evening was a real ear-opener in terms of repertory, and it included some beautiful performances, not least of Hanns Eisler's highly obscure ''Roman Cantata.''

title: Now, Class, Beware of Strangers and Irony
description: BECAUSE of its sophistication and vertiginously high production values, the ''Martha Stewart Living'' show is often thought of as an entirely original concept that sprang directly from the mind of its creator. Yet, in its obsession with the polishing of candlesticks, the folding of towels and the almost Prussian deployment of napkins and bed linen, Martha Stewart actually owes an enormous debt to the implacably didactic ''mental hygiene'' films that were popular in American schools from 1945 to 1970.

title: M Is for a Million Variations
description: Pioneering American builders have long been fascinated by flexible modular houses. The one below is by Michael Jantzen, an artist based in Valencia, Calif. He has devised his building from a kit of parts he calls M-Vironment: steel tubing and concrete and wood-fiber panels, which unfold from seven cubes into walls, ceilings and furniture.

title: Giuliani Campaign Says Donors Gave $12 Million in 1999
description: Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani's Senate campaign disclosed yesterday that it collected $12 million last year, reaping numerous donations from people across the country vexed at the notion of his opponent, Hillary Rodham Clinton, mounting a political career.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOLDFARB, EDWIN
description: GOLDFARB-Edwin. Died peacefully on January 18, 2000. Beloved husband of the late Sydney (nee Hammer). Devoted father of Lynne & Robert Gordon, Elliot & Ginger Goldfarb. Adored Pop Pop of Lori, Emily, Jennifer and Robbie. Funeral and interment private

title: A Tall Order On the Hudson; Rural Area Looks Skeptically At Friary's Development Plans
description: For 70 years, the brothers and priests in training at the Mary Immaculate Friary of the Capuchin Order here lived an unremarkably quiet existence of prayer and Bible instruction on wooded grounds overlooking the Hudson River.

title: I.B.M. Profit Off, but It Beats Expectations
description: I.B.M. said late yesterday that its earnings during the last three months of 1999 fell more than 11 percent from the previous year, but Wall Street had expected even worse and the company's stock moved up in after-hours trading.

title: University, Mexico's Pride, Is Ravaged by Strike
description: One of the first things the administrators of the national university here will have to do, if they ever get it back from student strikers who have occupied it for nine months, is to fumigate. Rats and bugs, even the odd scorpion, have run free on the leafy campus as it sits largely empty.

title: Denny's Reviewing Its Account
description: Denny's, part of the Advantica Restaurant Group, is starting a review on its account after parting ways with its agency of five years, Lowe Lintas & Partners in New York.

title: Nago Journal; U.S. Copters? No, No, No. Not in Their Backyard.
description: With his large hands and sun-leathered skin, Takuna Higashionna seems particularly well-suited for the kind of living he earns, fishing and farming the land near the shore on the outskirts of this modest town on the island of Okinawa.

title: Hedy Lamarr, Sultry Star Who Reigned in Hollywood Of 30's and 40's, Dies at 86
description: Hedy Lamarr, the raven-haired Viennese beauty who became one of the reigning temptresses in Hollywood films in the 1930's and 40's, especially as Delilah vamping Victor Mature's Samson, was found dead in her home in Orlando, Fla., yesterday. She was 86.

title: Matthaus Reassures Team on Arrival
description: Nick Sakiewicz, the MetroStars' general manager, said yesterday upon returning to the New York area from his meeting with Lothar Matthaus in Valencia, Spain, that the German star would unequivocally join the team. Matthaus, who is now training with his Bayern Munich team, met with both Sakiewicz and MetroStars Coach Octavio Zambrano.

title: Diallo Judge Lets Defense Have Tapes Of Witnesses
description: The judge presiding over the case of the four Bronx police officers charged with murder in the shooting of Amadou Diallo ruled today that their lawyers should have access to the possibly favorable statements of several people who saw the events leading up to the shooting.

title: 25 Years Later, Suspect Is Charged in Murder Case
description: Nearly 25 years after 15-year-old Martha Moxley was bludgeoned to death on the lawn of her family home here, the police today charged Michael Skakel, her former friend and neighbor and a nephew of Ethel Kennedy, in the slaying.

title: Out of the Air, and Back Into It
description: Neil Greenberg is like that child who was good or horrid, with not much in between. Just as one wants to strangle him for his circumscribed, galumphing movement vocabulary or extraneous projections of lines of text, along comes a dance like the engaging and good-looking ''Sequel,'' performed on Saturday night at the Joyce Theater by the Dance by the Neil Greenberg troupe.

title: Letting the Housewares Do the Thinking
description: To soothe the dread of a 6 a.m. alarm clock call, wouldn't it be nice to know that the clock has told the coffee maker to start brewing the coffee?

title: Apple Chief Rewarded for Company's First-Quarter Results
description: Apple Computer Inc. once again handily surpassed analysts' estimates for its first quarter, and a grateful board thanked its chief executive, Steven P. Jobs, for the company's turnaround by giving him a Gulfstream V jet and 10 million stock options.

title: Calls Growing for Stopping Tube Feeding in Dementia
description: Nursing homes and hospitals should end the widespread use of stomach tubes to feed people with advanced Alzheimer's disease or other types of dementia, according to an article published today in The New England Journal of Medicine.

title: 300 Rabbis In U.S. Group Say Jerusalem Is Shareable
description: A group of American rabbis, concerned that the Israel-Palestinian peace talks might collapse over the tangled issue of Jerusalem, called yesterday for the two sides to share the city.

title: Chase Manhattan Earnings Jump 48%
description: Riding huge gains from investing in start-up technology companies, Chase Manhattan said yesterday that its fourth-quarter earnings rose 48 percent, easily exceeding investors' expectations.

title: Accounts
description: Boston Beer Co., Boston, to Mediacom, New York, part of Grey Advertising, to handle media planning and buying, which had been at McCann-Erickson Worldwide Advertising, New York, part of the McCann-Erickson World Group unit of the Interpublic Group of Cos. Billings were estimated at $20 million to $25 million.

title: A Strong and Sassy Mama With a New Verse on Life
description: The jazz singer Teri Thornton, who is in her 60's and is just now reviving a once-promising career (the story involves record-company trouble, self-imposed exile in Los Angeles and illness, among other things), sounds the most up-to-date when she is singing a blues. That's when the stagey, Minnelli-like vibrato of her husky voice drops away and she becomes radical and individual; her voice suddenly gains twice the character it had in torch songs and standards like ''Somewhere in the Night'' and ''East of the Sun (and West of the Moon).''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BECKER, SIDNEY
description: BECKER-Sidney. The Jewish Reconstructionist Federation mourns the passing of our friend and supporter, Sidney Becker. A lifelong Reconstructionist, he was committed to Israel and the Jewish people, to study and scholarship and to peace and social justice. We extend our condolences to his beloved wife and partner, Dorothy, and to their family. Richard Haimowitz, President Mark A. Seal, Executive Vice President

title: Bitter Cold
description: The deep cold we have been having across the Northeast these past few days is inherently silent, of course. But if it made a sound it would be the scissoring and gnashing of a skater's blades against hard gray ice, or the screech of upcountry snow when you walk across it in the blue light of afternoon. The sound might be the stamping of frozen feet at bus stops and train stations, or the way the almost perfect clarity of the audible world on an icy day is muted by scarves and mufflers pulled up over the face and around the ears.

title: Free Speech or Interference? Abortion Case Is Argued
description: The Supreme Court wrestled today with whether a Colorado law intended to protect patients and staff members at abortion clinics from intimidation and verbal harassment goes too far in limiting demonstrators' right to free speech.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MOHR, RUTH CABOT (NEE BOUVE)
description: MOHR-Ruth Cabot (nee Bouve). Born February 11, 1930, passed away on January 18, 2000, beloved wife of the late Tom L. Mohr, loving mother of Leslie Griesmer, of Dedham, MA, Claudia Mohr, of New York, NY, Thomas Mohr, of Atlanta, GA, John Mohr, also of Atlanta, GA. Devoted grandmother of Tom Corydon, Andrew George, and Marguerite Bouve Griesmer, and Yuri Mohr. Dear sister of Marjorie Pratt and Walter Bouve. Mrs. Mohr was raised in Pittsburgh, PA, and Worchester, MA, and received her Bachelors of Arts in English Literature from Clark University in Worchester. She received her MSW from Adelphi University in Garden City, NY. Services to be held at All Souls Unitarian Church at Lexington Avenue and 80th Street Friday January 21, 2000 at 11 A.M. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to The Ruth B. Mohr Scholarship Fund of The Ackerman Institute For The Family, 149 East 78th Street, NY, NY 10021.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption yesterday with a review of ''The Voysey Inheritance'' at the Mint Theater in Manhattan included incorrect names provided by the play's publicist for the two actors at the right. They were Chet Carlin and Arleigh Richards, not George Morfogen and Lisa Bostnar.

title: New York Coffers
description: Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani's Senate campaign disclosed that it collected $12 million last year, and Hillary Rodham Clinton's campaign reported raising $8 million. Both totals break the record for a Senate campaign in a year before an election.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHICK, WILLIAM, DR.
description: SCHICK-William, Dr.. Of Riverdale, Bronx, New York, January 13, 2000. Beloved husband of Jessica (nee Cotins) Schick for 51 years, devoted father of Gary & Sandor Schick and Teri SchickBilenker, cherished grandfather of Daniel and Carrie Bilenker. Dr. Schick was Professor Emeritus at Fairleigh Dickinson University, where he taught electrical engineering for 33 years, served as chair of the electrical engineering department, assistant dean of the College of Science & Engineering, and assistant dean for academic computing. A memorial service was held at the Riverdale-Yonkers Ethical Culture Society on January 16, 2000. Contact family members for information on donations in his memory.

title: Genial Mosh-Pit Offices Keep New-Media Workers Happy
description: WHEN William Wordsworth wandered lonely as a cloud amid all those daffodils, he addressed the poignant dilemma of the individual trying to find a unique place among the masses. One can only wonder how the poet would feel at a new-media company.

title: Liberty-Comets in May Opener
description: The Women's National Basketball Association will start its 2000 season May 29 with a rematch of last season's championship rivals: the Liberty and the Houston Comets.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: METROMEDIA FIBER NETWORK INC., White Plains, a fiber optic cable company, acquired the closely held network builder M.I.B.H. Inc. for about $51 million in cash and stock.

title: Essay; 'Thou Shalt Not Steal!'
description: At the tumultuous 1912 Republican Convention, former President Theodore Roosevelt denounced the denial of credentials to his supporters by his successor, William Howard Taft. Teddy labeled the Taft men ''stolen delegates'' and thundered: ''Thou shalt not steal!''

title: Saluting the woman who took I.B.M. from staid to cutting edge in its approach to e-business.
description: THE feminist revolution of the 1970's hasn't exactly upended the top echelons of the corporate world. But it has achieved a slow, significant evolution of women joining the ranks of top corporate officers at large corporations.

title: Keeping Holocaust Memory Alive
description: To the Editor:

title: A Joyous Afternoon of Song (Including 'Happy Birthday')
description: To celebrate her 66th birthday, and to call attention to the work of the foundation that she started in 1993 to encourage American singers to give song recitals, the mezzo-soprano Marilyn Horne convened a starry assembly of singers to join her in a free concert at Carnegie Hall.

title: Canada Seeks to Jolt Smokers With a Picture on Each Pack
description: Taking its war on smoking to a more graphic level, Canada's government proposed today that cigarette packs carry color photographs of diseased hearts and cancerous lungs and lips.

title: AUTO PARTS MAKER'S STOCK JUMPS AFTER IT HIRES ADVISER
description: The stock of Mark IV Industries jumped yesterday after the company said it had hired Bear Stearns & Company to advise its board on strategic options, including a possible sale or merger. Mark IV, a maker of hoses, belts, manifolds and water pumps for the automotive market, among others, said it believed it had more opportunities to grow internally and added that its share price remained well below the $28 high established in October 1997. The company, based in Amherst, N.Y., said it had initiated several programs since 1997, including a restructuring. The shares of Mark IV gained $4.125, to $22.5625, on the New York Stock Exchange.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STONE, IRVING
description: STONE-Irving. Boys Town Jerusalem mourns the passing of its esteemed Vice President, Chai founder and cherished friend, whose valued relationship with the school and its founders spanned over three decades. Mr. Stone's commitment to Jewish continuity was best expressed with his simple yet profound imperative: ''We can't break the chain that goes back 3,800 years.'' Thanks to Irving Stone's vision, guidance and magnanimous support, the chain has been strengthened, enabling the timeless values of our sacred heritage to reach even those who before had been unreachable. Irving Stone's firm belief in the lofty principle of Jewish unity was echoed by former Israeli President Chaim Herzog when he visited the school so generously supported by the illustrious Saperstein-StoneWeiss families: ''At Boys Town Jerusalem I have found a source of hope for unity and love between the different parts of the Jewish People.'' Irving Stone's legacy and memory will endure as a lasting blessing and inspiration. May God comfort and console the entire family among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Josh S. Weston, Chairman Michael J. Scharf, President Rabbi Moshe Linchner, Dean Rabbi Ronald L. Gray, Exec. V.P.

title: PLANT CLOSING THREATENED
description: A conglomerate linked to the government of Singapore, SembCorp Industries Ltd., threatened to close an industrial park worth 188 million Singapore dollars ($113 million) that it manages on an Indonesian island if violent demonstrations there continued. On Saturday, villagers on Bintan stormed a power plant demanding better compensation for land they say they were pressured to sell in 1991 to make way for the park. SembCorp developed the park, which now employs 9,600 people at 27 factories, with the Salim Group of Indonesia.

title: Beginning Of Time: Jan. 4, 1980
description: Q. Why do all computers think time began on Jan. 4, 1980?

title: Deconstructivism Miniaturized
description: In Los Angeles, even a treehouse may be designed by an architect. This example, in the yard of a house in a rustic canyon, was commissioned by an artist as a gift for her sons, one of whom was convalescing from a serious illness. The treehouse, made of galvanized steel pipes, with sailcloth for shelter and sides of redwood and translucent polycarbonate wall panels, evokes the agitated compositions of deconstructivist architects. Yet the designer, Greg Crawford of CMG Architects in Pasadena, said the treehouse was meant to be a place to ''let the imagination run free.'' CMG also rebuilt the 5,500-square-foot house in the same style. But while neighbors have complained about the look of the house, no one has complained about the treehouse, which turns avant-garde architecture into a charming folly.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ELLIOTT, MARY ANGELA CONNAGHAN
description: ELLIOTT-Mary Angela Connaghan. Age 84, died on January 18, 2000 at Halifax General Hospital in Daytona Beach, FL. She was a resident of Florida since 1976 after living for many years in Ocean Township, NJ. Mrs. Elliott was born July 28, 1915 to Hannah (Sweeney) and Cornelius Connaghan in Motherwell, Scotland. She was raised in Falcarragh County Donagal, Ireland, and was a graduate of The Mercy Convent School in Strabane, Ireland. She emigrated to the United States in 1939 as a teacher and governess. During World War II, she was employed as a draftsman in the design of submarines. In 1943, she married John T. Elliott in New York City. In addition to her husband, she is survived by her six children, John C., of Fort Lauderdale, FL, James G., of Forest Hills, NY, Michael D., of Ormond By The Sea, FL, Brendan P., of New York City, NY, T.J., of Tarrytown, NY, and M. Irene Elliott-Hupe, of Eatontown, NJ. She is also survived by her thirteen grandchildren, three great grandchildren, and one brother, James Connaghan, of Lisburne County Antrim, Northern Ireland. Reposing at Walter B. Cooke-Kennedy Funeral Home, 117 West 72 Street, NYC, Thursday and Friday from 2-5 and 7-9 P.M. Mass of The Resurrection at Holy Trinty R.C. CHurch, Saturday 9:45 A.M. Interment Mary Rest Cemetery, Mahwah, NJ.

title: How to Lure Writers To an Afterlife In Texas
description: When Thomas F. Staley calls, writers know that money and posterity are on the line. Under Mr. Staley's direction, the Harry Ransom Humanities Research Center at the University of Texas at Austin has strengthened its position as one of the world's primary repositories of literary archives. Once, when an author asked for three reasons that his papers ought to be at Austin, Mr. Staley said, ''Graham Greene, Evelyn Waugh and James Joyce.''

title: Reviving the Fine Art of Haggling, Online
description: I WAS raised to believe that status meant having enough money to pay list price for just about everything. Of course, I also was raised to believe that if you wear pajamas with elastic cuffs, your skin won't be able to breathe. But I have slept in sweat pants for years without clogging my pores.

title: A Ray of Hope on D.S.L.
description: To the Editor:

title: Gift of $100 Million To Promote Literacy
description: James L. Barksdale, the former president of the Netscape Communications Corporation, and his wife, Sally, plan to give $100 million to promote the teaching of reading in Mississippi, their home state, which suffers from the nation's lowest literacy rates.

title: DIGITAL ISLAND BUYS LIVE ON LINE, A WEB VIDEO PROVIDER
description: Digital Island Inc., a fast-growing provider of Web hosting and Internet content-distribution services, said yesterday that it had acquired Live on Line Inc., a provider of Internet video services, for $70 million in cash and stock. Digital Island, which is based in San Francisco, specializes in hosting Web sites for business and in speeding the delivery of Internet data through its own network. Its stock fell $1 a share yesterday, to $81, in Nasdaq trading. Closely held Live on Line, of New York, specializes in hosting Web-based video events.

title: Scanners You Can Take to the Library
description: IF you have ever done research in a library, you have probably encountered this annoying situation: You've found a paragraph of helpful information in an otherwise useless book. There is no point in lugging the book home for the sake of those 300 words. So you face two choices: transcribe the paragraph by hand or trot over to the photocopy machine, stand in line, fish around for change and make three copies the wrong size before getting one that captures what you want.

title: Giving Mr. Levy a Chance
description: Yesterday's narrow, 4-to-3 vote by the Board of Education to confirm Harold O. Levy as New York City's interim schools chancellor was at least mercifully free of the acrimony that dominated the meeting of 10 days ago, when the board endorsed Mr. Levy's candidacy despite strident disapproval from City Hall. The atmosphere seemed to improve after Mayor Rudolph Giuliani announced that he would not seek court action to prevent Mr. Levy's appointment, thus averting a battle that would have jeopardized the search for a permanent chancellor and thrown the system into chaos at a time when crucial decisions have to be made.

title: State of the Art; Look Out! New Wrist Devices on the Loose
description: IT took more than half a century, but the consumer model of the Dick Tracy two-way wrist radio is almost here. With the relentless miniaturization of technology, the time has come for wrist devices that have function lists as long as your arm: depending on design, they double as cell phones, one-way pagers, e-mail readers, computers, cameras, MP3 music players, television receivers, voice recorders, automobile security keys, television and VCR remote controls, health monitors, weather stations, compasses, Global Positioning System monitors, altimeters, games and simple amusements. Some can even serve as admission passes for ski lifts and museums. And, almost as an afterthought, they tell time.

title: UNEMPLOYMENT RATE FALLS
description: Britain's unemployment rate fell to 4 percent in December from 4.1 percent, the Office of National Statistics said. The annual growth in wages in the three months through November held steady at 4.9 percent. The figures reflect faster economic growth leading to hiring in the construction and services industries, analysts said. Alan Cowell

title: Advanced Micro Posts a Profit
description: Helped by rising sales of its new Athlon microprocessor, Advanced Micro Devices Inc., a maker of computer chips, posted its first profit in four quarters yesterday, exceeding forecasts.

title: Levy Enters Maelstrom As Leader Of Schools
description: Harold O. Levy officially became one of New York City's most visible public figures yesterday, plunging into his new job as interim schools chancellor with optimism, nervous humor and the frenzied pace of a power broker eager to shake things up.

title: For Writers, a Murder Case That Had All the Ingredients
description: For writers, the killing of Martha Moxley had everything: celebrity, wealth, youth and a mystery. It highlighted one of America's most affluent communities, featured a possibly bungled police investigation and, of course, there was that connection to the Kennedy family.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FISHMAN, ANSHEL
description: FISHMAN-Anshel. Of Teaneck, New Jersey, died on January 13, 2000. Beloved husband of Sara. Devoted father of Fern Segal and Dr. Robert Fishman. Cherished father-in-law of Donald Segal and Susan Fishman. Loving grandfather of Richard, Robin and Robert, Danielle, Benjamin, Cory, Lauren and Samantha. title: Without A Mirror In Sight
description: Fancy a martini while having eyeglasses fitted? That's a possibility at Artistic Eye, the Beverly Hills store of the eyeglass designer Micheal Sparks. He did not want his store ''to be like walking into somebody's refrigerator,'' he said, meaning clinical and cold. Instead he wanted a homage to modernism at its most luxurious. The inspiration was the 1937 Saks Fifth Avenue store in Beverly Hills by the architect Paul Williams. With Landworth Debolske Associates, Mr. Sparks has created a warm interior with a kidney-shape ceiling cove, a Sputnik-style chandelier, a tuck-and-roll martini bar and 1950's furniture. The sense of an intimate boudoir is increased by the lack of showroom mirrors or photos of models wearing glasses. Artistic Eye is at 459 North Canon Drive, (310) 278-1810, and at 463 Union Street, San Francisco, (415) 397-5111.

title: BRITISH TELECOM PURCHASE

title: Growing Pineapple
description: Q. My daughter decided she needs her own bedroom plant, and of all things, she wanted to grow a pineapple. Luckily, we all love pineapple because we have now eaten three in order to get the tops for her to start, all without success. Each time we have been careful to keep a thin layer of fruit attached to the leaves. She suspended one on toothpicks over water, like an avocado pit; immersed another in water up to the leaves; and planted the third in good garden soil. I don't mind eating another one, but she is becoming disenchanted and I would like this one actually to grow.

title: ASTRA IS URGED TO REVEAL PLANS
description: Indonesia's bank restructuring agency has requested that the country's largest automaker, Astra International, hold an extraordinary shareholders' meeting on Feb. 8 to discuss management changes and review plans to sell new Astra shares. Bank closings and pledges by big corporate debtors have made the agency Astra's largest shareholder, with a stake of roughly 40 percent. The agency aims to sell its holding to help raise money for the nation's bank bailout and last month it named as its preferred buyer a group of investors led by Gilbert Global Equity Partners and Newbridge Capital.

title: CHAIRMAN OF SUN INTERNATIONAL HOTELS LEADS BUYOUT BID
description: Sun International Hotels Ltd., owner of the Atlantis resort in the Bahamas, said yesterday that a group led by its chairman had offered $379 million for the 47 percent of the company that it did not already own. Sun International Investments Ltd., led by Sun's chairman and chief executive, Solomon Kerzner, offered $24 a share in cash. The stock jumped $3.1875 a share, to $22.50, on the New York Stock Exchange. The group is taking advantage of a 50 percent drop in Sun's shares in the last year; Hurricane Floyd damaged the Atlantis resort in September. Sun said it would form an independent board committee to consider the offer. Sun owns the Resorts casino in Atlantic City and manages the Mohegan Sun Casino in Connecticut.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BLOCH, JOEL
description: BLOCH-Joel. New York City Opera mourns the passing of our good friend and colleague, Joel Bloch, who died in New York on January 8th of a massive heart attack at the age of 50, and was buried in Israel. As an artists' manager, he was an important member of the operatic community with an encyclopedic knowledge of opera repertory, who had built his carer through years of hard work and commitment. His judgment was acute, and his opinions, which he was never afraid to share, were often delivered with a razor-sharp sense of humor. He had an honest passion for and real love of the operatic art form and the human voice. Joel was tremendously supportive of New York City Opera and believed firmly in its goals and its mission. He was a real friend to all of us and we will miss him. We extend our deepest sympathies to his wife Ilene, his daughters, and his many friends around the world. Paul Kellogg, General Director Robin Thompson, Director of Artistic Administration

title: Restful Destinations for the Nap-Inclined
description: POWER napping, in simpler times called a siesta, does not require a king-size bed. A reclining chair, or maybe a floor mat will do. Dr. James B. Maas, the author of ''Power Sleep'' (Villard Books, 1998), says that even people who are not sleep-deprived can benefit from a short daily nap. Napping, he says, increases efficiency, reduces accidents and increases alertness. The best plan: right after lunch (no coffee, please), set the timer for 30 minutes maximum and close your eyes. This is more easily achieved in a home office, but some companies are increasingly accepting of employee naps.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GRUSKIN, DOROTHY LIEBERMAN
description: GRUSKIN-Dorothy Lieberman., 88, on Wednesday, January 19, 2000. Born April 18, 1911 in Pittsburgh, Penn. In 1928 she moved to Brooklyn, N.Y., where she met her husband-to-be, Dr. Samuel Gruskin. They married in June of 1932 and shared a life of 67 years full of travel and wonderful experiences. Dorothy and Sam attended NYU and Columbia University. Dorothy received her master's degree in social work from the New York School of Social Work. She was initiated as a member of Alpha Kappa Delta, a national honorary sociological fraternity, in 1932. For 25 years, she practiced social work in Westchester County, New York City and Long Island. She was cofounder of and volunteer for the Brooklyn section of the National Council of Jewish Women. In 1978, the Brooklyn section of the NCJW gave her the Hannah G. Solomon Award for woman of the year. Dorothy is survived by her husband, Sam; her son and daughter-in-law, Dr. Philip and Antoinette Gruskin; her daughter and son-in-law, Regina and Lewis Appelbaum; her grandchildren Neal, Phyllis, Steven and Susan, his wife. She is also survived by her brother and sister-inlaw, Dr. William and Marcia Lieberman, and their children Kathy and Jay; her brother-in-law, Samuel Cohen, and his daughters, Lois and Elaine, and their families; and by her sister-in-law, Bea Gruskin of California. Her sister, Helen Lieberman Cohen, brothers-in-law Robert Gruskin and Irving Berman, and sister-in-law, Ann Gruskin Berman, preceded her in death. Dorothy was a strong, loving and caring person, and we will miss her. Services will be held at 1:30 PM today at Garlick-Kirschenbaum Funeral Home, 1153 Coney Island Avenue, Brooklyn. Donations in her name may be sent to the Visiting Nurse Service of NY Hospice Care, 2170 McDonald Avenue, Brooklyn, NY 11223 or the National Council of Jewish Women-Brooklyn Section, 1001 Quentin Road, Brooklyn, NY 11223.

title: SPANISH BANK BUYS BRAZILIAN CONCERN

Banco Santander said it would become Brazil's fifth-biggest financial services company, increasing its current Brazilian assets of $7.6 billion to $12.5 billion, after the completion of the purchase. Banco Santander merged last year with Banco Central Hispano of Spain, and the combined bank has major equity stakes in 16 banks in 10 Latin American nations. Al Goodman

title: NORTHERN STATES TO BUY EASTERN POWER PLANT INTERESTS
description: The Northern States Power Company, owner of Minneapolis's electric utility, agreed yesterday to buy four coal-fired power plants and stakes in two others from Conectiv Inc., which sells power in four Eastern states, for $800 million. Northern States will get 1,875 megawatts of generating capacity in New Jersey, Delaware, Maryland and western Pennsylvania. Northern States has 1.5 million customers in North Dakota, South Dakota, Minnesota and Wisconsin. Last year, the company's NRG Energy unit paid more than $1 billion to buy power plants in Connecticut and New York.

title: Aluminum Supplier Stake

The stake was acquired from the Reynolds Metals Company and SGF Mineral Inc. SGF Mineral, a Canadian investment company, will get the remaining 40 percent of Reycan. Reycan is a supplier of thin aluminum for the United States automobile industry and has annual sales of about $183 million. Corus is based in London.

title: Remembering John Lautner, Who Hated And Loved Los Angeles
description: Five years after the death of the architect John Lautner, two excellent tributes to his work have been published: ''John Lautner'' (Taschen; $29.99) by Barbara-Ann Campbell-Lange and ''The Architecture of John Lautner'' (Rizzoli, $75) by Alan Hess, with new photographs by Alan Weintraub. Both books grapple with a man who despised Los Angeles while he took inspiration from its topography, climate and freedom. Despite the difficulty of photographing what Ms. Campbell-Lange calls the ''complex nonrectilinear spaces'' of Lautner's buildings (as in his 1950 Louise Foster house, top), both books are glorious to look at.

title: Santa Monica Takes On Glow Of Sculpture
description: Architects call utilitarian things like newsstands, phone booths and street lamps ''street furniture,'' and interesting examples are rare. So the new lampposts on Pico Boulevard in Santa Monica are a delightful surprise. The lamps were commissioned by Santa Monica and designed by Katherine Spitz Associates, a Los Angeles-based landscape architecture firm, as part of a 30-block street-improvement program to give the boulevard an identity. Inspired by Jean Arp and Alexander Calder, the lamps consist of 11 feet of galvanized pipe with a concealed light at the top, which bounces a soft, candlelike glow off a galvanized steel leaf. The effect is simultaneously cool and elegantly sinuous.

Like much of the whining, that turned out not to be true. Of course, stalking the big-bang novel is always a must, but a casual roll call of the houses this week shows that some publishing schedules for 2000 are bursting with first novels, both literary and commercial.

title: DEXTER SEEKS A LARGER STAKE IN LIFE TECHNOLOGIES

The offer values Life Technology, the maker of biotechnology chemicals and cell nutrients, at $1.24 billion. Dexter offered in July 1998 to buy the rest of Life Technologies, but it was thwarted when a group led by International Specialty's chairman, Samuel Heyman, bought a 25 percent stake in Life Technologies. Last month International Specialty made a $45 a share offer for Dexter, which Dexter rejected.

title: LEGATO SHARES FALL AS 4TH-QUARTER PROFIT DIPS
description: The shares of Legato Systems Inc. fell 44 percent yesterday after the company, a software maker, said late on Wednesday that its fourth-quarter profit had tumbled, revenue growth would slow and third-quarter earnings had been restated. Legato plunged $23.875, to $29.75, as almost 39.7 million shares were traded. The company, a maker of software used to back up computer data, said it had to defer $19 million in revenue until 2000, leading to the restatement and the fourth-quarter profit shortfall. It also said revenue growth would slow to 50 percent this year, below the 70 percent that analysts had forecast. Legato's fourth-quarter earnings fell to $3.05 million, or 3 cents a share, from $7.08 million, or 8 cents, a year earlier.

description: Lionbridge Technologies Inc. said yesterday that it had agreed to acquire Int'l.com, a rival provider of software conversion and Internet portal globalization services, for about $190 million in stock. Lionbridge, based in Waltham, Mass., and Int'l, based in Framingham, Mass., both help multinational companies convert software, translate help manuals and globalize Web sites for use by people in their native languages. Lionbridge and Int'l will have a combined work force of 900 employees in 10 countries. Lionbridge had sales of $38.4 million in 1998. Shares of Lionbridge rose $3.75 yesterday, to $25, in Nasdaq trading.

title: British Panel Wants Some House of Lords Members to Be Elected
description: The House of Lords should include, for the first time in history, some members who have been elected by the British public, a commission studying the future of the Lords recommended today.

description: Four years after Greece and Turkey went to the brink of war over a barren islet in the Aegean Sea, their foreign ministers met here today to sign a series of accords and pledge themselves to peace.

title: SINGAPORE'S EXPORTS BOOM
description: Underscoring the importance of the global technology boom to Southeast Asia's economic recovery, Singapore reported 25 percent annualized growth in nonoil domestic exports in December, led by printer exports that more than doubled and a surge of more than 50 percent in exports of integrated circuits. The strong finish to 1999 capped a 9.5 percent rise in nonoil domestic exports for the year, the highest growth since 1995. Most encouraging, economists said, was robust growth in Singapore's exports to other countries in Southeast Asia. Wayne Arnold

title: SWEDISH MATCH TO BUY STAKE IN GENERAL CIGAR
description: Swedish Match A.B., Sweden's only maker of matches and tobacco products, offered yesterday to buy a 64 percent stake in General Cigar Holdings Inc. for $170 million to expand abroad while focusing on cigars and snuff products. Swedish Match is offering $15.25 a share. General Cigar rose $5.625, to $14.5625. The Cullman family, which has managed General Cigar since 1961, agreed to sell one-third of its holdings to Swedish Match for $15 a share in cash. The Cullman family plans to hold the remaining 36 percent of the company and will continue to manage it.

description: A business student who argued with two men he had caught urinating near a door to his Queens apartment building was killed Wednesday night when the men returned and one of them shot him in the head, the police said.

title: Last Double-Entendre of a Gender Bender?
description: Do we really have to say goodnight to Hedwig? It's true that this stitched-together collage of a woman has put in close to two years down there on the waterfront, where she has turned the Jane Street Theater into her personal confessional. But as of last Wednesday night, she was looking awfully healthy for someone who describes her own exterior as a ''paper shroud,'' and she was still wearing her scarred heart like a rhinestone lavaliere. That heart still glitters; it still hypnotizes.

title: Metro Business; Office Space Sought
description: Senator Charles E. Schumer announced yesterday that he had formed a blue-ribbon panel to address what he described as the greatest obstacle facing New York City's economy: a lack of office space for the financial services, high technology and biotech industries.

title: Chicago Board of Trade Recommends a Split
description: Responding to the growing threat of competition from electronic trading systems, the directors of the Chicago Board of Trade voted overwhelming yesterday to split the exchange into two for-profit companies.

title: Whitman Orders Attorney General to Investigate Possible Cover-Up in Auto Emissions Tests
description: Besieged by complaints that New Jersey's new auto emissions inspection program has forced drivers to wait in line for hours, Gov. Christine Todd Whitman ordered her attorney general today to investigate whether contractors or state employees had deliberately concealed the extent of the problems as the system was being developed.

description: Former Senator Bill Bradley disclosed tonight that he had suffered four bouts of irregular heartbeat, a recurring condition known as atrial fibrillation, since Dec. 10, when he first said he suffered from the aliment.

title: Corrections

title: Union Says Poll of Teachers Predicts Wave of Retirements
description: More than 14,000 of New York City's 75,000 public school teachers plan to retire over the next 18 months, a far faster pace than previously predicted, according to a new survey by the teachers' union.

title: Mr. Helms at the U.N.
description: The United Nations Security Council has long echoed with heated confrontations. But there has never been anything quite like the strained but polite scene yesterday as Senator Jesse Helms sat in the council chamber and warned that the United States would withdraw if the U.N. sought ''to impose its presumed authority on the American people without their consent.'' Several members of the Security Council disputed Mr. Helms, but with utmost diplomacy. In the end, like most disagreements at the U.N., the exchange was healthy for all sides. It was even likely to increase understanding between the United Nations and its critics in Congress and throughout the United States.

title: Popular and Full of Pride, Barbara Bush Campaigns
description: ''I want to thank all of you who are helping George W. Bush get elected,'' Barbara Bush said today, in the pleasant but rather flat tone of a practiced campaigner on yet another stump.

title: Cuts at Network Equipment
description: Network Equipment Technologies Inc., a maker of telecommunications networks, said today that it had cut about 300 jobs, or 30 percent of its work force, as it reduces costs and focuses on new products. More than half of the job cuts were at the company's headquarters here, with the rest in Network Equipment's European operations. The cuts will result in a $12 million charge in the quarter that ends on March 31. The company plans to split into two units, one of which will develop new equipment for high-speed online services, said a spokeswoman, Brenda Ropoulos.

title: Mosley Likes Chances In Higher Weight Class
description: Sugar Shane Mosley may have jumped two weight classes, going from lightweight (135 pounds) to welterweight (147 pounds), but he has not lost any of his confidence.

title: New Jersey Plans Grand Makeover for Ellis Island
description: New Jersey officials sketched a $300 million vision today for the redevelopment of Ellis Island, most of which has been concealed behind overgrown weeds and chain-link fences from the millions who visit every year.
