description: Twenty-six members of a Lower East Side gang known as the Top Notch Crew have been charged with felony drug sales, the Manhattan district attorney, Robert M. Morgenthau, announced yesterday.

description: The entwined coaching careers of Bill Parcells and Bill Belichick will very likely be resolved today.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BRAFMAN, MORRIS
description: BRAFMAN-Morris. On January 20, 2000. Beloved and most devoted husband of Frances for over 60 years. Loving father of Dr. Irving and Mona, Annette and Dr. Seymour Jotkowitz, Milton and Sandy. Cherished grandfather and great grandfather. Mr. Brafman escaped from Austria following Kristallnacht and made his way via Cuba to the United States. He was a successful businessman, community leader and humanitarian, especially distinguishing himself as one of the original and most active supporters of the struggle of Soviet Jewry. A prolific writer, he published the newspaper for the Jewish community in Cuba, authored many articles and several books. He supported Torah institutions here and in Israel. Services Sinai Chapels, Horace Harding Blvd., Fresh Meadows, NY, Friday, January 21, 9:30 AM. Shiva at the Jotkowitz home, 484 Kensington Rd., Teaneck, NJ, through Thursday morning, January 27.

title: SUEZ LYONNAISE SELLS UNIT
description: The French utility company Suez Lyonnaise des Eaux sold its remaining 30 percent stake in the financial-services company Sofinco to Credit Agricole d'Ile de France, the country's largest bank, for $502 million. The move gives Credit Agricole full control of Sofinco, which specializes in consumer credit. Suez Lyonnaise sold 70 percent of Sofinco to Credit Agricole in January 1999. The sale is part of Suez Lyonnaise's strategy of focusing on its core water, energy, waste and communications divisions. The sale will bring Suez Lyonnaise a pretax capital gain of $280 million, which will be recorded this year.

title: To Schuss, To Shop
description: Zermatt it's not. It's not Vail or even Stratton, its tonier neighbor in the Green Mountains of southern Vermont. But Bromley, a four-hour drive north of Manhattan, offers congenial family skiing and snowboarding with a bonus: proximity to the outlet mecca of Manchester Center with its designer shops of discounted Giorgio Armani, Calvin Klein, Gianni Versace, Dansk, Godiva and other haut-branded fashions, housewares and edibles. In short, all the makings for a perfect ''ski 'n' shop'' excursion.

description: The General Electric Company said today that its fourth-quarter profit rose 16 percent, to a record $3.09 billion, driven by sales of service contracts at industrial businesses and advertising at its NBC television network.

description: TUBERT-George. The friends and family of George and Sabine are profoundly saddened to announce George's death at age 42 on January 20, 2000. title: General Motors Earnings Decline but Still Beat Expectations
description: Profits fell as sales rose at General Motors in the fourth quarter, when the company ran short of high-margin models and offered discounts to keep sales booming for its less-profitable cars and trucks.

title: VITRISEAL TO BUY THERMOFLOW AND LIQUITEK
description: VitriSeal Inc., which makes products that protect against metal corrosion, agreed to buy the closely held Thermoflow Corporation and the Liquitek Corporation for a combined $86.4 million in stock to improve profitability. VitriSeal shares rose $1.75 each, to $5.375, a 52-week high. VitriSeal will issue 10.06 million shares, or $54.1 million, for Thermoflow, a Las Vegas company that has technology for the recovery of antifreeze. It will issue six million shares, or $32.3 million, for Liquitek, which is based in Knoxville, Tenn., and uses a form of Thermoflow's technology to clean waste water.

title: Mild-Mannered Pair With a Very Sexy Plan
description: DAN GLUCK and Alison Maddex -- the stylish young entrepreneurs who hope to build the Museum of Sex on Fifth Avenue -- always worry about revealing to reporters the story of how they met.

title: Simondium Journal; No Wine Sold Before Its Time, Very Little Since
description: Ah, harvest time in the wine country! The lush vines twist on wooden gables, the green leaves unfurl in the warm summer sun and the sweet grapes hang heavy and ripe in the shadow of the craggy Drakenstein mountains.

title: History Will See Kohl's Strengths
description: Overnight, King Kohl becomes King Lear. The political fall of Helmut Kohl must, irresistibly, be described in terms of classical tragedy. Nemesis follows hubris. Two months ago, on the 10th anniversary of the fall of the Berlin Wall, he seemed an unchallenged national hero. When he walked down Unter den Linden, people approached him, like the old kaiser, just to touch his sleeve. It was as if they still believed in the royal touch.

title: CONCORD TO PURCHASE FIRSTSENSE SOFTWARE
description: Concord Communications Inc., a maker of computer programs that detect flaws in computer networks, agreed yesterday to acquire FirstSense Software Inc., which makes programs that manage e-commerce software, for $101 million in stock. Concord, based in Marlboro, Mass., will exchange 1.94 million shares for the stock in FirstSense, a closely held company based in Burlington, Mass. The announcement was made after the close of the stock markets. Concord shares fell $1.5625 each yesterday, to $52.25, in Nasdaq trading.

title: Poised and Elegant, Like the Brahmins
description: No one could accuse Boston of being a hotbed of the avant-garde. From early on, its prominent citizens, many of them arrivistes themselves, evinced a snooty disdain for the new in their houses and furnishings, opting instead for conservative environments that were dignified, elegant and ''tastey,'' as a prominent Boston textile merchant, Nathan Appleton, put it.

title: Aides Fear That Bradley Let Iowa Momentum Slip Away
description: After pouring vast resources into this state, some of Bill Bradley's top advisers are questioning whether their campaign passed up an important opportunity by not responding more rapidly, or aggressively, to Vice President Al Gore's attacks.

title: DNA Data Suggest Sperm In Competition For Mating
description: A startling insight into the evolution of human mating behavior has been extracted from the dry DNA data generated by the federal human genome project.

title: DINER'S JOURNAL
description: It's hard to know whether Grace is a restaurant with a bar or a bar with a restaurant. Visually the bar comes first, and it's impossible to miss. Weighty, glossy and a mile long, it dominates the front room, and there's more to it than polished mahogany. Fred McKibbin, one of the owners, did pioneering cocktail work at Nosmo King, now defunct, and he has transferred his obsessions to Grace, where the bar list includes an apple martini made with vodka and Berentzen Apfelkorn, a tangerine margarita and a superior winter warmer made with hot spiced cider, Maker's Mark bourbon, fresh lemon juice and a stick of cinnamon.

title: Gore Meets With Gay Leaders Before Homestretch in Iowa
description: Vice President Al Gore opened his final four-day push for the Iowa vote at a rally here today by countering Bill Bradley's efforts to cast him as the candidate of entrenched power, but he began his day with a private meeting with 20 gay leaders at his residence in Washington.

description: ATTRACTIONS

title: Seton Hall Won't Compete For the Rest of This Week
description: In the wake of the fatal dormitory fire at Seton Hall University, officials there said yesterday that none of its athletic teams would compete for the rest of the week.

title: Eyeing Crime Rate, Police to Work Overtime on Drug Arrests
description: In an effort to stop the crime rate from creeping up, the Police Department plans to spend about $20 million in overtime to put more than 400 additional narcotics officers on the streets and increase the number of daily drug arrests, several police and city officials said yesterday.

title: To the Manner Fashioned
description: Michael Flanigan, an antiques dealer in Baltimore, recently offered a tip to aficionados of early-19th-century Boston antiques.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BOYER, KENNETH R.
description: BOYER-Kenneth R., 67, of Quogue, NY, died January 19, 2000, at University Hospital Stony Brook. Beloved companion, brother, uncle, and friend and mentor to many. He was much loved and will be sorely missed. Memorial service to be arranged for spring.

title: Painfully Fresh Memories of a Fire's Young Victims
description: While officials searched for an explanation, the families and friends of Frank S. Caltabilota, Aaron C. Karol and John C. Giunta, the three freshmen killed in a fire at Seton Hall University, searched today for words to describe three good kids who died much too young.

title: Bond Insures Union Against Theft
description: The losses claimed by the American Federation of State, County and Municipal Employees are covered by a form of insurance often referred to as a fidelity bond.

title: If Dessert Is the Goal
description: Winter makes one yearn for comfort food, and what could be more comforting than dessert. Here are a dozen places with desserts worth breaking your diet for. (These summaries are taken from dining reviews, columns and articles in The Times by William Grimes, Eric Asimov and others.)

title: A Couple of Palookas Who Don't Sting or Float
description: Ron Shelton's screwball boxing comedy ''Play It to the Bone'' is so constrained by its formulaic plot that the movie's juicy, freewheeling dialogue feels shoehorned into a story that makes more sense mathematically than psychologically. If the movie (which is predictable right down to the outcome of its climactic bout) had been allowed to take one quirky left turn, it might have come closer to matching the power of Mr. Shelton's baseball film ''Bull Durham'' or his golf film, ''Tin Cup.''

title: Ledyard Stebbins, 94, Dies; Applied Evolution to Plants
description: Dr. G. Ledyard Stebbins Jr., one of the leading evolutionary biologists and foremost botanists of the 20th century, died on Wednesday at his home in Davis, Calif. He was 94.

title: THEATER GUIDE
description: Here is a selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy Broadway and Off Broadway shows this weekend. Approximate running times are in parentheses. * denotes a highly recommended show.

description: My Kingdom For a House!

title: Union Cleanup Praised; U.S. Oversight Is Eased
description: The Justice Department agreed yesterday to relax its oversight of the Laborers union after five years of threatening to take over the union if the efforts by the Laborers to root out corruption stumbled.

title: Where Women Are Merry And Men Hide in Closets
description: The plot of ''The Merry Wives of Windsor'' is simple. An aging, seriously overweight man gets it into his head that two attractive married women in town have eyes for him, and he decides to make their lives complete by sleeping with them. Separately. The women's husbands hear about this plan, and one of them puts on a disguise in order to find out just how interested the wives are. When the women themselves hear about it, they decide to have a little fun with the old guy. Meanwhile, almost every other man in town wants to marry young Anne Page, who is apparently the Liv Tyler of 14th-century Windsor.

title: EUROPEAN RATES ARE UNCHANGED
description: The European Central Bank said that its key interest rates were left unchanged after a meeting of its governing council. The decision had been widely expected, though most economists predict that the bank will raise rates during the first quarter of this year. The deposit rate remains at 2 percent, the marginal lending rate at 4 percent, and the refinancing tender at 3 percent. The central bank said it would allocate 20 billion euros, or $20.6 billion, at its long-term refinancing tenders in the first half of 2000.

title: To the Dance

Confidant, mentor and pal to numerous nieces, nephews, grandnieces, grandnephews and cousins. Brother of Lillian Sherman, Joseph Rosenberg, and the late Sylvia Ginsberg, Simon and Louis Rosenberg. True friend to many, both within and outside his beloved practice of law, which was centered on creditors' rights and Federal Bankruptcy Court in Brooklyn. As humanitarians and philanthropists, he and Judy have been lifelong supporters of medical research, the performing arts, and education, especially in the establishment of scholarship funds. Contributions may be made to Albert Einstein College of Medicine of Yeshiva University, Jack and Pearl Resnick Campus, Room B803, Center for Genetic and Translational Medicine, 1300 Morris Park Avenue, Bronx, NY 10461. title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STONE, IRVING I.
description: STONE-Irving I. Torah UmesorahNational Society for Hebrew Day Schools, deeply mourns the loss of Irving Stone ob''m, a great pioneer and prominent philanthropic lay leader of the Hebrew Day School movement for over half a century. When the majority of American Jewry considered day schools parochial and anti-American, Mr. Stone established one of the first day schools, the Hebrew Academy of Cleveland, a benchmark school and shining example of day school education par excellence. He thus paved the way for the phenomenal growth and success of today's North American Day School movement - 600 schools and 170,000 students strong - now recognized as a bulwark against assimilation. Irving Stone has left a profound and indelible impression upon Jewish history. When the great Rav Shraga F. Mendlowitz founded Torah Umesorah, working together with its eminent founding director, Dr. Joseph Kaminetzky, Mr. Stone became their partner and a founding pillar in the lay leadership of the National Day School movement. May his dear wife, children and extended family be comforted amongst the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Rabbi Elya Svei, Chairman Rabbinical Board Rabbi Jacob Rajchenbach President Rabbi Joshua Fishman, Exec. VP

description: KLASS-Sholom, Rabbi. At the age of 83. The Board of Governing Rabbis and the Ecclesiastical Rabbinical Court of the Rabbinical Alliance of America-Igud Horabbonim-deeply mourns the passing of the Publisher and Editor of The Jewish Press, the largest AngloJewish circulation newspaper in the world. Rabbi Klass authored ''Responsa of Modern Judaism'' (3 volumes) and is considered to have been the greatest disseminator of Jewish learning in modern times. Rabbi Klass was the single most powerful voice of Jewish tradition in our times. His support for the State of Israel and for Orthodox Judaism was instrumental in formulating national and international policies. Rabbi Klass was a distinguished member of the Directorate of the Rabbinical Alliance. World Jewry lost one of its most powerful advocates. We extend our heartfelt condolence to the children, grandchildren and great grandchildren, and to the entire family. Rabbi Abraham B. Hecht, Pres. Rabbi Gershon Tannenbaum, Dir. title: Paid Notice: Deaths  AXENFIELD, SIDNEY
description: AXENFIELD-Sidney. After a brief illness, Sidney Axenfield (formerly of New York City) passed peacefully in his 90th year at Hearthstone, Lee, Mass., on January 19, 2000. A veteran of World War II, Sidney returned to New York in 1946 and completed his degree at City College. In his professional life Sidney was a chartered accountant and maintained an independent practice in New York until his retirement. Those who knew Sidney will always cherish his love of family, literary works, classical music, his humanitarian causes, his generosity and superb sense of humor. Sidney's family would like to extend their appreciation to the staff at Hearthstone, the Berkshire Medical Center and HospiceCare of Lee. In particular, we wish to thank Charles Redd, his nurse at Hearthstone, as well as Dr. Jay Ellis of Pittsfield, Mass., and Dr. Patricia Bloom of New York City for their special care of Sidney. Predeceased by his wife, Fay (Rothe), in 1988, and his brother, Dr. Milton Axenfield, in 1998, Sidney is survived by his beloved daughter, Alice, and son-in-law, Dr. James Storm, of Ancram, N.Y.; beloved granddaughter, Stephanie Ava, and her husband, Richard Keller; great-granddaughter Samantha Fay Maelen of Leonia, N.J.; grandson Ivan Goldberg of Millbrook, N.Y.; niece Ellen Axenfield Kohler of Berkeley, Calif.; nephew Howard Klumack of Hollywood, Fla.; Allen and Therese Axenfield of Warrensburg, N.Y.; and granddaughter Allyson. Funeral arrangements are being made for a private service. However, the family will be sending invitations for a memorial celebration of Sidney's life in the spring at the family residence, StormField, in Ancram. In lieu of flowers, please support Sidney's favorite cause, Amnesty International.

description: A Long Island man killed his wife in a car in Suffolk County yesterday morning and then traveled to his job in Queens, where he locked up a co-worker at a co-op complex, killed his supervisor and tried to kill himself, the authorities said.

description: Because of an editing error, an article yesterday about Bill Bradley's use of advisers in his campaign for the Democrats' presidential nomination referred incorrectly to the New Jersey institution at which his wife, Ernestine Schlant, teaches. It is Montclair State University, not Montclair State College.

title: Recording Industry Files Copyright Lawsuit Against MP3.Com
description: Recording Industry Files Copyright Lawsuit Against MP3.Com

title: It Seems to Be U.S. vs. the Other Six at the Group of 7 Meeting
description: Against the backdrop of the record $26.5 billion United States trade deficit, the meeting of officials of the Group of Seven industrialized nations that will take place here Sunday has shaped up as a conflict between the United States and the others.

title: Hillary Clinton Vows to Fight to Preserve Abortion Rights
description: Signaling that she will not yield the issue of abortion rights in her race for United States Senate, Hillary Rodham Clinton yesterday presented herself as a stronger advocate on the issue than Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani.

title: Clifford Truesdell, 80, Master Of 2 Disciplines of Mechanics
description: Clifford Truesdell, a mathematician and historian of mathematics who also was an authority on European art and culture, died on Jan. 14. in Baltimore. He was 80 and lived in Baltimore.

title: Whitman's Transport Plan Would Not Raise Gas Tax
description: Buoyed by hundreds of millions of dollars in unexpected state revenue, Gov. Christine Todd Whitman and legislative leaders agreed today on a plan to provide $1 billion for New Jersey's transportation trust fund in each of the next three years without raising the state's gasoline tax.

title: Cake Is Her World, and What a Small World That Is
description: Extremely good-looking people tend to be shallow, self-involved and not very bright. Let's call this statement what it is: a form of prejudice, a stereotype. It is, sadly, a stereotype that ''Down to You'' does everything in its power to promote. The film's stars, Freddie Prinze Jr. and Julia Stiles, are wonderful to look at: their dimples match beautifully, their bodies move with effortless grace, their teeth are downright inspiring.

title: Gain for Germany's Far Right Feared
description: German Christian Democracy has had two basic functions: to defeat the left and to present a conservative front broad enough to marginalize any extreme-right movement. Now, with the party in crisis, fears are mounting that Germany's rightist fringe parties will benefit.

title: GORE GOES BACK TO SCHOOL
description: When the candidate's campaign was flagging, he found that he needed to take a crash course -- in politics. A report by James Bennet in The Times Magazine.

title: From Assembly Line to Book Awards
description: Twenty-five years ago, when Christopher Curtis was working at the Fisher Body Plant in Flint, Mich., hanging doors on Buicks one a minute, he would hallucinate at night about the assembly line. In his sleep, he would see the door frame waiting to be clamped onto a car. He would feel his bed moving underneath him. The only way he could escape the line's indelible imprint was to write. But Mr. Curtis never dreamed he could ever be a ''real'' writer.

title: No One's in Charge, and Biggest Loser Is Boxing
description: Vernon Forrest will step into a ring in Las Vegas tonight for the 31st time as a professional boxer. It will not be a title fight. Although he is undefeated in eight years as a pro and is considered one of the best welterweights in the world, Forrest has never been given a chance to fight a champion.

title: He's a King in Name, a Titan in Action
description: Samari Rolle is a Tennessee Titans cornerback with a royal name and an unusual physique. He is 6 feet tall, but he weighs only 175 pounds. Spindly, all arms and legs. He is reminiscent of a pencil or a blade of grass.

title: Abroad at Home; 'Imposing on Them a Badge of Inferiority'
description: On May 17, 1942, Elmer Henderson, a federal government employee, took a Southern Railway train from Washington to Atlanta. The trip was on government business.

title: Case Illustrates Powerful Lure of Stolen-Car Rings
description: Danny Domingo was a determined cutter. Working with a ring of thieves and racketeers who bought protection from the Bonanno crime family, Mr. Domingo ran a chop-shop operation that helped feed a stolen-parts enterprise.

title: INSIDE
description: Revisiting Federalism

title: Indulging an Eye for Design and Color
description: Inbal Pinto worked for a time creating store-window displays to support her career as a dancer. Her bold, clear eye for design and color was evident in ''Wrapped,'' a new work the young Israeli choreographer and dancer presented at the Kitchen on Thursday night.

title: Ex-School Board Official Acquitted of Charges
description: Joseph McCarthy, a former official on Community School Board 10 in the Bronx, was acquitted yesterday in State Supreme Court of 15 felony counts of violating the state election law and forging applications for absentee ballots in a 1993 school board election. He was accused of ballot tampering to help his brother, Edward McCarthy, an unsuccessful candidate in that election.

title: INFLATION UP IN CANADA
description: The annual rate of inflation in Canada, as measured by the consumer price index, was 2.6 percent in December, up from 2.2 percent in November, Statistics Canada reported. Higher prices for oil and gas accounted for most of the increase. Excluding energy, prices were only 1.6 percent higher than a year ago. For the last nine months, consumer price inflation excluding energy has been 1.5 or 1.6 percent. Timothy Pritchard

title: A Misdirected College Tax Credit
description: President Clinton's plan to provide tax subsidies to cover college tuition was a bad idea when he proposed it five years ago. It was still a bad idea when he proposed it again this week, calling for a tuition tax credit of as much as $2,800 a year for families with incomes of up to $120,000.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''The sport is a bit like Dodge City.''

title: Myanmar Issues Tough Internet Restrictions
description: Myanmar Issues Tough Internet Restrictions

title: McCain Faults Landmark Abortion Decision
description: Senator John McCain today criticized the landmark Supreme Court decision that created a legal right to abortion as ''overreaching.''

title: Labor Ends Its Long Slide
description: The number of union members increased more last year than at any time in the past two decades, drawing cheers from organized labor. But a sober look at the numbers mutes enthusiasm. Unions barely kept pace with the overall economy, accounting for an unchanged 13.9 percent of the work force. That is a drop from about 35 percent in the 1950's.

title: Canada Kills Subsidy Plan for 6 N.H.L. Teams
description: Three days after agreeing to help subsidize the National Hockey League teams based in Canada, the Canadian government yesterday abandoned its plan after it was deluged with angry public reaction.

title: Planned Buildings to Shift To Save a Manhattan View
description: It only lasts for a few seconds, depending on how fast you are driving and how much attention you are paying to the road, but the big, booming view motorists have of the Manhattan skyline from the corkscrew approach to the Lincoln Tunnel will be saved under an agreement with a builder that wanted to block it partially with an office project.

title: Agreement Bars Using Children as Soldiers
description: Negotiators in Geneva agreed today on a new international accord prohibiting the use of child soldiers in war after the United States dropped its opposition to establishing 18 as the minimum age for sending soldiers into combat.

title: Making an Apartment a Home for a Fresh Start
description: Tyquail Sykes, 2, stood on his bed and stared out the window at the first snowfall of the year. He could see thicker and thicker flakes swirling in the wind and eventually falling to the pavement.

title: China Airlines Tries to Fix Its Reputation on Safety
description: For China Airlines, the 1990's were a recurring nightmare: three fiery crashes in six years that resulted in nearly 500 deaths. The only cold comfort for Taiwan's flagship carrier is that travelers seem to have developed shorter memories.

title: Goal to Perform the New, but What If the New Is Old?
description: New-music groups must be in the forefront of the ''it's not really the 21st century yet'' argument. Having made their careers crusading on behalf of ''the music of our own century,'' they now find themselves with repertories composed in the last one. But if the new century begins in 2001, composers have a year to provide works with composition dates that at least begin with 2, even if they are technically still works of the 20th century.

title: Corrections
description: The Classical Music and Dance Guide in Weekend yesterday misstated two telephone numbers for New York City Ballet events. The number for ordering tickets is (212) 307-4100. The number for information on today's ''Family Fanfare'' programs, an introduction to ballet for children, is (212) 870-4074.

description: The Food and Drug Administration temporarily shut down human gene therapy experiments at the University of Pennsylvania today after an inspection uncovered ''numerous serious deficiencies'' in ensuring patient safety during a clinical trial that cost an 18-year-old Arizona man his life.

title: Bradley and Doctor Say Bouts Are No Worry
description: A day after he disclosed that he had suffered four incidents of irregular heartbeats in the past month, former Senator Bill Bradley sought to assure voters in Iowa today that the condition was just ''a nuisance'' that would not affect his ability to campaign for president.

title: Politicians' Rally Protests Marital Fidelity Questions
description: As City Hall protests go, it was far from routine. Yesterday, when 10 of New York City's Democratic politicians gathered in the rotunda outside Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani's office, the point was to defend a Republican mayor and attack the media for its treatment of Hillary Rodham Clinton.

title: A Loud Defense That Takes Its Cue From Quiet Coach
description: For a quiet guy, Tony Dungy has certainly assembled and led some fierce and brutal defenses.

title: A Provocateur for Whom Liberal Principles Are a Sham
description: If I was to berate Stanley Fish the way some of his critics have -- calling him a ''trafficker in scurrility,'' a ''morally disgusting'' writer, an ''intellectual boot-boy'' -- then Mr. Fish, a professorial lover of polemic, might even get a certain amount of pleasure out of the diatribe. But he also might point out that the name calling itself is not objectionable; it's just ineffective. The disgust at his supposed scurrility will neither change his own beliefs nor convince anybody else to join in opposition. Far more interesting, he might suggest, would be to attack him in the name of liberal democracy, raising high the banner of principle, invoking reason, fairness and truth.

description: Trying to defuse a bitter standoff with the Giuliani administration, the Fisher real estate family and Morgan Stanley Dean Witter have abandoned plans for a private fund to invest $1 billion of public-employee pension money in New York real estate projects.

description: Vice President Al Gore stumped across farm country in central Iowa today, recalling his days in the 4-H Club, his Angus cattle and how his father had taught him to stop gullies.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PETINA, IRRA
description: PETINA-Irra. The Metropolitan Opera mourns the death of Irra Petina, a stalwart member of our company for 13 seasons between 1933 and 1950. Following her debut as Schwertleite in ''Die Walkuere,'' she sang 38 roles, including Carmen, in 444 performances with our company. She was much admired for her lively characterizations and keen gift for comedy in many supporting roles. We extend our deepest condolences to her family and friends. Joseph Volpe, General Manager James Levine, Artistic Director

description: Can Derek Jeter really be worth $17 million a year? George Steinbrenner thinks so, and in many ways that's all that matters. By and large, the public seems to think so, too.

description: Procter & Gamble's board met yesterday to consider stepping up merger talks with two pharmaceutical giants, American Home Products and Warner-Lambert, that would create one of the world's largest consumer products and drug companies.

title: A PLAN TO SELL A NATWEST UNIT
description: Trying to bolster its hostile bid for National Westminster Bank, the Bank of Scotland said it would sell Natwest's life insurance unit to Prudential P.L.C., if it beats out its rival, Royal Bank of Scotland Group, for control of Natwest, Britain's third-largest bank. As part of the sale of Natwest Life, Bank of Scotland said it would sell Prudential's insurance, pensions and mutual funds through its branches. Andrew Ross Sorkin

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: ANDERSEN CONSULTING , Chicago, will expand the finance and administrative services it provides for BP Amoco P.L.C., London, the oil and petrochemical company, for refining and marketing operations in the United States in a 10-year, $200 million agreement.

title: 4 Robbed at Gunpoint In Honduran Consulate
description: Four people were robbed at gunpoint inside the Honduran Consulate yesterday afternoon, the authorities said. Two men who entered the consulate at 80 Wall Street shortly after 3 p.m. forced two consulate agents and two other employees into a room, tied them up, and took $2,800 in cash, plus jewelry and personal effects, said Detective Joseph Pentangelo. No one was hurt in the robbery.

title: HOLZMANN ACCORD WITH UNION
description: The shares of the German builder Philipp Holzmann rose 18 percent after the company, which almost went out of business last year, said it had completed an agreement with the construction union IG Bau on a wage pact for its domestic work force. IG Bau, Germany's biggest construction union, and Holzmann said they agreed on a wage-savings pact under which employees will work five additional hours a week free, to be repaid again starting in the the middle of 2002, if Holzmann is profitable by then.

title: Russell L. Wenkstern, 87, Toy Chief and Dump Truck Co-Developer
description: Russell L. Wenkstern, who as the chief executive of Tonka Toys made them a household name, died on Tuesday in Spring Park, Minn. He was 87.

title: Conciliatory Election in Chile
description: The narrow election last weekend of Ricardo Lagos, a Socialist, as Chile's new president reflected a welcome break from the polarized past. Even before the final vote count was in, the defeated conservative candidate, Joaquin Lavin, went to Mr. Lagos's headquarters and embraced him on a flag-draped balcony, declaring, ''I am at his disposal to help unify Chile.'' It was an astonishing gesture of conciliation between right and left that would have been unthinkable only a few years ago, when politics was still riven by recriminations from Chile's era of repression, torture and political murder.

title: George Crowley, 80, Developer Of the Modern Electric Blanket
description: George C. Crowley, an engineer and inventor whose work led to 80 patents, including one for the first thermostatically controlled electric blanket, died Jan. 15 in Pinehurst, N. C., after suffering from pneumonia. He was 80 years old.

title: CITING INCREASED COSTS, HERCULES ISSUES PROFIT WARNING
description: Hercules Inc., one of the world's biggest makers of chemicals used in paper manufacturing, said yesterday that its fourth-quarter earnings would be as much as 25 percent less than expected because of higher costs and lower selling prices. The chemical maker was expected to earn 58 cents a share, the average estimate of analysts who were surveyed by First Call/Thomson Financial. Hercules shares fell $2.3125, or 11 percent, to a seven-year low of $19, in trading on the New York Stock Exchange. Though Hercules said its sales rose during the quarter, it has been forced to cut prices as customers in the paper industry merged and used their size to negotiate lower rates, analysts said. Hercules also blamed higher-than-expected costs in its BetzDearborn unit, which it acquired in 1998.

description: WASHINGTON  Adding an uncertain new element to the international dispute over young Elian Gonzalez, the Cuban boy's grandmothers flew to New York on Friday to make a public appeal on U.S. soil for his return.

title: Schools Too Grand To Turn Into Trash
description: Driven by a desire to prepare New York City's children for success in an economy built on computers and communication, some city leaders want to abandon or demolish existing public schools and replace them with state-of-the-art buildings. What they overlook is the beauty and value of hundreds of wonderful school buildings that are among the great glories of our city. New York doesn't have to savage this heritage to get technologically functional schools.

title: STARWOOD TO SELL SAN FRANCISCO HOTEL TO BLACKSTONE
description: Starwood Hotels and Resorts Worldwide Inc., the operator of the Sheraton and Westin Hotels, said a partnership it controlled will sell the Westin St. Francis hotel in San Francisco for $243 million. Westin St. Francis L.P. will sell the 1,192-room property to BRE/St. Francis L.L.C. BRE is a unit of Blackstone Group, a New York investment bank. Starwood will continue to manage the property. Starwood, based in White Plains, has said it will raise up to $500 million selling hotels this year. It plans to use that money to buy back some of its own stock.

Matt Gogel, a tour rookie, was in second place at 19 under par, while David Toms was tied with Duval for third place at 18 under par.

title: EQUITABLE LIFE LOSES APPEAL
description: The British insurer Equitable Life Assurance seemed vulnerable to predators after Britain's High Court ruled against it in a battle with policyholders protesting plans to pay reduced annuities -- a move inspired by falling interest rates. The case will now be heard by the House of Lords, the highest court in England and Wales. Analysts said uncertainty surrounding the future of Equitable Life, the world's oldest mutual insurance company, could provoke takeover moves by insurers and banks. Alan Cowell

title: Geoffrey E. Perry Dies at 72; Monitored Soviet Satellites

Perry, a British grammar school teacher who used rudimentary equipment to uncover secret details of the Soviet space program during the cold war and later became a trusted consultant to United States government agencies, died on Tuesday near his home in Bude, Cornwall. title: ORACLE TO SELL PART OF LIBERATE TECHNOLOGIES STAKE
description: The Oracle Corporation will sell almost 10 percent of its stake in Liberate Technologies Inc. as part of a larger stock offering. Liberate filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission for the sale of 8.5 million shares by the company and existing stockholders. Those selling shares through the offering include Oracle, Netscape, Comcast and Mitchell Kertzman, Liberate's chief executive. Liberate, based in San Carlos, Calif., is a provider of software for delivering Internet content to devices like television set-top boxes and game consoles. Liberate shares rose $19.50 each, to $106. The company held an initial public offering at $8 each, after adjusting for a split, in July.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROSENBERG, ALFRED A.
description: ROSENBERG-Alfred A. Passed away January 20 at age 84, after a spirited 12-year fight against illness. Loving and devoted husband and partner of Judy R. Rosenberg. Confidant, mentor and pal to numerous nieces, nephews, grandnieces, grandnephews and cousins. Brother of Lillian Sherman, Joseph Rosenberg, and the late Sylvia Ginsberg, Simon and Louis Rosenberg. True friend to many, both within and outside his beloved practice of law, which was centered on creditors' rights and Federal Bankruptcy Court in Brooklyn. He inspired all with his intelligence, sensitivity and courage. As humanitarians and philanthropists, he and Judy have been lifelong supporters of medical research, the performing arts, and education, especially in the establishment of scholarship funds. Contributions may be made to Albert Einstein College of Medicine of Yeshiva University, Jack and Pearl Resnick Campus, Room B803, Center for Genetic and Translational Medicine, 1300 Morris Park Avenue, Bronx, NY 10461. title: MICHAEL FOODS STOCK FALLS AS POSSIBLE SALE IS RULED OUT

Michael Foods hired U.S. Bancorp Piper Jaffray and Merrill Lynch & Company in August to review options, including a possible sale of the company. The company, which had $1.02 billion in 1998 revenue, produces eggs, milk, cheese, and bagels for grocery stores and food-service customers.

title: Books in Brief: Nonfiction; An Immensity of Greatness
description: America is great. It may even be the greatest. But just what is it that makes it so great? With the help of a bevy of writers, including David Halberstam, Christopher Buckley and John Updike, Robert A. Wilson, who has produced documentaries for public television, and Stanley Marcus, chairman emeritus of Neiman Marcus, have assembled dozens of short essays and a host of wonderful photographs, paintings and drawings -- more than 250 of them -- pinpointing exactly what it is that has and does make America great. The results are somewhat uneven. AMERICAN GREATS (Public Affairs, $50) is at its best when it uncovers somewhat obscure, unexpected treasures -- like Charles F. Kettering, who invented the self-starter, which changed the face of automobiles forever; the invention of ''the devil's hatband,'' otherwise known as barbed wire; Keeneland, in Lexington, Ky., where the best of the best racehorses are trained (the reader gets a useful betting tip: when unsure of what horse to put your money on, choose the one that's been trained in Keeneland); The Chicago Defender, a black newspaper, established by Robert Abbott, which aided and abetted the migration of blacks from the South to the North; and the Mohawk Indians who work the high beams on skyscrapers and bridges, staring acrophobia in the eye without blinking. Some choices are interesting simply because the subject matter is so absorbing: Thomas Edison, ''Huckleberry Finn,'' The New Yorker, the Iditarod, Coney Island and the Corvette. Others are so obvious that they elicit little more than a ho-hum, like ticker tape parades, black baseball and Thomas Paine. Of course, as the editors say, everyone will have a personal list of greats, which will simply open up welcome debates across this great nation. I wonder about the glaring omission of fast food from this list, in particular Ray Kroc and his brainchild, McDonald's. But restaurants are represented, in a charming essay by Ruth Reichl on the restaurant Chez Panisse. Charles Salzberg

title: Crime

Like Frank Sheffield, an F.B.I. field agent in Miami who is drawn into an elaborate operation to catch the killer of a United States senator's daughter, his alpha males are attractive loners: reflective, emotionally wary and too intense for the ''breezy beach bum'' persona they project. His women tend to be less romantic. Like Hannah Keller, a successful crime novelist whose parents were victims of the same killer and who is being set up by the F.B.I. as bait, they bristle with intelligence and some sort of nascent or full-blown neurosis. Hall's villains, however, take the cake. Monsters all, they are cruel in the perversely creative way of homicidal artists.

title: The Contest in Iowa and Beyond

It is always worth noting that Iowa and New Hampshire, which votes in 10 days, are rural, conservative and largely white states with an exaggerated role in the nomination process. But both states have lively political cultures, and their voters have shown themselves to be attentive listeners with good questions for the candidates. As a result, Gov. George W. title: A Fantasy on Foot
description: I HAD never been dressed this outlandishly in my life. Fitted over my shoulders was a triangular breastplate, with leafy designs in green and gold glitter. It had a four-foot shoulder span, curving behind me, with streamers of lace and green iridescent plastic, like a fusion of a Ming the Merciless cape and a shower curtain. I wore green and gold leaf-design wristlets and anklets, and a triangular quasi-loincloth tied at the sides over a green bikini bottom. On my feet were flip-flops with more green-and-gold leaves. Oh, and I was carrying a headdress that radiated yardlong imitation palm fronds. I could have been the Jolly Green Giant's sidekick. But as I struggled through a crowd, no one gave me a second glance.

title: Books in Brief: Fiction; Impersonating Themselves
description: The idiosyncratic survivors and self-inventors who populate the eight stories in Lynne Barrett's new collection, THE SECRET NAMES OF WOMEN (Carnegie Mellon University, paper, $15.95), speak a sassy American demotic tinged by a loopy melancholia: ''I kicked Tommy Falcon out at the end of May '91. Tommy had never formally moved in, but was sleeping over most nights and accumulating stuff and just getting more and more comfortable, which was courtship as I knew it.'' All but one of these stories feature offbeat female protagonists facing some juncture or transition -- mourning a love affair's end, marrying an Estonian to get him a green card, facing an unplanned pregnancy. Barrett focuses on the pathos and dignity of the underdetermined life: the late-20th-century life shaped by improvisation, bad or good luck and the seemingly random impulses of the heart. When her characters rename themselves, they do so less to assert identity than to clean the slate, all the while making clear that the slate is already a well-worn, much-marked surface. A few stories work up striking conceits: in ''Hush Money,'' a ''gardener to the stars'' in Hollywood befriends a lonely recluse who was Marilyn Monroe's friend back when Monroe was Norma Jean and new to town. In ''Elvis Lives,'' Barrett chronicles the predicament of three addled Elvis impersonators under the thumb of a latter-day Colonel Parker. Although Barrett occasionally stretches her form to accommodate a more complex narrative structure, this collection has a certain sameness of tone and stance -- a wry, lucid optimism. Her truest allegiances and richest writing emerge in those stories with musician-heroines (''Meet the Impersonators!'' and ''The Former Star Carlson''): their slightly bruised openness to experience and their straightforward commitment to their art mirror Barrett's own. Maureen McLane

Velvet paintings may be the Rodney Dangerfield of the art world, but Leeteg, who died in 1953, was known as the American Gauguin. His work was displayed on menus, matchbooks and the walls of Polynesian restaurants. In the introduction, the Hawaiian music king Martin Denny recalls his days at Don the Beachcomber restaurant in Honolulu: ''Six nights a week, I faced a Leeteg velvet of a bare-breasted Polynesian beauty on the wall behind the bar. Jim was a man of principle who refused to use the words ''live'' or ''team coverage'' to hype a broadcast. He challenged reporters with an unrehearsed, sharp question when he thought something was left unclear in their stories. He was a voracious learner, a nonintrusive interviewer and a mesmerizing storyteller.

She has created six traveling exhibits showcasing the achievements of African-Americans in different fields, educating herself about inventors, scientists, and leaders, some of whose contributions have been unnoted. Mrs. Sanders recently spoke about her work and the need to remember these men and women.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEFFERTS, KATE CARTERET
description: LEFFERTS-Kate Carteret. Of St. James, NY. Died at Gladwyne, PA, on January 18, 2000. Aged 88. She graduated from Bryn Mawr College and earned an MFA from NYU. Following service with OSS during World War II, she became an art conservator at the Metropolitan Museum, where she rose to head the department. In 1972 she co-published a paper reauthenticating a classical Greek bronze horse. As an adjunct professor at Columbia University, she taught techniques of art restoration, exploring the uses of radioactivity in the examination of paintings. An avid lifelong traveler, she served as US delegate to international conferences for the Council of Museums Conservation Committee. Upon her retirement she became trustee and mayor of Head-of-the-Harbor, LI, for 10 years before moving to Waverly Heights in Pennsylvania. Devoted sister to Lysbet Lefferts Bartlett, and the late Isabella Lefferts Edwards. Beloved mentor and friend to her nieces and nephew: Phyllis Bartlett, Sarah B. Jones, Isabella E. Martin, and Oliver Edwards, seven great-nieces and nephews, one great-great-nephew. Memorial service Saturday, February 5, at 2 PM, St. James Episcopal Church, St. James, NY. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to Bryn Mawr College, 101 N. Merion Ave., Bryn Mawr, PA, or St. James Episcopal Church, 490 N. Country Rd., St. James, NY.

title: Two Wheels, Many Miles
description: To many people, bicycles are basically toys, vehicles ridden for fun and often left to rust or tossed out when the fun is past. But for much of the world, they are essential tools of transportation, used to get people to and from work, to get medical help out to the needy, and even to serve as farm machinery. An organization called Pedals for Progress, with headquarters in High Bridge, collects used bikes -- 32,227 as of the end of last year -- and sends them to developing countries, where they are refurbished and distributed. To bring attention to the organization and its beneficiaries, a photographer from Cherry Hill, Eric Schenk, last week began a yearlong 15,500-mile bike trip through 15 countries in Central and South America, Africa and Oceania, ending in Washington. He is already posting dispatches and photos at a Web site, www.wt200.com. Bike collections begin again in April. To find out where and when, contact Pedals for Progress at (908) 638-4811 or at its Web site, www.p4p.org

Pi, the ratio of the circumference of a circle to its diameter, is approximately 3.14159265, but the sequence of numbers beyond the decimal point is believed to be infinite.

It will have a separate entrance and admission price from the theme and safari parks already at the site, though combination tickets will be available. At the beginning of 1999, he was certain to stroll to the Democratic nomination. Who would have predicted that, before the year was out, he would change campaign managers and chiefs of staff, replace his pollsters and his admen, truck his headquarters from Washington to Nashville and begin the year 2000 worried he would have less cash on hand after the New Hampshire primary than Bill Bradley, the challenger he once dismissed? Though born and bred for higher office and schooled by Bill Clinton for seven years in the getting and holding of the presidency, Gore was unprepared to run for the job to a degree baffling to some of his advisers. This past year -- particularly the past four months -- has provided a bracing political education for a man who had no clue how much he needed it.

title: The New American Gold Standard
description: WHEN it comes to their money, Americans hate -- pardon the pun -- change. The United States Mint is well aware of this, and is spending some $45 million to assure public acceptance of the ''golden dollar,'' a new gold-colored coin that replaces the Susan B. Anthony silver dollar this month. The Mint expects, among other things, to circulate 100 million golden dollars through 4,000 Wal-Mart outlets and even slip them into 5,000 boxes of Cheerios. The new coin, carrying the image of Sacagawea, Lewis and Clark's Indian guide, is needed because stockpiles of Susan B. Anthonys are almost gone, and because nobody seemed to like them in the first place (they were easily mistaken for quarters). So the Treasury Department took a new approach -- a coin whose color and smooth edge should be appealing and easily distinguishable from its numismatic brethren.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FENTON, ALAN D.
description: FENTON-Alan D. Died of natural causes, January 1, 2000, in Cleveland at the age of 72. Alan Fenton was an abstract painter in the ''New York School'' tradition of artists, and long time NYC resident and real estate innovator. Fenton's quiet and contemplative nonobjective paintings and drawings were widely recognized for their demanding yet understated means of revealing a serious and sober essence. He identified greatly with Mark Rothko, a friend, as well as Adolph Gottlieb and Jack Tworkov, with whom he had studied privately. Fenton painted in NYC in the late 50's as the explosion of Abstract Expressionism turned into a rebellion against gestural, emotional painting. More concerned about his art than his posture, expanded upon a tradition in painting with influences as diverse as Whistler and Turner as well as Ad Reinhardt and Joseph Albers. Alan Fenton was born in Cleveland in 1927, studied at the Cleveland School of Art, The Arts Students League, The New School, and at NYU, earning his BFA at Pratt Institute, where he later taught painting for many years. At seventeen, Fenton served in the Merchant Marines where he began a career as a professional boxer, a skill he had honed on the streets. He moved successfully through the graphic design business en route to becoming a painter in NY at the height of the art revolution of the fifties and sixties. He moved to NY in 1955 with his wife, Naomi Feigenbaum. She died in 1995. Fenton enjoyed success with his subtle washes and pencil drawings as well as large abstract canvases in acrylic, landing one-man shows at the prestigious Pace Gallery in NY, The NY Cultural Center Museum, The Barbara Fielder Gallery in Washington, et al. In his introduction to Fenton's exhibition catalogue for his one-man show at the Phillips Collection in Washington, Vincent Melzac wrote, ''Fenton is his own man, producing work that is uniquely his...in his work one feels that Fenton is testing the accepted and pushing for a newer and richer visual experience.'' Fenton's work resides at The Hirschhorn Museum of Art, The Corcoran Gallery, The Cleveland Museum of Art, The Smithsonian, and countless others as well as in private collections. In the late 60's he turned his artistic vision and NY business savvy towards developing creative environments where ''good and beautiful people'' could live and work together. His first endeavor was to turn the Tiffany Glass Building on lower Park Avenue into an artistic community where notable photographers, painters, and filmmakers moved in, setting the stage for a modern, hip, yet warm and friendly working space for the community which he had nurtured. He later developed the first live/work loft in Cleveland, where Fenton resided during his last years. Fenton is survived by his daughter Danielle, son-in-law Bill Garrity, their two children Adam and Gabriel, and his son David, all of NYC. He leaves behind a brother, Calvin Freedman of Tarzanna, California, and a sister, Marilyn Gelman of Boca Raton, Florida. Fenton had said about his own work, ''All that happens in my work is natural and human, hard and soft, large and small, heaven and earth. All this with the image of man, (my glow) forms a system to attain the sublime. All of these paradoxes form a triad that is the way of everything. The line is the 'hard', the formless form and the imageless image is the 'soft'. They are inseparable, one cannot exist without the other.''

title: A Raider Follows A Champagne Dream
description: Asher Edelman, the American corporate raider who turned to Europe during the 1990's, says his long pursuit of the family-run company that controls Taittinger Champagne, Baccarat crystal and 70 fancy hotels including the Crillon in Paris is about to take a critical turn, probably in his direction. On Feb. 1, he said, a French court will hear him present his challenge to the management of Anne-Claire Taittinger, chairman of the Societe du Louvre, and her family. For what amounts to a mini-LVMH, he has bid $700 million, having already accumulated about a 17 percent stake. While driving from his Geneva office to Gstaad for the weekend, he called himself an active investor but, please, not a hostile one. ''My intentions are to get control,'' he said. ''Stay tuned.''

title: Otis Regrets
description: In Otis Chandler's office there are pictures of his immediate family, pictures of the sea, pictures of faraway places. But there is not a single picture of Otis Chandler shaking hands with a major news figure or standing beside one of his famous reporters or anything that bears the Los Angeles Times logo, except for that day's paper spread across his conference-room table. ''I do look back on my life for certain lessons that I have learned,'' said the man who was publisher of that paper for 20 years, from 1960 to 1980, ''and I do look back with great appreciation for the kind of life I've led, which has been fascinating. But I tend to live in the moment and look forward to the future. So I don't sit in an office surrounded by Los Angeles Times photos and memorabilia and Pulitzer Prizes. No, I don't.''

title: Film; When Soccer Doesn't Stand in the Way of Nirvana

The walls are scrawled with soccer slogans; during morning meditation, monks pass notes about France and Brazil.

title: Bookend; Falling Out With Superman
description: I STUMBLED upon Friedrich Nietzsche when I was 17, following the usual trail of existential candies -- Camus, Sartre, Beckett -- that unsuspecting teenagers find in the woods. The effect was more like a drug than a philosophy. I was whirled upward -- or was it downward? -- into a one-man universe, a secret cult demanding that you put a gun to the head of your dearest habits and beliefs. That intoxicating whiff of half-conscious madness; that casually hair-raising evisceration of everything moral, responsible and parentally approved -- these waves overwhelmed my adolescent dinghy. And even more than by his ideas -- many of which I didn't understand at all, but some of which I perhaps grasped better then than I do now -- I was seduced by his prose. At the end of his sentences you could hear an electric crack, like the whip of a steel blade being tested in the air. He might have been the Devil, but he had better lines than God.

title: Electing A Co-op's Board

Those tenants' unsold shares were purchased about six years ago by a group of investors. The investors somehow automatically get two of the seven seats on the board, leaving five seats up for election every year. But in addition to the two automatic seats, they also get to vote their shares every year to elect the five other board members. Is this proper? Are there any state laws governing this kind of arrangement or is this something the co-op bylaws can legally allow? . . . Norm Magnusson, Manhattan.

''Our idea was to present classical concerts in an at-home, living room atmosphere,'' Ms. Balint said. ''The hall at the Bronxville Women's Club, with its near perfect acoustics, lends the feeling of being a guest in a home. With a preconcert lecture to give familiarity to what is coming up and a lavish, festive reception following the music, the series offers complete evenings of friendship, music and food.''

In ''The Mullet: Hairstyle of the Gods'' (Bloomsbury Publishing, $14.95), Mark Larson and Barney Hoskyns suggest it may be both. title: Gogol a Go-Go
description: Upon returning to Moscow recently from a stay in a Buddhist monastery in South Korea, the Russian novelist Victor Pelevin received a surprise phone call from an Orthodox priest. Why, the patriarch demanded to know, had Pelevin -- unlike the great Alexander Solzhenitsyn, or the even greater Leo Tolstoy -- neglected his Christianity? ''I told him I hadn't neglected my Christianity,'' Pelevin says. ''I grew up in an atheist country! He was unconvinced. He said that because I was popular with the young, I had a responsibility to set a good example. I was polite to the old man, but his expectations of me were ridiculous. I'm a writer. I have a responsibility to no one.''

In ''Home on the Road: The Motor Home in America'' (Smithsonian Institution Press, $24.95), Roger B. White, a land transportation historian, recounts the evolution of these mobile dwellings and explains their allure as an irresistible ''combination of wanderlust and family togetherness.'' The author takes a pop culture approach, including the psychedelic buses of the 60's like Ken Kesey's poetically named Furthur and Wavy Gravy's Road Hog. Eight years ago, the author writes, Winnebago Industries rolled out its 250,000th motor home, so even in a no passing zone, this is no passing fancy. description: After hitting a spectator on the head with an errant tee shot on the 15th hole today, Jesper Parnevik was shaken. His concern eased, however, when the fan was not seriously injured and displayed a sense of humor.

title: Restraint, Subtleties and Bells for a Celestial Vision
description: Does Rachmaninoff still need rehabilitation? Although long scorned in more reclusive quarters as an anachronism, a benighted holdover from 19th-century Romanticism, he always retained popularity in corners of the repertory, specifically those involving the piano. And in recent decades, as the compositional climate again became safe for Romanticism, he was finally welcomed into the company of 20th-century masters.

title: 'American Beauty' Wins 3 Golden Globe Awards
description: Box-office giants mixed with independent-film newcomers at the 57th annual Golden Globe Awards tonight at the drizzle-drenched Beverly Hilton Hotel, with established stars like Jim Carrey, Tom Cruise and Denzel Washington joining relative movie newcomers like Hilary Swank, Janet McTeer and Angelina Jolie among the winners.

title: Jean MacArthur, General's Widow, Dies at 101
description: Jean MacArthur, the widow of Gen. Douglas MacArthur, who remained at her husband's side through the darkest days of World War II and was often introduced by him as ''my finest soldier,'' died on Saturday at Lenox Hill Hospital in Manhattan. She was 101.

title: Market Place; DOW VS. NASDAQ: As technology stocks outperform again, it's the smaller players that are doing the heavy lifting.
description: THESE are blue days for blue chip owners, but they're great days if your money is in small technology stocks.

title: Bradley Heads to Campus
description: Former Senator Bill Bradley spent the final day before the Iowa caucuses at three college campuses, trying to energize the students and professors he hopes will help power his insurgent candidacy.

title: E-Commerce Report; A mad dash to create electronic marketplaces for business-to-business transactions.
description: THE news barely registered on the radar of Internet industry analysts and executives: The Uniform Code Council, the nonprofit organization that created the bar code system, recently said it had chosen AppNet, an Internet consulting company, to build what it called ''the largest electronic marketplace for business-to-business transactions.''

title: ACCOUNTS
description: * Carclub.com, San Francisco, an online company that offers members services related to buying, selling, insuring, financing and maintaining automobiles, to Goldberg Moser O'Neill, San Francisco, part of the Lowe Group unit of the Interpublic Group, as the first agency to handle its account. Billings were estimated at $15 million to $20 million.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article on Friday about a Taiwan presidential candidate gave the date of the election inconsistently in some copies. It is March 18, not next month.

title: 3 Marketers Award Accounts
description: Three companies have made decisions about their accounts.

description: INTERNATIONAL A3-10

description: To the Editor:

title: Forbes Focuses on Abortion
description: Virtually assured of coming in second, Steve Forbes continued today to push hard on his anti-abortion views and accused Gov. George W. Bush of attacking him with negative phone calls and advertisements.

title: Internet Monopolies?
description: To the Editor:

title: That's Show Biz, and Academia
description: Here in the city where ''entertainment'' means everything from a televised freeway chase to a multimillion-dollar movie, the University of Southern California is embarking on an ambitious interdisciplinary effort to study entertainment as a defining concept of 21st-century life, in fields from law to architecture, from business to journalism, with the dual goal of prompting intellectual debate and training the next generation of media moguls.

description: To the Editor:

title: Guarding the President's Words and, Maybe, His Legacy
description: J. TERRY EDMONDS is the keeper of the disk.
