description: To the Editor:

title: The 'Malcolm' Sensibility; New Sitcom's Early Success May Spawn Host of Imitators
description: Only a few months ago, the situation comedy was a fading genre on television. Television executives groaned about low ratings, derivative shows, lazy comedy writing, the rise of hipper cable-channel programs and the same old tired format set in an apartment or workplace.

title: Taking a Chance on Times Square
description: The long line that snaked down 43rd Street from Broadway to Eighth Avenue and the screaming fans who rushed to get inside were reminiscent of the days when Frank Sinatra played the old Paramount Theater in Times Square.

title: My Virtual Library
description: The recent coronation of Jeff Bezos, founder of Amazon.com, as Time magazine's ''Man of the Year'' gave doomsayers a new opportunity to predict that ''bricks and mortar'' bookstores would soon be washed away in a foamy sea of latte.

title: Miscellany
description: * True North Communications, Chicago, acquired a 49 percent stake in the Imada Wong Communications Group, an agency specializing in marketing to Asian-American consumers. Wong, which had a nonequity affiliation with True North, will operate as part of the New America Strategies Group, a subsidiary of True North Diversified Cos.

title: Master Vermeer, Isn't It, Um, Missing a Little Spark?
description: GIRL WITH A PEARL EARRING

title: President Of Israel Faces Accusations With Defiance
description: Striking a note of somber defiance, President Ezer Weizman of Israel tonight refused either to resign or to step down temporarily while the police pursue a criminal investigation of his receipt of hundreds of thousands of dollars from a French businessman and political supporter.

title: Time Warner To Acquire Control Of EMI Music
description: Time Warner Inc. plans to acquire control of the music business of the EMI Group and merge it with Warner Music, creating what could become the world's largest record company, officials close to the negotiations said yesterday.

title: McCall Gingerly Lays Foundation for 2002 Governor's Race
description: H. Carl McCall has a reputation as a most cautious politician. So as he contemplates the most incautious of acts, challenging a popular incumbent governor, he is going about it in the most cautious way -- starting almost three years before the election.

title: Minnesota-Duluth Wins in Lake Placid
description: Minnesota-Duluth, which has a wealth of talent, relied on a recent addition to claim the High Peaks women's hockey tournament championship yesterday in Lake Placid, N.Y.

title: A Bad Day at the Office Drives the Jaguars Out of the Playoffs
description: Jacksonville quarterback Mark Brunell was asked to pinpoint the moment it all started to slip away, the play that irrevocably turned the tide in today's American Football Conference championship game and swept the Jaguars out of the playoffs.

title: To Share Jerusalem? To Touch a Nerve!
description: To the Editor:

title: People
description: * James A. Warner was named president at iballs, New York, part of Avenue A, an Internet media planning, buying and performance tracking agency. He succeeds Michael Cohen, who will become a consultant to the company. Mr. Warner had run Third Floor Enterprises, Larchmont, N.Y., an Internet consulting company; before that, he held top posts at CBS.

title: 3 Copyright Lawsuits Test Limits of New Digital Media
description: A flurry of court activities last week revealed a growing conflict between the entertainment industry, which is struggling to protect its products and profits in the Internet age, and consumer groups, which accuse the industry of interfering with free speech and people's rights to control their watching or listening experience.

title: Turning 1960's Innocence Into 90's Toughness
description: Wesla Whitfield

title: Big Board Reports a Slip In Uncovered Short Sales
description: Open positions of short sales on the New York Stock Exchange slipped seven-tenths of 1 percent in the most recent monthly period, the exchange reported on Friday.

title: Burmese Rebels Seize Hostages in Thailand
description: About 10 armed rebels from a Burmese insurgent group called God's Army crossed the border into Thailand this morning and seized a local hospital, taking as many as 200 people hostage and demanding medical care for their wounded, officials said.

title: Racist Hatred in America's Past Stirs Emotions at Exhibition
description: Thay Bowser of the Upper West Side remembers being a little girl in Pickens, S.C., when a black man was lynched some 30 miles away. ''My mother was told to keep her children in, her boys in, because there might be problems,'' she said.

title: Subways Trade No. 2 Pencils For 21st-Century Technology
description: It was a joke that got big laughs around New York City Transit as the end of last year approached: The subways were fully Y2K compliant.

title: Some advertisers are concluding that passing is the best strategy for Super Bowl Sunday.
description: The hoopla and hyperbole surrounding the costly commercials that will run on Sunday during Super Bowl XXXIV has been intensified by the dozen or more dot-coms scheduled to appear for the first time. And the noise is generating a bit of a backlash centered on ''anti-advertising'': promotions, public-relations campaigns, sweepstakes and other efforts off the gridiron to reach consumers.

title: Playing Free and Fancy With a Moody Sonata
description: Janine Jansen, violinist

title: A Million Protesters in Spain Denounce Terrorism's Return
description: A million people marched here today in a protest against the Basque separatist group E.T.A., government officials said, two days after the government blamed the rebels for a bombing that killed an army officer and appeared to reignite separatist violence after a lull of 18 months.

title: Autobytel Plans to Sell Cars Directly Over the Internet
description: Autobytel.com, the Internet car-buying service, plans to announce on Monday that it will act as a car broker by selling cars directly over the Internet.

title: Both Parties Seek Ways to Tame Fast and Furious Primary Process
description: Even before the voting begins in this year's primaries and caucuses, Republican and Democratic Party officials are exploring ways to change a presidential nominating system that critics say has become too chaotic, too fast for informed decision making and even, in some fundamental ways, undemocratic.

title: Patriots Looking to Capers
description: The Jets and the New England Patriots have not been able to agree on compensation to free Bill Belichick from his Jets contract, and now the Patriots have asked to interview Dom Capers of the Jacksonville Jaguars for their head coaching position.

title: U.S. Health Officials Reject Plan to Report Medical Mistakes
description: Federal health officials say they are unwilling at this time to embrace the National Academy of Sciences' recent call for a new federal law requiring hospitals to report all mistakes that cause serious injury or death to patients.

title: Helping the Disabled Travel for Fun
description: Before standing and leaving the van she rides in, Linda Freedman needs to get her bearings. She clutches the seat in front of her, and if a helping hand is extended, she takes it, too.

title: Designer Bets on Brainpower Over Battery Power
description: David Ditzel must have secrecy in his genes.

title: An Accord on Child Soldiers
description: From Colombia and Chechnya to Congo and Sierra Leone, some 300,000 child soldiers -- some as young as 10 -- are killing, raping and maiming in today's conflict zones. Press-ganged or lured by the promise of booty or revenge, many of them orphans, some not much taller than their automatic rifles, children are among the most readily brutalized participants in modern warfare.

title: Japan Sect's Name Change Brings Confusion and Fear
description: By changing its name and denouncing its spiritual leader last week, the religious sect that killed 12 people in a nerve gas attack in the Tokyo subways in 1995 tried to convince Japanese society that it was no longer a threat.

title: Treasury to Auction Bills This Week
description: The Treasury's schedule of financings this week is confined to today's regular weekly auction of three- and six-month bills and a two-year note auctioned on Wednesday.

title: PRO FOOTBALL: One More Sunday for Tennessee and St. Louis; Titans Have the Jaguars' Number: XXXIV
description: With two minutes left and ahead by 19 points, the Tennessee Titans paced their sideline and offered mild and measured congratulations among themselves. The Titans, though, looked worried. They wondered if this three-peat against the Jacksonville Jaguars was really complete, if their apparent spot in Super Bowl XXXIV would somehow vanish in an odd twist of surprise.

title: This Week
description: EVENTS

title: Football Team Has Nashville Singing Ballad of the Titans
description: As the final minutes of today's American Football Conference playoff game ticked away, the more than 2,200 Tennessee Titans fans who had gathered downtown to watch the matchup on the huge television screen at the Wildhorse Saloon began to chant, almost in disbelief, ''Su-PER Bowl, Su-PER Bowl.''

title: Media; Time and Fortune play catch up -- ever so carefully -- on the AOL-Time Warner deal.
description: IT was around cocktail hour on the Sunday night before Time Warner and America Online announced the big deal that Norman Pearlstine, the editor in chief of Time Inc., heard the news.

title: Jack Segal, 98, a Talent Agent Representing the Colorful Fringe
description: Jack Segal, a talent agent known for booking prodigious numbers of singers and comedians at hotels in the Catskills and the personal manager for a menagerie of eccentric and largely uncelebrated performers, died on Jan. 12 in Livingston, N.J. He was 98 and lived in West Orange, N.J.

title: Lead Doesn't Slow Gore
description: With a new poll showing his lead growing over former Senator Bill Bradley, Vice President Al Gore today went after another opponent -- complacency.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Autobytel to Sells Cars Directly Over Internet

title: Precious Rooms, Even Where Rent Is Low; For Apartment Hunters on a Budget, a Tough Task Is Even Tougher
description: Nobody could accuse Martha Arroyo, a 22-year-old store clerk and mother from the Bronx, of being too picky in hunting for an apartment.

title: Bronx Man Is Accused of Running a Videocassette Counterfeiting Operation
description: A Bronx man was arrested Saturday night and accused of running a videocassette counterfeiting factory, the police said yesterday.

title: Microsoft Makes Another Interactive TV Investment
description: In another step toward extending its reach from the personal computer to the television set, the Microsoft Corporation will invest $56 million in Intertainer Inc., a privately held company that provides a video-on-demand service, Microsoft executives said.

title: Failing to Find Rhythm, Serena Williams Ousted
description: The surface was still green, hard and quick. The lines were still white. But the tennis that Serena Williams produced in this Grand Slam event bore little resemblance to the tennis she produced on her way to the title at Flushing Meadows in September.

title: Moderation in All Things, Especially Country
description: ''Boy, y'all are lively here tonight,'' said Alan Jackson to the whooping crowd at Irving Plaza on Wednesday. The Manhattan club is hardly a sawdust-floor honky-tonk, but it is a long way from coliseums and Las Vegas showrooms this 42-year-old country star normally fills. His self-deprecating comments to the thrilled audience seemed genuine. But it was also part of a mystique that has allowed Mr. Jackson to keep topping the country charts.

title: Troops in Grozny Measure Their Gains in Yards
description: Today's flag-raising ceremony in northwest Grozny was supposed to be a made-for-television event that would illustrate the progress Russian forces have made in taking back the tattered ruins that are the Chechen capital.

title: Many Reformers Ruled Off Iran Ballot
description: With less than four weeks remaining before Iran's 38 million voters elect a new Parliament, the conservative Muslim clerics who have held the country in a rigid political grip since 1979 have moved to shore up their power by excluding scores of reformist candidates from the ballot on the grounds that they are insufficiently ''Islamic.''

title: Spurs Turned Up Heat And Knicks Lost Cool
description: Jeff Van Gundy had watched his team's composure disintegrate on impact against another elite team when he decided to do as the Knicks had done all night and vent.

title: Will Kohl Name Names? No, Report Is a Hoax
description: The scandal surrounding secret payments to Germany's Christian Democratic Union took a bizarre turn today with a hoax in which a statement was falsely issued in the name of former Chancellor Helmut Kohl saying he would reveal the names of the donors who gave him more than $1 million.

title: Fixing the Tax Code
description: To the Editor:

title: PRO FOOTBALL: One More Sunday for Tennessee and St. Louis; Rams Have Enough To Squeak Past Bucs
description: This is what can happen when a team gets a little too smug. Kurt Warner, the league's most valuable player? Three interceptions. Isaac Bruce, the wide receiver who basically said the Tampa Bay secondary could not cover his grandmother? Just three catches. Dick Vermeil, the coach who bragged that his offense had no weaknesses? Stumped.

title: City Investigates Program, Citing Disproportionate Granting of Day Care Benefits
description: The city's Department of Investigation is examining a city subsidy program that has awarded a disproportionate share of day care benefits to Orthodox Jews in Brooklyn, officials said yesterday.

title: Media Talk; Newsweek Drops an Excerpt of Gore Book
description: An excerpt from a new biography of Al Gore was scheduled to run in Newsweek in the issue dated Jan. 24, which arrived on newsstands last week. But as the presidential primaries neared, the day before closing the issue, Newsweek editors pulled the excerpt, which featured new allegations of marijuana use by Mr. Gore two and a half decades ago.

title: Dividend Meetings
description: MONDAY

title: Despite U.S. Heat on Belgrade, Radio Services Cut Broadcasts
description: While the Clinton administration intensifies its efforts to oust President Slobodan Milosevic of Yugoslavia through increased support for the Serbian opposition and independent media, both Radio Free Europe and the Voice of America have recently curtailed their Serbian-language transmissions.

title: Leaders and Laggers Alike Make Final Pleas to Iowans
description: After months of clashing at debates and through commercials, candidates for president today finally delivered a common message: They implored Iowans to vote in the precinct caucuses on Monday.

title: 500,000 Homes Left Dark By Ice Storm in Southeast
description: A sluggish winter storm dripped a crippling coating of ice on much of the Southeast today, cracking thousands of drooping pine trees and cutting off electric power to more than 500,000 households, mostly in Atlanta.

title: The Bell Rings but the Students Stay, and Stay
description: The revolution begins at 3 p.m.

title: Exposing the Meanings Hiding in Gymnastics
description: Yung Wook Yoo, pianist

title: Talks on Big Merger Continue
description: Discussions by executives at Procter & Gamble and the drug makers Warner-Lambert and American Home Products continued over the weekend as Procter & Gamble explores whether to buy one or both drug companies in a deal that would create one of the largest consumer products and pharmaceutical companies in the world.

title: One Last Year at 1600
description: As he commented on the end of his seventh year in office last week, President Clinton professed to be ''feeling good and grateful'' about his time in the White House, and he spoke about his eagerness ''to milk every last moment of every day.'' For all that, 1600 Pennsylvania Avenue seems to radiate an aura of isolation and missed opportunities these days. Presidential friends speak of his ''lonely voice'' on the telephone. Mr. Clinton's two closest political associates -- Vice President Al Gore and Hillary Rodham Clinton -- do not want him hovering as they launch their new careers. The image of a home-alone presidency was reinforced when Mr. Clinton was asked if he felt mournful about starting his final year in the White House. ''When I go in a room in the White House now I look around more carefully to make sure . . . that I've actually noticed something that I may not have seen.'' He added, ''I wish I didn't have to sleep at all for a year.''

title: Metropolitan Diary
description: DEAR DIARY:

title: PALESTINIAN TALKS MAY MISS DEADLINE, ISRAELI AIDE SAYS
description: Israel and the Palestinians will intensify their peace negotiations during the next few weeks, but it is growing increasingly unlikely that they will reach a framework agreement by their goal of mid-February, Israel's senior negotiator said today.

title: 'Harry and Louise'
description: To the Editor:

title: Merging Mind and Body To Let Stories Unfold
description: The pleasures of literate dance and solid craft are not much attended to these days. Pascal Rioult made a strong case for both, however, in the dances he presented on Friday night at the Joyce Theater in the Altogether Different festival. Mr. Rioult's new ''Home Front,'' set to Ravel's ''Tombeau de Couperin,'' is not only thoughtful and well made, but a joyous hymn to order.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''I heard an explosion, and then I ran. This huge branch fell right where I was standing.''

title: Republicans Court Core Bloc, in an Evening With Social Conservatives
description: The pale, slight 14-year-old in a severe black suit stood before a crowd of more than 1,000 at the Family, Faith and Freedom rally on Saturday night while her mother gave a graphic account of how, ''under the influence of pornographic videos,'' the girl's father had sexually abused her ''on her very first birthday.''

title: Our Fear of Death
description: To the Editor:

title: Bucs Grounded By a Replay Call Voiding a Catch
description: With 40 seconds left in today's National Football Conference championship game, Tampa Bay wide receiver Bert Emanuel appeared to make a 12-yard reception that would have brought the Buccaneers, who trailed by 5 points, to the St. Louis 23-yard line.

title: Big East Is Ideal Crucible to Mold Champion
description: Why not another national basketball champion from the Big East? Why not two teams representing the conference on Final Four weekend in Indianapolis? Halfway through this strange college basketball season, neither one is a fanciful notion.

title: Physicality And Polish Imported From Europe
description: Hans van Manen is a choreographer of international repute, Mauro Bigonzetti and Uwe Scholz less so. Yet all are experienced dance makers in Europe, and it is with their works, all New York premieres presented on Friday, that the Stuttgart Ballet should have opened its brief run at City Center.

title: Talks on Biotech Food Today in Montreal Will See U.S. Isolated
description: Nearly a year after the United States blocked a proposed global treaty to regulate trade in genetically modified products, delegates from more than 130 nations will resume negotiations today in Montreal in search of a breakthrough. After months of international protest and concern about bioengineered food, Washington will be even more on the defensive.

title: New Role of Guard Transforming Military
description: Daniel L. Teafatiller, a rancher, sold all his cattle, except his two prize bulls, which he asked his son-in-law to look after while he is away. Patrick F. Martin, an account manager for Microsoft, is trying not to think about the six-figure stock bonus he will miss when he is gone. Ron De La Rosa, a lawyer with his own practice down by the courthouse here, is scrambling to try or settle as many cases as possible.

title: Media Talk; Ms. Is Ready to Give Ex-Globe Columnist Another Chance
description: If Mike Barnicle, the former Boston Globe columnist who admitted recycling stories he heard from others without checking if they were actually true, can get a job at a decent newspaper like The Daily News, why shouldn't Patricia Smith, his former colleague who admitted that she fabricated characters and quotes, get a nice respectable job, too?

title: Candidates Use Different Tacks In Stretch Run
description: Vice President Al Gore has representatives from organized labor working the phones and stuffing envelopes. Bill Bradley has turned to the Internet to try to reach voters. Gov. George W. Bush of Texas has tapped into his network of friends and supporters. And Steve Forbes wants to make sure everyone has a ride.

title: Editorial Observer; Courting Born-Again G.O.P. Voters in Iowa
description: Of all the Republican presidential hopefuls peddling their views in Iowa recently, Gary Bauer has been the most inventive in waging his war against abortion. First, he offered his campaign donors a chance to visit the McCaughey septuplets, whose parents support Mr. Bauer and his platform. Then, on Saturday, he staged a media event in a Des Moines cemetery where a local anti-abortion group had provided a burial site in 1994 for a discarded fetus.

title: Rome Journal; Cleaning Up a Capital and Noticing the Homeless
description: Termini, Rome's long-neglected central train station, now gleams like a temple of traveler comfort and consumer delights. After a 14-month renovation, there are polished floors, posh cafes, computerized ticket sales and even a glossy, well-lit underground shopping mall, patrolled by the police and private security guards who politely but firmly expel vagrants.

title: Of Medicine, Money and Wrinkles
description: To the Editor:

title: Carta Wins Again
description: Italy's Fabio Carta won the 3,000-meter title at the European short track championships in Bormio, Italy, yesterday, one day after winning the 500. Carta was timed in 4 minutes 50.37 seconds, beating Britain's Nicky Gooch.

title: Of Medicine, Money and Wrinkles
description: To the Editor:

title: Americans Defeat Brazilians To Win the Bermuda Bowl
description: The Orbis world championships, which ended on Friday in Bermuda, were a triumph for the local organizers headed by Sheena Rayner. Careful planning, plus a team of enthusiastic volunteers, ensured that every visitor had a memorable experience, topping all previous efforts.

title: Media Talk; DreamWorks Scrambles to Find Another Hit
description: It has been a rough television season for DreamWorks SKG. First came the cancellation of the studio's situation comedy ''It's Like, You Know.'' Then, last week, Michael J. Fox announced his departure from the studio's stalwart hit on ABC, ''Spin City,'' leaving the show with a shaky future.

title: Iowa Teetering Under the Weight of Cameras and Ink
description: Over coffee at the Waveland today, the NBC News anchor Tom Brokaw was telling a group of Iowans that by his calculation, if the reporters and editors covering the caucuses were voting in them, they would make up 1 percent of the electorate.

title: Craig Claiborne, 79, Times Food Editor And Critic, Is Dead
description: Craig Claiborne, who emerged from the Mississippi Delta to become the nation's pre-eminent food journalist and whose writings coaxed millions of meat-and-potato Americans to the table of fine cuisine, died on Saturday at St. Luke's-Roosevelt Hospital Center. He was 79 and lived in East Hampton, N.Y., and Manhattan.

title: Outsider Wins In Kitzbuhel
description: In only his third World Cup race, and starting 47th in the opening leg, the unheralded Mario Matt of Austria became the skier with the highest start number to win a World Cup slalom, capturing the event at Kitzbuhel, Austria. The previous high starting spot was No. 42, by Italy's Piero Gros in 1972.

title: Is There a Doctor in the House? Perhaps Too Many
description: As television learned early, there is inherent drama in medicine: the human body at war against alien invaders or even against itself, doctors marshaling the forces of modern science and technology to combat disease and save lives. But it's a drama that seldom transfers to the stage.

title: Patents; An inventor devises a new way for homeowners to turn the family car into the family snowplow.
description: SNOW fell on much of the Northeast last week, sending homeowners and merchants outside to clear off sidewalks and cars. Municipal plows took care of most town and city streets, but private residents once again were stuck shoveling the drifts with those bulky shovels. Anyone with a long driveway or large parking area surely dreads that cold, back-wrenching labor.

title: Stevens Is Arrested in Drug-Related Case
description: Kevin Stevens, a 34-year-old left wing who serves as an alternate captain of the Rangers, was arrested in Collinsville, Ill., early this morning and charged with soliciting a prostitute and possessing drug paraphernalia.

title: Bush Sets Jaw and Course, if Not Views
description: At no point in the last several months did Gov. George W. Bush seem quite as rattled as he did at a news conference on Thursday, when reporter after reporter challenged him to elucidate his feelings about the Supreme Court and abortion.

title: Britain Grants Embryo Cloning Patent
description: Britain last week became the first country in the world to grant a patent covering cloned early-stage human embryos. The decision could ignite new controversy among biotechnology critics even though the Geron Corporation, the company licensed to use the patent, has no intention of creating cloned humans.

title: Iowas Primarys Colors
description: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

title: Bush Keeps Father in Mind
description: His lead in the opinion polls is so large that Gov. George W. Bush spent much of today warning supporters against taking things for granted. ''I'm concerned about the polls,'' he said. ''I'm concerned about the fact that people are going to say, 'Well, George W. has got it made, therefore I don't need to vote.' ''

title: George Foerstner, 91, Amana Founder and Advocate of the Microwave Oven
description: George Foerstner, an Iowa entrepreneur who founded Amana Appliances during the Depression and led it for 48 years while introducing the microwave oven and the side-by-side refrigerator to American homes, died Monday in Miami, near his winter home in Bal Harbour, Fla. He was 91 years old.

title: Records Tumble In Montana Sprints
description: Chris Witty of West Allis, Wis., and Hiroyasu Shimizu of Japan set world outdoor records yesterday at the fourth Essent World Cup speed skating sprints in Butte, Mont.

title: Cosmic Unity: East and West Meet Between the Notes
description: Chris Rael celebrated the 10th anniversary of his band, Church of Betty, in do-it-yourself downtown style: producing his own concert on Thursday night at the Angel Orensanz Foundation on the Lower East Side. He also booked two fellow composers: Simon Shaheen and Elliott Sharp. The lineup of rock songs, Middle Eastern music and an hourlong composition based on algorithms and acoustic phenomena was united by downtown eclecticism and a shared taste for microtonal areas between the notes of the Western scale.

title: Sports of The Times; Warner's Travels Take Him From Supermarket to Super Bowl
description: HE had one of the most improbable seasons in football history. A virtual rookie, Kurt Warner threw 41 touchdown passes and was the most valuable player of his sport. No quarterback had ever come from so far, so suddenly.

title: In America; A Cold Wind Blows
description: We were in the middle of a brutal cold snap last week, just like the winters of old, with temperatures diving into the single digits and winds as sharp and merciless as a razor slicing through the city's streets.

title: In New Hampshire, a Grudging Admission: Iowa Results Could Be Influential
description: While they will be watching closely on Monday night, people in New Hampshire like to claim that the results in Iowa will not affect their primary eight days later.

title: Groh Gets His First Loss: Crennel Goes to Cleveland
description: It is a classic coaching conundrum: Man does great job coaching linebackers, man gets promoted to head coach, thus losing the great linebackers coach.

title: Nets Are Leaving Home With Shot of Confidence
description: The Nets were clearing off the practice floor at the Champion Center on Friday afternoon when Dallas Coach Don Nelson and his players streamed into the gym, stopping to exchange pleasantries as they passed. Along with the small talk, Nets Coach Don Casey moaned to Nelson about how his team had struggled in the past week, failing in three straight games to win or tie with a last-second shot.

title: Hazel Wolf, 101; Fought for the Environment
description: Hazel Wolf, an ardent environmentalist whose life spanned the 20th century and whose causes encompassed the era's social turmoil, died in Port Angeles, Wash., on Wednesday. She was 101 and lived in Seattle.

title: Economic Calendar
description: Expected dates for the release of major economic indicators this week.

title: Of Medicine, Money and Wrinkles
description: To the Editor:

title: Sports of The Times; McNair's Next Stop Ends an Odd Journey
description: ABOUT six years ago, Steve McNair stood in front of his mother's modest home in Mount Olive, Miss., and contemplated questions I asked about the path he had chosen. Why hadn't he gone to one of the prestigious colleges that had recruited him? Why had he opted for tradition and followed his brother to Alcorn State?

title: Market and Lawsuit Test New Philadelphia Paper
description: A new breed of daily newspaper that has had phenomenal success here and throughout Europe is about to face its first test in the United States when Metro Philadelphia begins publishing on Monday.

title: Metro Matters; Justice, But Only Just In Time
description: LAST Friday, a man on trial for something he did not do was released by federal prosecutors, who admitted to a case of mistaken identity.

title: A Girl Group That Takes No Prisoners In Love
description: Pop's ideal woman, vintage 2000, is a bundle of contradictions. She's a wild party girl and a levelheaded career woman. She's independent but she gets lonely. She's streetwise but upwardly mobile, materialistic but not for sale, tough yet insecure, lusty but choosy. It's too much for one woman, so TLC splits the duties three ways. As the group announced during its show on Friday night at Madison Square Garden, Lisa Lopes (Left Eye) is ''crazy,'' Rozonda Thomas (Chilli) is ''sexy'' and Tionne Watkins (T-Boz) is ''cool.''

title: Before Models Do Their Turns, Publicists Do Their Spins
description: A designer whose career hangs in limbo requests a meeting with a journalist in the hope of receiving more ''personal'' consideration. A press agent for a French house invites reporters to preview its collection, so the designer can explain his ideas; and a few days later their reviews are cozily full of those very ideas. In Milan, still another publicist reacts to a bad review by primly scolding the writer for not attending a preview, where she would have ''understood'' the designer's finer points.

title: Budget Rise Is Proposed By Whitman
description: Saying New Jersey's sustained economic boom and the state's mounting surpluses had created an ''unprecedented opportunity,'' Gov. Christine Todd Whitman proposed today her most generous budget yet, a $21.2 billion plan that increases spending by $1.3 billion for a host of new programs, tax cuts and ambitious school and highway construction projects.

description: All right, ''Never Say Die,'' the title of tonight's ''Scientific American Frontiers,'' is hyperbolic, but it signals a real quest by researchers to discover ways to prolong the physical and mental well-being of humankind.

title: Jail Officer Goes on Trial In Inmate's Fatal Beating
description: A jury yesterday began deliberating the case of a Nassau County jail supervisor, Cpl. Joseph Bergen, who was charged with falsely reporting that an inmate, Thomas Pizzuto, 38, died after slipping in the shower, when he had actually been beaten by guards.

title: A Consumer Products Giant Will Most Likely Stay With What It Knows
description: After ending merger discussions with Warner-Lambert and American Home Products, the Procter & Gamble Company will probably stick to consumer products rather than court another big pharmaceutical company anytime soon, investors and stock analysts said yesterday.

title: SIDANKO SETTLEMENT ADVANCES
description: Russia's biggest foreign investor, BP Amoco P.L.C., moved significantly closer to shoring up its half-billion dollar investment in the bankrupt oil company Sidanko, after creditors voted to halt the company's liquidation. Creditors overwhelmingly accepted an amicable settlement of the bankruptcy, which essentially calls for a restructuring of $431 million in debts. The agreement, which could be approved by a bankruptcy court Friday, is the first significant sign of progress on a compromise struck in late December by BP Amoco and a rival Russian oil concern, the Tyumen Oil Company.

title: Mayor Urges Lawmakers to Eliminate City School Board
description: Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani brought his escalating campaign against the New York City Board of Education to the Capitol today, calling on state lawmakers to abolish the seven-member board and give the mayor greater control over the city school system.

title: Russia Says Cost of Chechen War Far Exceeds Estimate
description: Acknowledging that the Kremlin had underestimated the cost of defeating Islamic rebels in Chechnya, a senior Russian official said today that Russia spent 50 percent more for the war in Chechnya last year than it initially planned.

title: Foreign Affairs; Momma America
description: Movies and plays about America are all the rage in Egypt lately. Let's see, there are two plays running now -- ''Monica and the Blue Dress'' and ''Me, My Wife and Monica.'' Then there's the recent film ''Momma America,'' which was a huge hit. It's the story of a family in which America is the mother, Egypt is the son, the Arab world are his brothers and sisters and everything is fine until a cousin shows up -- Israel -- and a fight breaks out over Momma America's inheritance. The movie ends with the Statue of Liberty exploding and the Egyptian being arrested because he looks like a terrorist.

title: Party Audit Finds Shortfall in Kohl Era
description: FRANKFURT  Germany's scandal-shaken conservative party, which Monday confirmed that it cannot account for more than 12 million Deutsche marks in political funds, said that it was mired in an "existential trial" and would begin a national campaign to win back public trust.

title: With Tylenol and Children, Overdosing Is Perilously Easy
description: Let me start with the bottom line: the pain and fever reliever acetaminophen, popularly called Tylenol, its first over-the-counter trade name, is a very safe drug for children as well as for adults. But as with any medication, the dose makes the poison. And with acetaminophen, which has properly replaced aspirin as the drug most often given to infants and children, there is a relatively small window of safety.

title: Excerpts From the Supreme Court Ruling on Campaign Contribution Limits
description: Following are excerpts from the Supreme Court's decision today upholding Missouri's limits on campaign contributions. The vote in the case, Nixon v. Shrink Missouri Government PAC, was 6 to 3. Justice David H. Souter wrote the majority opinion. Justice Clarence Thomas wrote a dissent, as did Justice Anthony M. Kennedy.

title: NATWEST'S EARNINGS RISE
description: In the midst of its battle to remain independent, National Westminster Bank P.L.C. reported 1999 earnings that beat analysts' expectations. The bank, Britain's third largest, said its net income rose 6.4 percent this year, to 1.67 [pounds] billion, from 1.57 [pounds] billion a year earlier. The bank also said it planned to to buy back 17 percent, or $5.8 billion, of its own shares in its effort to thwart its two unwelcome Scottish suitors: Bank of Scotland and Royal Bank of Scotland. Andrew Ross Sorkin

title: CITADEL IN DEAL TO PURCHASE BLOOMINGTON BROADCASTING
description: The Citadel Communications Corporation, the largest United States radio station owner in midsize markets, agreed to buy closely held Bloomington Broadcasting for about $176 million in cash to gain 20 stations in the Southeast and Midwest. Citadel, based in Las Vegas, will own almost 200 radio stations in 42 markets after the close of this and other purchases. Bloomington, based in Bloomington, Ill., owns stations there and in Grand Rapids, Mich.; Columbia, S.C.; the Johnson City, Tenn., region; and Chattanooga, Tenn. Citadel's shares fell $1.875 each, to $56.125, in Nasdaq trading.

title: In a Booming Reno, No Room for the Old Inn
description: The second floor of the Mapes Hotel had been gutted. Mayor Jeff Griffin stood ankle deep in the wreckage of what had been a suite, bits of red-velvet-wallpapered walls all around him, and glanced out a gaping window.

title: Front Row; Jil Sander is divorcing Prada. After next month's fall women's collection in Milan, she plans to leave her signature company.
description: In the world of corporate mergers and acquisitions, matches are often made between companies as they are between men and women in Woody Allen movies: according to the rule of opposites. The buttoned-up marry the buttoned-down, the glitzy wed the discreet. But when Prada acquired a 75 percent stake in the house of Jil Sander late last August, the union seemed to be one of like minds. Both labels stand for sanity in fashion and a kind of postmodern good taste. And both Ms. Sander and Patrizio Bertelli, Prada's chief executive, are thought of as intelligent, visionary sorts who live far removed from the world of the laid-back.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MACARTHUR, JEAN

Our condolences to the family on the passing of Jean MacArthur, USO of Metropolitan New York's 1973 Woman of the Year. Oliver M. Mendell, Chairman Myron J. Berman, President

title: Corrections

Charles de Gaulle sent from Washington by Winston Churchill to his cabinet during World War II, and the cabinet's response, referred incompletely to the documents' secrecy classification. While the British Public Record Office kept them classified secret until Jan. 4, they in fact became known publicly. They were cited in a 1981 biography of the two leaders, ''Churchill and de Gaulle'' by Francois Kersaudy.

The acquisition adds voice capabilities to Virata's digital subscriber line software. Virata, based in Santa Clara, Calif., makes communications processor chips used in digital subscriber line equipment D2 Technologies is based in Santa Barbara, Calif. Shares of Virata rose $2.25 each, to $41.25, in Nasdaq trading.

title: The Disabled Soar On Poetry's Wings; Lost Freedom Is Often a Theme
description: Vanessa Cole writes poetry with her toe. She cannot move her arms or legs. She cannot talk, nod, smell, or taste, though she has a brilliant smile that compels a response, for Ms. Cole's entire expressive nature is tied up in her smile. And then there is her poetry, which she writes by pointing her toe at letters on a plastic sheet that someone holds in front of her foot.

title: CARNIVAL TO ACQUIRE FAIRFIELD, TIME-SHARE OPERATOR
description: The Carnival Corporation, the world's biggest cruise operator, said yesterday that it would buy the time-share company Fairfield Communities Inc. in a $775 million deal, rounding out the roster of travel packages it can offer vacationers. Fairfield, based in Orlando, Fla., has 28 resorts in North America and 6 more under development. It has been selling Carnival cruises since 1996 and is the largest buyer of its cruises among time-share companies. Carnival, based in Miami, said it would pay 0.3164 of its shares for each Fairfield common share. The deal is valued at $725 million, plus the assumption of $50 million in debt. Carnival's stock dropped $3.50 a share, to $43.125, on the New York Stock Exchange while Fairfield's fell 50 cents, to $11.6875.

title: U.S. Asserts Pakistan Backed Hijacking of Air India Jetliner
description: The United States now believes that a terrorist group supported by the Pakistani military was responsible for the hijacking of an Indian Airlines jet last month, a judgment that puts Pakistan at risk of being placed on Washington's list of nations that support terrorism, Clinton administration officials said.

title: GLOBESPAN TO ACQUIRE UNIT OF PAIRGAIN TECHNOLOGIES
description: GlobeSpan Inc., which develops integrated circuits, said yesterday that it had agreed to acquire the microelectronics group of PairGain Technologies. GlobeSpan said it would give PairGain 1.08 million shares, valued at about $145 million, and a $90 million subordinated redeemable convertible note. GlobeSpan's shares jumped $6.8125, to $141.125, while PairGain rose 31.25 cents, to $13.75. PairGain, based in Tustin, Calif., is a leader in digital subscriber line networking systems. GlobeSpan, based in Red Bank, N.J., is a leading developer of advanced digital subscriber line chip sets.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RUBENSTEIN, JEAN EVANS
description: RUBENSTEIN-Jean Evans. Died at her home in Lexington, MA. January 20, 2000 attended by her husband Neal and children Elizabeth and David Edward. Born in San Diego, CA., the daughter of Dr. Edward Ellsworth Evans, U.S.N., and Elvira Jeannette Thurlow, both deceased, she grew up in many places, meeting her husband when they were at Reed College together. Jean was the Executive Secretary of Mass. PAX in the '60s and '70s, an active opponent of the war in Vietnam, worked for Shirley Chisholm for President, and was an Aide to Paul Tsongas for more than twenty years, beginning as his Executive in Middlesex County. She did these things because she knew they were necessary, the right things to do. As Paul said, ''She took the moral high ground and let the rest of us fend for ourselves.'' Jean had a deep love and a fierce loyalty for her friends and family, and in her last years, delighted mostly in two grandchildren, Rachel and Evan.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SARGENT, DAVID RUTLEDGE
description: SARGENT-David Rutledge. Financial publisher and civic leader, died on January 22 of complications from Parkinson's disease. He was 79 years old. Mr. Sargent, former president of United Business Service of Boston, was a resident of Wellesley, MA from 1947 until he retired to his family farm in Norwich, VT, in 1992. An active public servant in his town and the greater Boston area, he served Wellesley for more that twenty years as town meeting member, member and chairman of the Wellesley School Committee and the Select Board, as well as Town Moderator. He was Chairman of Wellesley Red Feather in 1955, the forerunner of the United Fund, and also served on its greater Boston Board. In 1966, he was a cofounder of Metco, the Metropolitan Council for Educational Opportunity, which organized volunteer busing of Boston children to suburban schools. He was a gubernatorial appointee to several state committees on economic policy. During the same period, he served as a member of the Board of Trustees of the Peter Bent Brigham, now known as Brigham and Women's Hospital. From 1983-1993, he was a member of the Board of the Hitchcock Clinic and a trustee of Mary Hitchcock Memorial Hospital. Born December 21, 1920 in Orange, NJ, he entered Dartmouth College from Hastings on Hudson, NY's high school, graduating in 1942. He was an active alumnus and was class secretary from 1982-1988. After college, Mr. Sargent joined the military serving from 1942-45 as an R.A.F. pilot and U.S. Air Force flying instructor. He joined United Business Service in 1946, and became president in 1961. An author of two books on personal finances, he was also a nationally syndicated columnist in the 1980's. A man of tremendous wit and energy, his life was enriched by his wide variety of interests. Mr. Sargent was an accomplished tennis player and bicyclist. When he was 60 years old, he rode his bicycle across the state of Iowa in the annual Ragbrai bike ride, sponsored by the Des Moines Register. An avid birder and outdoorsman, he canoed many local rivers and could identify most birds by sight and sound. He had a restless intellect, which fueled his passion for books, learning, and verbal debate. He is survived by his wife of 57 years, Jane Oman; two daughters, Karen Sirkin of Wayland, MA; Anne Walker of Wellesley, MA; and four sons, Dwight Sargent of Norwich, VT; Carl Sargent of Boston, MA; David Sargent Jr. of Norwich, VT; and Thomas Sargent of Wellesley, MA; and ten grandchildren. A memorial service will be held at a later date. Memorial donations may be made to: American Parkinson Disease Association, 1250 Hylan Blvd., Suite 4B, Staten Island, NY 10305, The Visiting Nurse Alliance of VT and N.H., 46 South Main Street, White River Junction, VT 05001, Norwich Conservation Trust Fund, Norwich Conservation Commission, PO Box 376, Norwich, VT 05055. Information: Rand-Wilson Funeral Home of Hanover, NH.

title: A Genetic Tool to Track Evolution. Or Is It?

Unlike the nuclear DNA, a pastiche of genes from both parents, the mitochondrial genome has long been assumed to replicate itself by cloning, passing solely through the maternal line.

title: Editorial Observer; What Happens if the Budget Surplus Is Real?
description: There has been a large dose of unreality to the presidential debates from the start. Each of the major candidates proposed paying for initiatives by tapping surpluses that were more speculative than real. True, the Congressional Budget Office had told them that the federal surplus, outside the Social Security program, would equal about $1 trillion over the next 10 years. But that estimate was based on a highly debatable assumption -- that Congress would adhere to onerous spending caps it set in 1997 to achieve a balanced budget. Those caps were broken open this year, a measure of the difficulty in meeting them. If scrupulously observed the next two years, the caps would require Congress to cut non-military discretionary programs by an astonishing 30 percent and then maintain the programs at that level for the next decade. Virtually no one expects Congress to inflict that much pain. Under the more reasonable assumption that Congress keeps current programs intact, there will be no federal surplus.

title: EVANS SYSTEMS AGREES TO BUY I-NET HOLDINGS
description: Evans Systems Inc., a Texas convenience-store operator, agreed yesterday to buy I-Net Holdings for $142.5 million in stock as part of its plan to become a provider of Internet marketing services to the convenience-store industry. Evans Systems will issue 15 million new common shares for the closely held I-Net. I-Net, based in Dallas, is developing and managing a network of business-to-business electronic-commerce companies. Evans Systems, based in Bay City, Tex., said it planned to change its name to I-Net Holdings Inc. The shares of Evans Systems fell $1.8125 each, to $7.6875, in Nasdaq trading.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CLAIBORNE, CRAIG
description: CLAIBORNE-Craig. The Trustees, Faculty, Staff, and Students of the Culinary Institute of America mourn the death of Craig Claiborne, standard-bearer and consummate food writer. Mr. Claiborne's history with the CIA spans almost forty years, including dedicated service as a member of the corporation since 1978. Mr. Claiborne is one of ten individuals in the CIA's ''Hall of Fame''. His memory will live on at the CIA with our Craig Claiborne Bookstore and Hospitality Center, as well as in the Craig Claiborne Collection at the College's Conrad N. Hilton Library. Future CIA students will continue to benefit from the Craig Claiborne Scholarships. Our deepest sympathies are extended to his family, friends, and colleagues.

title: Croatia Is Looking at a Runoff on Feb. 7
description: A witty former Communist leader took a commanding lead in voting on Monday to replace the late president of Croatia, Franjo Tudjman. But results early this morning mean that a runoff will be necessary between the two top finishers.

title: Jazz Meets Latin on a Swinging Two-Way Street
description: The idea of Latin jazz, present through half of jazz's history, is a long, wide two-way street connecting North America with Cuba, Puerto Rico and South America. It's nearly meaningless as an umbrella concept, but incredibly meaningful in a case-by-case basis. Lincoln Center's three-day program, ''Cubana-Be, Cubana-Bop,'' which started on Thursday night at Alice Tully Hall, demonstrated several of the music's different formulas.

title: 37 Popeyes Outlets Bought
description: Interfoods of America Inc. said today that it had bought 37 Popeyes Chicken and Biscuits restaurants in Mississippi and Louisiana for $34 million from Ellis Enterprises, making it the largest franchisee of Popeyes, the No. 2 chicken chain based on sales. Miami-based Interfoods now has 91 Popeyes restaurants in six markets. Popeyes offers Cajun-style fried chicken as well as red beans and rice, shrimp and crawfish. Popeyes restaurants are in 40 states and 23 countries.

title: Justices Uphold Ceiling of $1,000 On Political Gifts

His team, the Denver Broncos, is the two-time defending champion for only six more days. Either the Tennessee Titans or the St. Louis Rams will take the Broncos' throne on Sunday night. title: In Love With Orchids, Their Inspiration and Excess
description: Several years ago, while staying at a half-built research station in the middle of a remote tropical rain forest in Ecuador, I became desperate to have something other than boiled river water to drink. Wondering whether I was within driving distance of anything like a soda, I went searching for the man who would know, a gruff, musclebound Ecuadorean who was in charge and was, with his own two hands, fighting back the rain forest to build the station.

title: Corrections

Holbrooke, the United States representative to the United Nations, at a hearing of the Senate Foreign Relations Committee misstated his comment about the United States' assessment at the United Nations. He expressed confidence that the organization would eventually cut the share of its regular budget that the United States must provide; he did not see a cut as unlikely.

title: Thais Say They Rescued Hostages After Standoff

title: VITAL SIGNS: RISKS & REMEDIES; Less Risk to Liver From Hepatitis C
description: Tests performed on blood taken from Air Force servicemen a half century ago and frozen appear to show that the long-term risk of liver disease from hepatitis C is lower than has been commonly feared.

The deal will cement Clariant's lead in the $36 billion market for base chemicals supplied to the manufacturers of drugs. The acquisition will give Clariant an array of high-margin products.

title: Ecuador's Endangered Democracy
description: Military meddling in politics has become rare in Latin America during the past two decades. But Ecuador is a conspicuous and worrisome exception. Last weekend's forcible removal of President Jamil Mahuad is disturbing, especially since it is the second time in less than three years that an elected Ecuadorean leader has been prematurely ousted from office. Ominously, on both occasions the army played a decisive role in shaping the presidential succession.

title: Rat Studies Raise Hope Of Conquering Paralysis
description: Researchers at the University of Massachusetts Medical School have taken immature cells from the spinal cords of adult rats, induced them to grow and then implanted them in the gap of the severed spinal cords of paralyzed rats. Within two weeks, the paralyzed animals began to move, the scientists say, and within three months several of them could stand and walk.

title: E.D.S. TO SELL COMMERCE ONE HOLDING FOR $400 MILLION
description: The Electronic Data Systems Corporation agreed yesterday to sell its 2.15 million-share holding in Commerce One Inc. to the investment bank Credit Suisse First Boston for about $400 million. E.D.S., which is based in Plano, Tex., said the sale would take place over five years. The transaction was structured to eliminate E.D.S.'s exposure to a decline in Commerce One's share price while locking in 20 percent of any share-price increases that occur. E.D.S. acquired its Commerce One holdings as part of its purchase of SHL Systemhouse from MCI WorldCom Inc. in February 1999. Commerce One, which is based in Walnut Creek, Calif., provides electronic-commerce software and services. Its shares closed up 18.75 cents each, to $199.87, in Nasdaq trading.

title: Presentation
description: In the preparation of this stew, we've had the looks of the final dish in mind all along. We use only the stems of the mushrooms in the beginning stages -- to flavor the stew -- and save the caps for the last 20 minutes so that they remain beautiful. The same idea holds for the onion. One quartered medium onion was used in the beginning, but toward the end we add a handful of white, perfect little pearl onions. The olives and tomatoes are added moments before serving to brighten the stew with touches of green and red. The thyme sprigs, orange rind and bay leaf should be removed and discarded before plating.

title: Regent Offering Rises 41%
description: Shares of the radio broadcaster Regent Communications Inc. rose 41 percent yesterday in their first day of trading. The initial offering of 16 million common shares was priced at $8.50 a share in the morning. The shares closed at $12 on the Nasdaq exchange. The offering price was at the top end of the expected price range of $6.50 to $8.50 a share. The size of the offering was increased from the originally planned 13.35 million shares. The company, which is based in Covington, Ky., focuses on acquiring, developing and operating radio stations in small and midsize markets.

Tellabs makes equipment that manages traffic on phone networks, and it is facing pressure to sell more sophisticated equipment. Its shares fell $9.5625, to $59.50 each, in Nasdaq trading.

For all the dark dreams that are suggested in her choreography, this is dance that is firmly rooted in some urban approximation of the earth.

title: SCHEIN TO CUT WORK FORCE AND EXPLORE SALE OF COMPANY

As a result, it said, it planned to cut its work force by 15 percent and explore a sale. Analysts polled by First Call/Thomson Financial had forecast a profit of 15 cents a share for the fourth quarter ended Dec. 26. Shares of Schein, which is based in Florham Park, N.J., and employs 1,625 workers, fell $2.3125 each, to $8.5625, on the New York Stock Exchange.

title: THE CHEF
description: CRISP-FRIED pork is a classic Japanese dish today, but it is actually a very early example of fusion cooking. Sometime early in the century, Europeans brought veal Milanese to Japan. The flavor and style of the breaded and fried veal cutlets became widely popular, but the dish could not be duplicated without importing meat, since there is almost no veal in Japan. So it was adapted, using pork and Japanese bread crumbs, called panko, and Worcestershire, steak sauce or ketchup.

title: ONLINE UNIT STOCK TO BE SOLD

Telekom will sell as many as 100 million shares in T-Online; this would be less than 10 percent of the total. The phone company did not name a price range, and the chief executive, Ron Sommer, declined to react to speculation that the unit was worth 20 billion euros, or $20.1 billion. With 4.2 million subscribers, T-Online is Europe's largest Internet service provider.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MCGARRY, MARTIN
description: McGARRY-Martin Joseph. Former newspaperman and retired public relations executive, died on January 20, in Hartford, CT, of complications resulting from pneumonia. Mr. McGarry was 82 years old. Mr. McGarry was born on November 12, 1917, in Philadelphia, PA, to Patrick and Isabel McGarry. He graduated from Philadelphia's renowned Central High School and received a BA in journalism from Temple University, where he served as an editor of the Temple News. He joined the Philadelphia Evening Bulletin as a reporter and became a White House correspondent during FDR's second administration until entering the US Army as a field artillery officer. He served for four years in the Pacific Theater during World War II and was commissioned a Major. Mr. McGarry received the Bronze Star as well as other military decorations. While in the Army, he frequently filed news stories to the Bulletin about Pennsylvanians serving in the war there. After the war, Mr. McGarry returned to the Bulletin and later joined Curtis Publishing in 1947. As a reporter, he contributed to the magazines of Curtis Publishing including Holiday and The Saturday Evening Post. In 1951, Mr. McGarry became a corporate public relations executive with Owens-Illinois in Toledo, OH. In 1956, he became Vice President of Communications with International Minerals and Chemicals Corporation in Chicago, IL. As part of this international mining and fertilizer company, he worked with then US Secretary of Agriculture, Orville Freeman, on projects to advance the initiatives of the World Food Organization around the globe. In 1968, Mr. McGarry joined Heublein, Inc., in Hartford, CT, as Vice President of Public Relations. During his over twenty years with Heublein, the company expanded its holdings in the beverage and food markets. Mr. McGarry created and led several innovative projects to publicize the company and its products. These national projects ranged from unique sporting events like surfing competitions in Hawaii and transcontinental sail plane races to Heublein's internationally acclaimed National Auction of Rare Wines. In the early 1980's, Mr. McGarry returned to Washington to lead Heublein's Government relations team. At both International Minerals Corp. and Heublein, Mr. McGarry had developed and coordinated a corporate-sponsored collection by world-renowned artists and sculptors. The collection was often on display for the public and was frequently on tour to museums throughout the world. Mr. McGarry was involved in the Hartford civic community. He served as President and on the Board of the Hartford Ballet and was a former member of the Board of St. Francis Hospital in Hartford, CT. Mr. McGarry served on advisory committees to Archbishop Whelan of the Archdiocese of Hartford. He was also involved in the political arena and played an active role in the campaigns of President John F. Kennedy and presidential candidate George McGovern. Mr. McGarry is survived by his beloved wife of 52 years, Kathryn; sons Denis McGarry, his wife, Patricia and their children Kaitlin, Erin, Connor and Michael of New Canaan, CT; F. Devin McGarry of Waltham, MA; and daughter Kathryn Ann O'Brien, her husband, Stephen, and their sons Liam and Rory of Simsbury, CT. Visitation will be held at the McGarry home on Friday, January 28, from 2 PM to 8 PM. Contact Molloy Funeral Home in West Hartford for further details, 860232-1322. A Funeral Mass will be held at 11 AM, on Saturday, January 29, at St. Timothy's Church, 1116 N. Main St, West Hartford. Memorial donations may be made to St. Francis Hospital, 114 Woodland St., Hartford, CT 06105; or the American Heart Association, 5 Brookside Drive, Wallingford, CT 06492.

RealNetworks, which is based in Seattle, is adding software and other features in a bid to hold off competition from the Microsoft Corporation and Apple Computer. It will distribute Netzip's software to customers who use its software for playing audio and video over the Internet. Shares of RealNetworks rose $11 each, to $157.875, in Nasdaq trading.

title: 18 Hurt in 3-Alarm Fire In Brooklyn Building
description: A three-alarm fire in a Brooklyn apartment building injured 18 people last night, two of them critically, and displaced about 70 residents, fire officials said.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SNYDER, FRED
description: SNYDER-Fred. Congregation Kehilath Jeshurun, its Men's Club and Sisterhood, mourn the passing of their devoted member, Fred Snyder, beloved husband of Myrna. We extend heartfelt sympathy to members of the bereaved family. Rabbi Haskel Lookstein Rabbi Joshua Lookstein Fred Distenfeld, President

title: Reckonings; Being Bob Forehead
description: In the opening scene of ''Washingtoon,'' Mark Alan Stamaty's classic Reagan-era political comic strip, an insomniac plutocrat is impressed by a late-night infomercial host. ''Anyone who can sell glow-in-the-dark coat hangers to me could probably sell supply-side economics to America,'' he declares. And thus, with guidance from the nation's leading charismatician, begins the career of Congressman Bob Forehead.

title: Malaysia Sex Trial Reopens, and Adjourns
description: The sexual misconduct trial of Malaysia's opposition leader, Anwar Ibrahim, reopened today after a two-month recess, along with a handful of shouting protesters, some legal gamesmanship and political attacks that have made the hearing a dispiriting spectacle.

title: Leave Agony to Us
description: Even on a good day, driving the B41, one of Brooklyn's busiest buses, down Flatbush Avenue, one of the borough's busiest streets, isn't easy. Sometimes, the cars are barely moving. Yesterday some were not moving at all. Like the blue Chrysler LeBaron that seemed to be waiting -- and waiting and waiting -- in a mountain of icy gray goop at the stoplight near Flatbush and Empire Boulevard.

title: Thomson Expected to Buy Sylvan Testing Unit
description: The Thomson Corporation, the data-publishing giant and owner of The Globe and Mail newspaper in Toronto, is expected to announce the $775 million acquisition today of Sylvan Prometric, a computer-based testing company that certifies professionals and graduate school applicants.

title: Doctor in Carving Case Soon Had New Job
description: An obstetrician who carved his initials into a woman's abdomen at Beth Israel Medical Center after delivering her first baby in September worked for two months at a Queens women's clinic performing abortions after being dismissed from both the hospital and his former practice, the clinic's president said yesterday.

title: Hartford Five-Oh? No
description: On Monday afternoon, Bill Smith, 79, of Ipswich, Mass., had been lolling on the sandy beaches of Hawaii. The next morning he found himself on a magic carpet ride, as his return flight was diverted by the storm from Kennedy International Airport, first to Syracuse and then to Hartford. The plane sat on the runway for an hour, then the passengers were discharged to fend for themselves.

title: Moscow Journal; They Stir the Soul and Leave a Ringing in the Ears
description: Maybe it is the belfry of the Church of the Nativity of the Mother of God, but it is still cold as Hades. Some 60 feet up a corkscrew staircase so narrow that your shoulders brush the cobbled walls during the stumbling ascent, a north wind tears beneath the arches supporting a blue onion dome, pauses to flash-freeze any bare skin it can find, then whips away.

title: Groh Gets Down to Business Of Hiring Coaching Staff
description: Al Groh has what he calls ''a very definitive list, but a short list'' of coaching candidates whom he is interested in hiring to be assistants on the Jets. And working with that list, the Jets' new head coach got busy yesterday trying to fill the many openings on his staff.

title: OFF THE MENU
description: A Splashier Ruby Foo's

title: FORBES IS FORCING A RENEWED DEBATE ABOUT ABORTIONS
description: Gov. George W. Bush of Texas and Steve Forbes arrived here in darkness early today from Iowa, to join Senator John McCain in a quickly developing three-way race for New Hampshire's primary and perhaps for the Republican presidential nomination itself.

title: Brisk Market at Sundance, but No Frenzy
description: The Atom Short Bus, actually a recreational vehicle, was double-parked on Main Street, a long line of impatient S.U.V.'s stacked up behind it, while inside people in designer glasses and black leather lounged on a queen-size bed or around a Formica dining table.

title: Sports of The Times; Matthews Remembers Houston
description: ONLY a few days from representing the city of Nashville and the state of Tennessee, Bruce Matthews will not paint a gaudy ''H'' on his forehead for the Super Bowl. That is too flamboyant for an offensive lineman, but he will be thinking about the city that sustains him still.

title: When War Steals a Parent, or a Childhood; Filmmakers Explore How Young Victims Fared in Four of the World's Battlegrounds
description: ''It's very difficult to live in war,'' says Sanel, who is 12. ''You just wait for the moment you will die.''

title: Introduction
description: Dont underestimate the stew. Its more than just soul-warming winter food -- although it is that  its also a classic example of culinary magic. It starts with tough meat that, in the end, becomes as tender as meat can be. It takes the most ordinary vegetables, like celery and carrots, and turns them into stunning players in an extraordinary sauce. And once you learn the basic principles of cooking one stew, it can free your imagination so that you can invent and embellish at will, as all good cooks do.

title: FOOD CHAIN
description: One, Two, Three Molasses

title: Sports of The Times; Navratilova Still Goes Own Way
description: IT was just a couple of months ago that Martina Navratilova glanced at her flight instructor's seat and was hit with the stunning realization that it was empty. It was too late to back out, though. She was at 8,000 feet, flying solo again.

title: Commercial Real Estate; Combining Old With New: Joining Two Buildings
description: The former Abercrombie & Fitch building at the northwest corner of Madison Avenue and 45th Street, which once housed the store famous for outfitting big-game hunters and those who merely aspired to look like them, will soon be growing, both upward and laterally.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RIATTI, DR. PIERLUIGI
description: RIATTI-Dr. Pierluigi. Died Monday, January 24 in Tahiti where he was vacationing. He was 74. He was an Attending Anesthesiologist at United Hospital in Port Chester NY where he served as Chairman of the Department from 1974-1986. Dr. Riatti was predeceased by his beloved wife Doris O'Donnell Riatti and is survived by three daughters, Lisa Gatti of Greenwich, CT, Suzanne Dudley and Julia Riatti of Dallas, TX, a son David Riatti of Dallas, TX and his beloved fiancee, Marguerite Sargeant.

title: In Japan, What Price Coca-Cola?; 'Throwaway' Lawsuit Grows Into a Far-Reaching Case
description: For years, Japanese consumers have had two Coca-Colas to choose from -- identical except for their packaging, but at strikingly different prices. There is the locally bottled brand, labeled simply Coca-Cola, and ''American Coke,'' labeled Coca-Cola Classic -- bottled in America and shipped abroad.

title: Now in New York: True Mexican
description: FOR years, Tequila's on Columbus held out a welcoming sombrero to the Upper West Side, offering powerful frozen margaritas, sizzling fajitas, enchiladas loaded with melted cheese and all the other party essentials that New Yorkers have come to regard as Mexican food. Then, last year, Tequila's was sold. The new owners, Cristina Castaneda and Raul Bonetto, had a different vision.

title: Democrats Plan To Aid McCain In Ballot Fights
description: Democrats in Albany plan to thwart an attempt by the Republican State Committee to knock Senator John McCain off the presidential primary ballot in much of upstate New York, injecting a new level of partisanship into what had largely been a family feud among Republicans.

title: Business Travel; From plumbing problems to medical evacuations, International SOS can be a big help on the road.
description: I was doing the old Dallas quick-step one day last week, huffing a half-mile between gates at the nation's most aerobically demanding airport to lunge for a connecting flight whose tail fin could be seen gliding away just as I reached the counter, where the ticket agent wore a look that said, ha-ha.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CARLTON, EILEEN
description: CARLTON-Eileen. Age 77. Of Delray Beach, FL. Died January 24, 2000 in New York City. Survived by sister Amy, brother Stanley, children Pamela and William and grandson Christopher. Cherished for her warmth, compassion and sense of humor. She will be sorely missed. Service today, 10AM, Harmon Funeral Home, Staten Island. Shiva Wednesday and Thursday, 11AM-9PM, Friday 10AM-12N at the home of Pamela Carlton, 495 Castleton Ave, Staten Island, N.Y.

title: Master Plans or Pipe Dreams; Giuliani Proposes Monuments; Skeptics See Fantasies
description: All New York City mayors dream about changing the face of their realm, of erecting a physical legacy. Fiorello La Guardia is remembered for his public housing, the airport that bears his name and the alliance he forged with Robert Moses, the most grandiose builder of all. John V. Lindsay fought for urban renewal. Edward I. Koch is credited with the rehabilitation of the South Bronx, and David N. Dinkins made the deal with Disney that led to the new Times Square.

title: Return of the White Stuff
description: Something about a sudden heavy snow of the kind that fell yesterday carries New York right back to the end of the 19th century and to a vision of urban winter caught by Alfred Stieglitz. In 1893 he photographed a horse team plodding through deep gray slush along Fifth Avenue on a similar day of driving snow, diminished sightlines, rapid accumulation. Yesterday, of course, it was taxis, not horses, slithering gingerly through intersections. Buses slipped their wheels on the barely perceptible grade up West 42nd Street toward the library. During the thickest snowfall the city seemed almost depopulated. Pedestrians became studies in gray and white. The skyline withdrew into a pale monochrome, and yet the fallen snow sharpened the horizontal lines of every building in sight, just as it did for Stieglitz.

title: Qualcomm Warning Sends Its Shares Down After Hours
description: Qualcomm Inc., the highflying wireless technology company, warned yesterday that shipments of cellular telephones and chips may dip in the second quarter, sending its shares downward in after-hours trading.

title: Bahraini Diplomat Claims Immunity in Suit
description: A Bahraini government official accused of making a domestic servant a virtual slave has claimed diplomatic immunity and asked a federal judge in Manhattan to dismiss the charges.

title: Strongman From Congo Seeks Image Change at U.N. Meeting
description: Elusive and unpredictable, President Laurent Kabila of Congo kept the United Nations guessing about whether he would attend a special Security Council session on the war in his country almost until his plane landed on Friday night, disgorging the largest of seven presidential parties for what has become an impromptu African summit.

Shares of British Biotech fell 19.25 pence, to 28.

description: Shamika Petersen thought she would take a break. And so a few minutes before 4 p.m. on Monday, she left her desk in the Empire State Building and stepped into an elevator at the 48th floor, planning a swift ride down to the lobby.

title: Knicks' Game Is Snowed Out
description: The Knicks flew down to Washington late Monday night, after defeating the Seattle SuperSonics at Madison Square Garden, to prepare for last night's game against the Wizards. They then took a train back to New York yesterday afternoon after a snowstorm that blanketed the East Coast led to the cancellation of the game.

description: The headmasters of the city's elite private schools, increasingly facing a loss of authority, demanding parents and huge fund-raising campaigns to build ever more lavish facilities, have begun to fall like dominos, tossed aside by impatient boards or resigning in exhaustion.

title: Medicaid Smokers Seek to Gain a Share of States' Settlement
description: With 46 states beginning to receive payments from their $206 billion settlement with the nation's leading cigarette makers, a legal fight is emerging over whether some smokers are themselves entitled to any of the money.

title: I Check Out Your Genes
description: Jack Gerson, 53, an antiwar activist in the 1960's, finds himself part of a very different subculture today: the world of genetic technology, where a booming market could turn his intellectual pursuits into wealth he never expected.

title: The Snow Keeps Falling, And Clinton Keeps Chatting
description: President Clinton called reporters in today to talk policy, introducing a plan to pay off the federal debt by 2013. But his schedule had been cleared by a snowstorm, and so after his announcement the president continued talking, and talking.

title: Correction
description: A recipe for beet, endive and walnut salad on Jan. 12 with an article about new brasseries in New York omitted an instruction for one ingredient. In Step 3, the toasted walnut halves should be combined with the endive pieces, Roquefort cheese and parsley.

title: EVIDENCE IS SEEN LINKING BIN LADEN TO ALGERIAN GROUP
description: American investigators have uncovered what they believe are links between Algerians who have been charged with plotting a terrorist attack in the United States and Osama bin Laden, the exiled Saudi accused of bombing two American Embassies in East Africa, law enforcement officials said yesterday.

title: Sempra to Cut Dividend
description: Sempra Energy said today that it planned to reduce its quarterly dividend and buy back 15 percent of its shares in initiatives to raise earnings and give the company greater financial flexibility to expand. Calling the moves an effort to bring itself in line with industry peers, Sempra, an energy services company based here, said it would cut its quarterly dividend to 25 cents a share from the current 39 cents a share. The company also said it had begun an offer to purchase as many as 36 million shares at prices between $17.50 to $20 each.

title: America One's Rally Ties Challenger Series
description: Battling from behind to stage a stirring comeback on a strange, fickle day better suited for water skiing than for yacht racing, Paul Cayard's America One overtook Italy's Prada Challenge today and won by 1 minute 33 seconds to even the five-of-nine-race final round of the Louis Vuitton Cup at 1-1.

title: Man Convicted in Killing Of Syosset Firefighter
description: A Huntington man was convicted of second-degree murder yesterday in the 1997 shooting of a Syosset firefighter who was gunned down on his own front lawn.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  REICHGOTT, GERTRUDE
description: REICHGOTT-Gertrude. To Michael and his family, we extend our heartfelt condolences. Matthew E. Fink, M.D., President and CEO

title: OIL GAINS HELP TOTALFINA
description: Sharply higher oil prices helped TotalFina more than double its profits in the second half of 1999, to 987 million euros, or about $988 million. TotalFina, the first major European oil company to report second-half results, plans to acquire its big French rival Elf Aquitaine for $54 billion this year, which will double its production of oil and gas. John Tagliabue

title: When the Game's on the Line, the Line's on the Screen
description: DURING last year's Super Bowl, partygoers could rack up another advantage over fans who attended the game. Not only did television watchers save the price of admission, get all the munchies they could eat and have a chance to critique the latest batch of million-dollar commercials, but they could also see exactly where the first-down stripe was.

description: A TEST for voters, an old one, but it still works.

description: ''If she was playing anyone else, I would want her to win,'' Lindsay Davenport said before taking the court against Jennifer Capriati.

title: Pick-Up Sticks
description: ''They are not meant for traveling,'' said Judy Vilmain of the salt and pepper shakers she designed with David Klinger. ''They are just supposed to sit on the table and puzzle your guests.'' Each six-inch brushed stainless steel tube has a lever and knob that open and close the dispensing holes. And they can be stored in a small drawer or pocketed to take out of town, despite Ms. Vilmain's warning; $65 a set at Zao, 175 Orchard Street, (212) 505-0500. MARIANNE ROHRLICH

description: Don Budge, the red-haired athlete who helped redefine the terms of his sport by becoming the first player to win the Grand Slam of tennis, in 1938, died yesterday in Scranton, Pa. He was 84.
