title: Warning Signs for Dangerous Times
description: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

title: ESSAY; People Who Live in Glass Houses Must Stay on Their Toes
description: LAST fall I set up a Webcam in my living room. A Webcam is a video camera (in our case, a very modest one) connected to a computer and through it to the Internet; it doesn't record videos but sends signals across the World Wide Web. So when I sign on to the Internet and turn on the Webcam, I transmit a continuous jerky rendition of a small portion of my family's daily life to anyone who wishes to view it online. So far, that has been about 10,000 people, for about a minute each, all in an apparent desire to see a dumpy middle-age mother of three take her clothes off (www.camarades.com/946860167).

title: Working on the Railroad: The Reincarnation of a Classic Station
description: The story of Pennsylvania Station is big but not often told in full, from its beginnings as the grandest building in New York in 1908, larger even than St. Peter's Basilica in Rome, to its end in 1963 amid a hue and cry that gave birth to the preservation movement. The latest chapter -- its reincarnation, above, within the shell of the monumental New York Post Office -- is now under way to intense scrutiny. New Yorkers can see the epic unfold at ''Gateway to Metropolis: New York's Pennsylvania Stations,'' an exhibition at Columbia University's Wallach Art Gallery, opening on Wednesday. The show includes never-before-seen original construction photographs, Norman McGrath's wrenching images of the demolition, sculptural fragments recovered from a Meadowlands landfill and the first extensive views of the new interiors, right. David Childs of Skidmore, Owings & Merrill, the new station's architects, called it ''the flash point frontier'' for redevelopment west to the Hudson. The gallery is at Schermerhorn Hall, 116th Street and Broadway.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PERLMUTTER, NATALIE (NEE SHMERLER)
description: PERLMUTTER - Natalie (nee Shmerler)., of New York City, on January 25, 2000. Devoted wife of the late Louis Perlmutter. Dear mother of Robert Schneider. Survived by grandchildren, greatgrandchildren. Sister of Edwin, Walter and the late Irving. Funeral services private.

title: Cameras in Courtrooms
description: Justice Joseph Teresi has struck an important blow for constitutional rights and an open judicial process by allowing cameras to televise the murder trial of the four New York City police officers who shot Amadou Diallo. Justice Teresi, who sits on the State Supreme Court in Albany, ruled that the New York State law imposing an absolute ban on television cameras in courtrooms was unconstitutional. The public and press have a constitutionally protected right to view criminal trials, and the use of television cameras is a natural and reasonable extension of that right. The justice found that given the great interest in this case, and the limited seating available, the right of the public and press to observe the trial would be curtailed if not denied without television cameras.

title: When the Weather Bypasses the Computers
description: Six months ago, the National Weather Service celebrated the completion of a decade-long modernization program that gives forecasters access to computer and satellite data that their professional predecessors could scarcely have imagined.

description: MANHATTAN

title: Man vs. Beast: Whose Neighborhood Is It, Anyway?
description: DAN DODGE'S 12-year-old son, Jake, was playing outside the family home in this mountain-ringed town when his father heard him yell, ''There's a mountain lion!'' Mr. Dodge looked out the window to see a dun-colored cat crouched about 30 feet away from a picnic table, moving stealthily toward his son.

title: In Astoria, One Less Stately Mansion
description: ON a block in Astoria, Queens, where 19th-century lumber magnates built their Greek Revival mansions, three women, all near 70, sat around a starched white tablecloth on Monday afternoon. They sipped tea and ate butter cookies the size of silver dollars and wondered what to do about the big old house on their block, the one with the demolition sign posted on it.

title: Syria Businessmen Yearn for Reforms
description: They have luxury cars, marble-floored offices, satellite dishes, tailored suits and high-end computers. But young Syrian entrepreneurs, eager to catch up with their contemporaries in other Arab countries, are feeling distinctly bankrupt.

title: Freed Puerto Rican Militants Revel in Life on the Outside
description: Luis Rosa had never seen El Yunque, Puerto Rico's renowned rain forest. He had never tasted a seafood stew like the one he ate the other day or tried many of the tropical fruits people here pick from their backyard trees.

title: NORFOLK SOUTHERN OFFERS MANAGERS EARLY RETIREMENT
description: The Norfolk Southern Corporation said yesterday that it would offer early retirement to as many as 1,180 managers, a fifth of the total, as its fourth-quarter profit fell 81 percent on higher costs. The company, the fourth-largest United States railroad, said it expected about 800 people to accept the offer, made to nonunion workers older than 55 with more than 10 years of service. A spokeswoman, Susan Terpay, declined to discuss the severance costs. Norfolk Southern has been trying to cut costs since it began integrating part of the former Conrail Inc. system. The company, based in Norfolk, Va., and the CSX Corporation bought Conrail in 1998 for $10 billion. Norfolk Southern shares fell $1.0625 each, to $17.75, on the Big Board.

title: All Russian, In Every Way
description: The Russian National Orchestra, which was founded in 1990 following the collapse of the former Soviet Union, is financed privately and operates with no government influence. A dose of capitalism has worked well for the organization, which has attracted some of the best players from other former Soviet orchestras and won much praise from critics over the last 10 years.

title: New York Collegium's Treasure Hunt for Rarely Performed Baroque Repertory
description: Well into its second season, the New York Collegium seems to be in fine estate, at least in artistic matters. The latest of several attempts to establish a period instrument chamber orchestra in New York, the ensemble has formed an association with Gustav Leonhardt, who is listed as its founding music director, as well as some of the best European early music conductors and some superb young soloists. At Town Hall on Monday evening, Christophe Rousset presided over the orchestra and its chorus, drawing trim, finely polished performances of works by Rameau and Mondonville.

title: Slow Play Can Lose a Title, And It's Often for Naught
description: For the first time in the history of the game, a world title has been decided by a slow-play penalty. In the Orbis World Championships in Bermuda a week ago, in the final of the Venice Cup for women's teams the Netherlands beat the United States by half an imp, the smallest margin ever, and created considerable controversy. Some feel that such penalties should never decide a match, but they cannot explain how to restrain those who tend to hurt the scheduling and infuriate their opponents by excessive thinking.

title: Study Finds Strong Evidence Jefferson Fathered Slave Son
description: The foundation that administers Monticello, Thomas Jefferson's estate in Charlottesville, Va., said today that an extensive study it had commissioned concluded that Jefferson was almost certainly the father of one, if not all six, of the children of Sally Hemings, one of his slaves.

title: IKON TO CUT UP TO 5% OF ITS WORK FORCE IN RESTRUCTURING
description: Ikon Office Solutions Inc., the No.2 United States supplier of copiers to companies, said yesterday that it would cut 1,500 to 2,000 jobs, or about 5 percent of its work force. The cuts are in addition to the 1,000 sales jobs eliminated last year. Ikon, based in Valley Forge, Pa., has 39,400 employees and 950 operations in the United States and seven other countries. The company said it would close or consolidate 140 facilities and make changes to 65 others to cut costs and improve profits. The restructuring would result in about $15 million of savings in the 2000 fiscal year and $45 million annually after that.

title: U.N. Urges End to Congo Cease-Fire Impasse
description: Laying the groundwork for an eventual United Nations peacekeeping operation in Congo, the Security Council today urged African nations involved in the war to put into effect a peace accord they negotiated last summer.

description: WITHOUT any fanfare or hoopla, Wal-Mart rolled out its redesigned Internet site on Jan. 1. After trying to shop there last week, I understand why nobody was bragging about it.

description: Strange that the St. Louis Rams and the Tennessee Titans first met this season on Halloween. It was a frightening game for both teams -- especially the Rams' start and the Titans' finish.

description: While Syria and Israel have been discussing an end to their 52-year state of war, many Syrian businessmen fear they would not reap any economic dividends of peace, despite its promise of access to Western markets and investment.

title: Secret Spots In Rome
description: When in Rome, do as Danny Meyer, John Guare and Richard Meier do. With the notion that the discerning traveler wants the inside dope, Robert Kahn, a New York architect, canvassed poets, chefs, architects and others for their favorite haunts in ''City Secrets Rome'' (Little Bookroom, $19.95). Mr. Meyer, the chef at Union Square Cafe, recommends La Taverna da Giovanni, a family trattoria near the Castel Sant'Angelo; Mr. Guare, the playwright, points the way to a relic, St. Thomas's finger at Santa Croce in Gerusalemme, and Mr. Meier, the architect, is awed by Borromini's all-white star-shaped interiors for Sant'Ivo alla Sapienza. This idiosyncratic guide helps jaded visitors see the Eternal City anew. To order: (212) 691-3321.

title: House Republicans to Draft Bill On Medicare Prescription Drugs
description: House Republican leaders said today that they would soon create a group of about a dozen Republican lawmakers to draft legislation providing coverage of prescription drugs for Medicare beneficiaries.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  JULIEN, ROBERT

It is made of polypropylene sheets lit from within by fluorescent lighting shrink-wrapped in colored gels; a dimmer switch adjusts the color to suit the moment. Studies of nature -- say, the tip of a flower stamen -- inspired the screen's fluid shape. ''I enjoy taking things you don't necessarily focus on and then magnifying them,'' Mr. Lwin said. title: New York's Ballot Machinations

The move -- a rare instance of the state's partisan election machinery working in favor of democracy -- thwarted, at least for the moment, the state Republican Party's effort to keep Mr. McCain off the presidential primary ballot in much of upstate New York.

There was a Sky Room on the 11th floor, a Turkish bath in the basement, and all the amenities in between. In 1982 the hotel closed, and 16 years later it was placed on the National Trust for Historic Preservation's list of the 11 most endangered historic buildings. But now, if the City of Reno has its way, the Mapes Hotel will be imploded at 8 a.m. on Jan. 30, Super Bowl Sunday, while Reno residents and film crews watch.

title: A Disappointing Choice on Iraq

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  O'CONNELL, THOMAS J.
description: O'CONNELL-Thomas J.., 68, of 226 Lee Farm Drive, Southbury, Conn., died Tuesday, January 25, at Waterbury Hospital. He was the husband of Cynthia (Baxter) O'Connell. Mr. O'Connell was born June 7, 1931, in Bronx, N.Y., son of the late Thomas J. and Catherine (Scully) O'Connell. He was a veteran of the Korean War, serving with the U.S. Army. He retired from the New York Times as a marketing representative in the circulation department, where he worked for more than 40 years. He was a member of the Knights of Columbus in Blauvelt, N.Y.; a member of the Mount St. Michael Academy in Bronx; a member of the New York Times 30 Year Club; and a member of the American Legion Camp Shanks of Rockland County, N.Y. He was an avid sports enthusiast. Formerly of Blauvelt, he and his wife moved to Southbury in 1993. Besides his wife of 41 years, he leaves sons Daniel T. O'Connell of Southbury, Edward J. O'Connell of Wolcott, Conn., and Robert B. O'Connell of Naugatuck, Conn; a daughter, Mary Norris, of Southbury; one sister, Eileen Perdick, of Yorktown Heights, N.Y.; and five grandchildren. Funeral mass will be at 10 AM Friday at Sacred Heart Church, Main Street South, Southbury. Burial in St. James Cemetery, Naugatuck. Calling hours from 6 to 8 PM Thursday at Carpino Funeral Home, 750 Main Street South, Southbury. Memorial contributions may be made to Connecticut Children's Medical Center Foundation, 12 Charter Oak Place, Hartford, CT 06106.

title: Lehman Brothers Sets a Buyback
description: Lehman Brothers Holdings Inc. said yesterday that it would buy back up to 8.3 million shares of its stock in the current fiscal year, plus another 16 million shares over the following two years. The total buyback represents about 20 percent of Lehman's stock outstanding. Shares of Lehman rose $1.8125 yesterday, to $72.375, on the New York Stock Exchange. At this price, the buyback would be worth more than $1.7 billion. Companies use buybacks to increase earnings per share by reducing the shares outstanding. The buyback for the current fiscal year, which ends Nov. 30, 2000, is intended to offset dilution resulting from employee stock plans, the company said. Lehman, a New York investment bank, also said it would increase its quarterly dividend to 11 cents a share, from 9 cents.

Cherished grandmother of Jesse, Rachel, Wendy Goldman, Alexandra Sopko & Rebecca Finkel. Loving sister of Phyllis Wendorf and treasured sister and sister-in-law of Arline and Marvin Lubin. Lorraine's interests were wide and varied: she was an active participant in artistic and community affairs and an intrepid outdoors woman, having trekked in recent years in the Himalayas, Andes and Karakoram. She was a truly unique person who will be sorely missed by all who had the privilege of knowing her. We celebrate her life and deeply mourn her passing. Funeral services will be held at 12:45 PM at Beth Shalom Funeral Home, 760 Smithtown Bypass, Smithtown, NY, 516360-3038. Interment to follow at Mt. Zion Cemetery, Queens, NY. Based on 19th-century designs that originated in Appalachia and evolved in the Ozarks, the brooms are handmade of broomcorn, with handles of carved sassafras or wood that has been shaped naturally by twining honeysuckle vines. From $7 pot scrubbers to $200 sweeps, the brooms are reminders that everyday objects don't have to be mundane. From Grassy Creek Brooms, (870) 269-8372.

Mr. Nelson was the President, CEO and Director of US Energy Systems, Inc. He received his B.A. degree from Princeton University in 1961. The same year, he went to work in Washington, D.C., as special assistant to Bill Moyers, deputy director of the Peace Corps. In 1962, Mr. Nelson became military aide to Vice President Lyndon B. description: Humbled by a year of problems at home and abroad, Coca-Cola said yesterday that it would cut 6,000 jobs, or a fifth of its global work force of 30,000, in the biggest reductions ever by the company.

title: Getting a 3-D View
description: Virtual reality meets common sense. In an effort to make squinting at stamp-size paint chips a thing of the past, Benjamin Moore has equipped every store that sells its paint with an interactive room display. Using eight-inch-square paint samples, customers can mock up wall colors and insert flooring options. Though the big paint chips can't be taken out, the ones you can take home are far larger than average. Unfortunately, Benjamin Moore won't come over and move furniture, but this is a big help. For locations, (800) 826-2623. MARIANNE ROHRLICH

title: Once More, The Question Of Abortion Dogs McCain
description: Struggling to answer a hypothetical question, Senator John McCain said today that if his teenage daughter became pregnant, she would have the ''final decision'' on whether to have an abortion. He then backtracked and said it would be a ''family decision.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PHILIPS, MORRIS
description: PHILIPS - Morris. Of Roslyn Heights, N.Y. Died January 26, 2000. Married for more than 58 years, he and his wife Evelyn were the parents and parents-inlaw of Carol, Alice, Laura, Bill and Ellen and the grandparents of Rose, Ruby and Julia. Morrie was the brother and brother-in-law of Connie and Mary, Mickey and June, and the late Ben and Elsie. He was selflessly loving to his wife, children, grandchildren and all the members of his extended family who dearly loved him in return. He will be remembered by them and his many friends for his warmth, generosity, sharp wit and passion for social justice. Services 10AM Friday, Riverside-Nassau North Chapels, 55 Station Road, Great Neck, New York.

description: Four of the roughly two dozen guards who oversee the women's quarters in the Westchester County jail were arrested today on sex-abuse charges, including raping and sodomizing prisoners and forcing them to strip in exchange for medication.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GORDON, PAUL
description: GORDON-Paul., 54. Died suddenly Jan. 25, 2000, in Forest Hills, NY. Paul is survived by his best friend & loving wife of 33 years, Randee, his devoted son and business partner, Jonathan, his daughter-inlaw, Elisabeth, his sister Annette Fox, sister-in-law and brother-inlaw, Sandra and Bert Wasserman. Paul was President and CEO of Trans World Facilities, Inc., an excess and surplus lines agency for many national companies. Born in Brooklyn, Paul married his college sweetheart, Randee Raab, after graduation from Brooklyn College. Paul will be remembered as a loving and devoted husband, father, brother and uncle, and missed by many of his cherished friends and colleagues. Services are at Schwartz Bros.-Jeffer Memorial Chapels, 114-03 Queens Boulevard, Forest Hills, New York, at noon, on January 27.

title: Excerpts From Debate Between the Democratic Candidates for President
description: Following are excerpts from a debate between Vice President Al Gore and former Senator Bill Bradley, candidates for the Democratic presidential nomination, last night at the WMUR television studio in Manchester, N.H., as recorded by The New York Times. The candidates answered questions Judy Woodruff of CNN, Tom Griffith of WMUR and each other.

title: For Gore, a Bitter Lesson From the Campaign Trail
description: By any measure, April 18, 1988, was a frustrating day for Albert Gore Jr. It began at 7:30 a.m. at a subway station on the Upper East Side of Manhattan, with Mr. Gore, who had just turned 40 and was running for president for the first time, standing in visible shock as Mayor Edward I. Koch bellowed a morning greeting to commuters: ''Hi, everybody, it's us! Al Gore and me!''

title: We're Not All Connected, Yet
description: IF, as most people in the computer industry seem to think, the Internet is on its way to becoming the dominant mode of information exchange, then it is no longer a luxury but, like the telephone, a necessity. Anyone without it is in danger of being shut out.

title: Top Yanks Prospect Is Hurt in Accident
description: D'Angelo Jimenez, a top Yankee prospect who was expected to be part of the major league team, injured his back in a car accident in the Dominican Republic and is expected to miss most or all of the 2000 season. On a day the Yankees signed a veteran former Yankee, outfielder Roberto Kelly, to a minor league contract and agreed to terms with Jason Grimsley, an arbitration-eligible relief pitcher, they learned they must now identify another infielder to take Jimenez's place.

title: Sonics' Basket at Buzzer Frustrates Game Nets
description: The Nets were familiar with the phenomenal shooting ability of Chuck Person. He had victimized them with a 21-point shooting barrage last season while playing with the Charlotte Hornets, so they should have known that he was capable of determining the outcome of a game even at the age of 36.

title: O'CHARLEY'S REJECTS MANAGEMENT-LED BUYOUT PROPOSAL
description: O'Charley's Inc., which operates 119 casual restaurants in the South and Midwest, has rejected a management-led buyout proposal. O'Charley's board ''continues to believe that the execution of O'Charley's business plan by its current management team as a public company is in the best long-term interests of shareholders,'' its chairman and chief executive, Gregory Burns, said. David Wachtel Jr., one of O'Charley's largest shareholders and a former chief executive, had made the proposal.

title: Pennsylvania Bank Deal
description: The Sterling Financial Corporation said today that it had agreed to acquire Hanover Bancorp Inc. for about $102.5 million. Hanover, with assets of $504 million, is the holding company of the Bank of Hanover and Trust Company, with 10 offices in York County and Adams County, Pa. Sterling, based in Lancaster, has assets of $1.06 billion and operates 34 banks through its Bank of Lancaster County and First National Bank of North East units.

title: A Guitarist Synonymous With a City And a Sound
description: This month a new statue went up here in Music City. Crowning the Bank of America Plaza downtown, it depicts a young guitar player seated on a stool, one foot on the ground and the other with the heel hooked back over a rung. From its pose alone, the figure is unmistakable: Chet Atkins, the virtuoso guitarist, the architect of the Nashville Sound, the producer who helped create Music City by stockpiling top musicians and singers in its studios, and a man credited with having performed on more records than any other guitarist.

title: The Frigid Majesty Of the Far North
description: With much of the Eastern Seaboard digging out from this week's storm, perhaps it's a good time to be reminded of what winter really looks like. Alaska Web Art, a design company in Wasilla, Alaska, has put more than a dozen panoramic views of the state on the Web (www.360alaska.com). Included are vistas of Prince William Sound and Seward Harbor that rotate 360 degrees and aerial photographs of the spectacular Denali National Park. There is even a look at downtown Anchorage, where today's forecast calls for snow and a high of 9 degrees. BRUCE HEADLAM

title: Sharpton to File Libel Suit Against New York Post
description: The Rev. Al Sharpton said yesterday that he would file a $20 million libel lawsuit against The New York Post today, saying that a recent column and an editorial irreparably damaged his reputation and ability to raise money for his civil rights organization.

title: In Japan, Life Insurers Losing Popularity
description: TOKYO  Japan's life insurance industry is on the verge of a monumental change. That is because people like Shinichi Suda are increasingly unhappy with the way they are initiated into insurance products.

description: Current and retired police officers living in the Albany area have invited the defendants to stay in their homes. Local civil rights advocates have invited New Yorkers who plan to demonstrate against the defendants to stay in theirs. Courthouse rooms are being painted, offices are being rented and security plans laid. Baby sitters are being lined up, hotel prices negotiated, and buses chartered.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  NACHMAN, ANNE S.
description: NACHMAN-Anne S.. (nee Sugerman) died peacefully on January 23, 2000 after a long illness at the age of 87. A resident of Palm Beach for the past 33 years, Anne formerly was a resident in Philadelphia, Pennsylvania, Greenville, South Carolina and New York, New York. Anne was devoted to many philanthropic causes over the years, but was most proud of being founder of TelMed, Crisis Line of Palm Beach County. Beloved wife of the late Jack Nachman, loving mother of Jody and Larry Nachman. Mother-in-law to Lynne and Susan. Cherished grandmother to Beth, Bobby, Jed, Billy and Missy. Great grandmother to Victoria, Ellen and Clara. Services and Interment will be private. Contributions in her memory may be made to The Leukemia Society of America, 5840 Corporate Way, Suite 102, West Palm Beach, Florida, 33407 or The National Alliance for Research on Schizophrenia and Depression (NARSAD), 60 Cutter Mill Road, Suite 404, Great Neck, New York 11021.

title: Roughing It With TV: Satellite Dish for S.U.V.'s

title: Burglary Alarm Sends Plainclothes Officers to Fire and Rescue
description: Two plainclothes police officers responding early yesterday to a burglary alarm in Astoria, Queens, instead found a burning building filled with people, prompting the officers to break in with a sledgehammer in search of residents, police officials said.

title: QUINTILES TO TAKE $55 MILLION CHARGE IN RESTRUCTURING
description: The Quintiles Transnational Corporation, a drug research company, said yesterday that it would cut 800 jobs, close offices and take a $55 million charge in a restructuring intended to save up to $50 million a year. The job cutbacks would represent about 4 percent of the 19,000-employee work force it will have after it sells its Envoy Corporation unit to the Healtheon/WebMD Corporation. Quintiles, which is based in Research Triangle Park, N.C., agreed on Monday to sell the unit for $2.5 billion in cash and stock.

Loving grandmother of 18 and greatgrandmother of 10. Friends may call from 12 to 2 PM and 7 to 9 PM today at Gray-Parker Funeral Home, Port Jervis, New York. Funeral mass at 11 A.M., Friday at St. Mary's Church, Port Jervis. Burial in St. Mary's Cemetery.

title: Belichick Drops Lawsuit Against Jets and N.F.L.
description: Bill Belichick dropped the antitrust lawsuit he had filed against the National Football League and the Jets yesterday, one day after the judge in the case refused to grant a temporary restraining order that would have allowed Belichick to negotiate with other teams for a new job.

title: JAPAN TRADE SURPLUS GROWS
description: Japan's merchandise trade surplus rose in December as exports notched their biggest rise in six months and imports retreated from November's record. The surplus widened 28.3 percent from November to 777.2 billion yen ($7.3 billion), seasonally adjusted, the Ministry of Finance said. Economists had expected the surplus to rise 25.7 percent. From a year ago, the surplus fell 20.4 percent. Over all, Japanese exports rose 2.3 percent in December from November and rose 3.4 percentcompared with a year ago. Imports fell 2.4 percent, though they were up 15.8 percent from a year earlier.

title: Bitter Indians Let Ecuador Know Fight Isn't Over
description: Last week, the Indians marched by the thousands from this Andean market town to overthrow the government in Quito. This week, with a new president in place but all their other demands unmet, those same protesters have been drifting back to the farms here, feeling defeated, angry and bitter and warning of the fire next time.

description: Pakistan's military government sharply curtailed the independence of the nation's judiciary today, by requiring that all higher court judges swear an oath of office that would bar them from challenging army decisions.

That handshake subtly captured the magical interplay that has kept these two rappers afloat through 12 years of triumphs and downturns.

title: Call It Granny Pop
description: Some people take up knitting when they get restless; Luis Aleman of Brooklyn started sewing straw. Known for his fashionable hats, he's now moved on to straw and wool floor mats. Part grandmotherly rag rug, part optical illusion, Mr. Aleman's mats are designed with Jeffrey Moore and use fashion palettes and Pop patterns (six-foot-diameter versions start at $1,000). The duo's expanding home range also includes a plant or lamp stand ($550 to $600) straight out of Dr. Seuss. Information, (718) 349-8221.

title: The Flashing Pen That Thinks It's a Ringing Cellular Phone

The Flashing Fone Pen, marketed by B.U.C.A., a wholesaler of phone and pager accessories in Long Branch, N.J., silently alerts the user when a call comes in to a nearby mobile phone.

title: HYUNDAI FORMS CHINA VENTURE

Under the agreement, Hyundai Motor will own a 50 percent stake in the joint venture, while the Chinese company will hold the remaining stake. Kia Motors and Jiangsu Yueda Group had already established a joint-venture company in 1998, and Hyundai Motor acquired Kia last year. The original joint venture has produced around 2,000 cars each year until now. The joint venture will manufacture 150,000 cars annually by 2002. Samuel Len

Union Carbide was expected to earn 46 cents a share on average by analysts surveyed by First Call/Thomson Financial, with a high forecast of 60 cents. Union Carbide, which is based in Danbury, Conn., is the largest producer of ethylene glycol, a chemical used in antifreeze. title: KIMBERLY-CLARK WILL RAISE PRICES ON SEVERAL PRODUCTS
description: The Kimberly-Clark Corporation will raise prices on several consumer products in March and April, its president and chief operating officer, Thomas Falk, said yesterday. The Dallas-based company plans to raise prices on its bathroom tissue 3 percent to 4 percent, on its paper towels 8 percent to 9 percent, and on its napkins 5 percent, all effective on March 6. In addition, the price of Kleenex facial tissue will go up 7 percent on April 3. The increases are intended to adjust for higher costs for pulp, Mr. Falk said. Kimberly-Clark's shares rose $2.6875 each, to $64.9375, on the New York Stock Exchange.

description: National Football League security officials warned both Super Bowl teams this week that because of the presence of a large number of undercover police officers, who will be scouring the city for everything from ticket scalpers to drunken drivers, any kind of questionable activity could lead to an embarrassing arrest.

Service today 10AM, ''Parkside'' Memorial Chapel, 2576 Flatbush Avenue, Brooklyn, New York (near Avenue V).

title: AT&T to Invest $250 Million In Application Services Sector
description: Trying to tap into a new sector, the AT&T Corporation plans to announce today that it will invest $250 million in the next three years to expand its presence in the developing business of managing software applications for corporate customers.

title: CANADIAN RAIL GAINS
description: Riding the strong North American economy, Canadian National Railway, which is seeking approval to merge with Burlington Northern Santa Fe, posted solid gains for the fourth quarter of 1999 and the full year. Fourth-quarter profit rose 17 percent, to 213 million Canadian dollars ($148 million), or 1.03 dollars a share, on a 4 percent increase in revenue to 1.4 billion dollars. For the year, profit almost tripled to 746 million dollars, or 3.71 dollars a share. Revenue of 5.2 billion dollars was up 28 percent. Timothy Pritchard

title: China Lists Controls To Restrict the Use Of E-Mail and Web
description: The Chinese government issued stern new regulations today that were intended to control the release of information on the Internet, underscoring the government's love-hate relationship with cyberspace in a country where the number of Internet users is growing dramatically.

title: Philip Morris Net Income Is Up, Aided by Rise in Cigarette Prices
description: The Philip Morris Companies said yesterday that fourth-quarter earnings rose 2.7 percent, bolstered by higher cigarette prices.

title: Optimism at Global Trade Talks on Genetically Modified Crops
description: Negotiators trying to forge the first global treaty regulating trade in genetically modified products have tentatively agreed to eliminate some of what the United States government feared would be onerous restrictions on American farm exports.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  AMES, AMYAS
description: AMES-Amyas., 93. Formerly of New York, died peacefully at home in Lexington, Massachusetts, on Monday, January 24, 2000. He is survived by his beloved wife Lucia Millham Ames, two sons Oakes and Edward Ames of New York City, two daughters Olivia Hoblitzelle of Cambridge, MA., and Joan Ames of Eugene, OR., 11 grandchildren and six great grandchildren. A Memorial Service will be held at 11:30AM on February 4th at the First Parish Church, 14 Bedford Road, Lincoln, MA. In lieu of flowers memorial contributions may be made to the Brookhaven Nature Trail Fund, Brookhaven at Lexington, 1010 Waltham St, Lexington, MA. 02173.

title: CAPITAL FOR DAEWOO MOTOR
description: As part of its preparations to sell the Daewoo Motor Company in an international auction, South Korean creditor banks will inject fresh money into the ailing carmaker, according to the main creditor, the Korea Development Bank. The capital injection involves 1.5 trillion won ($1.3 billion) worth of debt-to-equity swaps, 7.3 trillion won in convertible bonds and 900 billion won in fresh operational capital. Domestic creditors have also promised to provide $2.35 billion in trade finance, in addition to reducing interest rates. Samuel Len

title: Audit Finds Financial Abuses At a Nassau Day Care Center
description: As Nassau County struggles to become solvent, a county audit released today found that a Freeport day care center overcharged the government by $482,000 while spending money on Broadway tickets, Champagne and expensive perquisites for the family members of its executive director.

title: PEARSON SELLS SHARES
description: The British media company Pearson P.L.C. has sold 11.5 million new shares worth $411 million to finance its emerging Internet businesses, which include the Web site of The Financial Times, ft.com. The company said the sale represented 1.9 percent of its share capital. The shares were sold at 2,200 pence a share. The stock fell 62 pence, to 2,260 pence. Andrew Ross Sorkin

title: Young America Designer Ends Silence on Mishap
description: For the second time in four days, the lack of consistent breeze forced the cancellation of a scheduled contest today in the final round of the Louis Vuitton Cup series to determine the challenger in next month's America's Cup match with Team New Zealand.

title: Gaining Freedom by Modem
description: At the end of the 20th century, American foreign policy acquired a new premise: history is on the side of freedom as never before. The basic idea is that economic and political liberty -- which always had a fairly close relationship -- are now, suddenly, joined at the hip. What joined them is information technology. As President Clinton said in 1998, justifying his policy of economic engagement with China: ''In this global information age, when economic success is built on ideas, personal freedom is essential to the greatness of any modern nation.''

title: Tax Cuts and Merit Pay System Are at Heart of Giuliani Budget
description: Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani called yesterday for an end to automatic pay raises for unionized city workers, from trash collectors to teachers, and proposed $2 billion in tax cuts over the next four years to residents and businesses as part of a $36.8 billion budget he released.

title: State Photo Card Is Proposed to Regulate New Handguns
description: President Clinton tonight proposed a nationwide system to regulate all future handgun purchases that would rely on the states to issue licenses with photographs but only to prospective buyers who could show they had no criminal records and had passed gun safety courses.

title: DINER'S JOURNAL
description: For years the east balcony of Grand Central Terminal was dominated by a giant Kodak sign. Now there's Metrazur, an American brasserie that for a long time looked as if it would never get on track. The restaurant, named after a train that runs along the French Riviera, was originally a joint venture between East Balcony Restaurant Associates and Matthew Kenney, the executive chef at Matthew's. After long delays, however, Mr. Kenney sold his interest and the baton was passed to Tony Fortuna and Charlie Palmer, who opened the Lenox Room together on the Upper East Side. Seemingly overnight, Metrazur pulled its act together and opened.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ADORAM, ELIEZER

description: Germany ended a decade of turbulent debate today over how to commemorate the Holocaust in its new capital by dedicating a vast site beside the Brandenburg Gate for a memorial designed by a New York architect.

title: Ed Clark, 88, Eye Behind Memorable Photos
description: Ed Clark, the veteran Life photographer who soon after President Franklin D. Roosevelt's death caught a nation's grief in the tear-stained face of a Navy bandsman playing an accordion salute, died on Saturday at his home in Sarasota, Fla. He was 88.

title: Mayor Giuliani's Election-Year Budget
description: An ebullient Mayor Rudolph Giuliani took the press and other onlookers through an elaborate slide show of his new four-year financial plan yesterday, missing no opportunity to congratulate himself for saving New York City from the financial mess left by his predecessors. He pointed with pride to this year's $2.2 billion surplus and said his plan would keep spending growing in line with inflation, cut taxes, avoid accounting gimmicks and reform the way the city negotiates with unions.

title: New F.A.A. Computers on the Job in Syracuse
description: A new computer system for air traffic control -- so far behind schedule that last year federal officials gave up predicting when it would be finished -- has begun service in Syracuse.

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about the selection of Hans Blix as the chief inspector of the United Nations' new disarmament commission for Iraq rendered a word incorrectly in a quotation from John Ritchie, the United States ambassador to the International Atomic Energy Agency. He said that new inspection authority and investigative technologies acquired by the agency when Mr. Blix was its director were ''now'' being put into effect worldwide; he did not say ''not.''

title: WORLD BUSINESS BRIEFING: AMERICAS; AMERICAN EXPRESS IN MEXICO
description: Offering direct banking services in Mexico for the first time, American Express Bank (Mexico) introduced a mutual fund and three other personal investment products that are aimed at middle- and higher-income families. American Express executives said that Mexico was a test market in Latin America. Customers will be able to buy the funds by phone or by computer. Dan Fineren

title: Sara Lee Sets Timetable for Shift in Power
description: John H. Bryan, the longtime top executive at Sara Lee who helped transform the company into one of the world's largest consumer packaged goods concerns, said today that he would step down as chief executive in July.

description: ABC Sports dashed any hope for a college football playoff yesterday by signing the Bowl Championship Series to a four-year extension worth about $400 million through 2006.

title: Navigating Keyboards With Bach
description: THE last Bach year wasn't so long ago: 1985, to be exact, the 300th anniversary of the composer's birth. And although Bach had to share the celebration with other masters born in the fateful, fertile year 1685, Handel and Scarlatti, he did not lack for attention.

title: After Sex Case, Guards' Union Vows To Keep Men's Jobs in Women's Jail
description: The day after sex abuse charges were brought against four Westchester County jail guards, their union said today that it would file suit to block the county's plan to stop using men to guard female inmates' living units.

description: An administrative judge has ruled against the Securities and Exchange Commission in a case against KPMG L.L.P. that was a cornerstone of the agency's effort to ensure the integrity of corporate financial statements.

title: ADIDAS TO STREAMLINE
description: The world's secondlargest sporting-goods maker, Adidas-Salomon A.G., said it would narrow its product range and streamline management to raise per-share earnings by 15 percent a year, starting in 2001. The shares rose 6 percent. Herbert Hainer, who was named deputy chief executive in November, said per-share earnings will fall 20 percent this year after a charge of 75 million marks ($38 million) for the cost cutting and expansion of online sales. No charges are planned for 2001.

title: Public Interests; Dignity, Always Dignity
description: We have finally had a moment in the 2000 presidential race that you are going to be sorry you missed, people. I am speaking, of course, about this week's Republican debate, when the social conservative Gary Bauer turned on the ultra-social-conservative Alan Keyes and said, ''I was a little surprised this week to see you fall into a mosh pit while a band called Rage Against the Machine played.''

title: RENAULT SALES RISE
description: Europe's No. 5 automaker, Renault S.A., said its fourth-quarter 1999 sales rose 10.8 percent, helped by strong sales of the Clio, above, its small car, and a buoyant French economy. Sales climbed to 59.8 billion French francs ($9.1 billion) from 53.9 billion francs a year earlier. In the full year, sales rose 5.2 percent to 247 billion francs.

title: U.S. APPEALS STEEL RULING

The injury could cause him to miss the entire year and already has the Yankees looking for another infielder.

description: The Clinton administration issued a public warning to Pakistan today that it could be branded a state sponsor of terrorism -- ending any hope for a resumption of large-scale American aid -- if the Pakistani Army continued to support terrorists blamed for the hijacking of an Indian Airlines jet last month.

title: Panel Chosen to Monitor Search for Schools Chief
description: Mark Green, New York City's public advocate, has appointed a panel to monitor the Board of Education's search for a permanent schools chancellor, saying it will give parents, advocates and business leaders a voice in the process.

title: HEALTH CARE WEB SITE OPERATOR SELLS SHARES TO JANUS
description: Continuing its recent flurry of deals, a health care Web site operator, the Healtheon/WebMD Corporation, said yesterday that it would sell 15 million restricted shares to the Janus Capital Corporation, a mutual fund group, for $930 million, or $62 a share. Shares of Healtheon/WebMD rose $4.75, to $71.0625, in Nasdaq trading. The company has 146.8 million shares outstanding. Janus Capital is a unit of Kansas City Southern Industries. Healtheon/WebMD said it would use the proceeds from the sale to pay for the cash portion of its pending acquisition of the Envoy Corporation.

title: Why the Titans Will Win
description: Gregg Williams, Tennessee's defensive coordinator, was asked how difficult it is for an offense to play the week following a game against Tampa Bay's hard-hitting defense. A smile went across Williams's face. After St. Louis had beaten Tampa Bay in the National Football Conference championship game, Rams players were limping around as if they had just played two games instead of one.

title: Tyson Draws Crowds and Praise
description: Mike Tyson and Julius Francis stood face to face yesterday on stage at the MEN Arena in Manchester, England, site of their heavyweight bout tomorrow night. Francis did not bother to remove his dark sunglasses, his stereo headphones or his black wool cap for the affair.

title: Gillette's Struggles Become Clear in Earnings Decline
description: Gillette not so proudly affirmed its place within the ranks of struggling consumer products companies yesterday, reporting lower sales and earnings for the fourth quarter of 1999.

description: The federal government decided today to postpone a decision on whether to block the proposed $30 billion merger of BP Amoco and Atlantic Richfield after the companies made a new offer to divest themselves of further assets, people involved in the discussions said.

description: A Brooklyn man accused of driving a Buick LeSabre at 117 miles per hour early yesterday became the first person to lose his car under a new city policy aimed at confiscating the vehicles of reckless drivers, the police said.

title: METLIFE ACQUIRING UNITS OF BUSINESS MEN'S ASSURANCE
description: The Metropolitan Life Insurance Company said yesterday that it had agreed to acquire the group workplace benefits division of the Business Men's Assurance Company. MetLife -- which recently filed for an initial public offering -- said it would acquire $100 million of group life and disability premiums that are marketed primarily to small and midsize businesses. MetLife will maintain the division's operations in Kansas City, Mo., and 17 other offices across the country. Business Men's Assurance is a unit of Assicurazioni Generali S.p.A. of Italy. MetLife, a New York-based insurer, has $404.2 billion of assets under management.

title: Camping Trip to Susann's Valley
description: Reading a Jacqueline Susann novel is like watching a drunk disarm a bomb, an experience that makes you flinch and generates a freakish kind of excitement. The kind of lurid pulp that we now take for granted -- with titles that sound like soft-core porn movies from the pay-per-view channels -- was a genre that Susann took to a new, sweaty level with books like ''Valley of the Dolls'' and ''The Love Machine.'' Humid novels about wide-eyed girl victims sucked into the world of sex, drugs, sex, celebrities and (gasp) sex while being romanced by heart-of-stone guys had been written before. But never in the way that Susann did, with the contradictory elements of pleasure in mining that mother lode of cubic zirconium and an undercurrent of sheer rage.

title: Editorial Observer; The Fight for an Open Presidential Primary
description: Gov. George W. Bush of Texas has taken to defending the rigged ballot rules for New York's March 7 Republican primary as a reasonable test of a candidate's grass-roots support in the state. He thus echoes the innocuous-sounding arguments put forth by his New York handlers, Gov. George Pataki and the state G.O.P. chairman, William Powers. But the intricate ballot rules for the Republican primary are in fact calibrated unfairly to exclude as many candidates as possible except for the one favored by state party leaders. This exclusionary system will be challenged today when lawyers representing Senator John McCain appear in federal court seeking to overturn the election rules as an unconstitutional burden on voting rights.

title: 'Pretty Woman,' Then and Now

''He said, 'I have this piece that's a little too dark for us, but maybe you can give it a different twist,' '' Mr. Marshall recalled this week. As a reference point, they used ''Mona Lisa,'' Neil Jordan's fine, dark film about a call girl. ''He said, 'If 'Mona Lisa' is a 2 and 'My Fair Lady' is a 10, give me a 7 or an 8,' '' Mr. Marshall continued.

title: Serenity Made Visible: Korea's Ceramic Art
description: ''Korean Ceramics from the Museum of Oriental Ceramics, Osaka'' is not, as Yogi Berra might have said, a case of deja vu all over again. More than 35 of the 48 pieces in this serenely beautiful show were part of a larger exhibition of ceramics from the same museum that traveled to Chicago, San Francisco and the Met in 1992. But it scarcely matters. The recidivists, like the first-timers, constitute the masterworks of the Osaka museum's extensive Korean holdings. They account rather fully for the innovations and high points of Korea's ceramic art, which occurred with impressive regularity throughout the Koryo (918-1392) and Choson (1392-1910) dynasties. In addition, seeing them cloistered in the Met's intimate yet spare, white-on-white Korean arts gallery, which opened in 1997, is an exceptional viewing experience.

description: BACHMANN-Louis, Jr., 83, of Stamford, CT., and New York City died peacefully at home, January 26, 2000. Beloved father and father-in-law of Bonnie and Tom Strauss. Devoted grandfather of Tracey M. and Elizabeth B. Strauss and step-grandfather of Peter B. Strauss, fond cousin of Frederick M. and Richard M. Danziger. He graduated from Phillips Exeter Academy and attended M.I.T. He joined L. Bachmann & Co. in 1937, which had been founded by his father in 1898, and subsequently served as a Captain in the Marine Corps during World War II. In 1946, he became President of Bachmann Uxbridge Worsted Co., the successor company to L. Bachmann & Co., which completed an IPO in 1951. Through a succession of mergers involving Bachmann Uxbridge Worsted, he became a Vice President and a Director of Amerace Corporation. His philanthropic activities included the chairmanship of the Clothing and Woolens division of the Federation of Jewish Philanthropies in 1948 and membership on Federation's Board in 1951. He was voted an honorary member of the Board of Trustees of the Lexington School for the Deaf in 1972. He served on the Board of Trustees of Elmira College from 1972 to 1985 and the following year received an honorary degree, Doctor of Laws. In 1993, he was elected an Honorary Director of the Dystonia Medical Research Foundation. He also served as Secretary and Member of the Board of Trustees of the Bachmann Strauss Dystonia & Parkinson Foundation from its inception in 1995. Service will be private. The family will receive at home on Friday, January 28th, Saturday, January 29th and Sunday, January 30th from 5:00 to 7:00 P.M. A memorial service is planned for February 11, 2000 at 4:00 P.M. in the Goldwurm Auditorium, Mount Sinai Medical Center, East Building, 1425 Madison Avenue, between 98th and 99th Streets. Milwaukee-based Brady said the hostile offer followed three friendly approaches in the last year, the most recent of which was last week. Including the 14.9 percent stake it already owns, Brady says it has the backing of owners of 43 percent of Critchley's shares.

It pauses to record, with admirable tact and affection, the pillow talk of young lovers after their first night together, and it does not flinch from the tears and accusations that ensue when things begin to go wrong between them.

title: Austria's Extremist Temptation

Austria's two other main parties, the Socialists and the conservative People's Party, could have kept Freedom out of power, either by continuing their 13-year-old power-sharing arrangement or by permitting the largest party, the Socialists, to form a minority government. Equitable Resources Inc., an energy company in Pittsburgh, bought the rest of MCN Energy's Appalachian properties for about $10 million.

It said Palm, which is based in Santa Clara, Calif., would have 570 million shares outstanding after the sale. title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHUBART, MARK
description: SCHUBART-Mark. With great sadness and a great sense of loss, the Board, staff, and friends of Lincoln Center for the Performing Arts, Inc., mourn the sudden passing of Mark Schubart, Founding Director and Chairman Emeritus of Lincoln Center Institute for the Arts in Education, and former Board Member and Director Emeritus of Lincoln Center for the Performing Arts. A true visionary, Mr. Schubart transformed the way that students and teachers interact with the arts by building Lincoln Center Institute into one of the nation's leading arts in education organizations. Under his nurturing leadership, the Institute's success grew into an international movement, with a network of affiliated institutes across the country and overseas. After completing two decades of service, Mr. Schubart became the Institute's fourth Chairman of the Board (1995-1998), and was subsequently named Chairman Emeritus. He first joined Lincoln Center in 1963 as its Director of Education, after serving as Director of Public Activities, Dean, and then Vice President of The Juilliard School of Music. Though his passion and commitment to the cause of education will be sorely missed, his spirit shines brightly through the ongoing work of the Institute. We extend our deepest sympathies to best friend Martin Rapp, his sisterin-law Margaret Schubart and eight nieces and nephews. Beverly Sills, Chairman Nathan Leventhal, President Lincoln Center for the Performing Arts, Inc. Scott Noppe-Brandon, Executive Director Bonnie Himmelman, Acting Chair Lincoln Center Institute for the Arts in Education

A retired Variety columnist, magician, theatrical booking agent, and worker for the American Civil Liberties Union and the American Friends Service Committee, he was born December 13, 1906 to Rudolf and Lulu Heine Reinhart. He was a graduate of Harvard and of NYU, was married to the late Catherine Johnson, and is survived by nieces and nephews. Donations may be made to Houdini Hospital Fund, 1735 East 26th Street, Brooklyn, NY 11229.

title: Spano Draws Prison Term For Fraud in Islanders Deal
description: John Spano, the poker-faced hockey fan who took control of the Islanders in 1997 with loans he had obtained illegally, was sentenced yesterday to 71 months in federal prison for bank and wire fraud.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  MIHLRAD, JACK
description: MIHLRAD-Jack. 5/17/14-1/29/95. Love is eternal, everlasting and unconditional. Always, Diane and Mom

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MELTZER, NEWTON
description: MELTZER-Newton. 80, of Roslyn Heights, L.I., on January 22. Independent writer, director and producer of documentaries, features and short subjects for film and television. Survived by his wife, Barbara, daughter Erica, son Stephen, and three grandchildren.

title: Officer Killed In Car Crash During Chase
description: A police sergeant from Middletown, Conn., chasing burglary suspects on a state highway at 80 to 85 miles per hour yesterday was killed after his car veered off the highway and crashed into trees.

title: Court Dismisses City's First Car Seizure Case
description: The first criminal case brought under the city's year-old policy of seizing the cars of people arrested on drunken driving charges was tossed out of court yesterday after the Brooklyn district attorney's office said that one of the arresting officers had been charged with perjury in a similar matter and that the arrest had been riddled with ''sloppy mistakes.''

title: Bush Makes Effort Outside New Hampshire
description: Locked in a tight race with Senator John McCain four days before the nation's first primary, Gov. George W. Bush has taken steps to cushion himself against a possible loss here by intensifying advertising and organizational efforts in states where he had not planned such heavy early investments.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Wednesday about Susan and Alan Raymond, the makers of ''Children in War,'' a television documentary to be shown Monday night on HBO, referred incorrectly to the cable network's experience with documentaries. HBO indeed originates and finances most of its documentaries, as it has ''Children in War,'' rather than buying films or works in progress.

title: Schools Chancellor Hires Aide for Privatization
description: Harold O. Levy, the interim New York City schools chancellor, has hired an executive assistant to oversee possible privatization efforts at the Board of Education.

title: SOFTBANK TO SPIN OFF ZIFF-DAVIS'S ONLINE UNIT
description: The Softbank Corporation of Tokyo, owner of a 69 percent stake in Ziff-Davis Inc., plans to spin off the United States company's online unit, ZDNet, and is in talks to sell its events unit, operator of the Comdex technology trade shows. Softbank, Japan's largest Internet investment company, will hold 45 percent of the independent ZDNet. The deal helps transform Ziff-Davis from a traditional media company into an Internet company. It will wrap its remaining assets into ZDNet, whose Web sites offer news, product listings and reviews and are among the most visited on the Internet. ZDNet shares fell $2.1875, to $27.875; Ziff-Davis fell 93.75 cents, to $17.875.

title: Hurricanes Catch Devils With Their Guard Down
description: Losses have been infrequent over the last month for the Devils, who had dropped only one of their 15 games before tonight on their way to achieving the best record in the National Hockey League.

title: Heavy Snow Gives South Rare Taste of Real Winter
description: A heavy blast of snow cut across parts of the Southeast today, forcing schools and businesses to close and slowing traffic in Arkansas, Mississippi and Tennessee. The storm weakened as it moved east into Alabama, but forecasters predicted that another storm could move into Georgia on Saturday, threatening to disrupt Super Bowl events in Atlanta this weekend.

title: To Create a Poem, Perchance to Go Free
description: To the Editor:

title: Tragedy or Comedy? Just Ask the Bass at the Met
description: ''Les Contes d'Hoffmann'' is a theatrical work hinged in the middle, capable of opening in two directions. Is it tragedy with comic properties, or comedy with a little of the tragic around the edges? Offenbach composed it with an eye to the first; a famous maker of musical farce, he was determined to write a serious opera. The Metropolitan Opera's 18-year-old production, which returned to the house on Thursday night, seems willing to go either way depending on the cast and the mood of the moment. A revival two years ago took dead aim at the gravity and hallucinatory scariness Offenbach seems to have intended, and created some very moving evenings of opera.

title: Oscar Wilde As a Rocket, Housman As a Shadow
description: Why, there's Oscar Wilde again, looking ever so sleek. The aesthete par excellence, who has been represented in melancholy terms of late, shows up fully restored to his flamboyant glory in Tom Stoppard's ''Invention of Love,'' which is receiving its American premiere here, insisting that he has no regrets after all. ''Better a fallen rocket,'' he declares in a voice that does indeed soar like a Roman candle, ''than never a burst of light.''

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-6

title: City Hall Accepts Bids to Operate Airports
description: Mayor Fiorello H. La Guardia, jealous of Newark Airport's trailblazing role in the infant aviation industry back in 1939, wanted New York to have its own bustling airport and decided to build two. But just nine years later, Mayor William O'Dwyer -- chafing under the airports' high costs -- signed a longterm lease ceding their operation to the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey.

title: Amazon.com Tumbles After Layoffs Are Discovered
description: January 28, 2000

title: From a Distance, Cuban Father Waits
description: Juan Miguel Gonzalez prefaces his answers to almost every question about his 6-year-old son, Elian, with a sigh and the word ''imaginate'' -- imagine, which has been all he has been able to do since the boy emerged at the fiery heart of an ideologically charged custody battle.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: ITEQ INC., Houston, a maker of natural gas and liquid processing equipment, agreed to sell its HMT storage tank-maintenance unit to a company led by the closely held Nassau Point Investors L.L.C. for $40 million.

title: Nets Want Van Horn And Kittles to Step Up
description: It would be easy to pity the Nets as a team that has simply been on the wrong end of some incomprehensible, last-second shots; as a club that would have won its last two games were it not for two freakish occurrences at the buzzer.

title: VERITAS CASH PRICE FOR ATP IS CUT TO $67 MILLION
description: Veritas Capital Fund, a private investment fund in New York, and Advanced Technical Products of Roswell, Ga., announced a revised deal in which the price Veritas pays for each ATP share is lowered to $12.75 from the $14.50 that was set when Veritas agreed in September to acquire ATP for $135 million, including debt. The move cuts the cash part of the deal to $67.6 million from $76.9 million. The companies attributed the termination of the original deal to recent developments at the Alcore division of ATP. In early January, the company said the federal government had served Alcore a warrant to search for financial and other information. ATP shares were up $2.0625, at $9.50.

title: The Big City; Rudeness And Riches Dot-Com
description: HALF the commercials during tomorrow's Super Bowl will be for young dot-com companies, and some not-so-young executives in New York will be watching with mixed emotions. They're delighted at all the money flowing back east to Madison Avenue and the old-media world here, but they have some qualms about the people spending it.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  GAYLE, MICHAEL
description: GAYLE-Michael. 2/29/60-1/29/96. The secret tears still flow, only those who really love you, really know. Sadly missed by father, Dudley; sister, Andrea; wife, Sonia; son, Christopher; Gladstone; nieces and nephew.

title: Abroad at Home; The Court Sees Reality
description: In the struggle to stop the corrupting flood of big money into our politics, the Republicans who oppose reform have relied on a constitutional argument. The First Amendment bars any limits on campaign financing, they say: Political money is speech!

title: Terror Suspect Is Rearrested In Africa at U.S. Request
description: A leading suspect in an aborted terrorist plot, who the authorities believe is linked to the Osama bin Laden terror network, has been arrested in Mauritania, after he was briefly detained and released in Senegal, law enforcement officials said today.

title: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
description: PLATINUM RISES. -- Platinum futures rose 1.8 percent to a 2 1/2-year high after Russian exporters said shipments were being delayed. In New York, platinum for delivery in April rose $8.20, to $453.80 an ounce.

title: INTERNATIONAL RECTIFIER TO BUY ZING FOR $28.5 MILLION
description: The International Rectifier Corporation, a supplier of power semiconductors in El Segundo, Calif., agreed to buy Zing Technologies of Valhalla, N.Y., for $28.5 million to improve its sales of products for aerospace and other power-systems applications. Zing stockholders will get $15.36 for each share. Zing's board has approved the sale, and shareholders owning about 57 percent of Zing shares have agreed to sell. International Rectifier's products squeeze more power per watt from electronic devices and are used in motor controls, cellular telephones and computers. International Rectifier shares were down 6.25 cents, at $33.875, while Zing was up 37.5 cents, at $15.375.

title: Friedrich Gulda, 69, Classical-Music Rebel
description: Friedrich Gulda, an iconoclastic Austrian pianist and composer who was as renowned for his jazz performances as for the intellectual clarity of his Bach, Mozart and Beethoven interpretations, died on Thursday at his home in Weissenbach, Austria. He was 69.

title: F.T.C. Puts Off Hearing on BP-ARCO Deal
description: The Federal Trade Commission today rescheduled its hearing to consider whether to block the proposed $30 billion merger of BP Amoco P.L.C. and ARCO.

title: NO BANKS FOR KOREAN CONGLOMERATES
description: The South Korean government will not allow the nation's major business conglomerates to own banks, the office of President Kim Dae Jung quoted Lee Ki Ho, left, senior secretary to the president for economic affairs, as saying. Mr. Lee, who is in Davos, Switzerland, for the World Economic Forum, made the remarks on Thursday. He also said he expected interest rates in South Korea to fall below 10 percent in the second half of this year, after the redemption early next month of bonds issued by the ailing Daewoo Group. Samuel Len (NYT)

title: Biotech Negotiators Press Past Deadline
description: Negotiators from more than 130 countries trying to create a treaty regulating trade in genetically modified crops passed a Friday midnight deadline with no accord, and one participant said it could take several more hours to resolve the outstanding issues.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KLEIN, BERTRAM L.
description: KLEIN-Bertram L., of White Plains, NY on January 27, 2000 age 83 years. Husband of Mary Shraberg Klein, father of Dr. Noah W. (Beverly) Klein, the Honorable David (Ellen) Klein, Jonathan J. (Barbara) Klein, Daniel E. Klein. Brother of Harriet K. Frank and the late Miles Klein. Grandfather of Benjamin, Ethan, Jennifer Klein Baldinger, Susanna, Jason, Michael, Rachel. Great grandfather of Jack Baldinger. Funeral service Sunday 11:45AM at The Chapel in the Woods at Congregation Kol Ami, Soundview Avenue, White Plains, NY. Interment Mount Pleasant Cemetery. Memorial contributions to the charity of ones choice would be appreciated.

description: President Clinton's proposal to license all new handgun buyers is unlikely to get through Congress and would be even harder to implement around the country. But the president has stepped onto what many regard as the next battleground for gun control.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ADLOW, SAM
description: ADLOW-Sam, 86. Of Whitestone, N.Y. Passed away on January 27, 2000. He is lovingly remembered by his wife Kay, children Karen and Herb Unterlack and Rita and Steven Adlow, grandchildren Michelle and Evan Unterlack and Stacey and Andrew Unterlack and Cindy Adlow and great-grandchild Jessica and many nieces and nephews. Services will be held at Temple Emanuel, Great Neck, N.Y. Sunday, January 30, 10:30AM.

title: Sports of The Times; Professionals Still in Need Of Mentors
description: BOBBY BELL yesterday lamented the passing of an era. The former Kansas City linebacker and a member of the Pro Football Hall of Fame was on a panel composed of 1970 Super Bowl participants. Two more former Chiefs, Willie Lanier and Jan Stenerud, were on the panel, along with Lamar Hunt, the team owner. Bud Grant, the former Minnesota coach, sat with two of his players, Paul Krause and Alan Page.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RAUCH, NEAL
description: RAUCH-Neal. West Palm Beach, Fla. Neal Rauch, age 51, died suddenly on Wednesday, January 23, 2000 in West Palm Beach, Fla., where he had resided since 1977. He graduated from Cornell University and Syracuse University Law School. He practiced law in New York State, and was a developer and a pilot in Palm Beach County, Flordia. He is survived by a son, Nicholas Rauch-Heine, and a brother Harry Rauch both of West Palm Beach, Fla. There will be no local arrangments.

title: They're No. 2, but Ready in a Snap
description: Neil O'Donnell was heading to the Newark airport for a trip to Nashville last summer. He told his friends in Madison, N.J., that he was going to play for the Tennessee Titans.

title: Collage of Past and Future Reveals State of the Union
description: If you were to freeze random television frames from Bill Clinton's State of the Union address, you might get a dignified presidential portrait. You might just as easily get an image with the eerie wit of a Salvador Dali painting or a Monty Python montage of floating heads: there is Vice President Al Gore's left eye, hovering spectrally over the president's shoulder; when the vice president stands, his disembodied left hand with wristwatch applauds.

description: January 27, 2000

title: Christie's Says It Is Cooperating With Antitrust Inquiry in Art World
description: Christie's, the worldwide auction house, said yesterday that it had given federal investigators information about ''possible conduct'' at the firm that was relevant to an antitrust investigation in the art world.

title: Times Co. Plans Stock Issue To Track Its Internet Assets
description: The New York Times Company announced plans yesterday to issue a new class of stock that will track the value of the company's Internet properties. In doing so it becomes one of the first newspaper companies moving to capitalize on investor enthusiasm for the Internet.

title: Op Art
Comeback Time in Japan For 3 Big Brokerage Firms
description: Japan's three largest brokerage firms reported their best profits in a decade today, illustrating a strong comeback from severe weakness just a few years ago and defying predictions of their demise.

title: A Virtuoso With a Visa To the Salon
description: Salon music -- virtuoso miniatures played for intimate, privileged audiences -- is back, and it can be a wonderful thing. Nadja Salerno-Sonnenberg, a violinist who's used to concert halls, made her cabaret debut on Wednesday night at Joe's Pub. She was performing music from her new album, a collaboration with the guitarists Sergio and Odair Assad on the Nonesuch label, that leaps national and stylistic borders in search of passion.

title: Bonilla May Play at Shea, But in a Braves Uniform
description: They kept the Mets from a playoff berth with a season-ending sweep in 1998. They eliminated the Mets in the National League Championship Series in 1999. They are John Rocker's team.

title: U.S. ACKNOWLEDGES RADIATION KILLED WEAPONS WORKERS
description: After decades of denials, the government is conceding that since the dawn of the atomic age, workers making nuclear weapons have been exposed to radiation and chemicals that have produced cancer and early death.

description: To the Editor:

title: Lawyers Get A Lecture From Judge In Boy's Case
description: The federal judge hearing the appeal by relatives of Elian Gonzalez to raise him in Miami, away from his father in Cuba, told their legal team today to stop all its ''hoopla'' and ''excesses'' in rallying public opinion.
