description: Ziff-Davis to 'Merge' With ZDNet Tracking Stock

title: The Other Battle of Bermuda Was Fought by Computers
description: One of the events at the World Championships in Bermuda earlier this month was decidedly unusual. It was the Orbis World Computer Championship, and it attracted a field of eight programs. They played a round robin of qualifying team matches, leading to semifinal and final playoffs. Effectively, there were four copies of each program, playing North, South, East and West.

title: Problems of Poor Persist Past the Holiday Season
description: The holiday season is over, and in recent weeks fewer people have sent in contributions to The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund. But the needs of the city's poorest citizens have not gone away.

title: RECYCLED GENERATION
description: Stem-cell research could lead to an endless supply of body parts. But it is bogged down in abortion politics, corporate rivalries and the questionable worth of human beings' living to be 150. A report by Stephen S. Hall in The Times Magazine.

title: Dispute Over Road in Nevada Rallies Anti-Government Forces
description: It is a narrow dead-end dirt road, ribbing along a narrow canyon for barely more than a mile before it hits wilderness. Snow puts it out of commission for half the year, rains can do it in entirely, and even then, only hikers and campers really miss it, as a means to a favorite trail head.

title: Japan to Turn To Direct Loans From Its Banks
description: In a striking demonstration of how precarious Japan's financial situation has become, the government plans to borrow money directly from banks to fulfill its obligations to local governments.

title: MONSANTO SPURNED OFFER FOR $49 A SHARE, FILING SHOWS
description: The Monsanto Company spurned a $49-a-share offer from a ''non-U.S.-headquartered'' company before deciding to merge with Pharmacia & Upjohn Inc. in a deal that values Monsanto at its current stock price of $36 a share, according to regulatory filings. Monsanto and Pharmacia filed a draft of their merger agreement yesterday. Under the agreement, Pharmacia shareholders will receive 1.19 shares of the merged company for each share of the company held. Each Monsanto share would be swapped for one share of the merged company. Analysts have said that the Swiss drugmaker Novartis wanted to enter the United States market and could have been a bidder for Monsanto.

title: Ex-Yeltsin Aide Denies Reports In Swiss Money-Laundering Case
description: A senior aide to former President Boris N. Yeltsin, apparently charged in a Swiss money-laundering case, said today that the accusations were slanderous and that he would face questioning in Switzerland if asked.

title: DoubleClick in Privacy Suit
description: DoubleClick in Privacy Suit

title: CHICAGO AD FIRM TO BUY SPR, COMPUTER SERVICES COMPANY
description: The advertising firm Leapnet Inc. said it had agreed to acquire SPR Inc., a computer technology services company, for about $92 million in stock. Both are based in Chicago. SPR shareholders will receive 1.085 Leapnet shares for every SPR share, representing a 28 percent premium at Thursday's closing prices. SPR has 12.8 million shares outstanding. SPR shares fell 62.5 cents yesterday, to $5, and Leapnet was down 90.625 cents, at $5.71875. Leapnet expects the combined company to generate revenue of $80 million during the year.

title: January 23-29; New Focus in Terror Probe
description: The focus of inquiry into the group of Montreal-based men accused of plotting a terrorist attack in America has shifted from Algeria to Afghanistan. Though several of the Algerians accused in the plot were once members of an Algerian militant group that had never before targeted Americans, investigators have come to believe that the head of the alleged terrorist cell was a Mauritanian with ties not to Algeria, but to Osama bin Laden, the exiled Saudi charged in the 1998 bombing of two American embassies in Africa. At Washington's request, Senegal arrested the Mauritanian, Mohambedou Ould Slahi, the alleged head of the Montreal Algerian cell. The Justice Department sought his extradition to America. JUDITH MILLER

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STEINFELD, PHYLLIS
description: STEINFELD-Phyllis Frank. Beloved wife of the late Joseph Steinfeld. Your beautiful marriage of 60 years was an inspiration to us all. You will finally be together.

title: Shopper's Banquet
description: Now that Club Monaco and Banana Republic have made knockoffs fashionable, a shopping guide has arrived modeled after the Zagat Survey, down to the rectangular shape (it fits neatly into a Fendi baguette). Called ''F.Y.I. Fashion Source'' and published by Tara Lowenberg, a former film assistant, it lists 500 stores by neighborhood, from NoHo boutiques to Bloomingdales ($14.95 at Barnes & Noble and Hudson News). The guide rates service, presentation and quality (A to D), and expense (1 to 4 inside a piggy bank).

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ALLEN, BLANCHE
description: ALLEN-Blanche. Beautiful and devoted wife of the late Irving. Dear mother of Linda Zografos and the late Adrienne Schachter. Darling grandmother of Kenneth, Karen, and Chris Schachter and the late Amy Zografos. Private services were held.

title: Of E-Friendships and Fleeting Face Time
description: WHEN the younger brother of a dear friend moved to the city, fresh from Stanford with a doctorate and a willingness to convert to New York ways, my husband and I reached out with telephone numbers and a dinner invitation. When we asked the best way to keep in touch, his reply made me realize that he was on his way to becoming a true New Yorker.

title: David Williams Jr., 78, Energy Industry Executive
description: David R. Williams Jr., an industrialist and engineering innovator whose companies built and operated oil and gas pipelines in North and South America and the Middle East, died on Jan. 15 at his home in East Hampton, N.Y. He was 78.

title: The New Reign of the Park Avenue Princess
description: LAST September, at the Michael Kors spring fashion show, three sets of sisters, reed thin and crisply dressed, threaded their way past curious publicists and editors before piling into the front row. The Lauder, Boardman and Miller sisters may as well have been on the runway for all the frantic camera clicking, notepad filling and neck craning of bystanders angling for a closer look.

title: Two Colts Return in Dead Heat at Gulfstream
description: If the racing world was looking for an early clue to its Triple Crown candidates, it found two today. But they came with some confusion when More Than Ready ran a dead heat with Summer Note in the Hutcheson Stakes, the first major prep for the Kentucky Derby in Florida.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FARBER, PAUL
description: FARBER-Paul. Of Roanoke, VA and Fort Lauderdale, FL; formerly of NYC. Died January 28. Beloved husband of Bernice; devoted father of Dr. Steven (Cary), Jill, Dr. Ellen (Stephen Schofel) and Lois; grandfather of David, Heather, Sarah, Daniel and Lauren.

title: January 23-29; U.S. Warns Pakistan
description: It is certainly not a list most nations care to join. But the United States is warning Pakistan that it may soon join Iran and Iraq on the State Department's official list of nations that support terrorism, which could mean new economic sanctions on that already impoverished nation.

title: A Complex Plan's Aim: Simpler Zoning Rules
description: IN what may be the single boldest zoning proposal since 1961, New York City's planning chief, Joseph B. Rose, says he wants to simplify the rules governing the size of new buildings.

title: Corrections
description: An article in some copies last Sunday about the proposed Trump National Golf Club in Briarcliff Manor, N.Y., misstated the estimated dues. They are projected to be $9,000 a year; $150,000 will be the initiation fee after March 10. Until March 10 it is $100,000.

title: Editor's Note
description: An article last Sunday about older homes discussed the renovation of a Rockland County house by Margaret Noto Clark and her husband, noting that in recent months the walks they took around their property had to be curtailed as she became incapacitated by serious illness. On Jan. 20, after the article had gone to press, Mrs. Noto Clark died.

title: The Nation: Election Time in Iran; In Islam's State, an Islamic Cry for Change
description: WHEN he arrived at the shop of a specialist in old Islamic scripts in Teheran, the mullah, about 40, was neatly bearded in the way of the college-educated Shiite clerics. But he was dressed in a business suit, not his cleric's attire, and he was flustered.

title: Harold H. Greene, Judge Who Oversaw the Breakup of the AT&T Colossus, Dies at 76
description: Judge Harold H. Greene, a drafter of landmark civil rights and voting rights legislation but best known for presiding over the monumental 1984 dismemberment of American Telephone and Telegraph, died yesterday at his home in Washington.

title: The Very Important V.I.P. Goody Bag
description: THE gift bag, a k a the goody bag, was once a simple token of thanks handed out at the end of a party. Remember the favors looted from a friend's birthday in second grade? Balloons! A Milky Way. Oh, happy day! But lately, whether at a charity benefit, a movie premiere or a store opening, guests are getting, even demanding, gift bags crammed with a mother lode of gratitude.

title: No Frogs Allowed
description: BOARDING a bus on my first day of language school in Santiago, Chile, I spotted a sticker on the plastic partition behind the driver: a green cartoon frog in a circle with a diagonal line through it. ''No se admiten sapos,'' read the caption. To me, a beginner in Spanish, it was a language lesson: picture + words = ''No frogs allowed.'' But why prohibit frogs on buses? I made a note to ask a teacher when I got to my school.

title: O'Neal and Bryant Selected as Starters
description: The Los Angeles Lakers, with the best record in the N.B.A., will be the only team with two starters in the All-Star Game -- Shaquille O'Neal and Kobe Bryant.

title: Couple Are Killed in Plainfield House Fire
description: A young couple who met at a job-training program died early yesterday in a basement bedroom when a fire that might have been started by a space heater on a bitterly cold night roared through a dormitorylike house in Plainfield, N.J., fire officials said. Five other residents escaped unhurt.

title: At Trade Forum, Clinton Pleads for the Poor
description: Against a sudden wave of apparent angst among some corporate and political leaders about the growing gap between rich and poor, President Clinton made an impassioned appeal today to make global trade work for the poor, too.

title: Interest in Black Art Just Grew and Grew
description: TIMING is everything.

title: Bordeaux Style, From Napa
description: The '97 Hawk Crest cabarnet sauvignon is-no contest-finer than rivals costing twice, three times, even four times as much.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PRICE, ALVIN
description: PRICE-Alvin. The New York Times records with deep sorrow the passing of Alvin Price, associated with The Times from 1966 until retiring in 1992.

title: Bronx Residents Take Aim At City Hall's Armory Plan
description: Ronn Jordan grew up in the Fordham section of the Bronx. When he was 4 years old, during a bus ride in the northwest part of the borough, he caught his first glimpse of the Kingsbridge Armory, a massive medieval-looking structure at Jerome Avenue and West Kingsbridge Road.

title: Two Tides Are Rising In Retirement Plans
description: Employees have long been asking for more facts and more choices when it comes to retirement plans. It seems that many employers have heard them loud and clear.

title: At the End Of a Century, A Whisper
description: FOR their New Year's Eve concert here at the Philharmonie, the Berlin Philharmonic and its conductor, Claudio Abbado, came up with an extraordinary program that worked extraordinarily well: seven finales in a row, to mark the passing of the year and, depending on how you count, the century. It made one think about endings and about finales and, indeed, about the ending of the finale, for the latest finale in the sequence was the one from Prokofiev's ''Alexander Nevsky,'' written shortly before World War II.

title: Dinning Out; Exotic, Yes, but With Some Stumbles
description: DINERS are often the last to know when a restaurant changes hands. That is especially true if the name remains the same and the decor is untouched. Who really notices a different owner's name on business cards? Tuscany in Rockville Centre is a case in point.

title: Everybody Talks About It
description: THE CHANGE IN THE WEATHER People, Weather, and the Science of Climate. By William K. Stevens. 357 pp. New York: Delacorte Press. $24.95.

title: Back to School for Artists
description: Some children may sing their way to good hygiene in New Jersey schools next year, while older students might learning the art of dance or about the theater.

title: He's Just Barely Settled In, but Groh Holds Jets' Reins
description: In his first week on the job as the Jets' coach, Al Groh quickly understood the immediacy of the role he inherited under unsettling circumstances.

title: Something Borrowed May Leave Market Blue
description: STOCK investors may hope that the one-quarter-point increase in interest rates that is expected this week from the Federal Reserve Board will not do more damage to their already clipped holdings. But another matter that could affect them a bit more directly has floated onto the radar screen of regulators. That is the year-end surge in borrowing by stock investors, known as margin debt.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BYER, BETTE
description: BYER-Bette. Beloved wife of the late Maurice. Devoted mother of Stephanie Byer-Malk, Allan, Erica & Mindy (a.k.a. Martine). Cherished grandmother of Sacha and Gabriel. We will love you forever. Service private.

title: Analysts Question Wisdom of Bradley's New Aggressiveness
description: With its attacks against Vice President Al Gore's credibility, its use of the bitterly contentious issue of abortion and its targeted appeals to women, former Senator Bill Bradley's campaign today seemed to be engaging more than ever in the kind of political warfare Mr. Bradley has railed against in much of this race.

title: Bronx Tenants Demand Heat
description: Citing inadequate heat and demanding quicker repairs, better lighting and increased security, tenants of four apartment buildings in the Bronx protested yesterday at the offices of a major landlord with thousands of apartments in the borough.

description: To the Editor:

title: English Walks
description: To the Editor: For organized walking tours of the Lake District, I highly recommend Footpath Holidays in Wiltshire. Their groups seldom number more than 20, the leaders are skilled and interesting, and the accommodations are most comfortable, in some instances almost luxurious. title: Paid Notice: Deaths  COPELAND, VINCENT MICHAEL
description: COPELAND - Vincent Michael. Passed away surrounded by his wife and family on Wednesday, January 26th, at Grady Memorial Hospital in Atlanta from head injuries sustained in an automobile accident on January 19th. Vincent was born in Waco, TX on April 21st, 1959. Vincent was a sales pioneer in the information technology industry, first with the GartnerGroup in Stamford, CT and for almost the last year, as Executive Vice President for Worldwide Client Development for iXL, inc. of Atlanta, GA. Vincent started the GartnerGroup ITM service line and then moved on to direct Gartner's business in Canada, the Asia Pacific region, and Latin America, and finally, as Senior Vice President for North America. Vincent left the GartnerGroup last April to help direct iXL's Internet business growth. Vincent served on the Board of St. Luke's LifeWorks. He is survived by his wife, Kelly, two sons, Kevin (7 years old) and Christopher (4 years old) of Atlanta, GA and Westport, CT, his parents, William G. and Patricia A. Copeland of Stamford, CT, a brother, William of Villanova, PA, and four sisters, Patrice Ainsworth of Hopewell Junction, NY, Susan Donnelly of New Canaan, CT, Eileen Marks of Greenwich, CT and Kathleen Swanson of Mission Viejo, CA as well as seventeen nieces and nephews. A memorial mass will be held on Tuesday, February 1st, at 12 Noon at St. Catherine of Siena Church at 4 Riverside Ave., Riverside, CT, followed by a reception at the Round Hill Club in Greenwich, CT. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made in his memory to St. Luke's LifeWorks, 141 Franklin St., Stamford, CT 06901.

title: Books in Brief: Fiction & Poetry; There's Something in That Lake
description: Irene Ziegler's often sparkling, occasionally choppy collection of linked stories, RULES OF THE LAKE (Southern Methodist University, $19.95), opens in 1965, when 9-year-old Annie Bartlett yearns to becomes a mermaid -- sequined costume, air hose, flowing hair and all -- at Weeki Wachee Springs near her central Florida home. In 14 tales tracing the next seven years, Ziegler assembles a wry, freshly detailed coming-of-age story around Annie. The excellent title story reveals the kind of shadowy, shameful family secrets that never seem more glaring than in a postcard-perfect climate: Annie's depressed mother obsessively swims laps in Widow Lake, which abuts the Bartlett's shabby house; Annie's teenage sister, Leigh, taunts their father, who delivers fuel oil, for having an affair; and Annie -- only partially understanding her parents' marital troubles -- has a run-in with a mysterious lake creature. Throughout the book, Widow Lake shimmers with changeable symbolism -- sometimes as Annie's haven from worldly problems, sometimes as an unfathomably dangerous place -- but always offering a reflection of each story's psychological undercurrents. Unfortunately, several tales feel muddied by an overcrowded series of unhappy or tragic events -- such as those in ''Hooked,'' which somewhat numbingly recounts a sexual molestation, physical abuse and suicide. But in stories like ''The Treasure Hunter's Daughter'' -- in which Annie accompanies her handsome, moody, sometimes violent father on his searches through old dumps with metal detectors, only to discover the truth about his feelings toward her -- Ziegler's dry wit and facility with metaphor offer a visceral evocation of a not-so-sunny childhood. Megan Harlan

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TELTSCHER, HERRY, O., DR.
description: TELTSCHER-Herry, O., Dr. A much beloved Viennese born psychotherapist, a distinguished clinical psychologist and world renowned handwriting expert, died on January 27 in New York. He lived fully until his unexpected passing at age 89, still vital, active and seeing clients. Dr. Teltscher was the author of two books on Grapho-Diagnostics. He had more than 60 years of experience as a handwriting expert in Europe and the United States and was widely respected for his pioneering efforts in the use of writing as a diagnostic tool in psychiatric and medical disorders. He was a member of military intelligence in the U.S. Army during WWII. In years past he worked closely with research physicians investigating the effects of Parkinson's Disease on handwriting. Another paper written with W.G. Eliasberg, M.D., PhD. postulated that Roosevelt was already ill at Yalta by examining his handwriting, an observation that was only recently validated by Roosevelt's personal physician. His published paper on Lee Harvey Oswald was submitted to the Warren Commission and his blind analysis of the socalled Swiss Nanny is reported in a segment of Joyce Egginton's book, ''Circle of Fire''. He published numerous articles in the scientific press and in popular magazines such as Vogue and Glamour. As an expert document examiner he testified in many court proceedings and was a Fellow of the American College of Forensic Examiners. In 1986 he was honored by the American Psychological Association for distinguished contribution to clinical psychology. As Director of Supervision for the Morton Prince Clinic for Hypnosis. He was also considered one of the foremost pioneers in the use of hypnosis and relaxation techniques in therapy. He taught self hypnosis to his clients to give them a greater sense of mastery. His positive, creative and comforting spirit was an inspiration to all who knew him. He was the father of John, Nina and two daughters from an earlier marriage, Elizabeth Timberman and Susan Telcher. He is survived by his wife of 37 years, Betti and his sister, Jane Melvin of California. He is dearly missed by all who loved him and who hoped he would live forever. And so he will in our hearts. A memorial service will take place at All Souls Unitarian Church, Lexington Ave. & 80th St on Tuesday, February 8 at 4:00 PM.

title: Lives; Unreal Estate
description: I admit it: I am what real estate brokers call a looky-loo, one of those people who go peeping at homes they have no intention -- or hope -- of purchasing. I stride purposefully through every manner of open house, asking about joists and floorboards as though my imaginary contractor were standing by to modify any property into the home of my dreams (5BR/2.5 BA, porch, gourmet ktch, FP, hdwd flrs, fnshd bsmnt). I picture myself in a place gracious, spacious and fragrant with history, somewhere to set root and fill with the flavor of new lives. I have tried to stay within $250,000 of my price range -- until a year and a half ago, when my husband and I moved from Washington to a rented house in Silicon Valley. In Palo Alto, the average single-family home costs $843,500. Houses for less than half a million dollars come on the market so rarely that the last time it happened I found myself trapped in Lexus-lock with would-be buyers desperate for a chance to bid on a forlorn stucco ranch (3BR/1BA, w/w shag) in the shadow of an apartment complex.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHUBART, MARK
description: SCHUBART-Mark. With great sadness and a great sense of loss, the Board, staff, and friends of Lincoln Center for the Performing Arts, Inc., mourn the sudden passing of Mark Schubart, Founding Director and Chairman Emeritus of Lincoln Center Institute for the Arts in Education, and former Board Member and Director Emeritus of Lincoln Center for the Performing Arts. A true visionary, Mr. Schubart transformed the way that students and teachers interact with the arts by building Lincoln Center Institute into one of the nation's leading arts in education organizations. Under his nurturing leadership, the Institute's success grew into an international movement, with a network of affiliated institutes across the country and overseas. After completing two decades of service, Mr. Schubart became the Institute's fourth Chairman of the Board (1995-1998), and was subsequently named Chairman Emeritus. He first joined Lincoln Center in 1963 as its Director of Education, after serving as Director of Public Activities, Dean, and then Vice President of The Juilliard School of Music. Though his passion and commitment to the cause of education will be sorely missed, his spirit shines brightly through the ongoing work of the Institute. We extend our deepest sympathies to best friend Martin Rapp, his sisterin-law Margaret Schubart and eight nieces and nephews. Beverly Sills, Chairman Nathan Leventhal, President Lincoln Center for the Performing Arts, Inc. Scott Noppe-Brandon, Executive Director Bonnie Himmelman, Acting Chair Lincoln Center Institute for the Arts in Education

title: Flapjacks and Flapjills

Ben Kamins, a Canadian chemist and ice-fisher has developed a skin-care line using sap harvested in Quebec in spring, frozen, purified and combined into products like his Menopause Cream ($102 for 1.6 ounces) and Revitalizing Booster Concentrate ($59 for 1.7 ounces) for rosacea and sunburn. Mr. Kamins began by wondering why maple trees thrived in Canada's harshest climates. He said that sap has tissue-preserving qualities that work on trees and skin, thanks to natural antioxidants, alpha-hydroxy acids and vegetable hormones. ''The sap seems to contain ingredients that are known to be good,'' said Dr. Laurie Polis, a New York dermatologist. ''Whether the ingredients are biologically active, we don't know.'' Though their anti-aging effects are not proven, they do smell like maple butter cream. B. Kamins is available in doctors' offices, Bliss spas and at Zitomer Pharmacy, 969 Madison Avenue (75th Street), where Judy Kerstein, a product development director, said they were selling like, well, hotcakes. ANNA HOLMES

title: Style; Man's Best Friend

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FENTON, ALAN D.
description: FENTON-Alan D. Died of natural causes, January 1, 2000, in Cleveland at the age of 72. Alan Fenton was an abstract painter in the ''New York School'' tradition of artists, and long time NYC resident and real estate innovator. Fenton's quiet and contemplative nonobjective paintings and drawings were widely recognized for their demanding yet understated means of revealing a serious and sober essence. He identified greatly with Mark Rothko, a friend, as well as Adolph Gottlieb and Jack Tworkov, with whom he had studied privately. Fenton painted in NYC in the late 50's as the explosion of Abstract Expressionism turned into a rebellion against gestural, emotional painting. More concerned about his art than his posture, expanded upon a tradition in painting with influences as diverse as Whistler and Turner as well as Ad Reinhardt and Joseph Albers. Alan Fenton was born in Cleveland in 1927, studied at the Cleveland School of Art, The Arts Students League, The New School, and at NYU, earning his BFA at Pratt Institute, where he later taught painting for many years. At seventeen, Fenton served in the Merchant Marines where he began a career as a professional boxer, a skill he had honed on the streets. He moved successfully through the graphic design business en route to becoming a painter in NY at the height of the art revolution of the fifties and sixties. He moved to NY in 1955 with his wife, Naomi Feigenbaum. She died in 1995. Fenton enjoyed success with his subtle washes and pencil drawings as well as large abstract canvases in acrylic, landing one-man shows at the prestigious Pace Gallery in NY, The NY Cultural Center Museum, The Barbara Fielder Gallery in Washington, et al. In his introduction to Fenton's exhibition catalogue for his one-man show at the Phillips Collection in Washington, Vincent Melzac wrote, ''Fenton is his own man, producing work that is uniquely his...in his work one feels that Fenton is testing the accepted and pushing for a newer and richer visual experience.'' Fenton's work resides at The Hirschhorn Museum of Art, The Corcoran Gallery, The Cleveland Museum of Art, The Smithsonian, and countless others as well as in private collections. In the late 60's he turned his artistic vision and NY business savvy towards developing creative environments where ''good and beautiful people'' could live and work together. His first endeavor was to turn the Tiffany Glass Building on lower Park Avenue into an artistic community where notable photographers, painters, and filmmakers moved in, setting the stage for a modern, hip, yet warm and friendly working space for the community which he had nurtured. He later developed the first live/work loft in Cleveland, where Fenton resided during his last years. Fenton is survived by his daughter Danielle, son-in-law Bill Garrity, their two children Adam and Gabriel, and his son David, all of NYC. He leaves behind a brother, Calvin Freedman of Tarzanna, California, and a sister, Marilyn Gelman of Boca Raton, Florida. Fenton had said about his own work, ''All that happens in my work is natural and human, hard and soft, large and small, heaven and earth. All this with the image of man, (my glow) forms a system to attain the sublime. All of these paradoxes form a triad that is the way of everything. The line is the 'hard', the formless form and the imageless image is the 'soft'. They are inseparable, one cannot exist without the other.''

He tries everything to get out of the rut and into the bed of Ms. MacDowell's character - money, inside information, seemingly magical powers - until in exhaustion he tries being real. title: Books in Brief: Nonfiction; Death Valley Daze
description: The Mojave is the smallest of North America's four deserts, stretching across 35,000 square miles in the region where Arizona, Nevada and California converge. Its best-known landmarks are Death Valley National Park in the north and Joshua Tree National Park in the south, and, despite the popular image of the desert as a barren moonscape, the Mojave is rich with flora and fauna and features enormously varied terrain, with elevations ranging from 282 feet below sea level to about 4,000 feet above sea level. All of this is brought to life with startling clarity in THE DESERT: The Mojave and Death Valley (Abrams, $49.50). Jack Dykinga's photographs capture the extraordinary blooming of desert plants brought on by the unusually heavy rainfall from El Nino in the winter and spring of 1997-98, an explosion of lupine, primrose, prickly pear and other colorful flowers. There are also more familiar images of sand dunes in Death Valley's blistering heat, canyons and foggy vistas of Joshua trees. Perhaps most surprising is the chapter on Racetrack Playa, a flat, dry lake bed where rocks mysteriously slide across the silt on their own, leaving weird zigzagging tracks behind them as they make their way along. Janice Emily Bowers's text is a heartfelt, closely observed testimonial to the desert's unexpected beauties. After a while, one may long for a little of the snaggle-toothed crankiness of Edward Abbey, a far feistier chronicler of the Southwest, but that may be beside the point. After all, this is a paean, pure and simple: ''Our job is to show you why we love the Mojave Desert, and why you might love it, too.'' Scott Veale

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WHITE, HAROLD T., JR.
description: WHITE-Harold T., Jr. A retired investment banker, avid skier and sailor, died January 29, 2000 in his home in New Canaan, CT. He was a resident of New Canaan since 1949 and a summer resident of West Falmouth, MA since 1955. After graduating from the Milton Academy (MA) in 1933 and then Harvard University Magna Cum Laude in 1937, Mr. White pursued graduate studies in Physics at both Harvard and Princeton Universities. His Investment Banking career to White, Weld & Co. was interrupted by WWII. He joined the Coast Guard as a Chief Petty Officer commanding a private yacht converted for year round antisubmarine picket duty off the New England coast. During the early years of WWII, he worked with Raytheon helping develop radar for military use. In 1946 he returned to White, Weld where he was a limited partner until the firms sale to Merrill Lunch in the 1970's. He was also a long time Director of the Hackensack Water Company in New Jersey and of the Chubb Insurance companies. For many years before WWII, Mr. White was successful in one design sailboat racing on the Long Island Sound. During the 1960's and 1970's he had similar success, mainly on Cape Cod, competing in many day and overnight cruising class races. He was also an avid down hill skier for over 50 years, until the late 1980's. During the 1970's he served as a trustee of Milbrook School in upstate New York and was a member of the New Canaan, CT Board of Finance. He was also a trustee of the Boy's Club of New York City. In addition to Penelope Weld White, his wife of 59 years, he leaves five sons; Charles Dana White of Santa Barbara, CA, Alexander Weld White of Byfield, MA, Harold T. White III of Bedford, NY, Christopher M. White of Boston, MA, and Francis Weld White of Nordland, WA. Seven grandchildren, Cynthia White, Alexander (Sandy) White, Nathaniel White, Gavin White, Henry White, Collin White and Bradley Hunt, also survive. A memorial service will be held on Tuesday, February 1, 2000 at 11:00 AM at the St. Matthew's Episcopal Church, 382, Cantitoe St., Bedford, NY. Contributions in his memory may be made to the Whittingham Cancer Center, Steven's St., Norwalk, CT.

title: Editorial Notebook; What the Marschallin Makes of Time
description: Near the end of the first act of Richard Strauss's opera ''Der Rosenkavalier,'' there comes a moment when the Marschallin, a married aristocrat in her mid-30's, explains a sudden awareness of time to her noble young lover, Octavian. It is one of the celebrated scenes in opera, not only for its music, but for the poetry, the psychological delicacy, of Hugo von Hofmannsthal's libretto, which is set in mid-18th-century Vienna. ''The whole opera would suffer,'' Hofmannsthal wrote Strauss in 1910, ''if the personality of the Marschallin were to be deprived of her full stature.'' But what that stature means is that the Marschallin is alone. Even her lover, so young, so triumphant, is incapable of understanding what she tells him, and us, about time.

title: How Long, in Opera, Is Too Long?

Puccini's ''Tosca,'' a miracle of dramatic streamlining, is conceded to be just right, but ''Madama Butterfly,'' which is not that much longer, is thought to have dead spots. Wagner's ''Siegfried'' is way too long, detractors say, and even many partisans concede as much, not to mention tenors who take on the exhausting title role, the most demanding in opera. Yet ''Gotterdammerung,'' an even longer work, is generally felt to be gripping theater.

title: The Recycled Generation
description: Almost every weekday morning, usually before 10:30, an overnight delivery truck with an unusual cargo negotiates the hilly streets on the outskirts of Worcester, Mass., and comes to a halt in front of a brick-and-tinted-glass building called Biotech Three. The courier disappears into the building with one or two large gray containers and drops them off at a small company called Advanced Cell Technology. The gray cases look like toolboxes, but they are actually sophisticated shipping containers, commonly used for transporting materials used in animal-breeding work, and they contain the starting material for a series of experiments that may completely rewrite the tables of human longevity. Or they may be remembered only for being among the most ethically troubling scientific endeavors of our times.

Going into Tuesday's election in 1992, those of us traveling with President Bush honestly believed that things could still break our way. The only time that any of us were really worried was Monday evening. The Oak Ridge Boys were very close to the president, and we had them on Air Force One. It was the president and Mary Matalin and myself and a couple of others who had been on the plane the whole time. The Oak Ridge Boys sang a melody of gospel songs, ending with ''Amazing Grace.'' None of us said a word, but there was a palpable sense that everything we'd worked toward could be over.

title: Istanbul Dinner
description: To the Editor: I was delighted to read ''What's Doing in Istanbul'' (Jan. 2). My daughter and I returned for the second time last September, and a big incentive was dinner again on the balcony at the white marble Ciragan Palace Kempinsky, looking out over the Bosporus. The service is impeccable. When the waiter seated us he said, ''If you are too cool, I will bring you a poncho.'' What he brought was a beautiful Turkish shawl. The food is delicious. Dinner for five with two bottles of wine plus tip came to $166. To get a table on the balcony, fax ahead: (90-212) 259-6686.

title: Art/Architecture; An Architect's Moment of Reckoning Arrives
description: FOR years, one of the burning questions in American architecture has been: Will Peter Eisenman find himself before the world finds Peter Eisenman? By himself, I don't mean Eisenman's personality. I mean his attitude toward his medium. Can he finally place architecture above the external sources -- linguistics; semiotics; structuralist philosophy -- he has relied on over the years? By the world, I don't mean popular acclaim, of the kind that Frank Gehry has achieved in recent years. I mean curiosity on the part of a public that has been slow to recognize its stake in Eisenman's ideas.

title: From Your Table to the Pig Sty
description: Anybody who cooks and eats has to dispose of table scraps. The same is true, on a much bigger scale, for restaurants, super-markets, hospitals and other institutions. In the past, farmers sometimes amde deals to pick u food scraps and feed them to their pigs. A year-old company called Enviro-Feed does much the same; it collects food waste (at a lower price than the garbage man) and takes it to its facility in Perty Amboy, where it turns it into dry feed that is sold for farm animals. John Metzger, who lines up business for the Enviro-Feed, says he knows of no other company like it in the country. Clients include the Hiltons at Short Hills, East Brunswick, and the Newark Airport, a number of supermarkets, Merck & Company and some state prisons; Mr. Metzger said all of them save perhaps $6,000 to $10,000 a year in garbage collection costs. Pickups are three to seven times a week, which, he says, makes supermarkets especially happy, as the odors from garbage bins tends to turn customers off.

title: Art/Architecture; Turning History's Leftovers Into Modern Relics
description: LIKE a slightly daft forensic detective, the British artist Cornelia Parker gathers evidence from moldering cultural artifacts. Tarnish from Davy Crockett's knife, a feather from Sigmund Freud's couch, dust from the grooves of a phonograph record that belonged to Adolf Hitler, all become loaded icons once she gets hold of them. Through precise presentations and mind-spinning titles, Ms. Parker cleverly turns the trivial into secular relics.

title: Corrections
description: A full-page chart on Jan. 9 tracing New York City's weather over the last 100 years misstated several statistics. The coldest years of the century were 1917 and 1903, not 1904. The longest consecutive run of days with temperatures of 100 or above were July 8-10, 1993, not 1990, and Aug. 26-28, 1948. The month with the greatest total precipitation was April 1983, with 14.01 inches, not September 1982. And the month with the most snow was December 1947, not November 1947.

Its legacy will be a reborn respect for America's potential. Limits to growth still exist, but they are not the stunted ones of the 70's, 80's and early 90's.

title: The World; 'Don Kohleone' and Germany Face Off
description: HELMUT KOHL has a new nickname: ''Don Kohleone.'' And no wonder. First the former German chancellor said he had always regarded ''close personal trust'' as the most important thing in political life. Then he placed his ''honor'' above the law. Finally he resorted to ''omerta,'' the Sicilian word for silence, refusing to reveal the names of people who secretly gave large sums of money to his Christian Democratic Union.

We, who treasure him, will fondly remember many stimulating conversations around many delightful dinnertables. Ti Riccordiamo Sempre.

title: Visiting a Very Large Paradise
description: AS I climbed into our rented van for the 36-mile drive from the fishing village of Chaiten to Pumalin Park in southern Chile, my mind was free of the usual visions inspired by travel brochures. Founded in 1991 by Douglas Tompkins, an American who made a fortune in fashion retailing, the Pumalin Park Project, as it is officially known, is Chile's newest park. Images of its pristine wilderness have yet to join popular symbols of South America such as Machu Picchu in Peru or Angel Falls in Venezuela.

title: Preserving a Lifetime's Memories on Video
description: THE large cardboard carton in Suzy Shechtman's Great Neck den was filled with memorabilia from Robert and Elaine Gordon's family. Sealed in individual plastic bags were Mrs. Gordon's parents' 1925 marriage license, a snapshot of the Gordons cutting their own wedding cake half a century ago, an old photograph of Mrs. Gordon's infamous tennis swing and a long-forgotten award for a hole-in-one. There was a certificate Mr. Gordon's father earned as a cook in the Army during World War I and a folder with century-old documents from his family's plumbing and heating supply company. Mrs. Gordon's master's thesis in library science from C. W. Post, a 1946 report card along with an honor roll certificate from Bayside High School were in another bag. Sidney bravely served his country as a second lieutenant for five years during the Second World War, and spent his working years as a talented and successful dress manufacturer. description: COLLINS-Robert D., 90. Of Smoke Rise, Kinnelon, NJ (formerly of Verona and East Orange, NJ), died January 28, 2000, of complications from a liver tumor. Born September 18, 1909. Husband of Doris (Sheldon Armstrong) Collins and the late Dorothy (Haythorn) Collins. Father of the late Richard H. Collins of Medina, OH, and David S. Collins of Dover, MA. Step-father of John S. Armstrong of Wrightsville Beach, NC, and Debra (Armstrong) Lausch of Carolina Beach, NC. Grandfather of Richard R. Collins and Linda (Collins) Salerno of Medina, OH, Holiday Collins of Baltimore, MD, and Jennifer A. Collins of Chicago, IL. Step-grandfather of Sean E. Armstrong of Alexandria, VA, Sharon A. Armstrong of Wilmington, NC, and Norma S. Devlin of Rose Hill, NC. Survived by sisters Ruth C. Turner of Vero Beach, FL, and Jean C. Brangs of Hatboro, PA, and three great-grandchildren and two stepgreat-grandchildren. Son of the late Robert O. Collins and Adelaide (Sherrer) Collins. Relatives and friends are invited to a memorial service at the Smoke Rise Community Church at 3 PM, Sunday, January 30, 2000. Interment is private. Memorial contributions are welcomed to the Chilton Hospital Memorial Fund, Pompton Plains, NJ 07442, or the Smoke Rise Community Church Memorial Fund, Kinnelon, NJ 07405. For information, contact the Morrison Funeral Home, 86 Bartholdi Ave., Butler, NJ.

title: A Thriving Market For Old Masters; Action Shifts to New York From London
description: Five museums -- the Metropolitan Museum, the National Gallery of Art in Washington, the J. Paul Getty Museum, the St. Louis Art Museum and the Los Angeles County Museum of Art -- bought old master paintings at Christie's on Thursday. On Friday an anonymous donor bought a rare Rembrandt drawing for the Morgan Library at Christie's sale of old master drawings. And two American museums were buyers at Sotheby's sale of old master paintings on Friday: the National Gallery and an institution that wished to remain anonymous. At both auction houses museums were willing to pay record prices for works that would fill gaps in their collections.

title: Clemency and Unjust Drug Laws
description: During the past Christmas season, Gov. George Pataki granted clemency to four New York prison inmates who were first-time, nonviolent drug offenders serving long mandatory sentences under the state's harsh drug laws, known as the Rockefeller laws. Mr. Pataki's compassionate gesture is to be applauded, but his real task is to push for reform of the misguided laws that created the need for clemency in the first place.

Or at least, he thinks he is.
